alphabetical letter * *
The ninth letter of the alphabet; called *aAlN: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]: and of the letters termed livawiy~ap [or gingival], which are v and * and Z; wherefore it is substituted for v in talaEo*ama for talaEovama; and it is said to be substituted for the unpointed d in fa$ar~i*o bihimo, [as some read] in the Kur [viii. 59, for fa$ar~ido bhm]. (TA.) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Seven hundred.]

*aA * is said by Aboo-'Alee to be originally *aYo; the Y, though quiescent, being changed into A: (M:) or it is originally *ayaY or *awaY; the final radical letter being elided: some say that the original medial radical letter is Y because it has been heard to be pronounced with imáleh [and so it is now pronounced in Egypt]; but others say that it is w, and this is the more agreeable with analogy. (Msb.) It is a noun of indication, [properly meaning This, but sometimes, when repeated, better rendered that,] relating to an object of the masc. gender, (S, M, K,) such as is near: (I'Ak p. 36:) or it relates to what is distant [accord. to some, and therefore should always be rendered that]; and h`*aA, [which see in what follows,] to what is near: (K in art. haA: [but the former is generally held to relate to what is near, like the latter:]) or it is a noun denoting anything indicated that is seen by the speaker and the person addressed: the noun in it is *a, or * alone: and it is a noun of which the signification is vague and unknown until it is explained by what follows it, as when you say *aA Alr~ajulu [This man], and *aA Alfarasa [This horse]: and the nom. and accus. and gen. are all alike: (T:) the fem. is *iY (T, S, M, K, but omitted in the CK) and *iho, (S, M, K, but omitted in the CK,) the latter used in the case of a pause, (S,) with a quiescent h, which is a substitute for the Y, not a sign of the fem. gender, (S, M,) as it is in TaloHaho and Hamozaho, in which it is changed into p when followed by a conjunctive alif, for in this case the h in *ih remains unchanged [but is meksoorah, as it is also in other cases of connexion with a following word]; and one says also *hiY; (M;) and taA and tiho: (S and K &c. in art. tA:) for the dual you say *aAni and taAni; (M;) *aAni is the dual form of *aA (T, S) [and taAni is that of taA used in the place of *iY]; i. e., you indicate the masc. dual by *aAni in the nom. case, and *ayoni in the accus. and gen.; and the fem. dual you indicate by taAni in the nom. case, and tayoni in the accus. and gen.: (I'Ak p. 36:) the pl. is A^ulaA='i [or A^ulaA='i] (T, S, and I'Ak ib.) in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, (I'Ak,) and A^uwlaY [or A^ulaY] (T, I'Ak) in the dial. of Temeem; each both masc. and fem. (I'Ak ib. [See art. AlY.]) You say, *aA A^axuwka [This is thy brother]: and *iYA^uxotuka [This is thy sister]: (T:) and laAA=tiyka fiY *iY Als~anapi [I will not come to thee in this year]; like as you say fY h`*ihi Als~anapi and fY h`*iY Als~anapi; not fY *aA Als~anapi, because *A is always masc. (As, T.) And you say, *aAni A^axawaAka [These two are thy two brothers]: and taAni A^uxotaAka [These two are thy two sisters]. (T.) And A^uwlaA='i A_ixowatuka [These are thy brothers]: and A^uwlaA='i A^axawaAtuka [These are thy sisters]: thus making no difference between the masc. and the fem. in the pl. (T.) ― -b2- The haA that is used to give notice, to a person addressed, of something about to be said to him, is prefixed to *aA [and to *iY &c.], (T, S, M, K,) and is a particle without any meaning but inception: (T:) thus you say h`*aA, (T, S, M,) and some say h`*aAA, adding another A; (Ks, T;) fem. h`*iY, (T, S, M,) and [more commonly] h`*iho in the case of a pause, (M,) and h`*ihi in other cases, (T, S,) and haAtaA, and some say h`*aAti, but this is unusual and disapproved: (T:) dual h`*aAni for the masc., and haAtaAni for the fem.; (T;) said by IJ to be not properly duals, but nouns formed to denote duals; (M;) and many of the Arabs say h`*aAn~i; (T;) some, also, make h`*aAni indecl., like the sing. *aA, reading [in the Kur xx. 66] A_in~a h`*aAni lasaAHiraAni [Verily these two are enchanters], and it has been said that this is of the dial. of Belhárith [or Benu-l-Hárith] Ibn-Kaab; but others make it decl., reading A_in~a h`*aAyoni lasaAHiraAni: (S, TA: [see, however, what has been said respecting this phrase voce A_in~a:]) the pl. is h`w^ulaA in the dial. of Temeem, with a quiescent A; and h`w^ulaA='i in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, with medd and hemz and khafd; and h`w^ulaA='K in the dial. of Benoo- 'Okeyl, with medd and hemz and tenween. (AZ, T.) The Arabs also say, laA haA A@ll~`hi *aA, introducing the name of God between haA and *aA; meaning No, by God; this is [my oath, or] that by which I swear. (T.) In the following verse, of Jemeel,
waA^ataY SawaAHibuhaA faqulona h`*aA A@l~a*iY
manaHa Almawad~apa gayoranaA wajafaAnaA
[it is said that] ha*aA is for A^a*aA, (M,) i. e., h is here substituted for the interrogative hemzeh (S * and K in art. hA) [so that the meaning is, And her female companions came, and said, Is this he who gave love to other than us, and treated us unkindly?]: or, as some assert, ha*aA is here used for h`*aA, the A being suppressed for the sake of the measure. (El-Bedr El-Karáfee, TA in art. hA.) ― -b3- One says also *aAka, (T, S, M, K,) affixing to *aA the k of allocution, [q. v., meaning That,] relating to an object that is distant, (T, *, S, and I'Ak p. 36,) or, accord. to general opinion, to that which occupies a middle place between the near and the distant, (I'Ak pp. 36 and 37,) and this k has no place in desinential syntax; (S, and I'Ak p. 36;) it does not occupy the place of a gen. nor of an accus., but is only affixed to *A to denote the distance of *A from the person addressed: (T:) for the fem. you say tiyka (T, S) and taAka; (S and K in art. tA, q. v.;) but not *iyka, for this is wrong, (T, S,) and is used only by the vulgar: (T:) for the dual you say *aAnika (T, S) and *ayonika, as in the phrases jaA='aniY *aAnika Alr~ajulaAni [Those two men came to me] and raA^ayotu *ayonuka Alr~ajulayoni, [I saw those two men]; (S;) and some say *aAn~ika, with teshdeed, (T, S,) [accord. to J] for the purpose of corroboration, and to add to the letters of the noun, (S,) but [accord. to others] this is dual of *`lika, [which see in what follows,] the second n being a substitute for the l; (T on the authority of Zj and others;) and some say taAn~ika also, with tesh-deed, (T, S,) as well as taAnika: (T in this art., and S and K in art. tA, but there omitted in some copies of the S:) the pl. is [A^uwlaAka and] A^uwl`y^ika. (T, S.) haA is also prefixed to *aAka; so that you say, h`*aAka zayodN [That is Zeyd]: (S, TA:) and in like manner, for the fem., you say haAtiyka and haAtaAka: (S and K in art. tA:) but it is not prefixed [to the dual nor] to A^uwl`y^ika. (S.) ― -b4- You also add l in *aAka, (T, S, M, K,) as a corroborative; (TA;) so that you say *`lika, [meaning That,] (T, S, M, K,) relating to an object that is distant, by common consent; (I'Ak pp. 36 and 37;) or hemzeh, saying *aAy^ika, (K,) but some say that this is a
mispronunciation: (TA in art. *wY:) for the fem. you say tiloka and taAlika: the dual of *`lika is *aAn~ika, mentioned above; and that of the fem. is vaAn~ika: (T: [and in the K in art. tA, taAlika is also mentioned as a dual, as well as a sing.:]) and the pl. is A^uwlaAlika. (S and M and K voce A^uwlaY or A^ulaY or A^ulaA. [See art. AlY.]) haA is not prefixed to *`lika (S) nor to tiloka [nor to A^uwlaAlika] because, as IB says, the l denotes the remoteness of that which is indicated and the hA denotes its nearness, so that the two are incompatible. (TA in art. tA.) ― -b5- In the saying in the Kur [ii. 256, the Verse of the Throne], mano *aA Al~a*iY ya$ofaEu Einodahu A_il~aA biA_i*onihi, (T, TA,) accord. to Th and Mbr, (TA,) h`*aA is syn. with *A [so that the meaning is, Who is this that shall intercede with Him but by his permission?]: (T, TA:) or it may be here redundant [so that the meaning is, Who is he that &c.?]. (Kull.) ― -b6- It is sometimes syn. with Aal~a*iY. (T, S, M.) So in the saying, maA *aA raA^ayota [What is it that thou sawest?]; to which one may answer, mataAEN HasanN [A goodly commodity]. (Sb, S.) And so in the Kur [ii. 216], wa yasoA^aluwnaka maA maA *aA yunofiquwna [And they ask thee what amount of their property is it that they shall expend in alms]; (T, M, TA;) accord. to those who make the reply to be in the nom. case; for this shows that mA is [virtually] in the nom. case as an inchoative, and *A is its enunciative, and ynfqwn is the complement of *A; and that mA and *A are not to be regarded as one word: [or] this is the preferable way of explanation in the opinion of Sb, though he allowed the other way, [that of regarding mA and *A as one word, together constituting an inchoative, and ynfqwn as its enunciative, (see Ham p. 521,)] with [the reply in] the nom. case: (M:) and h`*aA, also, is used in the same sense: (TA:) so too *A in maA *aA huwa and mano *aA huwa may be considered as syn. with Al*Y; but it is preferable to regard it as redundant. (Kull.) ― -b7- It is [said to be] redundant also in other instances: for ex., in the trad. of Jereer, as related by Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, who says that it is so in this instance: yaToluEu Ealayokumo rajulN mino *iY yamanK EalaY wajohihi masoHapN mino *iY mulokK [There will come to you a man from El-Yemen, having upon his face an indication of dominion]. (TA. [But this evidently belongs to art. *uw; in which see a similar ex. (A^atayonaA *aA yamanK). See also other exs. there.]) ― -b8- [ka*aA lit. means Like this: and hence, thus: as also h`ka*aA. ― -b9- It is also often used as one word, and, as such, is made the complement of a prefixed noun; as in sanapa ka*aA and fiY sanapi ka*aA In such a year. See also art. ka*aA: and see the letter k.] ― -b10- h`*aA is sometimes used to express contempt, and mean estimation; as in the saying of 'Áïsheh respecting 'Abd-Allah Ibn- 'Amr Ibn-'Abbás, yaA EajabFA liA@boni EamorKw h`*aA [O wonder (meaning how I wonder) at Ibn-'Amr, this fellow!]. (Kitáb el-Miftáh, cited in De Sacy's “ Gram. Ar., ” 2nd ed., i. 442.) [yaA h`*aA often occurs as addressed to one who is held in mean estimation: it is like the Greek ὦ οὗτος, and virtually like the vulgar Arabic expression yaA A^anota, and the Latin heus tu; agreeably with which it may be rendered O thou; meaning O thou fellow; an appellation denoting mean estimation being understood: in the contrary case, one says yaA fataY. See also, in what follows, a usage of *aAka and *`lika. ― -b11- h`*aA in a letter and the like is introduced when the writer breaks off, turning to a new subject; and means “ This is all that I had to say on the subject to which, it relates: ” what follows it is commenced with the conjunction wa.] ― -b12- One says, layosa bi*aAka [and layosa bi*`lika], meaning It is not approved: for, [like as a person held in mean estimation is indicated by h`*aA, which denotes a thing that is near, so,] on account of its high degree of estimation, a thing that is approved is indicated by that whereby one indicates a thing that is remote. (Kull voce lys.) [See also what next follows.] ― -b13- *`lika AlkitaAbu in the Kur ii. 1 is said by Zj to mean h`*aA AlkitaAbu [This book]: but others say that *lk is here used because the book is remote [from others] in respect of highness and greatness of rank. (TA.) ― -b14- ka*`lika [lit. Like that, often means so, or in like manner: and ― -b15- ] Let that suffice [thee or] you. (TA in art. *Er, from a trad.) ― -b16- The dim. of *aA is *ay~aA: (T, S, M:) you form no dim. of the fem. *iY, using in its stead that of taA, (S,) which is tay~aA: (T:) the dim. of the dual [*aAni] is *ay~aAni: (S:) and that of [the pl.] A^uwlaA='i [and A^uwlaY] is A^uwlay~aA='i [and A^uwlay~aA]: (T:) ― -b17- that of h`*aA is *ay~aA, like that of *aA; [and you may say h`*ay~aA also; for] that of h`w^ulaA='i is h`w^ulay~aA='i: (T:) ― -b18- that of *aAka is *ay~aAka: (S, K: *) and that of taAka is tay~aAka: (K in art. tA:) ― -b19- that of *`lika is *ay~aAlika: (S, K: *) and that of tiloka is tay~aAlika. (S.) A rájiz says,
A^awo taHolifiY birab~ika AlEaliY~i
A_in~iY A^abuw *ay~aAliki AlS~abiY~i
[Or thou shalt swear by thy Lord, the High, that I am the father of that little child]: (S, TA:) he was an Arab who came from a journey, and found that his wife had given birth to a boy whom he disacknowledged. (TA.) -A2- *aA is also the accus. case of *uw, q. v.

1 *uy^iba *
He (a man, M) was frightened by the wolf; (M, K;) as also *ay^iba, aor.
*aAa^a ; and *aw^uba, aor.
*aAu^a : (K:) or he (a man) was assailed, fallen upon, come upon, or overtaken, by the wolf. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) And [hence, in the opinion of ISd, as he says in the M,] (tropical:) He was frightened by anything; (M, K;) and so ↓ A*A^b, (AA, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. A_i*oA=bN; (TA;) said of a man. (S.) [Hence also,] *aA^abahu, (M, K,) aor.
*aAa^a , (K,) [inf. n. *aA^obN,] (tropical:) He frightened him [like as does a wolf]: (M, A, K, TA:) and *aA^abatohu Aljin~u (A, TA) and ↓ t*A^~bthu, as also t*E~bthu, (T, TA,) (tropical:) The jinn, or genii, frightened him. (T, A, TA.) [And hence, app.,] *aA^abotuhu Alr~iyHu (tropical:) The wind came to him from every side, like the wolf; when guarded against from one direction, coming from another direction: (A:) and Ailr~iyHu ↓ t*A='bti, (T, S, M, K,) and ↓ t*A^~bt, (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The wind varied, (T, S, M,) or came now from one direction and now from another direction, (S, M, K,) so says As, (S,) feebly: (M, K:) accord. to As, from Al*~iy^obu, (S,) [i. e.] it is likened to the wolf, (M,) because his motions are of the like description: (S:) or, accord. to some, Al*~iy^obu is derived from ↓ t*A='bt AlryH meaning the wind blew from every direction; because the wolf comes from every direction. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (i. e. *uy^iba) He (a man) had his sheep, or goats, fallen upon by the wolf. (S, K.) ― -b3- And *aw^uba, (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
*aAu^a , (T, S, K,) inf. n. *aA=bapN; (S, M, K;) and *ay^iba; (M, A, K;) and ↓ t*A^~b; (M, K;) (tropical:) He (a man, T, S, M) was, or became, bad, wicked, deceitful, or crafty, (T, S, M, A, K,) like the wolf, (S, M, A, K,) or as though he became a wolf. (T.) ― -b4- And *aA^aba, aor.
*aAa^a , (tropical:) He acted like the wolf; when guarded against from one direction, coming from another direction. (TA.) [And probably (assumed tropical:) He howled like the wolf; for,] accord. to Kr, (M,) *aA^obN signifies the uttering a loud, or vehement, cry or sound. (M, K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He hastened, or was quick, in pace, or journeying; (K;) as also ↓ A*A^b. (TA.) -A2- *aA^abahu, [aor.
*aAa^a ,] inf. n. *aA^obN, also signifies He despised him; and so *aA^amahu: (T:) or he drove him away, and despised him: (ISk, T, S, M, K:) or he drove him away, (Lh, M, TA,) and beat him; (Lh, TA;) and so *aA^amahu: (M, TA:) [or he blamed, or dispraised, him; like *aA^amahu; for,] accord. to Kr, (M,) *aA^obN signifies the act of blaming, or dispraising. (M, K.) ― -b2- And He drove him, or urged him on: (K:) or *aA^aba AlA_ibila, inf. n. *aA^obN, he drove, or urged on, the camels. (S, M.) -A3- He collected it; (T, K;) namely, a thing. (T.) ― -b2- He made it even; syn. saw~aAhu. (CK: omitted in other copies of the K and in the TA.) One says of the woman who makes even (tusaw~iY) her vehicle, [meaning the part of her camel-vehicle upon which she sits,] maA A^aHosana maA *aA^abatohu [How well has she made it even!] (T.) ― -b3- He made it; namely, a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab (K) and [such as is called] a raHol (TA.) -A4- He made, [or disposed,] for him, (namely, a boy,) a *uw^aAbap [q. v.]; as also ↓ A*A^bhu and ↓ *A^~bhu. (K.) -A5- *uy^iba said of a horse, He was, or became, affected with the disease termed *iy^obap. (T, Mgh.)

2 *aA~a^a see 1, last sentence but one. -A2- *A^~b Alr~aHola, (inf. n. ta*oy^iybN, K,) He made, to the rHl [or camel's saddle], what is termed a *iy^obap, (M, K,) or *iy^ob. (TA.) [See also mu*aA^~abN.]
4 A^a*oA^abati AlA^aroDu * (A, TA) The land abounded with wolves. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.
5 ta*aA~a^a see 6, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 1, in three places.

6 t*A='b liln~Aqapi * (S, M, K) and lahaA ↓ t*A^~b (M, K) (assumed tropical:) He disguised himself like a wolf to the she-camel, and, by so frightening her, made her to incline to, or affect, her young one: (S:) or he cloaked, or disguised, himself to the she-camel, making himself to seem like a wolf, in order to cause her to affect a young one that was not her own [by moving her with pity by the supposed danger of the latter]. (M, K) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. -A2- t*A='b $ayoy^FA and ↓ t*A^~bhu (assumed tropical:) He did a thing by turns; syn. tadaAwalahu: (M, K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, tanAwalahu:]) from Al*~iy^obu [the wolf], which, when guarded against from one direction, comes from another direction. (M, TA.)

10 Ast*A^b Aln~aqadu *
The nqd [or ugly sheep] became like wolves: a prov., applied to low, mean, or ignominious, persons, when they obtain ascendancy. (T, K.)
garobN *aA^obN * (assumed tropical:) A large bucket with which one goes to and fro; thought by As to be from ta*aAw^ubu Alr~iyHi: (M:) or in much [or quick] motion, ascending and descending. (M, K.)

*iy^obN * , also pronounced *iybN, without ', (S, Msb, K,) originally with ', (T, S,) The wolf, wild dog, or dog of the desert; kalobu Albar~i: (M, A, K:) applied to the male and the female; (Msb;) and sometimes, also, (Msb,) the female is called *iy^obapN: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. (of pauc., S, Msb) A^a*ow^ubN, and (of mult., S, Msb) *iy^aAbN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which may also be pronounced *iyaAbN, with Y, because of the kesreh, (Msb,) and *uw^baAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and *iy^obaAnN. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, Al*~iy^obu yukan~aY A^abaA jaEodapa [The wolf is surnamed Aboo-Jaadeh]: i. e. its surname is good, but its actions are foul. (TA. [See art. jEd; and see also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 449.]) ― -b3- And Al*~iy^obu yaA^o*uw AlgazaAla [The wolf lies in wait for the young gazelle]: a prov. alluding to perfidy. (TA.) ― -b4- And huwa *iy^obN fiY val~apK (tropical:) [He is a wolf among a flock of sheep]. (A.) ― -b5- And *iy^obapu miEozFY waZaliymN fiY Alxubori [A she-wolf among the goats, and a heostrich when tried]: i. e., in his evil nature he is like a [she-] wolf that attacks a herd of goats; and when tried, like a he-ostrich, which, if one say to it “ Fly, ” says “ I am a camel, ” and when one says to it “ Carry a burden, ” says “ I am a bird: ” a prov. applied to a crafty and deceitful person. (TA.) ― -b6- And A^akalahumo AlD~abuEu wa Al*~iy^obu [The hyena and the wolf devoured them]; meaning (tropical:) dearth, or drought: and A^aSaAbatohumo sanapN DabuEN wa*iy^obN, meaning (tropical:) A year that was one of dearth, or drought, befell them. (A.) ― -b7- *iy^obuhu laA ya$obaEu [His wolf will not be satiated], a phrase used by a poet, means (assumed tropical:) his tongue [will not be satisfied]; i. e. he devours the reputation of another like as the wolf devours flesh. (M.) ― -b8- *iy^obu yuwsufa [The wolf of Joseph] is a prov. applied to him who is charged with the crime of another. (TA.) ― -b9- *uw^obaAnu AlEarabi, (S, M, A, K,) also pronounced *uwbaAn, without ', (TA,) [The wolves of the Arabs,] means (tropical:) the thieves, (M, K,) or sharpers, (A,) and paupers, (A, K,) of the Arabs; (M, A, K;) or the paupers of the Arabs, who practise thieving: (T, S:) because they act like wolves. (TA.) ― -b10- *iy^aAbu AlgaDaA The wolves of the ghadà, that frequent the trees so called, (TA,) is an appellation of the sons of Kaab Ibn-Málik Ibn-Handhalah; (M, K;) because of their bad character; (M;) for the wolf that frequents those trees is the worst of wolves. (TA.) ― -b11- daA='u Al*~iy^obi [The wolf's disease] means (assumed tropical:) hunger; for they assert that the wolf has no other disease than hunger; (K, TA;) and they say A^ajowaEu mino *iy^obK [More hungry than a wolf]; because he is always hungry: or (assumed tropical:) death; because [it is said that] the wolf has no other sickness than that of death; and hence they say A^aSaH~u mina Al*~iy^obi [More sound than the wolf]. (TA.) [Hence the prov., ramaAhu A@ll~`hu bidaA='i Al*~iy^obi: see 1 in art. rmY.] ― -b12- Al*~iy^obaAni, in the dual form, [The two wolves,] is the name of (assumed tropical:) two white stars [app. ζ and η of Draco] between those called AlEawaAy^i*u and those called AlfaroqadaAni: and A^aZofaAru Al*~iy^obi [The claws of the wolf] is the name of (assumed tropical:) certain small stars before those called Al*~iy^obaAni. (K.) ― -b13- Einabu Al*~iy^obi: see vaEolabN. ― -b14- See also the next paragraph.

*iy^obapN * fem. of *iy^obN. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The [angular] intervening space between the daf~ataAni [or two boards] of the [kinds of saddle called] saroj and raHol (S, K, TA) and gabiyT, (TA,) beneath the place of juncture of the two curved pieces of wood; (S;) [or] what is beneath the fore part of the place of juncture of the two curved pieces of wood (M, K) of the [kinds of saddle called] raHol and qatab and A_ikaAf and the like; (M;) which falls, or lies, upon, (S,) or bites, or compresses, (M, K,) the part called the manosij (S, M, K) of the beast. (M, K.) A poet says,
waqatabN *iy^obatuhu kaA@lominojali
[And a qtb of which the *y^bp is like the reapinghook]. (M.) [See qarabuwsN.] Accord. to IAar, the ↓ *iy^ob [a coll. gen. n. of which *iy^obapN is the n. un.] of the [saddle called] raHol are The curved pieces of wood in the fore part thereof. (TA.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) A certain disease of horses (T, M, Mgh, K) or similar beasts, that attacks them in their fauces; (M, K;) for which the root of the beast's ear is perforated with an iron instrument, and there are extracted from it small, white, hard nodous substances, (T, Mgh, K, *) like the grains of the [species of millet called] jaAwaros, (K,) or smaller than those grains. (T, Mgh.)

*iy^obaAnN * a pl. of *iy^bN. (TA.) -A2- Also, accord. to AA, (S,) The hair upon the neck and lip of the camel: (S, K;) and accord. to Fr, who says that it is a sing. [in this sense], (S,) the remains of the [fur, or soft hair, called] wabar [after the greater part has fallen off or been shorn]. (S, K. [See also *uwbaAnN in art. *wbo, and *iybaAnN in art. *yb.])
*uw^aAbN * : see the next paragraph.

*uw^aAbapN * (also pronounced *uwaAbapN, T and K in art. *wb,) A portion [or lock] of hair, (S, A,) hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back: (A:) or the hair of the fore part of the head; the hair over the forehead; syn. naASiyapN; (M, K;) so called because, hanging down, it moves to and fro, or from side to side: (M:) or the place whence that hair grows: (M, K:) or the hair that surrounds the duw~aArap [or round part] of the head: (AZ, T:) or plaited hair of the head: and the part of the head which is the place thereof: (Lth, T:) or a plait of hair hanging down: if twisted, it is called EaqiySapN: (Msb:) and [a horse's forelock; or] hair (M, K) of the head, (M,) in the upper part of the naASiyap, of the horse: (M, K:) pl. (in all its senses, M, TA) *awaAy^ibu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) originally, (S, K,) or regularly, (T,) *aA=y^ibu, changed to render it more easy of pronunciation, (T, S, K,) and *uw^aAbaAtN also. (Msb.) Hence, futila *awaAy^ibuhu [His pendent locks of hair were twisted;] meaning (tropical:) he was made to abandon, or relinquish, his opinion or idea or judgment. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything that hangs down loosely. (TA.) (tropical:) The end of a turban, (A, Msb,) that hangs down between the shoulders. (A.) (assumed tropical:) The end of a whip. (Msb.) (tropical:) Of a sandal. The thing, or portion, that hangs down from, or of, [the upper part of] the qibaAl [or thong that passes, from the sole, between two of the toes; it is generally a prolongation of the qibaAl]: (T:) or the part that touches the ground, of the thing that is made to fall down upon the foot, (M, A, K,) attached to the $iraAk [or thong extending from the qibaAl above mentioned towards the ankle]; (A;) so called because of its waggling. (M.) (tropical:) Of a sword, The thong [or cord] which is attached to the hilt, (T, A,) and which [is sometimes also made fast to the guard, and at other times] hangs loose and dangles. (A.) (assumed tropical:) A skin, or piece of skin, that is hung upon the A=xirap [or hinder part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (S, M, K;) also termed Ea*abapN. (TA.) A poet speaks, metaphorically, of the *awaAy^ib of palmtrees [app. meaning (tropical:) Hanging clusters of dates]. (M.) And one says naArN saATiEapN Al*~awaAy^ibi (tropical:) [A fire of which the flames rise and spread]. (A.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The higher, or highest, part of anything: (M, K:) and ↓ *uw^aAbN is used as its pl., or [as a coll. gen. n., i. e.] as bearing the same relation to *uw^aAbapN that sal~N does to sal~apN. (M.) You say, EalawotN *uw^aAbapa Aljabali (tropical:) [I ascended upon the summit of the mountain]. (A.) And *uw^aAbapu AlEiz~i wa Al$~arafi (tropical:) The highest degree of might and of nobility. (T, * M.) And huwa fiY *uw^aAbapi qawomihi (assumed tropical:) He is among the highest of his people; taken from the *w^Abp of the head. (M.) And humo *uw^aAbapu qawomihimo (T, A) and *awaAy^ibuhumo (A) (tropical:) They are the nobles of their people: (A, T:) and mino *awaAy^ibi qurayo$K (tropical:) of the nobles of Kureysh. (TA.) And fulaAnN mina Al*~anaAy^ibi laA mina Al*~awaAy^ibi (tropical:) [Such a one is of the lowest of the people, not of the highest]. (A.) ― -b4- *awaAy^ibu AljawozaA='u is a name of (assumed tropical:) Nine stars disposed in a bowed, or curved, form, in the sleeve of Orion; also called taAju AljawozaA='i. (Kzw in his description of Orion.)
― -b5- *awAy^ibu layolapK (assumed tropical:) The last, or latter, parts, or portions, of a night. (Har p. 58.)

A^aroDN ma*oA^abapN *
A land containing, (S,) or abounding with, (M, K,) wolves: (S, M, K:) in the dial. of some of the tribe of Keys, ma*ayobapN, agreeing with *iybN. (M.)

mu*aA^~abN * A boy having a *uw^aAbap. (T, S, A, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A [camel's saddle such as is called] gabiyT [&c.] having [a *uw^aAbap, i. e.] a skin, or piece of skin, hung upon its A=xirap [or hinder part]: (S:) or having a *iy^obap [q. v.]. (TA.)

ma*ow^uwbN * A man frightened by wolves: (A, TA:) or whose sheep, or goats, have been fallen upon by the wolf. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) Frightened [as though by a wolf]. (T, TA.) -A2- Also A horse, (Mgh,) or such as is called biro*awonN, (Lth, T, M, K,) and, accord. to the Tekmileh, an ass, and so ma*obuwbN, as though from *iybapN for *iy^obapN, (Mgh,) Affected with the disease termed *iy^obapN. (Lth, T, M, Mgh, K.)
muta*aAy^ibN * (assumed tropical:) A man in a state of commotion, or fluctuation; from ta*aA='abati Alr~iyHu. (TA from a trad.)
*aAtu * ; dual. *awaAtaA; pl. *awaAtN: see art. *w.
*aAtiY~N * : and *aAtiy~apN: see art. *w.

1 *ay^ira Ealayohi * , (S, * K, * TA,) aor.
*aAa^a , (K,) inf. n. *aA^arN, (M,) He was angry with him: (M, * K, * TA:) he was enraged against him, namely his enemy, and prepared to spring upon him. (Lth.) ― -b2- He became emboldened against him. (S * K, * TA.) ― -b3- *ay^ira, aor.
*aAa^a , He became contracted in his bosom, and evil in his disposition. (Ibn-Es-Seed.) ― -b4- He was frightened, or terrified; he feared, or was afraid. (M, K.) ― -b5- He was disdainful, or averse [from a person or thing]; or he disdained, or scorned: (K:) he became affected with aversion and disapprobation: 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras says,
*ay^iruwA liqatolaY EaAmirK watagaD~abuwA
meaning They became affected with aversion and disapprobation on account of the slain of 'Ámir [and became angry]: (T, S:) or, as some say, were disdainful, or averse, thereat. (T.) ― -b6- *ay^irahu, (aor.
*aAa^a , TA,) He disliked, or hated, it, and turned away, or back, from it. (S, K.) ― -b7- *ay^irato EalaYzawojihaA, (As, S, K,) and ↓ *aA='arato, (K,) contracted by El-Hoteiäh into *aArato, (TA,) [see also art. *r,] She was disobedient to her husband, and hated him; (As, S, K;) was averse from him; and became emboldened against him. (As, S.) ― -b8- *ay^ira biAl$~aYo'i He became accustomed, or habituated, to the thing. (S, K.) -A2- *A^ara Aln~aAqapa He smeared the she-camels' teats with *iy^aAr, that her young one might not such her. (K.)
3 *aA='arato * : see 1. ― -b2- Also She (a camel) was averse from her young one when she brought it forth. (TA.)

4 A^a*oA^arahu Ealayohi *
He made him angry with him. (M, K. *) A 'Obeyd has transposed, and then changed, one of its letters, saying A^a*oraAniY, which is a mistake. (M.) ― -b2- A*A^rhu, (inf. n. A_i*oA=rN, AZ, S,) He excited him to animosity; (AZ, T, S;) incited him; (AZ, S, M, K;) emboldened him; (K;) biSaAHibihi [against his companion]. (AZ, S, M.) ― -b3- A*A^rhu A_ilaY $aYo'K, (M, K, *) and A*A^rhu $ayoy^FA, (TA,) He constrained or compelled or necessitated him to have recourse to, or to do, a thing. (M, K, * TA.)
*ay^irN * : see *aAy^irN, in two places. ― -b2- A_in~a $uw^uwnaka la*ay^irapN (S, K *) Verily thy tears are accompanied by a breathing, or sighing, (tanaf~us,) like that of the angry. (K.)

*iy^aArN *
Fresh camels' or similar dung, (baEar,) mixed with dust, or earth, with which a she-camel's teats are smeared, that she may not be sucked. (M, * K, * TA.) [See also art. *yr.]

*aAy^irN *
Angry; (IAar, T, K;) as also ↓ *ay^irN. (K.) ― -b2- Contracted in the bosom, and evil in disposition. (Ibn-Es-Seed.) ― -b3- Disdaining, or averse [from a person or thing]: disdainful; scornful. (IAar, T.) ― -b4- A woman disobedient to her husband, and hating him; (S, K;) averse from him; and emboldened against him; (S;) as also ↓ *ay^irN, and ↓ mu*aAy^irN: (K:) [all without *aAy^irN:] and in a similar sense *aAy^irN is applied to a man. (S, * TA.)

mu*aAy^irN * : see *aAy^irN. ― -b2- Also, [without p,] A she-camel averse from her young one when she has just brought it forth: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) or that makes a show of affection with her nose [by smelling her young one] (taroA^amu biA^anofihaA), and has not true love: (S, M, K:) or evil in disposition. (M.)

1 *aA^afa * , aor.
*aAa^a , inf. n. *aA^afaAnN, [in the CK *aA^ofAn,] He died: (Moheet, K, TA:) [or he died quickly: see *aA^ofN, which is app. an inf. n, as also, perhaps, *uw^aAfN.] -A2- *aA^ofahu, and *aA^afa Ealayohi, inf. n. *aA^ofN and *aA^afN, He despatched him; namely, a wounded man; or hastened and completed his slaughter. (M.) ― -b2- And ya*oA^afu is also said of poison [app. as meaning It kills quickly]. (Lth, T.) ― -b3- mar~a ya*oA^afuhumo He passed by driving them away, or pursuing them, or destroying them. (M.)

7 An*A^f *
His heart broke (AinoqaTaEa fuw^aAduhu). (K.) [See its syn. An*Ef.]

*aA^ofN *
Quickness of death; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also ↓ *uw^aAfN. (K.) [See 1, first sentence.] ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of *aA^afahu. (M.)
*aA^ofaAnN * : see *iy^ofaAnN. ― -b2- Accord. to the K, it signifies also Death: but the correct word seems to be *aA^afaAnN, [see 1, first sentence,] as in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
*uw^ofaAnN * : see what next follows.

*iy^ofaAnN * (Lth, T, M, K) Poison that kills quickly (ya*oA^afu): (Lth, T:) or simply poison; (M, K;) as also ↓ *uw^ofaAnN and ↓ *aA^ofaAnN, (K, TA,) all with ' (TA,) and *iyfaAnN (A 'Obeyd, T, M, K) and *ayofaAnN (A 'Obeyd, T, K) and *ayafaAnN and *uwfaAnN, (IDrd, K,) and ↓ *uw^aAfN. (T, K: the last, in the TA, without '.)
*uw^aAfN * Death that despatches quickly; (T, M, K;) as also *uEaAfN; thought by Yaakoob to be an instance of permutation. (M.) ― -b2- See also *iy^ofaAnN. -A2- And see *aA^ofN.
*aAka * : see art. *A; and k as a letter of allocution.

1 *aA^ala * , (T, K,) or *aA^alato, (S,) aor.
*aAa^a , inf. n. *aA^alaAnN (T, S, K) and *aA^olN or *aA^alN, (accord. to different copies of the S and K, the latter accord. to the TA,) He, (T, K,) or she, i. e. a camel, (S,) walked, or went, lightly: (AZ, T, S:) or quickly: (K:) or lightly, (K,) or quickly, (IF,) and proudly, with an inclining of the body from side to side. (IF, K.) [See also daA^ala: and see *aA^alaAnN, below.]

6 t*A='l *
He became vile, base, ignominious, abject, or contemptible; syn. tSAgr. (K.)

*aA^olaAnN * , (K,) or ↓ *aA^alaAnN, (ISk, S, M,) and ↓ *uA^olaAnN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) The jackal (Aibonu A=waY): or the wolf: (K:) or the second word has the latter signification: (ISk, S, M:) and the last word, the former signification: (M:) the pl. of the second word, having the latter signification, is *aA=liylu, with l. (ISk, S.) [See also daA^olaAnN and daA^alaAnN: and see *uw^aAlapN, below.]
*uwolaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

*aA^alaAnN * The walk, or manner of going, of the wolf: pl. *aA=liylu, with l: (M, K:) [but ISd says,] I know not how this is. (M. [See also daA=liylu.]) Also [as an inf. n. of 1, q. v.,] A quick walk or manner of going: (M:) or, as some say, a moderate running: or an extraordinary manner, or rate, of going, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (T.) -A2- See also *aA^olaAnN.
*aw^uwlN * Anything [or any animal] Quick, or swift. (T.) [See also daw^uwlN.]

*uw^aAlapu *
The wolf: (T, S, M, K:) so called because of his light walk or manner of going; (A 'Obeyd, T, S;) or because of a lightness in his running: (M:) it is determinate, (S, M, K, TA,) and imperfectly decl., being a proper name and [grammatically] of the fem. gender: (TA:) pl. *iy^olaAnN and *uw^olaAnN. (M, K.) One says, xa$~i *uw^aAlapa baAlHibaAlapi [Frighten thou the wolf with the snare]: (S, Meyd, TA:) a prov., applied to him whose threatening is not regarded: meaning threaten thou other than me; for I know thee: (Meyd,
TA:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, said by him who orders one to menace and threaten. (Meyd.) [See also *aA^olaAnN.]

mi*oA^alN *
Light and quick. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

1 *aA^amahu * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
*aAa^a , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. *aA^omN, (S, * M,) He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it; (T, S, Msb;) namely, a man, (T, [in which it is said that *aA^amotuhu in the sense of Eibotuhu is more common than *amamotuhu, ” though the contr. seems to be manifestly the case,]) or a commodity; (Msb;) and he despised him; like *aA^abahu: (S:) and he despised him and beat him: (T:) and he despised him and blamed him: (T, M, K:) or he despised him and drove him away; like *aA^abahu: (M:) and simply he drove him away: (M, K:) or he drove him away and beat him; like *aA^abahu: (M and TA in art. *A^b:) and he repaid him, or requited him; syn. jazaAhu: (T and M:) or he overcame him in abasing; syn. xazaAhu. (K and TA. [So in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK: but I doubt not that jazaAhu is the right reading.])

4 A*A^mhu * , (TA,) inf. n. A_i*oA=mN, (K, TA,) He frightened him, or terrified him; syn. of the inf. n. ruEobN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A^a*oA^amotaniY EalaY ka*aA Thou compelledst me against my will to do such a thing. (Fr, S.)

*aA^omN *
i. q. EayobN [as a subst., meaning A vice, fault, defect, or the like; like *aAmN, without ', and *ayomN; as well as an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]: with and without ' (S.)

*aA^omapN *
A word: so in the saying, maA samiEotu lahu *aA^omapF [I heard not a word that he had to utter]. (K.)
ma*ow^uwmN * pass. part. n. of 1. (S, Msb.) ma*ow^uwmFA in the Kur [vii. 17] means Blamed: (TA:) or driven away: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Lh and Mujáhid, banished. (T, TA. *)

1 *aA^anahu * , [aor.
*aAa^a ,] inf. n. *aA^onN, [app. from *uw^onuwnN, q. v.,] He held his state, or condition, to be contemptible and weak. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 *aA^onanati AlA^aroDu *
The land produced the kind of plant called *uw^onuwn. (IAar, M.)

R. Q. 2 xarajuwA yatadaA^onanuwna * (S, so in both of my copies, and K and TK, but [erroneously] written in the TT as from the M yt*A^onwn, and in some copies of the K yata*aA=y^anuwna, or yata*aA='anuwna, [the verb being evidently a denominative from *uw^onuwnN like tajalobaba from jilobaAbN,]) They went forth (S, M, K) to take, (S,) or to seek and take, (M,) or to gather, (K,) the kind of plant called *uw^onuwn (S, M, K.)

*uw^onuwnN * [A kind, or species, of fungus; perhaps a species of phallus;] a certain plant, (T, S, K,) of the same kind as the Eurojuwn and the Turovuwvi, which grows in the winter, and, when the day becomes hot, rots, and goes away; (IAar, T;) said by Abu-l-'Omeythil to be, in form, like the hiloyawon [or asparagus]: (T:) pl. *aA=niynu: (T, S:) and some pronounce the sing. *uwnuwnN, without '; and make the pl. *awaAniynu: (T, TA:) a certain plant that grows at the roots of the A^aroTaY and rimov and A^alaA='; the ground cleaving, and disclosing it, it comes forth like the sawaAEid [app. here meaning the upper arms, above the elbows,] of men; has no leaves; is black (A^asoHamu), and dustcoloured; is pointed [and roundish] in its extremity, like the glans of the penis in form; has envelopes (A^akomaAmu) like those of the [bean called] baAqil~aY; and has a yellow fruit at its upper part: some say that it is a plant that grows like the [fungi called] EaraAjiyn, of the plants termed fuTor: AHn says that what are termed *aA=niyn are things of the [fungi called] fuquwE, that come forth from beneath the ground like thick Eumud [or poles]; nothing eats them, except that camels feed upon them in the year of drought, and goats eat them and fatten upon them; they have a root-stock (A^aruwmap); and are used as medicines; and none but the hungry will eat them, because of their bitterness: he also says in one place, they grow at the roots of trees, most like to the asparagus (hiloyawon), except that they are larger and thicker; and have no leaves; but they have a buroEuwmap [app. here meaning a head, such as is termed a pileus, or cap], which assumes a roseate colour, and then changes to yellow: the *w^nwn is all [full of] water [or juice]; and is white, except what appears thereof, of that buroEuwmap; and nothing eats it, except when men are afflicted with drought and have nothing [else] to eat: the n. un. is with p: (M:) ISh says that it is of a tawny colour, smooth and round, having leaves that stick to it, tall like the Turovuwv, not eaten save by sheep or goats, [and grows] in plain, or soft, tracts: IB says that it is the wild hiloyawon. (TA.) One says of a people who were characterized by courage and excellence, and who have perished, their state having changed, *aA=niynu laA rimova lahaA wa TaraAviyvu laA A^aroTaY [Dhu-noonehs having no rimthehs, and turthoothehs having no artáhs]: meaning that they have been extirpated, and that none of them remains: (TA:) or *A=nyn lA rmv lhA is a prov. applied to him who is ruined, and has nothing remaining, after having had a family and dignity and wealth. (TA voce TurovuwvN.)

1 *ab~a Eanohu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
*abu3a , (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. *ab~N, (T, S, M, Msb,) He repelled from him: he defended him. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) You say, ya*ub~u Eano Hariymihi He repels from, or defends, his wife, or wives, or the like. (T, Msb.) [See also R. Q. 1.] ― -b2- And *ab~N signifies also The act of driving away. (T, TA.) You say, *ab~a Al*~ubaAba, and ↓ *b~bhu, He drove away the fly, or flies. (M, TA.) And AlwaHo$u ta*ub~u Albaq~a biA^a*onaAbihaA [The wild animals drive away the gnats with their tails]. (A.) ― -b3- And [hence,] A^ataAhumo xaATibN fa*ab~uwhu (tropical:) One demanding a woman in marriage came to them, and they rejected him, or turned him back. (A, TA.) -A2- *ub~a (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, possessed; or mad, or insane. (K, TA.) -A3- *ab~a, (M, K,) aor.
*abu3a , [irreg., (the verb being intrans.,) unless the first pers. be *abubotu, like labubotu &c.,] inf. n. *ab~N, (M,) He (a man, K) went hither and thither, not remaining in one place. (M, K. *) -A4- *ab~a, [aor.
*abi3a ,] It dried; dried up; or became dry. (T.) You say, *ab~ato $afatuhu, (S, M, K,) aor.
*abi3a , inf. n. *ab~N and *ababN and *ubuwbN, (M, K,) His lip became dry, (M, K,) or lost its moisture, (S,) by reason of thirst, (S, K,) or by reason of vehement thirst, (M,) &c.; (M, K;) as also ↓ *ab~abato. (M, K.) And *ab~a lisaAnuhu (S, M) in like manner [His tongue became dry &c.]. (M.) And *ab~a said of a plant, It withered, or lost its moisture. (S, K.) And said of a pool of water left by a torrent, It dried up in the end of the hot season. (IAar, M, K.) And *ab~a jisomuhu His body became lean, or emaciated, (S, K, TA,) and lost its moisture. (TA.) And *ab~a, (T, K,) aor.
*abi3a , inf. n. *ab~N, (T,) His colour, or complexion, became altered, by reason of emaciation or hunger or travel &c. (T, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2 *b~b Eanohu *
He repelled from him, or defended him, much, or often. (S.) ― -b2- *b~b Al*~ubaAba: see 1. -A2- *ab~abato $afatuhu: see 1. -A3- [*ab~aba, inf. n. ta*obiybN, also signifies It left a *ubaAbap, i. e. somewhat remaining. Hence,] *b~b Aln~ahaAru (S, A, TA,) or ↓ *ab~a, (so in the K, but corrected in the TA,) (tropical:) The day passed so as to leave thereof only a *ubaAbap; (A, TA; *) i. e. (TA) the day had only a [small] remainder of it left. (S, K, TA.) And TaEonN waramoYN gayoru ta*obiybK (tropical:) A thrusting, or piercing, and a shooting, or casting, with energy [so as not to leave any force unexerted]. (S, * A, TA.) ― -b2- [Also It left not a *ubaAbap, i.e. anything remaining: thus bearing two contr. significations. Hence,] *b~b fiY Als~ayori (tropical:) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in going, or journeying, so that he left not a *ubaAbap [or any part of his journey remaining unaccomplished]: (A, TA:) [or] *b~b signifies (assumed tropical:) he hastened, made haste, or sped; syn. A^asoraEa: (M:) [and, accord. to Et-Tebreezee, this is the primary signification: for he says,] Alt~a*obiybN is like AlT~iraAdu [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) the act of charging, by a horse or a horseman]: but the primary meaning is AlA_isoraAEu. (Ham p. 207.) And *ab~abonaA layolatanaA, (S, K,) inf. n. ta*obiybN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) Our beasts became fatigued, or jaded, by journeying [during that our night]. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 *abo*abN * , (T,) inf. n. *abo*abapN, (K,) He defended his neighbours and family. (T, K.) [See also 1.] -A2- And He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, (T, K,) people. (K.) -A3- And He made a thing to dangle, or move to and fro;
(L;) and made it to be in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. (L, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] *abo*abahu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He left him, or made him to be, confounded, or perplexed, not knowing his right course; wavering, vacillating, or going to and fro. (Msb.) -A4- *abo*abapN also signifies The dangling, or moving to and fro, of a thing suspended in the air: (S, M:) and ↓ ta*abo*ubN the being in a state of motion or commotion: (S, L:) [or the latter has both these meanings; for] you say, Al$~aYo'u ↓ ta*abo*aba the thing dangled, or moved to and fro, (M, A, L,) in the air; (A;) and was in a state of commotion or agitation. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., fakaA^an~iYA^anoZuru A_ilaY yadayohi tu*abo*ibaAni, meaning And it was as though I looked at his two sleeves in a state of commotion, or shaking. (TA.) And you say, bayona A^amorayoni ↓ t*abo*aba (assumed tropical:) He wavered, or vacillated, between two affairs. (MA.) And A^amoruhumo ↓ ta*abo*aba (assumed tropical:) [Their state of affairs was, or became, fluctuating, or unsteady]. (Lh, T in art. dl.)
R. Q. 2 ta*abo*aba * , inf. n. ta*abo*ubN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

*ab~N *
Repelling: fem. with p: hence *ab~aAtu Als~abiybi, a phrase used by Dhu-r-Rummeh, meaning repelling with their tails: or this may be from the signification next following. (Ham p. 510.) -A2- Much in motion. (Ham ubi suprà.) *ab~N, (M, L,) or ↓ *aAb~N, (K,) [the former correct, and perhaps the latter also,] applied to a camel, That does not, or will not, remain still, or motionless, in a place. (M, L, K.) A poet says,
fakaA^an~anaA fiyhimo jimaAlN *ab~apN
[And it was as though we were, among them, camels that would not remain still in a place]: which shows that *ab~N is not an inf. n. used as an epithet; for, were it so, he had said jimaAlN *ab~N. (M, L.) ― -b2- Al*~ab~u (tropical:) The wild bull; [a species of bovine antelope;] also called *ab~u Alr~iyaAdi; (T, S, M, K;) so called because he goes to and fro, not remaining in one place; (M;) or because he pastures going to and fro; (T, S, * M;) or because his females pasture with him, going to and fro: (T:) and called also ↓ AlA^a*ab~u, (T, K,) by poetic license, for Al*~ab~u; (T;) and ↓ Al*~unobubu. (K.) ― -b3- *ab~u Alr~iyaAdi is also applied to (tropical:) A man who goes and comes. (Kr, M, TA.) And (tropical:) A man who is in the habit of visiting women. (AA, T, K.)

*ubaAbN * [The common fly;] the black thing that is in houses, that falls into the vessel and into food; (M;) well known: (S, K:) so called, accord. to Ed-Demeeree, because of its fluttering about, or because it returns as often as it is driven away: (TA:) and likewise applied to the bee; (M, K;) which is also called *ubaAbu Algayovi [the fly of the rain], (IAth, TA,) or *ubaAbu gayovK [the fly of rain]; because the rain is the means of producing herbage, and by herbage it is fed; (Mgh;) or because it accompanies rain, and lives upon that which the rain causes to grow: (IAth, TA:) [accord. to some, it is a coll. gen. n.; and] the n. un. is ↓ *ubaAbapN: (S, Msb, K:) one should not say *ib~aAnapN [as the vulgar do in the present day]: (S:) or one should not say ↓ *ubaAbapN, though El-Ahmar and Ks are related to have used this word [as meaning a kind of fly]; for *ubaAbN is a sing. [properly speaking], and is used as such in the Kur xxii. 72: (M:) the pl. (of pauc., S, Msb) is A^a*ib~ahN and (of mult., S, Msb) *ib~aAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and *ub~N, (M, K,) the last mentioned by Sb, accord. to the dial. of Temeem. (M.) One says, A_in~ahu laA^awohaY mina Al*~ubaAbi [Verily he is more frail than the fly]. (A.) And huwa A^ahowanu EalaY~a mino Taniyni Al*~ubaAbi [He is more contemptible to me than the buzzing of the fly]. (A.) manojaY Al*~ubaAbi [The refuge of the fly] is a prov., applied to him who is protected by his ignobleness. (Har p. 332: there written manojaA; and in two places, mnjA^.) And A^abuw Al*~ubaAbi [The father of the fly] is an appellation used as meaning (assumed tropical:) He who has stinking breath; and some say A^abuw Al*~ib~aAni [the father of the flies]: (M, TA:) and is especially applied to 'Abd-El-Melik Ibn-Marwán: (M, A, TA:) whence the saying, A^aboxaru mino A^abiY Al*~ubaAbi (A, TA) and A^abiY Al*~ib~aAni (TA) [More stinking in breath than Abu-dh-Dhubáb and Abu-dh-Dhibbán]. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Evil, or mischief; (A, K;) and annoyance, or harm; as in the saying, A^aSaAbaniY *ubaAbN (tropical:) [Evil, &c., befell me]; (A;) and A^aSaAba fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK *ubaAbN laA*iEN (assumed tropical:) Evil, or mischief, [lit. a hurting fly] fell upon such a one from such a one: (T:) or (tropical:) continual evil, as in the saying, A^aSaAbaka *ubaAbN mino h`*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) [Continual evil hath befallen thee from this thing, or event]; and $ar~uhaA *ubaAbN (tropical:) [Her, or its, or their, evil is a continual evil]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Ill luck. (T, K.) Fr relates that the Prophet saw a man with long hair; and said *ubaAbN, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is ill luck: and hence, ↓ rajulN *ubaAbiY~N (assumed tropical:) [An unlucky man]. (T.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Plague, or pestilence. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Diabolical possession; or madness, or insanity. (K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Ignorance: so in the phrase rajulN maHo$iY~N Al*~ubaAbi (assumed tropical:) [A man stuffed with ignorance]. (M.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The A_inosaAn [as meaning the pupil, or apple,] of the eye: (AZ, T, S, M, A, K:) so in the saying, huwa A^aEaz~u EalaY~a mino *ubaAbi AlEayoni (tropical:) [He is dearer to me than the apple of the eye]: (A:) [ISd says,] I think it to be so termed as being likened to the *ubaAb [properly so called; i.e. the fly]. (M.) And Al*~ubaAbu also signifies (assumed tropical:) A black speck, or spot, in the interior of the Hadaqap [or dark part] of the eye of the horse. (M, K.) The pl. is as above. (M.) ― -b8- *ubaAbu Als~ayofi (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ *ubaAbapN Als~ayofi (TA) (tropical:) The Had~, (M, K,) or Taraf, (S, Msb,) [each app. here meaning the point, or extremity, though the former also means the edge,] of the sword, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is the part wherewith one strikes: (S, Msb:) or its extremity with which one is pierced, or transpierced; and the Had~ [here meaning edge] with which one strikes is called its giraAr: (En-Nadr, T:) or its tapering, or pointed, extremity; expl. by Tarafuhu AlmutaTar~ifu: (M, K:) or the point (Had~) of its extremity (M, A) which is between its $aforataAni: (M:) the parts of its two edges that are on either side of it are its ZubataAni: the ridge in the middle of it, on the inner and outer sides, is called the Eayor; and each has what are termed giraAraAni, which are the part between the Eayor and each one of the ZubataAni on the outer side of the sword and the corresponding portion of the inner side, each of the giraAraAni being on the inner side of the sword and its outer side. (AZ, T, TA.) [The swords of the Arabs, in the older times, were generally straight, twoedged, and tapering to a point; and so are many of them in the present day; a little wider towards the point than towards the hilt.] Hence the saying, vamarapu Als~awoTi yatobaEuhaA *ubaAbu Als~ayofi (tropical:) [The knot, or tail, at the end of the whip is followed by the point of the sword; i. e., whipping (if it effect not the desired correction) is followed by slaughter]. (A.) ― -b9- [Hence,] *ubaAbN signifies likewise (assumed tropical:) The Had~ [or point, or extremity, or edge,] of anything. (A 'Obeyd, T.) ― -b10- (tropical:) The pointed, or sharp, part of the extremity of the ear (A 'Obeyd, M, K) of a horse (A 'Obeyd, M) and of a man. (M.) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) The sharp edge of the teeth of camels. (S, TA.) ― -b12- And (assumed tropical:) The part that first comes forth of the flower of the Hin~aA=' (M, K.)

*ubaAbapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and see another sentence, in the latter half of the same paragraph. ― -b3- (tropical:) A remainder, or remains, (T, S, M, A, * Msb, K,) of a thing, (T, Msb,) of the waters of wells, (T,) or of thirst, (M, A,) and of hunger, (A,) and of a debt, (S, M, K,) and the like, (S,) and of the day, (A,) or, as some say, of anything; (M;) or of a thing that is sound, or valid, or substantial; distinguished from dunaAnapN, which signifies a remainder, or remains, of a thing that is weak, or frail, and perishing, and particularly of a debt, or of a promise: (S and L in art. *n:) pl. *ubaAbaAtN. (T, S, Msb.) You say, Sadarati AlA_ibilu wabihaA *ubaAbapN, (M,) or bihaA *ubaAbapN mino ZamaA^K (A,) i. e. (tropical:) [The camels returned from water having in them] somewhat remaining of thirst. (M.) ― -b4- And the pl. *ubaAbaAtN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Small mountains: so says El-Andalusee. (MF.)
*ubaAbiY~N * : see *ubaAbN.

*ab~aAbN * A man who repels from, or defends, with energy, his wife, or wives, or the like; as also ↓ mi*ab~N. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] yiwomN *ab~aAbN (tropical:) A sultry day in which the wild animals are infested by numerous gnats, and drive them away with their tails: the act being thus attributed to the day. (A.) -A2- See also what next follows.

$afapN *ab~aAnapN * , the latter word of the measure faEolaAnapN, in some of the copies of the K erroneously written ↓ *ab~aAbapN, (TA,) [and so in the TT as from the M,] A lip that has become dry, or has lost its moisture. (M, K, TA.)

*abo*abN * The penis, (T, * S, M, A, K,) as some say; (M;) as also ↓ *abo*abapN and ↓ *abaA*ibu, which
last is not a pl., (K,) though of a pl. measure; (TA;) so called because of the motion thereof, to and fro: (TA:) and the tongue: (M, A:) or ↓ *abo*abapN has this latter meaning: (K:) and ↓ *abaA*ibu signifies the genitals; or, as some say, the testicles; (M;) one of which is termed ↓ *abo*abapN. (M, K.)
*ubo*ubN * : see *abaA*ibu.
*ibo*ibN * : see *abaA*ibu, in two places.
*abo*abapN * : see *abo*abN, in three places: ― -b2- and see also *abaA*ibu.

*abaA*ibu *
Certain things that are hung to the [women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj, (S, M, K,) or to the head of a camel, (M,) for ornament; [i. e. tassels, or pendant tufts of wool, or shreds of woollen cloth, of various colours; (see raEavN;)] as also ↓ *abo*abapN: (M, K:) the sing. of the former is ↓ *ibo*ibN, (T,) or ↓ *ubo*ubN, with damm. (TA.) ― -b2- And The fringes, and edges, of a [garment of the kind called] burodap; because of their motion upon the wearer when he walks: sing. ↓ *ibo*ibN. (TA from a trad.) ― -b3- See also *abo*abN, in two places.
*aAb~N * : see *ab~N.
Al*~unobubu * : see *ab~N.
A^a*ab~u * : see ma*obuwbN: -A2- and *ab~N. -A3- Also The tush, or canine tooth, of the camel. (T, K.) -A4- And Tall, or long; syn. TawiylN. (K.)
mi*ab~N * : see *ab~aAbN.
A^aroDN ma*ab~apN * (S, M, K) and ↓ ma*obuwbapN (Fr, S, K) A land containing, (S,) or abounding with, (M, K,) flies. (S, M, K.)

mi*ab~apN *
A thing with which one drives away flies; (S, M, K; *) a fly-whisk made of horse-hairs: (T:) [pl. ma*aAbN whence,] one says of wild-animals, A^a*onaAbuhaA ma*aAb~uhaA (tropical:) [Their tails are their fly-whisks]. (A.)

mu*ab~ibN * (tropical:) A rider hastening, or making haste, (T, S, M, K,) apart from others: (S, M, K:) or striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, in going, or journeying, so as to leave not a *ubaAbap [or any part of his journey remaining unaccomplished]. (A.) And it is also applied to a [wild] bull. (A.) In the following saying,
↓ masiyrapN$ahorK lilobaEiyri Almu*abo*ibi
(assumed tropical:) [A month's journey to the hastening camel], (M,) or lilobariydi Almu*abo*ibi [to the hastening messenger], (TA,) by Alm*b*b is meant Almu*ab~ib. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) A quick journey: or one in which is no flagging, or langour.] You say, laA yanaAluwna AlmaA='i A_il~aA biqarabK mu*ab~ibK, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [They will not reach the water but by a] quick [night-journey thereto]. (S.) And ximosN mu*ab~ibN (assumed tropical:) [A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days] in which is no flagging, or langour. (T.) ― -b3- Zimo'N mu*ab~ibN (assumed tropical:) [An interval between two water-ings] of long duration, in which one journeys from afar (T, S, M, K) and with haste. (T, S, K.)

ma*obuwbN * A camel attacked by flies, (A 'Obeyd, S, M,) that enter his nostrils, (S,) so that his neck becomes twisted, and he dies; as also ↓ A^a*ab~u: or both signify one that, coming to a cultivated region, finds it unwholesome to him, and dies there: (M:) and the former, a horse into whose nostril the fly has entered. (A.) ― -b2- See also A^aroDN ma*ab~apN, above. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Possessed; or mad, or insane. (K.) ― -b4- And, accord. to the Abridgment of the 'Eyn, [in a copy of the S written *abuwbN, and in other copies thereof omitted,] (assumed tropical:) Foolish; stupid; or unsound, dull, or deficient, in intellect. (TA.)

mu*abo*abN *
Driven away: (TA:) or driven away, or repelled, much. (T, TA.) It is said in a trad., tazaw~ajo waA_il~aA faA^anota mina Almu*abo*abiyna, i. e. [Marry, or thou wilt be of] those driven away from the believers because thou hast not imitated them, and from the monks because thou hast forsaken their institutes: from Al*~ab~u “ the act of driving away: ” or, accord. to IAth, it may be from the signification of “ motion and agitation. ” (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [iv. 142], mu*abo*abiyna bayona *`lika, meaning Much driven away, or much repelled, from these and from those: (T, TA:) or this is an ex. of the meaning next following. (S, M.) ― -b2- A man (M, K) wavering, or vacillating, between two things, or affairs; (T, S, M, K;) or between two men, not attaching himself steadily to either; (T;) and ↓ mu*abo*ibN signifies the same; (K;) as also ↓ muta*abo*ibN. (M.)
mu*abo*ibN * : see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also mu*ab~ibN.
muta*abo*ibN * : see mu*abo*abN, last sentence.

1 *ubaHa * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
*abaHa , (K,) inf. n. *aboHN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and *ubaAHN, (K,) He cut, or divided, lengthwise; clave; split; slit; rent, or rent open; ripped, or ripped open. (S, Msb, K.) [Accord. to Fei,] this is the primary signification. (Msb.) [But see what follows.] You say, *abaHa faA^orapa Almisoka (assumed tropical:) He (a perfumer, A) ripped open the follicle, or vesicle, of mush, (A, TA,) and took forth the mush that was in it. (TA.) [In the A and TA this is said to be tropical; the authors evidently holding it to be from *abaHa in the sense here next following.] ― -b2- He slaughtered [for food, or sacrificed,] (L, TA) and animal, (Msb,) or a sheep or goat, (S, TA,) or an ox or a cow, and a sheep or goat, and the like, (Mgh,) [in the manner prescribed by the law, i. e.,] by cutting the wadajaAni [or two external jugular veins], (Mgh,) or by cutting the throat, from beneath, at the part next the head: (L, TA:) accord. to the K, i. q. naHara: but correctly, Al*~aboHu is in the throat; and Aln~aHoru is in the pit above the breast, between the collar-bones, where camels are stabbed: the latter word is used in relation to camels and bulls and cows; and the former, in relation to other animals: or, not improbably, both may have originally signified the causing the soul to depart by wounding the throat, or the pit above the breast, which is the stabbing-place in the camel; and may then have been applied in peculiar [and different] senses by the lawyers. (MF. [See also *akaApN, in art. *kw.]) Also (assumed tropical:) He slaughtered, or slew, in any manner. (L.) [You say, *abaHa Eanohu He slaughtered, or sacrificed, for him, by way of expiation.] And *abaHa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA (assumed tropical:) [They slaughtered, or slew, one another]. (S, K.) And A^axa*ahumo banuw fulaAnK biAl*~ubaAHi (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one slaughtered, or slew, them. (TA.) And ↓ *b~H (inf. n. ta*obiyHN, KL) signifies the same as *abaHa, except that it applies [only] to many objects; whereas the latter applies to few and to many: thus it is said in the Kur [ii. 46, and in like manner in xiv. 6], yu*ab~iHuwna A^abonaA='akumo (assumed tropical:) [They slaughtering, or slaying, your sons], accord. to the reading commonly obtaining. (Aboo-Is-hák, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (tropical:) He killed; because Al*~aboHu [in its proper sense, when the object is an animal,] is one of the quickest modes of killing. (TA.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) cautioning against accepting the office of a Kádee, (Mgh,) mano juEila qaADiyFA bayona Aln~aAsi fakaA^an~amaA *ubiHa bigayori sik~iynK (tropical:) [Whoso is made a Kádee among the people, he is as though he were slaughtered without a knife]: (Mgh, TA: *) expl. by some as meaning, (tropical:) he is as though he were killed [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, also, because Al*~aboHu renders the flesh of an animal allowable, or lawful, as food,] (tropical:) It rendered allowable, or lawful: as salt and the sun and the fishes called niynaAn (pl. of nuwnN) do wine, by changing its quality, as is said in a trad. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) He broached, or pierced, a dan~ [or wine-jar, making a hole in the mouth, or removing the clay that closed the mouth], so as to draw forth the contents. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) He, or it, choked. (K, TA.) You say, *abaHatohu AlEaborapu (tropical:) Weeping choked him. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And, said of thirst, (tropical:) It affected him severely, or distressed him. (A, TA.) ― -b8- *abaHati All~iHoyapu fulaAnFA (tropical:) The beard flowed down beneath the chin of such a one so that the anterior portion of the part beneath his lower jaw was apparent: in which case, the man is said to be biliHoyatihi ↓ ma*obuwHN. (K, TA.)

2 *ab~aHa see 1. -A2- ta*obiyHN is [said to be] syn. with ta*obiyHN, (K, TA,) in prayer: accord. to Hr, *b~H raA^osahu signifies He lowered his head, in inclining his body in prayer; like db~H: and accord. to Lth, *b~H signifies he lowered his head, in inclining his body in prayer, so that it became lower than his back: but Az says that this is a mistake, and that the correct word is db~H, with the unpointed d. (TA.)

6 t*AbHwA * (assumed tropical:) They slaughtered, or slew, one another. (S, MA, K.) One says, Alt~amaAduHu Alt~a*aAbuHu
(tropical:) [Mutual praising is mutual slaughtering]. (S, A.)

8 Ai*~abaHa *
He took, or prepared, for himself a slaughtered [or sacrificed] animal. (S, K.)

*iboHN *
An animal prepared for slaughter [or sacrifice; i. e. an intended victim]: (T, A, Msb, TA:) [see also *abiyHN, which occurs in this sense in a trad. as applied to a human being:] or an animal that is slaughtered [or sacrificed]; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) and so ↓ *abiyHapN; (Mgh, Msb;) or this signifies a slaughtered [or sacrificed] sheep or goat; (TA;) and is [nominally] fem. of *abiyHN, but the p is affixed only because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it: (S:) or the *abiyHN is added to denote that the word is applied to a sheep, or goat, [to be slaughtered or sacrificed,] not yet slaughtered [or sacrificed]; and when the act has been executed upon it, it is [said to be] *abiyHN: (M, voce ramiy~apN:) *iboHN is applied to an animal that is slaughtered either as a sacrifice on the occasion of the pilgrimage or otherwise; and is like TiHonN in the sense of maToHuwnN, and EiTofN in the sense of maEoTuwfN, &c.: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ *abiyHapN is *abaAy^iHu. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxvii. 107], wafadayonaAhu bidiboHK EaZiymK [And we ransomed him with a great victim]. (S, A.) Aljin~i ↓ *abaAy^iHu means Animals sacrificed to the Jinn, or Genii: for it was customary for a man, when he bought a house, or drew forth [for the first time] the water of a spring, and the like, to sacrifice an animal to the Jinn with the view of avoiding ill luck, (A, TA,) lest some disagreeable accident should happen to him from the Jinn thereof: (A:) and the doing this is forbidden. (A, TA.) -A2- See also *ubaHapN.

*ubaHN *
A certain plant which ostriches eat: (S:) this word and ↓ *ibaHN signify the plant called Aljazaru Alb~arY~u, (K, TA,) which is of a red colour: and, accord. to the K, another plant: but correctly a red plant (nabotN A^aHomaru, not nbt A=xaru,) having a stem, or root, (A^aSolN) from which is peeled off a black peel, whereupon there is taken forth a white substance, resembling a white xzrp [or bead, but perhaps this is a mistranscription for jazarap, i. e. a carrot], which is sweet and good, and is eaten: [each word is a coll. gen. n.;] and the n. un. is *ubaHapN and *ibaHapN: so says AHn, on the authority of Fr: and he says also, on the authority of AA, that the *ubaHap is a tree that grows upon a stem, and in a manner resembling the krAv [app. karaAv, not kur~aAv], and then has a yellow flower; its root is like a jzrp [i. e. jazarap, or carrot], and it is sweet, and of a red colour: (TA:) or the *ubaH is a plant having a stem, or root, (A^aSolN,) which is peeled, and there comes forth what resembles the jizr [i. e. jizar or jazar, meaning carrot]; and a black skin is peeled from it; and it is sweet, and is eaten; and has a red flower. (Ham p. 777.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ *ibaHN, (K,) the former the more common, (Th, TA,) A species of the kamoA^apN [or truffle], (K,) of a white colour. (TA.) ― -b3- See also *ubaAHN.
*ibaHN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
*uboHapN * : see *ubaHapN.

*iboHapN *
A mode, or manner, of *aboH [i. e. slaughter, such as is described in the first paragraph of this art.]. (Mgh.) -A2- See also what here next follows.

*ubaHapN * (AZ, S, A, K) and ↓ *uboHahN, (As, A, K,) but this latter, which is used by the vulgar, was unknown to AZ, (S,) and ↓ *ubaAHN (A, K) and ↓ *ibaHapN and ↓ *iboHapN and ↓ *ibaAHN (K) and ↓ *iboHN, (TA,) A disease, (T, A,) or pain, (AZ, S, K,) in the Haloq [or fauces], (AZ, T, S, A, K,) which sometimes kills: (T:) or blood which chokes and kills: (K:) or an ulcer that comes forth in the Haloq [or fauces] of a man, like the *iy^obap that attacks the ass: (ISh, TA:) or an ulcer that appears in that part, obstructing it, and stopping the breath, and killing. (TA.) One says, A^axa*atohu Al*~ubaHapu [The *bHp attacked him]. (S.) And ↓ AlT~amaEu *ubaAHN (tropical:) Covetousness is [like] a disease in the fauces: or a poisonous plant. (A.) And kaAna *`lika mivola Al*~ubaHapi EalaY Aln~aHori [That was like the disease called *bHp in the uppermost part of the breast]: a prov., applied to the case of a man whom one imagines to be a sincere friend, and who proves to be an evident enemy: (TA:) or kaAna mivola Al*~ubaHapi Alx He was like the *bHp &c., a disease in the Haloq, which does not quit the patient externally, and hurts him internally: said by him to whom you complain of one whom you imagined to be a sincere friend, and whose affection was outward, when his deceit has become manifest. (Meyd.) -A2- dubaHapN is also the n. un. of *ubaHN [q. v.]. (Fr, AHn.)
*ibaHapN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- It is also the n. un. of *ibaHN [q. v. voce *uabaHN]. (Fr, AHn.)

*ubaAHN *
A certain poisonous plant, (A, K, TA,) that kills the eater of it; as also ↓ *ubaHN. (TA.) One says, AlT~amaEu . *ubaAHN: see *ubaHapN, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] mawotN *ubaAHN (assumed tropical:) A quick, or sudden, death. (L.) -A2- See also *ub~aAHN.
*ibaAHN * : see *ubaHapN.

*abiyHN * and ↓ ma*obuwHN signify the same [i. e. Cut, or divided, lengthwise; &c.: see 1]. (S, Msb, K, TA.) You say misokN *abiyHN [for *abiyHN faA^oratuhu], meaning (assumed tropical:) [Musk of which the follicle, or vesicle, is] ripped open. (A. [It is there said to be tropical: but see 1.]) ― -b2- Both are [also] applied to an animal, (Msb,) or a sheep or goat, (TA,) [or an animal of the ox-kind, and a sheep or goat, and the like, (see 1,)] as meaning Slaughtered, in the manner described in the first paragraph of this art.: (TA:) the fem. of *abiyHN is with p: (S, TA: [see *abiyHapN below:]) but *abiyHN is used as a fem. epithet without the addition of p: you say $aApN *abiyHN as well as kabo$N *abiyHN, because *abiyHN is an instance of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; though you say $Ap *abiyHapN also; and in like manner naAqapN: the pl. [of *abiyHN] is *aboHaY and *abaAHaY and [that of *abiyHapN is] *abaAy^iHu. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing wine,
yuqaAlu lahaA damu Alwadaji Al*~abiyHu
meaning Alma*obuwHu Eanohu, i. e. [One would call it the blood of the external jugular vein,] for which it had been slit [to let it flow]. (AAF, TA.) And again he says,
wasirobK taTal~aY biAlEabiyri kaA^an~ahu
dimaA='u ZibaA='u biAln~uHuwri *abiyHu
[app. meaning And many a bevy of women rubbed over with perfume compounded with saffron, as though it were the blood of gazelles, the gazelles whereof had been slaughtered in the upper parts of the breasts]: he applies *byH as an epithet to dmA=', meaning *abiyHN ZibaAw^uhu; and he applies it as an epithet to a pl. n. because it is of the measure faEiylN [in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN], for such an epithet is applicable to masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. nouns. (TA.) ― -b3- *abiyHN also signifies An animal that is fit, or proper, to be slaughtered as a sacrifice: (ISk, S, K:) [or that is destined, or prepared, for sacrifice; i. e., an intended victim; like *iboHN; as appears from the fact that] Al*~abiyHu is (assumed tropical:) a surname of Ismá'eel, or Ishmael; (K, * TA;) for, accord. to some [or rather the generality] of the Muslims, he was the son whom Abraham designed to sacrifice, though others say it was Isaac: (TA:) and A^anaA A@bonu Al*~abiyHayoni occurs in a trad. [as said by Mohammad, meaning (assumed tropical:) I am the son of the two intended victims; namely, Ismá'eel and 'Abd-Allah]; for 'Abd-El-Muttalib incurred the obligation to sacrifice his son 'Abd-Allah, the father of the Prophet, by reason of a vow, and ransomed him with a hundred camels. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A slain man. (A.)
*abiyHapN * , and its pl. *abaAy^iHu: see *iboHN, in three places.

[
*ab~aAHN * One whose occupation, or habit, is that of slaughtering sheep or the like. ― -b2- And, in the present day, (assumed tropical:) An executioner.]

*ub~aAHN * (T, S, K) and sometimes ↓ *ubaAHN, without teshdeed, (T, K,) the former the more common, (T, K,) but disallowed by AHeyth, who holds it to be one of the words of the measure fuEaAlN denoting diseases, (TA,) (tropical:) Cracks in the inner [i. e. lower] sides of the toes, (S, K, TA,) next the fore part of the foot: (TA:) or a cut across the inner sides of the toes: (Ibn-Buzurj, T:) or a crack in the inner side, or sole, of the foot: (IAar, TA voce nakobapN:) pl. *abaAbiyHu. (TA.) Hence the saying, maA duwnahu $awokapN walaA *ub~aAHN (tropical:) [There is not in the way of its attainment a thorn nor are
there any cracks in the inner sides of the toes, &c.: see also nakobapN]. (S, TA.)

*aAbiHN * [act. part. n. of 1]. saEodu Al*~aAbiHi, (S, K,) or saEodN Al*~aAbiHu, (so in one copy of the S,) (assumed tropical:) Two bright stars, between which is the space of a cubit (*iraAE), over against one of which (fiYnaHori waAHidK minohumaA) is a small star that, by reason of its nearness, is as though it [app. meaning the bright star, or the pair of bright stars,] were about to slaughter it; (S, K;) whence the appellation of Al*~aAbiH: (S:) the two stars [alpha and beta] which are in one of the horns of Capricornus; so called because of the small adjacent star, which is said to be the sheep or goat ($Ap) of Al*AbH, which he is about to slaughter: (Kzw:) it is one of the Mansions of the Moon; (S, Kzw;) [namely, the Twenty-second Mansion: see also art. sEd: some give this appellation to the Twenty-third Mansion: and some, to the Twenty-fifth; but the two stars above mentioned are clearly the Twenty-second, with the place of which they agree accord. to those who make Aln~aw'u to signify “ the auroral rising ” and those who make it to signify “ the auroral setting: ” see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The Arabs [used to] say, A_i*aA TalaEa Al*~aAbiHu A@nojaHara Aln~aAbiHu (assumed tropical:) [When Al*AbH rises aurorally, the barker enters, or betakes itself to, its hole: the period of its auroral rising, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, being the 16th of January, O. S.]. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A mark made with a hot iron across the throat: or (assumed tropical:) the instrument with which it is made. (L, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Hair growing between the part immediately beneath the lower jaw and the part [of the throat] in which an animal is slaughtered. (K.)

*aAbiHapN * , of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, [with p affixed because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it,] Any animal which it is allowable to slaughter, of camels, and bulls or cows, and sheep or goats, &c. (TA.)

ma*obaHN * The place of [the slaughter termed] Al*~aboH: (K:) i. e. the place, or spot of ground, where Al*bH is performed: and the part of the throat which is the place of Al*bH, which is that below the part beneath the lower jaw; (MF, TA;) or the Huloquwm [i. e. windpipe]. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The chancel of a church; i. e. the part of a church that is like the miHoraAb of a mosque: (A, * K, * Msb:) pl. ma*aAbiHu: (A, Msb, K:) the ma*aAbiH are the maHaAriyb (S, A, K) of the Christians; (A;) so called because of the oblations (qaraAbiyn) there offered; (S, TA;) the maqaASiyr (K, TA) in churches, pl. of maqoSuwrapN; said to be the same as the mHAryb: (TA:) and the places, (A,) or chambers, (K,) of the books of the Christians. (A, K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A trench (S, A, K) in the earth, measuring a span or the like [in width], (S, K,) such as is made by a torrent: (S, A:) the channel of a torrent in the lower part of the face of a mountain, or in a plain depressed tract, in width equal to the space measured by the extension of the thumb and first finger or little finger; and sometimes it is a natural trench in a plain tract of land, like a river, in which flows the water of that land: it is in all descriptions of land; in valleys &c., and in depressed tracts: (L:) and a kind of river; as though it clave [the earth] or were cleft: (TA:) pl. ma*aAbiHu. (S, A, L.) You say, gaAdara Als~ayolu fiY AlA^aroDi ma*aAbiHa (assumed tropical:) [The torrent left in the ground trenches about a span wide]. (S.)

mi*obaHN *
A knife with which [the slaughter termed] Al*~aboH is performed: (Msb:) or a thing with which an animal is slaughtered in the manner termed *aboH, (T, K, *) whether it be a knife or some other thing. (T.)

ma*obuwHN * : see *abiyHN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Clean, or pure; not requiring to be slaughtered; [as though it had been already slaughtered;] an epithet applied in a trad. to everything in the sea. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence.

1 *abara * , (T, S, M, A, K,) aor.
*abura (T, S, M, K) and
*abira , (S, M, K,) inf. n. *aborN; (M, A, K;) and ↓ *b~r, (M, A,) inf. n. ta*obiyrN; (K;) He wrote (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, A, K) a writing, or a book; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, A;) like zabara: (A 'Obeyd, T, S:) or both signify, (M,) or the former signifies also, (K,) he pointed, or dotted, (M, K,) it: (M:) or (M, but in the K “ and, ”) he read it, or recited it, (IAar, T, M, K, *) with a low, or faint, voice; (M, K;) or easily; (M, A, each in relation to both verbs;) or quickly: (K:) all of the dial. of Hudheyl. (M.) You say, maA A^aHosana maA ya*oburu Al$~iEora How well he recites poetry, or the poetry, (K, TA,) without halting, or hesitating, therein! (TA.) And AlkitaAba ↓ maA A^aHosana maA yu*ab~iru How well he reads, or recites, the book, or the writing, without pausing therein! (A.) ― -b2- And *abara, (IAar, Th, T, M, K,) aor.
*abura , inf. n. *aborN and *ibaArapN, He knew, or learned, a tradition, well, soundly, or thoroughly; Eanohu from him: (IAar, Th, T:) or he understood it: (M, K:) and he understood, and knew, or learned, well, soundly, or thoroughly, a writing, or a book. (TA.) [See 2 in art. dbr, last sentence.] Accord. to some, *aborN signifies Understanding, and knowledge; (T;) knowledge of a thing, and understanding thereof; (K, * TA;) as also *ubuwrN [another inf. n.] : (TA:) or *ubuwrN signifies understanding with knowledge of a thing. (M.) It is said in a trad., of the people of Paradise, minohumo Al~a*iY laA *abora lahu, (T, TA,) i. e. Of them is he who has no understanding: (TA:) or, accord. to IAar, it means he who has no tongue with which to speak, by reason of his weakness. (T.) ― -b3- And *abara, aor.
*abira , (K,) inf. n. *ibaArapN, (so in some copies of the K,) or *abaArapN, (so in other copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) He looked, and did so well. (K, * TA.) -A2- *abira He was angry: (T, K:) so accord. to IAar: (T, TA:) [but SM says,] were it not set down on his authority, I should say that it is a mistranscription for *ay^ira. (TA.)
2 *ab~ara see 1, in two places.

*aborN *
A writing, (As, T, K,) in the dial. of Himyer, written upon Eusub [or leafless palmsticks, or the lower portions of palm-sticks, upon which no leaves have grown]: (K:) and i. q. SaHiyfapN [a piece of paper, or skin, upon which something is written; or a writing, or book]: (K:) pl. *ibaArN (As, T, K.) ― -b2- kitaAbN *aborN, (M, A,) or ↓ *abirN, like katifN, (K,) A writing, or book, easy to be read: (A, K:) or *aborN in this phrase is an inf. n. used in the place of the pass. part. n. ↓ ma*obuwrN [which signifies written; or pointed; or read, or recited, with a low, or faint, voice, or easily, &c.]. (M.) -A2- Also A mountain; in the Abyssinian language: so accord. to one reading, but accord. to another reading daborN, in a trad. cited in art. dbr. (TA.)
*abirN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

*aAbirN *
Knowing, or learning, well, soundly, or thoroughly, a matter of science or knowledge. (IAar, T, K.)

mi*obarN *
A reed-pen; like mizobarN. (TA.)
mu*ab~arN * A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with marks resembling writing, or otherwise; syn. munamonamN: (M, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.)
ma*obuwrN * : see *aborN.
mu*aAbirN * , occurring in a trad., is explained by IAth as meaning Going away; if it be not a mistranscription [for mudaAbirN, which seems to be probably the case]. (TA.)

1 *abala * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
*abula , inf. n. *abolN and *ubuwlN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and *abula; (S, Sgh, K;) said of a branch, (T,) or a herb, (S,) or a plant, (M, K,) or a thing, (Msb,) It withered; i. e., lost its moisture; (Msb;) or became thin, or unsubstantial, after being succulent; (M;) i. q. *awiYa. (S, K.) And in like manner it is said of a man: (M:) or *ubuwlN [in relation to a human being] signifies the drying up by reason of the loss of the beauty, or goodliness, of youth. (Ham p. 478.) And said of a horse, (S, K,) inf. n. *abolN, (TA,) He was, or became, lean, or light of flesh; slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (S, K.) You say also, *abala fuwhu, inf. n. *ubuwlN (T, TA) and *abolN, May his mouth, and his saliva, or spittle, dry up. (TA.) And maA lahu *abala ↓ *aboluhu, (M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, *abolapF,]) i. e. [What aileth him?] may his stock (A^aSoluhu) wither: meaning his body and his flesh: or, as some say, may his marriage, or coition, be ineffectual: (M, TA:) said in reviling: (TA:) as also dabala daboluhu. (TA in art. dbl.) One says also, in reviling, (TA,) ↓ *abalatohumo *ubayolapN [and dubayolapF, i. e. May a calamity, or mi(??)tune, befall them: or]
may they perish. (T, TA.) And *blt *bAy^lh [app. a mistranscription for ↓ *abalatohu *abaAy^ilu May calamities, or misfortunes, befall him]. (TA.) And ↓ *abalatohu *abuwlN (T, TA) and dabuwlN (T) May a calamity, or misfortune, befall him. (TA.) [See the latter part of the first paragraph of art. dbl.]

4 A*blhu *
It (the heat, S, TA) withered it; (namely, a herb [&c.], S;) caused it to wither, or lose its moisture; syn. A^a*owaAhu; (S, * K, TA;) rendered it *aAbil. (TA.) ― -b2- And tu*obilu Alr~iyHu biAlA^a$oyaA='i The wind twists, wreathes, or contorts, the things. (TA.)

5 t*b~l *
It became twisted, wreathed, or contorted. (TA.) One says, t*b~lt Aln~aAqapu bi*anabihaA The she-camel twisted, or contorted, her tail. (TA.) ― -b2- [It occurs in the K, in art. rA^d, said of a branch, or twig, app. as meaning It inclined limberly from side to side: but in the M and L, I there find in its place t*y~l.] ― -b3- t*b~lt She (a woman), being thin, or slender, walked in the manner of men: (M, K:) or she walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A2- Also He (a man) threw off [all] his garments, except one. (TA.)

*abolN * The prime, or first part, or the briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, (mayoEap,) of youth. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- maA lahu *abala *aboluhu: see 1. -A2- Accord. to As, one says ↓ *abolN *aAbilN and ↓ *aAbilN ↓ *ibolN, meaning [Deep] abasement or ignominy: and accord. to IAar, (T,) ↓ *abiylN ↓ *ibolN, meaning severe bereavement.
