(T, K.) ↓ *abolFA *abiylFA, (M, K,) or ↓ *abiylFA ↓ *ibolFA, (M,) is a form of imprecation [but app. not intended as such, lit. meaning May God send upon such a one deep abasement or ignominy, or severe bereavement]: (M, K:) and one says also ↓ *abolFA *aAbilFA, (K,) or ↓ *aAbilFA ↓ *ibolFA, (M,) meaning [likewise deep] abasement or ignominy, (TA,) or severe bereavement. (M, TA.) [See also dibolN and dabiylN.] -A3- Also [Turtle-shell, or tortoise-shell;] the back, (IAar, S, Msb,) or skin, (M, K,) [meaning shell,] of the sea-tortoise [or turtle], (IAar, S, M, Msb, K,) or of the land-tortoise, (M, K,) of which are made combs, (IAar, TA,) and, as some say, signet-rings &c., (TA,) or of which bracelets are made: (S:) or the bones of the back of a certain marine beast, of which are made, (M, K,) by women, (M,) bracelets (M, K) and combs; and the combing wherewith removes nits and the scurf of the hair: (K:) or horns of which are made [the bracelets, or anklets, called] masaka: (En-Nadr, TA:) or a certain thing [or substance] resembling ivory: (Msb:) Th cites a poet as using the phrase *aAtu Al*~abalaAt, forming the pl. of *abolN with A and t; but accord. to the citation of IAar, the word in this instance is Alr~abalaAt. (M.)
*ibolN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

*abolapN *
A piece of camels' or similar dung: (M, K:) because of its drying up. (M.) ― -b2- And A withering wind. (M, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
diyaArN maHatohaA baEodanaA kul~u *abolapK
[Abodes of which every withering wind had effaced the traces after they had been seen by us]. (M.)
*abolaA='u * A woman whose lip is dry. (O, K. *)
*ubaAlN * : see *ubaAlapN. -A2- Also Ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside; (K;) i. q. naq~aAbaAtN; and so dubaAlN, with d. (IAar, T.)

*abuwlN *
A calamity, or misfortune; (T, TA;) as also ↓ *abiylN and ↓ *iy^obilN: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) see 1. [See also *ubayolapN, in the first paragraph, and below.]
*abiylN * : see *abolN, in three places: ― -b2- and *abuwlN.

*ubaAlapN * (T, S, M, K) and ↓ *ub~aAlapN (T, K) A wick (T, S, M, K) that is lighted, (M,) or with which a lamp is lighted, or trimmed: (T:) or *ub~aAlapN signifies a wick of which a portion is burnt: (Ham p. 81:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] ↓ *ubaAlN and ↓ *ub~aAlN. (T, K, * TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAHuwlN.]
*ubayolapN * and [its pl.] *abaAy^ilu [or this is pl. of *abuwlN or *abiylN]: see 1.
*ub~aAlN * : see *ubaAlapN.
*ub~aAlapN * : see *ubaAlapN.

*aAbilN *
Withering, or withered; losing, or having lost, its moisture. (TA.) ― -b2- Spear-shafts (qanFA) slender, and of which the liyT [or exterior part] adheres [firmly]: (M, K: * [for laASiqN biAlil~yTi, in the K, I read laASiqu All~iyTi, as in the M:]) pl. *ib~alN and *ubulN. (M, K.) ― -b3- Lean, or emaciated: (Ham p. 788.) ― -b4- See also *abolN, in four places.
*iy^obilN * : see *abuwlN.

*aHolN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ *aHalN (Msb) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or concealment of enmity, and violent hatred, in the heart; or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it or exercise it; syn. HiqodN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and [simply] enmity: (S, K:) or blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide; or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood; syn. vaA^orN: or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: (K:) pl. (of the former) *uHuwlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and (of the latter, Msb) A^a*oHaAlN. (Mgh, Msb, K.) One says, Talaba bi*aHolihi, meaning bivaA^orihi [i. e. He sought to obtain his bloodrevenge, or retaliation]. (S, Msb.) And Einodahu *aHoliY [He owes me my blood-revenge], meaning he is the slayer of my relation. (A in art. vA^r.) [See also a verse of Lebeed cited as an ex. of the preposition bi.]
*aHalN * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 *axarahu * , aor.
*axara , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. ↓ *uxorN, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is *axorN; (Msb;) and ↓ Aid~axarahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S, Msb,) originally Ai*otaxarahu, the t being changed into d, and the * being incorporated into it; and some of the Arabs say ↓ Ai*~axarahu, which is allowable; but the former is more common; (Zj;) He hoarded it, treasured it, or laid it up for the future; reposited it, or stored it, in secret; (A;) or he prepared it, or provided it; (Msb;) for a time of need: (A, Msb:) or he chose it, or selected it, and (so in some copies of the K and in the TA, but in other copies of the K “ or ”) took it for himself, or prepared it. (K.) Some have made a distinction between *xr and dxr, saying that the former relates to the world to come, and the latter to the present world; but this is a manifest mistake. (MF and others.) ― -b2- *axara linafosihi HadiyvFA HasanFA (A) (tropical:) He reserved, or preserved, for himself [a good story, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b3- *axara mino Eadowihi (tropical:) [He (a horse) reserved somewhat of his run, i. e., power of running, or was sparing of it, for the time of need]. (M in art. Swn.) [See also mud~axirN, below.] ― -b4- fulaAnN maA nuSoHFA ↓ yad~axiru (tropical:) [Such a one does not treasure in his heart good advice]. (A, TA.)
8 Aid~axara * and Ai*~axara : see 1, in three places.
*uxorN * : see 1: ― -b2- and see the next paragraph, in two places.

*axiyrapN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ *axorN (A, Msb, * K) A thing hoarded, treasured, or laid up; reposited, or stored, in secret; (A;) or prepared, or provided; (Msb;) for a time of need: (A, Msb:) or taken for one's self, or prepared: (K:) pl. of the former, *axaAy^iru; (S, A, Msb;) and of the latter, A^a*oxaArN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- You say, Einoda A@ll~`hi ↓ jaEala maA lahu *uxorFA and *axiyrapF (tropical:) [He made his wealth to be a store in the hands of God, by applying it to pious uses]. (A.) ― -b3- And A^aEomaAlu Almuw^mini *axaAy^iru (tropical:) [The works of the believer are things laid up for the time of need, i. e. the day of resurrection]. (A.)
*aAxirN * (assumed tropical:) Fat; as an epithet. (AA, K.)

A_i*oxirN * [A kind of sweet rush; juncus odoratus; or schœnanthum;] a certain plant, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or herb, (K,) well known, (Msb,) in form resembling the kawolaAn [or papyrus-plant], (Mgh,) sweet-smelling, (K,) or of pungent odour; (Mgh, Msb;) which, when it dries, becomes white; (Msb;) used for roofing houses, over the wood, and for graves: (TA:) it has a root hidden in the ground, slender, pungent in odour; and is like the straight stalks of the kawolaAn [or papyrus-plant], save that it is wider, and smaller in the kuEuwb [which means either the joints or the internodal portions]; and it has a fruit resembling the brooms of reeds, but more slender, and smaller: it is ground, and is an ingredient in perfumes: it grows in rugged
and in smooth grounds; but seldom does more than one grow on the same spot: when it dries, it becomes white: (AHn:) 'Iyád asserts that its ' is a radical letter; but this is a mistake: (MF:) the n. un. is A_i*oxirapN; (S;) which is applied to a single plant, (AHn,) or to a single fascicle thereof. (Mgh.)

mi*oxarN * (tropical:) The [part of the intestines called] Eafaj: (TA:) [its pl.] ma*aAxiru is also explained as signifying the intestines; and bellies; (S, K;) and veins: (K:) or the lower part of the belly: (As, K:) or the parts of the inside of a beast in which he stores his fodder and water. (A.) You say fulaAnN malaA^a ma*aAxirahu (tropical:) Such a one filled the lower parts of his belly. (As.) And malaA^ati Ald~aAb~apu ma*aAxirahaA (tropical:) The beast satiated itself. (TA.) And tamal~aA^ato ma*aAxiruhu (tropical:) He became satiated. (A.) And malaA^a lanaA fiY ma*aAxirihi EadaAwapF (tropical:) [He filled his heart with enmity towards us]. (A.)

mud~axirN mdxr , or mu*~axirN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) (assumed tropical:) A horse that reserves his run; expl. by AlmuboqiY liHuDorihi: (AO, K, TA:) [Freytag's reading of mu*ax~arN for mud~axirN or mu*~axirN, and his proposed emendation, of AlmanoqiY~u for AlmuboqiY, both taken from the TK, but neither found by me in any copy of the K, are evidently wrong: see *axara mino Eadowihi, above:] such is the misowaAT, a horse “ that will not give what he has without the whip: the fem. is with p. (TA.)

1 *ar~a * , (T, S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
*aru3a , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. *ar~N, (S, M, K, &c.,) He sprinkled, or scattered, salt (T, * S, A, Msb, K) upon flesh-meat, and pepper upon a mess of crumbled bread with broth, (A,) and a medicament (S, A) into the eye, (A,) and grain (S, A, K) upon the ground, (A,) &c.; (T, Msb, K;) as also ↓ *aro*ara, inf. n. *aro*arapN: (K:) he took a thing with the ends of his fingers and sprinkled it upon a thing. (M.) You say, *ar~a Eayonahu, (TA,) and *ar~a Eayonahu biAl*~aruwri, aor.
*aru3a , (M, TA,) inf. n. *ar~N, (K, TA,) He put the medicament called *aruwr into his eye. (M, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He spread. (A, K.) You say, *ar~a A@ll~`hu EibaAdahu fiY AlA^aroDi (tropical:) God spread his servants, or mankind, upon the earth. (M, * A.) Whence the word *ur~iy~apN. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And *ar~ati AlA^aroDu Aln~abota The ground put forth the plant, or plants. (K.) -A2- *ar~a, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
*aru3a , [contr. to analogy,] (T, M,) inf. n. *uruwrN, (M,) It (a herb, or leguminous plant,) came up, or forth, (IAar, AZ, T, S, K,) from the ground: (AZ, S:) or it (a herb, or leguminous plant, and a horn,) began to come forth; put forth the smallest portion of itself. (A.) ― -b2- *ar~ati Al$~amosu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. *uruwrN, inf. n. *uruwrN, (S, M,) (tropical:) The sun rose; (S, M, K;) and appeared: (M:) or began to rise: $uruwquhaA is when its light first falls upon the earth and trees: (T, TA:) and *ar~a qaronu Al$~amos, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The upper limb of the sun rose: (Msb:) or began to rise. (A, TA.) -A3- *ar~a is also syn. with taxad~ada [app. as meaning His flesh became contracted, shrunk, or wrinkled]. (K.) -A4- Also, (T, K,) aor.
*ara3a , contr. to analogy, (K,) unless *ar~a be for *arira, (MF,) said of a man, The fore part of his head became white, or hoary. (T, K.)

3 *aAr~ato * , (aor. tu*aAr~u, S,) inf. n. mu*aAr~apN and *iraArN, She (a camel) became evil in her disposition. (Fr, S, K.) Hence the saying of Hoteiäh, satirizing Ez-Zibrikán, and praising the family of Shemmás Ibn-Láy,
wakunota ka*aAti Albaw~i *aArato biA^anofihaA
famino *aAka tabogiY buEodahu watuhaAjiruho
i. e. [And thou wast like her who has a stuffed skin of a young camel made for her and placed near her that she may incline to it and yield her milk,] that has inclined to the young one of another; [and on that account desires its distance from her, and severs herself from it:] in the S we find, for Albaw~i, AlbaEoli; and for buEodahu, gayorahu; but the former are the correct readings: *aArato is a contraction of *aAr~ato: or, accord. to some, it is for *aA='arato: see art. *A^r. (IB and TA.) ― -b2- One says also, fiY fulaAnK *iraArN, meaning (assumed tropical:) In such a one is aversion, arising from anger, like that of a she-camel: (AZ, S:) or anger and aversion (Th, M, K, TA) and disapprobation. (Th, TA)
R. Q. 1 *aro*ara * : see 1, first sentence.

*ar~N * The young ones [or grubs] of ants: (M, A, Msb, K:) accord. to Th, (M, TA,) one hundred of them weigh one barley-corn: (M, K:) or, accord. to En-Neysábooree, [who perhaps held *ar~N to signify ant's eggs,] seventy of them weigh a gnat's wing, and seventy gnat's wings weigh one grain: (MF:) or the smallest of ants: (S:) or small red ants: (TA:) or it signifies, (TA,) or signifies also, (A,) the motes that are seen in a ray of the sun that enters through an aperture: (A, * TA:) as though they were particles of a thing sprinkled: and in like manner *ar~aAtu Al*~ahabi [minute particles of gold]: (A:) the sing., (S,) or [rather] n. un., (Msb, K,) is *ar~apN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [of which the pl. is *ar~aAtN.] [See an ex., from the Kur x. 62, voce mivoqaAlN.] ― -b2- See also *ur~iy~apN.

*aruwrN *
A thing sprinkled: (M:) a dry medicament, (T, TA,) such as is sprinkled in the eye, (T, A, K,) and upon a wound, or sore: (T, TA:) or a kind of A_ivomid [q. v.]. [Har p. 86.) ― -b2- See also *ariyrapN.

*uraArapN *
What falls about, (M, A, K,) of perfume, when one sprinkles it, (A,) or of *aruwr, (K, TA,) or of what is sprinkled. (M, and so accord. to the CK.)

*ariyrapN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ *aruwrN (S, Msb, K) A kind of perfume, (Msb, K,) the particles of the qaSabu AlT~iybi [or calamus aromaticus, also called qaSabu Al*~ariyrapi, q. v., in art. qSb], (T, M, A, Msb,) which is brought from India, (A, Msb,) and resembles the reeds of which arrows are made: (T, A, Msb:) its internodal portions are filled with a white substance like spiders' webs; and when powdered, it is a perfume, inclining to yellowness and whiteness: (Sgh, Msb:) or, as some say, it is a mixed kind of perfume: (TA:) [but this, if correct, seems to be a second application:] pl. of the latter, A^a*ir~apN. (S, K.)

*ar~iY~N * a rel. n. from *ar~N, (T,) (tropical:) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword: (T, M, A, K:) likened to the track of young ants. (M, A.) It occurs in poetry, in which some read dur~iY~N [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A sword having much of such wavy marks, &c. (K.)

*ur~iy~apN * , (S, Msb, K,) the most chaste form, (Msb,) and *ir~iy~apN, (Msb, K,) and *ariy~apN, this last without a sheddeh to the r (Msb,) [respecting the derivation of which see art. *rA^,] (assumed tropical:) Children, or offspring, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) as also ↓ *ar~N, (Msb,) of a man, (S, K,) [and of genii: see art. *rA^,] male or female: (IAth:) little ones, or young ones. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Progenitors, or ancestors. (Msb, MF.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Women. (Mgh, K.) ― -b4- Used in a sing. as well as a pl. sense. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b5- Pl. *ur~iy~aAtN and (sometimes, Msb) *araAriY~u. (S, Msb, K.) [In the CK, the latter pl., with the article, is written Al*~araAriY, without a sheddeh to the Y. ― -b6- For examples, see art. *rA^.]

mi*ar~apN *
An instrument with which grain is scattered. (K.)
mu*aAr~N * A she-camel evil in disposition. (Fr, S, K.) [See 3.]

1 *araA^a * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
*araAa , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. *aro'N, (S, M, Msb,) He (God) created, syn. xalaqa, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) Alxaloqa [the creation; i. e. the things that are created]. (T, S, M, Msb.) walaqado *araA^onaA lijahan~ama kaviyrFA mina A@lojin~i wa A@loA_inosi, in the Kur [vii. 178], means [And verily] we have created [for Hell many of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind]. (T.) ― -b2- He multiplied, or made numerous. (K.) ya*oraw^ukumo fiyhi, in the Kur [xlii. 9], means He multiplieth you thereby; i. e., by making of you, and of the cattle, pairs, males and females: so says Zj; and Fr says the like; and this is a correct explanation. (T.) ― -b3- Also, (S, M, K,) and so *araA, (TA,) He sowed land: (S, M, K, TA:) but the latter verb is said to be the more chaste. (MF.) -A2- *araA^a fuwhu His teeth fell out from his mouth; (K, TA;) as also *araA and *araY, without ': (TA:) but the most chaste is said to be without ': *araA^a, with ', is said to be of weak authority, or a mispronunciation. (MF.) ― -b2- *ariy^a, (M, K,) or *ariy^a $aEarahu, (S,) aor.
*araAa , (K,) inf. n. *araA^N; (S, * M, O;) and *araA^a, (S, K,) aor.
*araAa ; (K;) and *aruw^a, aor.
*aruAa ; (Ktr, TA;) His hair became white, or hoary, in the fore part of his
head: (S:) or he had whiteness intermixed with blackness in the hair of his head: (M:) or his hair became white, or hoary: (K:) or he began to become white, or hoary, (M, K,) in the fore part of his head, (K,) or in the upper part of each side of the head. (A, TA.) The epithet is ↓ A^a*oraA^u; fem. *aroA='N. (S, M, K. [In some copies of the K, *aroA^aY is erroneously put for *aroA='u.])

4 A*rA^hu *
He angered him; provoked him to anger. (T, M, K.) ― -b2- A*rA^hu biSaAHibihi He incited him against his companion. (AZ, T.) And A*rA^hu biAl$~aYo'i He incited him, or urged him, to do, or attempt, the thing. (M, K.) And A*rA^hu A_ilaYka*aA He constrained him, or compelled him, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing. (K, * TA.) A 'Obeyd mentions A^a*oraY, without '; but 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh asserts that this is incorrect. (M.) ― -b3- A*rA^ Ald~amoEa He, or it, made tears to flow. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And A*rA^h He frightened him. (M, K.) -A2- A^a*oraA^ato She (a camel) excerned (A^anozalato) the milk (M, K, TA) from [app. a mistake for into] her udder: a dial. var. of A^adoraA^ato [q. v.]. (TA.) The epithet applied to the she-camel so doing is ↓ mu*oriy^N. (M, K.)

*aro'N * The act of creating; inf. n. of *araA^a. (S, M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of that verb; and alike as sing. and pl. because originally an inf. n.] *aro'u Aln~aAri, (S, K, TA,) [for *aro'N liln~aAri,] related as occurring in a trad. (S, TA) of 'Omar, (TA,) means Created [i. e. destined] for the fire [of Hell]: (S, K, TA:) but as some relate it, the phrase is *arowu Aln~aAri, meaning [either “ the children of the fire, ” agreeably with what next follows, or] “ to be scattered in the fire. ” (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also The number of [ones] offspring: one says, A^anomaYA@ll~`hu *aroA^aka May God increase [the number of] thine offspring; as also *arowaka. (T.) -A2- Somewhat; (M, K;) as in the saying, balaganiY *aro'N mino xabarK [Somewhat of news, or information, reached me, or came to my knowledge]: (K, TA:) or *aro'N mino xayorK [somewhat of good]: (so in some copies of the K and M:) thus *r' is written by IAth: in some copies of the K, *uro'N, with damm: (TA:) or *aro'N here means a little; and *arowN is a dial. var. thereof. (M in art. *rw.) Also A little of what is said. (TA.) -A3- A thing intervening as a separation or an obstacle: so in the saying, maA bayonanaA wa bayonahu *aro'N [There is not anything intervening &c. between us and him, or it]. (K, * TA.)
*araA^N * : see what next follows.

*uroA^apN * (S, M, K) and ↓ *araA^N, (S,) the latter an inf. n. (M, [see 1,]) the former a simple subst., (S,) Whiteness, or hoariness, in the fore part of the head: (S:) or whiteness intermixed with blackness in the hair of the head: (M:) or whiteness, or hoariness, of the hair: (K:) or the beginning of whiteness or hoariness (M, K) in the fore part of the head, (K,) or in the upper part of each side of the head. (A, TA.)

*aroA=niY~N * and *araA=niY~N Intensely white salt: (S, M, K:) derived from *uroA^apN: one should not say A^ano*araAniY~N; (S, K;) for this is a vulgarism: some pronounce it with the unpointed d. (TA.)

*ariYo'N *
Sown seed. (S, M, K.)

*ur~iy~apN * (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and *ir~iy~apN (M, K) and *ar~iy~apN, (K,) [or *ariy~apN, without a sheddeh to the r, accord. to the Msb in art. *r,] always pronounced by the Arabs without ': (S:) accord. to some, (TA,) from Al*~aro'u; (M, TA;) so says Th; (M;) the measure of the first being fuE~uwlapN or fuE~iylapN; [so that it is originally *ur~uw'apN or *ur~iyoy^apN;] (TA;) but the ' is suppressed because of frequency of usage: (M:) accord. to others, from Al*~ar~u, signifying “ the act of scattering; ” because God scattered the *r~y~p upon the earth; and the measure is fuEoliy~apN or fuE~uwlapN, [if the latter,] the word being originally *ur~uwrapN, the last r being changed into Y, in a manner similar to the case of taqaD~ati AlEuqaAbi [in which taqaD~aDat becomes taqaD~ayat and then taqaD~at; so that *ur~uwrapN becomes *ur~uwyapN and then *ur~iy~apN]: (TA:) Children, or offspring, (T, S, Mgh, K,) of a man, and used as a sing. also, (Mgh,) or of men and of jinn, or genii: (S, K:) pl. [*ur~iy~aAtN (see art. *r) and sometimes] *araAriY~u. (S.) Hence, habo liY mino ladunoka *ur~iy~apF Tay~ibapF [in the Kur iii. 33, meaning Give me, from Thee, a good offspring]. (Mgh.) And in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, fajaEalaniY fiY Al*~ur~iy~api means And he put me among the little ones, or young ones. (Mgh.) ― -b2- It is also applied to signify Progenitors: as in the saying, in the Kur [xxxvi. 41], HamalonaA *ur~iy~atahumo fiY A@lofuloki Alma$oHuwni [We carried their progenitors in the laden ark]. (T.) ― -b3- And it is used also to signify Women; [because they are the sources of offspring;] (T, Mgh, TA;) like as samaA='N is used to signify “ rain: ” (TA:) as in the saying of 'Omar, Huj~uwA biAl*~ur~iy~api [Perform ye the pilgrimage with the women]. (T, Mgh, TA. [See his saying in full, voce riboqN.])
Al*~aAriy^u * an epithet applied to God, The Creator. (T.)

A^a*oraA^u * ; fem. *aroA='u: see 1, last sentence. Applied to a ram, Having whiteness in the head; (M, K;) and so the fem. applied to a ewe: (M:) or having the ears variegated, or speckled, with black and white, and the rest black: (K:) or it has this latter meaning when applied to a horse, and to a kid; and so the fem. applied to a female kid, (S, O,) or to a she-goat: (M:) and is not applied to the sheep-kind. (S, O.)
mu*oriy^N * : see 4, last sentence.

1 *ariba * , aor.
*araba , inf. n. *arabN (M, A, Msb, K) and *araAbapN, (S, * M, A, K,) said of a sword, and a spear-head, (A,) or of a thing (M, Msb) of any kind, (M,) It was, or became, sharp, (S, * M, A, Msb, K,) and cutting, or penetrating: (Msb:) or, said of a sword, and of a spear-head, it signifies [or signifies also] it was steeped in, or imbued with, poison. (A.) ― -b2- *ariba lisaAnuhu, aor. as above, [and so the inf. n.], His tongue was, or became, sharp [properly speaking, i. e. sharp in the extremity: (see *aribN:) and also tropically, i. e., in a good sense, as meaning (assumed tropical:) chaste, or eloquent; without barbarousness, or vitiousness, or impediment: and in a bad sense, as meaning (assumed tropical:) profuse of speech; or clamorous: bad, or corrupt: foul, unseemly, or obscene]: he cared not what he said. (TA.) [For] *arabN (S, M, A, TA) and *araAbapN (S, A, TA) signify Sharpness of the tongue [properly speaking, or, as is said in the A, tropically]: (S, M, A, TA:) and the former, (TA,) or the latter, (Msb,) [or each.] metaphorically, (TA,) (tropical:) chasteness, or eloquence, thereof; (Msb, TA;) without barbarousness, or vitiousness, or impediment; a quality approved: and (tropical:) profuseness, or clamorousness, thereof; a quality disapproved: (TA:) and the former, [or each,] (assumed tropical:) badness, or corruptness, thereof: (M, K:) and the former, (AZ, S, M, K,) or the latter, (Msb,) or each, (A,) (tropical:) foulness, or obscenity, thereof: (AZ, S, M, A, Msb, K:) and the pl. of the former [used as a simple subst.] is A^a*oraAbN. (AZ, IAar, S, M, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Hadramee Ibn-'Ámir El-Asadee, (TA,)
walaqado Tawayotukumu EalaY bulalaAtikumo
wa Earafotu maA fiykumo mina AlA^a*oraAbi
(tropical:) [And I have borne with you not withstanding your vices and evil actions, and have known what is in you of foul, or obscene, qualities of the tongue]; (AZ, S:) [or] ElY bulalaAtikumo (IAar, M, TA) means notwithstanding what is in you of annoyance and enmity: (TA:) but accord. to Th, he said, AlA^aEoyaAbi, pl. of EayobN. (M, TA.) [Accord. to Z,] fiyhimo A^a*oraAbN means (tropical:) In them are [qualities that are] causes of evil, corruption, wrong, injury, or the like. (A.) ― -b3- *aribato maEidatuhu, (T, S, M, A, Msb,) aor.
*araba , (S, Msb,) inf. n. *arabN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and *araAbapN and *uruwbapN, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) His stomach was, or became, sharp, or keen, by reason of hunger: (M; but only the first of the inf. ns. of the verb in this sense, and not the verb itself, is there mentioned:) [or] (assumed tropical:) his stomach was, or became, in a good, or right, state: (K; but only the inf. ns. of the verb in this sense, and in the next, and not the verb itself, is there mentioned:) and also, (M, K,) (tropical:) his stomach was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (M, K.) ― -b4- *ariba AljuroHu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. *arabN, (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The wound admitted not of cure: (S, A:) or was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state, and wide, (M, K,) and admitted not of cure: (M:) or flowed with Sadiyd [i. e. ichor tinged with blood]. (M, K.) ― -b5- *ariba A^anofuhu, inf. n. *araAbapN, (assumed tropical:) His nose dripped; let fall drops. (M.) -A2- *araba: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] *arabotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I excited, or provoked, [or exasperated,]
such a one. (A.) And fulaAnN yaDoribu bayonanaA waya*oribu (tropical:) [app. Such a one makes a separation between us, (see Daraba,) and excites discord: ya*oribu is perhaps here used for ya*orubu, to assimilate it to yaDoribu]. (A.)

2 *r~b * , (M, K,) inf. n. ta*oriybN, (S,) He sharpened (M, S, K) an iron instrument [such as a sword and a spear-head &c.]; (M;) as also ↓ *araba, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
*aruba , (M, L, Msb, TA,) accord. to the K
*araba , but this is without any other authority, and contr. to analogy, as neither its third nor its second letter is a faucial, (TA,) inf. n. *arobN; (M, Msb, TA;) and ↓ A*rb. (KL.) Also, inf. n. as above, He poisoned a sword, i. e. steeped it in poison, and, when it was well steeped, took it forth and sharpened it; and ↓ *araba, likewise, is allowable. (T, TA.) -A2- The inf. n. also signifies A woman's holding her infant in order that it may satisfy its want [by evacuation, as the words in the explanation (Hat~aY yaqoDiYa HaAjatahu) commonly mean, not, as Freytag supposes, by sucking]. (T, K.)

4 A*rb * : see 2. -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) He became chaste in speech, after having been barbarous therein. (IAar, T in art. rb*, and TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) His life became bad, or corrupt. (IAar, T in art. rbd, and TA.)

*arobN * , (so in the CK and in a MS copy of the K,) or ↓ *aribN, (so accord. to the TA, [which is followed by the TK, and so in my MS copy of the K, but altered from *arobN, which I incline to think the right reading,]) A shoemaker's A_izomiyl [a word well known as signifying his knife, with which he cuts the leather, but here explained in the TA as signifying his A_i$ofaY with which he sews]. (K.)
*urobN * an irreg. pl. of *aribN, q. v.

*irobN *
i. q. gud~apN [i. e. A ganglion; &c.]: (AZ, T:) or so ↓ *irobapN: and both signify a certain thing that is sometimes in the neck of a human being or of a beast, like a pebble: or the former word signifies a certain disease in the liver, (K, TA,) slow of cure: (TA:) the pl. of the former is *irabN, (K,) or *irabapN, (AZ, T,) or this latter is pl. of *irobapN. (TA.)

*arabN * an inf. n. of *ariba [q. v. passim]. (T, S, M, &c.) ― -b2- See also *arabay~aA: and see there a pl. or a dual form, in three places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) An incurable disease: (M, K:) [in the present day applied to diarrhœa; and this is app. meant by what follows:] a disease that attacks the stomach, in consequence of which it does not digest the food; becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state, and not retaining the food. (L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Rust. (S, K.)

*aribN *
Sharp; (T, S, M, K;) applied to anything, (S, M,) as, for instance, a sword, (S,) or a spearhead; and so ↓ ma*oruwbN: (T:) or this latter, applied to a spear-head [&c.], signifies sharpened; (S;) as also ↓ mu*ar~abN: (T, S:) or *aribN (A, TA) and ↓ mu*ar~abN (M, K) and ↓ ma*oruwbN, (T, TA,) applied to a sword (T, M, A, K) and a spearhead, (A, TA,) signify [or signify also] poisoned; (A, K;) i. e. steeped in, or imbued with, poison, (T, M, A, TA,) and then sharpened. (T, M, TA.) And sum~N *aribN means Sharp poison. (M, A.) A rájiz says, (referring to cattle, TA,)
dab~ato EalayohaA *aribaAtu AlA^anobaAro
meaning [Upon which have crept insects resembling ticks, that produce swellings where they creep,] sharp in stinging. (S.) ― -b2- lisaAnN *aribN [properly signifies] A tongue sharp in the extremity. (M, TA.) Tropically, (A,) (tropical:) A sharp tongue; (S, A, TA;) as also ↓ ma*oruwbN: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) a chaste, or an eloquent, tongue: (Msb:) [and (assumed tropical:) a profuse, or clamorous, tongue: (see *ariba:)] and (assumed tropical:) a foul, or an obscene, tongue. (Msb.) And *aribu All~isaAni (assumed tropical:) Sharp in tongue: (TA:) [(assumed tropical:) profuse, or clamorous, therein; long-tongued: (see *ariba:)] (assumed tropical:) bad, or corrupt, in tongue: (Abu-l-'Abbás [Th], TA:) (assumed tropical:) wont to revile; (T;) foul, or obscene, in tongue; (ISh, T, TA;) who cares not what he says. (ISh, TA.) And *aribN, alone, (assumed tropical:) Sharptongued: and (tropical:) long-tongued, or clamorous; or foul, or obscene, in tongue: (K, * TA:) and so *aribapN, applied to a woman; (AZ, T, S, A, Msb; *) and ↓ *irobapN: (AZ, T, S, M, K:) this last [is app. a contraction of *aribapN, and used by poetic license: it] is applied by a rájiz to his wife, (T, S, *) as meaning (tropical:) bad, or corrupt, and unfaithful to her husband in respect of her faroj; or, accord. to Sh, it means long-tongued; and foul, or obscene, in speech: (T:) and ↓ ma*oruwbN likewise, accord. to Sh, means foul, or obscene, in speech: (TA:) the pl. of *aribN is ↓ *urobN, (K,) which is irreg.; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) sharp; (M, K;) and (assumed tropical:) sharp in tongue [&c.]: (K:) and the pl. of ↓ *irobapN is *irabN. (T, S, M.) ― -b3- maEidapN *aribapN [(assumed tropical:) A stomach sharp, or keen, by reason of hunger: or (assumed tropical:) in a good, or right, state: (see *aribato maEidatuhu:) and also, the contr., i. e.] (tropical:) a stomach in a bad, or corrupt, state. (M, TA.) ― -b4- jurHN *aribN (tropical:) A wound in a bad, or corrupt, state, and wide, and not admitting of cure: or flowing with Sadiyd [i. e. ichor tinged with blood]. (M, TA.) ― -b5- *aribu Alxuluqi (tropical:) A man of a bad, or corrupt, natural disposition. (A, TA.) -A2- See also *arobN.
*irobapN * : see *irobN: ― -b2- and see also *aribN, in two places.
Al*~aribap * : see what next follows.
*arabaY * : see what next follows.
*arabiY~N * : see what next follows.
*arabay~apN * : see what next follows.

*arabay~aA * (assumed tropical:) A vice, fault, defect, or the like; as also ↓ *arabaY. (K.) ― -b2- And A calamity, or misfortune; (S, M, K;) from *ariba AljuroHu meaning “ the wound admitted not of cure; ” (S;) as also ↓ *arab~aY, (K, TA,) or ↓ *arabiY~N, (so accord. to the CK,) and ↓ *arabay~apN [or *arabiy~apN?]. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says, maAniY biAl*~arabay~aA meaning (assumed tropical:) [He smote me, or afflicted me,,] with calamity, or misfortune: or with evil, or mischief; and discord, or dissension; (T;) as also ↓ biAl*~arabayna [in the form of a pl. applied to rational beings, as though denoting personifications], (K, accord. to the TA,) or ↓ biAl*~~arabayoni [in the dual form]; (so in the CK and in my MS copy of the K;) which likewise means with calamity, or misfortune. (TA.) And laqiytu minohu Al*~arabay~aA and ↓ Al*~aribapa and ↓ Al*rbayn, [thus this last is written in the TT as from the M,] meaning (assumed tropical:) [I experienced from him, or it,] calamity, or misfortune. (M.) And ↓ A^uloqiYa bayonahumo Al*~araba (assumed tropical:) Evil, or mischief, and discord, or dissension, were cast among them, or between them. (T.)
*arab~aY * : see the next preceding paragraph.

*uraAbN *
Poison. (Kr, M, A, K.)

*iroyabN *
A yellow flower: (K:) or yellow, applied to a flower and to other things. (M.)

SuwfN A^a*orabiY~N *
Wool of Ádharbeeján or Adharbeeján or Adhrabeeján; for there are different opinions respecting the orthography of this name: (TA:) A^a*orabiY~N is a rel. n. from A*rbyjAn: (K, TA:) contr. to rule; for by rule it should be A^a*ariY~N or A^a*oriY~N. (IAth, TA.)
mi*orabN * The tongue: (K:) so called because of its sharpness. (TA.)
mu*ar~abN * : see *aribN, in two places.
ma*oruwbN * : see *aribN, in four places.
1 *araHa AlT~aEaAma * : see 2. -A2- *araHa Al$~aYo'a fiY Alr~iyHi He winnowed the thing; syn. *ar~aAhu. (Kr, K.)

2 *r~H AlT~aEaAma * , (S, K,) inf. n. ta*oriyHN; (S;) and ↓ *araHahu, aor.
*ariHa ; (K;) He put *araAriyH [or cantharides] into the food. (S, K.) ― -b2- *r~Hh fiY AlmaA='i, inf. n. as above, He put a small quantity of it, namely, saffron, &c., into the water. (S.) ― -b3- And *r~H, [or *r~H labanahu, (see *araAHN, below,)] He poured water into his milk, in order that it might become much in quantity. (TA.) ― -b4- ta*oriyHN also signifies The smearing with clay a new [water-vessel of skin such as is called] A_idaAwaAp, in order that its odour may become good. (AA, K. *)

*araHN *
A certain tree, of which camels' saddles are made. (K, TA.) [Forskål mentions, in his “ Flora Aeg. Ar., ” p. xcvi. a fabrile wood of an uncertain kind, of which spears, or lances, are made, called drH (thus with the unpointed d), brought from the region of San'à.]
*uraHN * : see *ur~aAHN.

*araAHN * , applied to milk, i. q. SayaAHN, (AA, K,) i. e. Mixed with water; as also ↓ mu*ar~aHN: (TA:) or
the latter, milk, and honey, mixed with a larger quantity of water. (K.)
*uraAHN * and A^ibuw *uraAHK: see *ur~aAHN.
*aruwHN * : see *ur~aAHN.
*ariyHN * [a coll. gen. n.] i. q. hiDaAbN [i. e. Hills; or mountains spreading over the surface of the ground; &c.]: n. un. with p. (S, K.)
*ariyHapN * : see *ur~aAHN.

A^aHomaru *ariyHiY~N *
Intensely red; (S, A;) i. e. (TA) i. q. A^urojuwaAnN. (K, TA.) -A2- A_ibilN *ariyHiy~aAtN A certain race of camels, so called in relation to a stallion named *ariyHN. (S, K. *)
*ur~aHN * : see what next follows.
*ar~aAHN * : see what next follows.

*ur~aAHN * and ↓ *ur~uwHN, (S, A, K,) the latter (respecting which see below) anomalous in form, (TA,) and ↓ *ar~uwHN, (K,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and ↓ *ir~ayHN (K) and ↓ *ar~aAHN (Fr) and ↓ *aruwHN and ↓ *uraAHN (K) and ↓ *uraHN (IO) and ↓ *ur~aHN (K) and ↓ *ur~uwHapN and ↓ *ir~ayHapN (ISd) and ↓ *ariyHapN and ↓ *uronuwHN (K) and ↓ *aronuwHN, accord. to some, (TA,) and ↓ *uronuwHapN (ISd) and ↓ *uraHoraHN and ↓ *uruHoruHN, and ↓ the second letter [in the latter of these two forms, or in both,] is sometimes doubled by teshdeed, (K,) and sometimes the second r is meksoorah, and the termination p is also added thereto, (ISd,) and ↓ A^abuw *rHrHK and ↓ Abw *aroyaAHK and ↓ Abw *uraAHK, and ↓ Abw *rHrHpa imperfectly decl., (Kr,) [The cantharis, or Spanish fly;] a kind of insect of a red colour, (S, A, K,) spotted, or speckled, with black, which flies, (S, K,) and is of a poisonous nature; (S, K;) a kind of insect larger than the common fly, variegated with red and black and yellow, having a pair of wings with which it flies, and of a deadly poisonous nature: when they desire to allay the heat of its poison, they mix it with lentils, and so mixed it becomes a remedy for him who has been bitten by a mad dog: (IO:) Ibn-Ed-Dahhán the Lexicologist says that the *r~wH is a kind of fly variegated with yellow and white; and what is called faroxapu Ald~ayolami: by certain of the acute physicians it is described as HayawaAnN duwdiY~N, app. meaning a worm-like animal, of the size of the finger, and of a conical shape, the head of which is at the thickest part of it: and IDrst says that it is a flying insect, resembling the zunobuwr [or hornet], and of a deadly poisonous nature. (TA.) It is observed in the S, with reference to *ur~uwHN, that, in the opinion of Sb, layosa fiY AlkalaAmi fuE~awolN biwaAHidapN; meaning, there is not in the language a subst. (as distinguished from an epithet) of the measure fuE~awolN; (marg. note in a copy of the S;) or his meaning is, [there is not a word of this measure] with damm alone; (MF;) or with a single dammeh, that is, to the f; but with dammeh to the f and to the E: (IB:) and it is added in the S, that he (Sb) used to say sab~uwHN and qad~uwsN: Sb, however, also mentions the forms sub~uwHN and qud~uwsN. (MF.) The pl. is *araAyiHu: (S, K:) in the L, *ur~aAHN is also said to be a pl.: and Kr mentions *araAriHu; but AHát says that this last is only used in poetry. (TA.) Sb says that the sing. of *araAriyHu is *uraHoraHN, (or, in other words, that one of the [insects called] *rAryH is [called] *rHrH,) which is of the measure fuEaloEalN, and of which the dim. is ↓ *urayoriHN, formed by throwing out the first *uryoriHN; [not H, as it would be by rule, making it of the measure *urayoHirN, and its curtailed original fuEayoliEN;] for there is not in the language a word of the measure fElE, except fElE, (S,) which is the proper name of a man. (MF.) AHát cites a verse in which HadoradN occurs as pl. of *araAniHu; but the correct reading is *rnwH. (MF.)
*araAriHu * and *ar~uwHN and *ur~uwHN: see *ur~aAHN.
*ir~iyHN * and *ir~iyHapN: see *ur~aAHN.
*uronuwHN * and *aronuwHN and *uronuwHapN: see *ur~aAHN.
A^abuw *aroyaAHK * : see *ur~aAHN.
*uraHoraHN * and *uruHoruHN and *r~HrH and A^abuw *rHrHK and A^abuw *rHrHpa: see *ur~aAHN.
*urayoriHN * dim. of *uraHoraHN: see *ur~aAHN.
mu*~araHN * : see *araAHN.

TaEaAmN ma*oruwHN *
Food into which cantharides (*araAriyH) have been put. (TA.)

1 *aroEN * , [inf. n. of *araEa,] in its primary acceptation, signifies The stretching forth, or extending, the arm, or fore leg: (S, TA:) [or rather, when said of a man, the fore arm; and of a beast, the arm; though the whole arm of a man is generally stretched forth with his fore arm, and the whole fore leg of a beast with his arm: and ↓ ta*oriyEN and ↓ A_i*oraAEN and ↓ ta*ar~uEN signify the same, as will be shown by explanations of their verbs.] You say, *araEa AlbaEiyru yadahu The camel stretched forth, or extended, his fore leg in going: and AlbaEiyru ↓ t*r~E The camel stretched forth, or extended, his arm (*iraAEahu) in his going. (TA.) ― -b2- *araEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
*araEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. *aroEN, (S, Msb,) He measured it with the *iraAEN [or cubit]; (Msb, K;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, Msb, K,) &c.: (S:) and *araEahu bi*iraAEihi he measured it with his *rAE. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b3- You say of a she-camel, ta*oraEu AlfalaApa (assumed tropical:) She goes quickly, or swiftly, over the desert, as though measuring it; as also ↓ tu*aAriEuhaA: and buEodaAlT~ariyqi ↓ tu*aAriEu (tropical:) She stretches forth her fore legs and so traverses the distance of the way. (TA.) ― -b4- *araEa fulaAnFA He strangled, or throttled, such a one from behind him with the fore arm; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also ↓ *r~Ehu: (K:) or the latter, inf. n. ta*oriyEN, signifies, simply, he strangled, or throttled, him; (S, L;) but more properly, he put his neck between his fore arm and neck and upper arm, and so strangled, or throttled, him; and lahu ↓ *r~E, also, has both of these significations. (L.) ― -b5- *araEa AlbaEiyra, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He trod upon the arm (*rAE) of the camel, [while the latter was lying with his breast upon the ground and his fore legs folded,] in order that a person might mount him. (K.) -A2- *araEahu AlqaYo'u, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Mgh,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) Vomit overcame him, and came forth to his mouth before he was aware, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, * TA,) and issued from him: (Mgh:) or vomiting came upon him without his intending it. (Mgh.) -A3- *araEa Einodahu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. as above, (Ibn-'Abbád,) (tropical:) He made intercession with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [Said in the TA to be tropical; I suppose because the stretching forth the arm is a common action of a person interceding.] You say, *araEotu lifulaAnK Einoda AlA^amiyri (tropical:) I made intercession for such a one with the prince. (Z, TA.) And *ariEa A_ilayohi, like fariHa, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. *araEN, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He made intercession to him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) In the O, *ariEa bihi (assumed tropical:) He made intercession [by him]. (TA.) -A4- *ariEa, aor.
*araEa , He drank from a skin (ziq~) such as is called *aAriEN. (K.) -A5- *ariEato rijolaAhu His legs became tired, or fatigued. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) -A6- *araAEapN [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is *aruEa,] The being wide in step, (S, TA,) and light, or active, in pace, or going. (TA.)

2 *r~E * , (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. ta*oriyEN: (S:) see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He spread himself out widely, (El-Moheet, L, K,) and stretched forth his fore arms, (El-Moheet, L,) in swimming: (El-Moheet, L, K:) said of a man. (El-Moheet, L.) ― -b3- He (a man) raised his fore arms; and particularly, in announcing good tidings or in warning: (TA:) or he (an announcer of good tidings) made a sign with his arm, or hand. (S, K.) ― -b4- *r~E fiY Alma$oYi He moved about his fore arms in walking, or going along. (S, K.) And *r~E fY Als~aEoYi, (L, TA,) in the O and Moheet and K, erroneously, fYAls~aqoYi, (TA,) He helped himself with his arms, and moved them about, (O, El-Moheet, L, K,) in walking, or walking quickly, or running. (L.) ― -b5- *r~E liY $ayoy^FA mino xabarihi (tropical:) He acquainted me with somewhat of his tidings, or case; (K, TA;) [as though he stretched forth his arm with his information;] said by one who has asked another respecting his case. (TA.) ― -b6- [And hence, app.,] *r~E bika*aA (assumed tropical:) He acknowledged, or confessed, such a thing. (K, TA.) ― -b7- *r~E fulaAnFA and *r~E lahu: see 1. ― -b8- [Hence, perhaps,] *r~Ehu, inf. n. as above. (assumed tropical:) He killed him; or slew him. (TA.) ― -b9- *r~E AlbaEiyra, and *r~E lahu, He bound both of the arms of the camel [to the shanks]: (K:) and the latter, he
bound the camel with the redundant part of his nose-rein upon his [the camel's] arm. (K, TA.) [See also ta*oriyEN below.] ― -b10- ta*oriyEN also signifies The tinging a captive's fore arm with crocus, or with xaluwq, as a sign of slaughter; which was done in the time before Mohammad. (Meyd, cited by Freytag.) ― -b11- [See also the act. and pass. part. ns., below.]

3 mu*aAraEapN * signifies The selling by measure with the cubit; not by number, and without knowing the measure. (K.) [In the CK, wAljuzAfu is put by mistake for wAljuzAfi.] You say, biEotuhu Alv~awoba mu*aAraEapN I sold to him the garment, or piece of cloth, by measure with the cubit. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- *araAEotuhu, (TA,) inf. n. mu*aAraEapN, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) I mixed with him in familiar, or social, intercourse; or became intimate with him: or I became copartner with him; or shared with him: syn. xaAlaTotuhu. (K * TA.)

4 A*rE * , (K,) inf. n. A_i*oraAEN: (S:) see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- (tropical:) He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits, in speech, or talk; (S, K, TA;) he talked much; (S, TA;) as also ↓ t*r~E: (S, Msb, * K, TA:) J says, [in the S,] I am of opinion that it has originated from the stretching forth of the fore arm; for he who talks much sometimes does that; and ISd says the like. (TA.) ― -b3- A^a*oraEa *iraAEayohi mino taHoti Aljub~api and ↓ Ai*~araEahumaA, He put forth, (K, TA,) and extended, (TA,) his fore arms from beneath the jubbeh: (K, TA:) or A^a*oraEa *iraAEayohi, and ↓ Aid~araEahumaA, [the latter with the d unpointed,] he drew forth his fore arms from the sleeves of a narrow-sleeved jubbeh: (Mgh:) the latter verb being of the measure AifotaEala; (Mgh, K;) like Ai*~akara, (TA,) or Aid~akara, (Mgh,) from Al*~ikoru: (Mgh, TA:) the former accord. to one relation, the latter accord. to another, occurring in a trad. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- A*rE also signifies He seized with the fore arm. (K.) ― -b5- maA A^a*oraEahaA [How long, or large, is she in the fore arm!] is [from Al*~iraAEu, being] of the same [anomalous] class as A^aHonaku Al$~aAtayoni [from AlHanaku]. (TA.) -A2- A*rE qayoy^ahu He (a man) emitted, or ejected, his vomit. (TA.)

5 ta*ar~aEa see 1; first and second sentences: ― -b2- and see also 4. ― -b3- ta*ar~uEN also signifies The measuring a thing with the fore arm. (S, K.) [See also 1.] A poet says, (S,) namely Keys Ibn-El-Khateem El-Ansáree, (TA,)
taraY qiSada Almur~aAni tuloqaY kaA^an~ahaA
ta*ar~uEu xiroSaAnK biA^ayodiYAl$~awaATibi
[Thou seest the fragments of the hard and pliant spears thrown as though they were what is seen in the measuring, with the fore arm, of rods of palm-sticks in the hands of the females who pare them]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to As, ta*ar~aEa fulaAnN Aljariyda signifies Such a one put the palm-sticks upon his fore arm, and pared them: and xiroSaAnN means, originally, rods of palm-sticks: and $awaATibu is pl. of $aATibapN; meaning a woman who peels the Easiyb, and then throws it to the munaq~iyap, who removes all that is upon it with her knife until she has left it slender, when she throws it back to the $ATbp. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, The splitting (ta$aq~uq [which is intrans., but I think it is a mistake for ta$oqiyq, which is trans.,]) of a thing into several oblong pieces of the measure of the cubit in length. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- ta*ar~aEati AlmaroA^apu The woman split palm-leaves to make of them a mat. (IDrd, K.) Thus some explain the saying of Ibn-El-Khateem, quoted above. (TA.) ― -b6- ta*ar~aEati AlA_ibilu AlkaraEa The camels came to drink of the rain-water and waded in it with their arms. (K.) -A2- t*r~E bi*ariyEapK (tropical:) He obtained, or sought to obtain, access, or intimacy; or he ingratiated himself, or sought to ingratiate himself; by a means of doing so. (S, K, TA.) You say, also, t*r~E A_ilayohi (tropical:) He obtained, or sought to obtain, access to him; &c. (TA.)
8 Ai*~araEa * or A_id~araEa: see 4.

10 Ast*rE bihi *
He concealed, or protected, himself by it, (namely a thing, TA,) and made it a *ariyEap [q. v.] for him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

*aroEN * , in its primary acceptation, has the signification explained in the first sentence of this article. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, it is used in the sense of] (tropical:) Power, or ability; as also ↓ *iraAEN; (TA;) or a man's reach, or extent of power or ability. (Msb.) And hence the phrases, DaAqa biAlA^amori *aroEuhu, and ↓ *iraAEuhu, (K,) and DaAqa biAlA^amori *aroEFA, (S, Msb, K,) in which the last word is in the accus. case as an explicative, for the original form of the phrase is that first mentioned, (TA,) and sometimes they said ↓ *iraAEFA, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He was unable to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair; as though meaning, he stretched forth his arm to it and it did not reach it; (S, TA; *) or these phrases are thus used because he who is short in the fore arm will not reach that which he who is long therein reaches, nor will the power of the former equal that of the latter; therefore they are proverbially applied to him whose power falls short of the attainment, or accomplishment, of an affair: (TA:) or he lacked strength, or power, or ability, to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair, and found not any way of escape from what was disagreeable therein: (K:) or he was unable to bear, or endure, or undertake, the thing, or affair. (Msb.) You say also, maA liY bihi *aroEN, and ↓ *iraAEN, (tropical:) I have not power, or ability, to do it. (TA.) And kasara *`lika mino *aroEiY (tropical:) That disabled, hindered, prevented, or withheld, me from doing that which I desired. (TA.) And AiqoSido bi*aroEika (tropical:) Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself restrain thyself; i. q. AirobaEo EalaY nafosika; (S, TA;) and let not thy soul, or mind, carry thee beyond thy measure or extent [of power or ability]. (TA.) And A^aboTarotu fulaAnFA *aroEhu (tropical:) I imposed upon such a one more than he was able to do: (S, TA:) but *aroEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) the body: and [accord. to IAar] A^abaTaraniY *aroEiY means (tropical:) He wasted my body, and cut off my means of subsistence. (TA.) [See also art. bTr.] You likewise say, rajulN ↓ raHobu Al*~iraAEi [and Al*~aroEi] (tropical:) A man having ample strength, and power, and might in war or fight, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA. [See also raHobN.]) And DaEiyfu Al*~aroEi (tropical:) Impotent. (KL.) ― -b3- And hence, fulaAnN xaAliY Al*~aroEi (tropical:) Such a one has his heart devoid of anxieties, or solicitudes, and griefs; because the heart is sometimes one of the seats of power: or it may mean, agreeably with the original signification of *aroEN, such a one is free from the causes of occupation which require the stretching forth of the fore arm and extending of the hand. (Har p. 131.) And rajulN waAsiEN Al*~aroEi, and ↓ Al*~iraAEi, (tropical:) A man large, or liberal, in disposition. (K.) And kabura fiY *aroEiY (assumed tropical:) Its occurrence, or befalling, was of great moment, momentous, grievous, or distressing, to me. (TA.) ― -b4- *aroEN also signifies The measure of anything: and naxolapN *aroEu rajalK, A palm-tree of the measure of the stature of a man. (TA.)

*araEN *
A coveting; desiring eagerly; or lusting. (S, K.) [Perhaps an inf. n. of which the verb is *ariEa.] -A2- See also *ariyEapN.

*ariEN * : see *ariyEN, in two places. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) That journeys by night and by day. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Longtongued with evil speech. (K.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) Good in social, or familiar, intercourse. (K, TA.)
*uroEapN * : see *ariyEapN.
*araAEN * (S, K) and ↓ *iraAEN (ISd, K) (assumed tropical:) A woman (S) light, or active, with the hands in spinning: (S, K:) or one who spins much; who has ability to do so. (TA.)

*iraAEN * , of a man, (Msb,) [The part] from the elbow to the extremities of the fingers; (Mgh, Msb;) the fore arm; syn. saAEidN [q. v.; thus corresponding to the saAq of the leg]: (Lth, K:) and (tropical:) [the space] from the extremity of the elbow to the extremity of the middle finger: (M, Mgh, * K: [in the last of which, the space is plainly shown to be meant, like as the part is shown in the Msb to be meant in the explanation cited above from that work and the Mgh: see also jariybN:]) in both these senses, sometimes masc., (K,) accord. to Kh: (TA:) J says, (TA,) as relating to the arm, it is masc. and fem.; but Sb says that it is fem.: (S, TA:) [Mtr says,] it is fem.: (Mgh:) [Fei says,] the measure so called is in most instances fem.: accord. to ISk, it is fem.; but some of the Arabs make it masc.: Fr says that it is fem.; but that some of [the tribe named] 'Okl make it masc.: As did not know an instance of its being masc.: and Zj says that such an instance is extr.; not choice: (Msb:) the measure thus called, [i. e. the cubit,] (Msb,) the *iraAEN mukas~arap [or cubit which is divided into fractions], (Mgh,) is six qabaDaAt [or fists] (Mgh, Msb) of middling measure; (Msb;) and this is
called *iraAEu AlEamaAm~api [the cubit of the common people, or the common cubit], because it wants one qaboDap [or fist] of what is called *iraAEu Almaliki [the cubit of the king], namely one of the Kisràs, (Mgh, Msb,) not the last of them, whose *rAE was seven qabaDaAt: (Mgh:) [see also miylN: it is also an astronomical measure; and as such, it seems, from several instances in which it is mentioned by Kzw and other writers, to be, probably, by rule, two degrees; nearly the half, or quarter, of the length assigned in different instances to the measure termed rumoHN; but, like the latter, not precise nor uniform in every instance:] the dim. is ↓ *uriy~aEapN, with p because it is fem.; (TA;) or ↓ *urayoEN [or ↓ *uray~iEN, without p, accord. to those who make it masc.]: (L voce HarobN:) the pl. is A^a*oruEN and *uroEaAnN; (O, Msb, K;) or, accord. to Sb, the former only; (S, Msb;) and Sb adds, they have given it this form of pl. because it is fem.; meaning, that fiEaAlN and fuEaAlN and faEiylN, when fem., have the pl. of the measure A^afoEulN. (TA.) In the phrase Alv~awobu saboEN fiY vamaAniyapK [The garment, or piece of cloth, is seven cubits by eight spans], they say sbE because A^a*oruE is fem., and vmAnyp because A^a$obaAr is masc.; (S; [and the like is said in the Mgh;]) and because the length is measured by the *rAE, and the breadth by the $ibor. (S in art. vmn.) *iraAEN is also used as an epithet, applied to a masc. n.: thus they say, h`*aA vawobN *iraAEN [This is a garment, or piece of cloth, a cubit in length]. (Kh.) You say also, huwa min~iY EalaY Haboli Al*~iraAEi It is prepared, or made ready, on my part: (S:) and huwa laka EalaY Haboli Al*~iraAEi I will pay it to thee in ready money: or it is prepared, or made ready, for thee: the Hbl being a certain vein in the *rAE. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence several tropical significations:] see *aroEN, in six places: and see also *araAEN. ― -b3- Hence also, (Z, TA,) (tropical:) The instrument with which one measures the length of the *rAE [or cubit], (S, Z, O, Mgh, K,) made of a piece of wood, (Mgh,) or whether it be iron or a rod of wood. (O, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) A sleeve: as in the phrase vawobN muwa$~aY Al*~iraAEi (assumed tropical:) [a garment, or piece of cloth, variegated, or figured, in the sleeve]: pl. ↓ ma*aAriEu, a pl. not agreeing with its sing., like malaAmiHu and maHaAsinu. (TA.) ― -b5- Of the fore legs of bulls or cows, and of sheep or goats, [The arm; i. e.] the part above the kuraAE: and of the fore legs of camels and horses and mules and asses, [likewise the arm; i. e.] the part above the waZiyf: (K:) [also the arm-bone of any of the animals here mentioned:] accord. to Lth, (TA,) of any animal, [but this is by synecdoche, (assumed tropical:) the fore leg;] i. q. yadN; (Msb, TA;) applying to the whole of whatever is called thus: (TA:) [thus, again, corresponding to saAqN; this latter term, in like manner, having a proper and a synecdochical acceptation. Hence the prov.] laA tuToEimi AlEaboda AlkuraAEa fayaTomaEa fiY Al*~iraAEi [Feed not thou the slave with the shank, lest he covet the arm]. (K.) ― -b6- [Hence,] Al*~iraAEu, also called *iraAEu AlA^asad (assumed tropical:) Two bright stars, which are one of the Mansions of the Moon: (S:) [there are two asterisms thus called; together, Al*~iraEaAni: one of them is] Al*~iraAEu AlmabosuwTapu, [also called *iraAEu AlA^asadi AlmabosuwTapu,] the two bright stars [ α and β ] in the heads of Gemini: (Kzw in his description of Gemini:) [the other is called Al*~iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu, and] *iraAEu AlA^asadi AlmaqobuwDapu, the two bright stars [ α and β ] of Canis Minor: (Kzw in his description of Canis Minor:) [hence it appears that the ancient Arabs, or many of them, extended the figure of Leo (as they did also that of Scorpio) far beyond the limits which we assign to it: the former *rAE accord. to those who make Aln~awo'u to signify “ the auroral rising, ” but the latter accord. to those who make it to signify “ the auroral setting, ” is the Seventh Mansion of the Moon: the following descriptions in Kzw's account of the Mansions of the Moon, and in the O and K and TA, are obscure and inaccurate:] Al*~iraAEu is one of the Mansions of the Moon, (O, Kzw, K,) and is called *rAE AlAsd AlmqbwDp, (O, Kzw,) or *rAE AlAsd AlmbswTp: (K:) the lion has a *rAE which is mbswTp and a *rAE which is mqbwDp, (O, Kzw, K,) and this is the one next to Syria, (O, K,) or on the left, (Kzw,) and in it the moon has a mansion; the mbswTp being next to El-Yemen, (O, K,) or on the right; (Kzw;) [but this description of their relative positions should be reversed, as is shown by what precedes and by what follows;] each being two stars, between which is the measure of a sawoT [or whip]; (O;) and the latter is higher in the sky, and more extended, than the other, (O, K,) wherefore it is called mbswTp; (O;) and sometimes the moon deviates, and so has a mansion in it: (O, K:) [it is said in the TA that Al*rAE is also a name of one of the asterisms (nujuwm) of AljawozaA='; but this is the same that is called the mbswTp:] it rises [at dawn] on the fourth of tam~uwz [or July O. S.], and sets [at dawn] on the fourth of kaAnuwn AlA=xir [or January, O. S.]: (O, Kzw: [and so in the K, except that in this last, it is erroneously said to set in kaAnuwn AlA^aw~al:]) so says IKt: but Ibráheem El-Harbee says that it rises on the seventh of tm~wz, and sets on the sixth of kAnwn AlA=xr. (O, TA.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also nawo'N, and nakobaA='u.] The rhyming prosaist of the Arabs says, A_i*aA TalaEati Al*~iraAEo Hasarati Al$~amosu AlqinaAEo waA@sotaEolato fiY AlA^ufuqi Al$~uEaAEo wa taraqoraqa Als~araAbu fiY kul~i qaAEo [When the Dhiráa rises at dawn, the sun puts off the veil, and the rays ascend in the horizon, and the mirage flickers, or glistens, in every plain]. (TA.) And the Arabs assert that when there is no rain [at any other season] in the year, the *rAE does not break its promise, though it be but a bago$ap [or weak shower of rain]: (Kzw, TA:) [or] its nawo' is approved, and seldom does it break its promise. (Kzw.) ― -b7- *iraAEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the arm (*rAE) of a camel: (S, K:) and is a mark of the Benoo-Thaalebeh in El-Yemen, and of some persons of the Benoo-Málik-Ibn-Saad. (K.) ― -b8- Also (tropical:) The fore part of a spear or spear-shaft: (K, TA:) this is called (S, TA) also (TA) *iraAEu AlaEaAmili. (S, TA.)
*aruwEN * : see what next follows.

*ariyEN *
Wide in step, (S, K,) and light, or active, in pace, or going; (K;) applied to a horse, (S, K,) and to a camel; as also ↓ *aruwEN: (K:) and quick: (S, Msb, K:) [and so ↓ *ariEN; for] ↓ *ariEaAtN, (S, O, K,) applied to the legs of a quadruped (qawaAy^imN), (S, TA,) signifies quick, (S, K,) wide in step, taking much of the ground: (O, K:) or, as some say, this last word signifies the legs of a beast, (TA,) like ↓ ma*aAriEu, (S, K,) pl. of mi*oraAEN. (K.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., kaAna *ariyEa Alma$oYi (assumed tropical:) He was quick, and wide of step, in walking. (TA.) And you say, rajulN *ariyEN biAlikitaAbapi (assumed tropical:) A man quick in writing. (TA.) And A^akala A^akolFA *ariyEFA (assumed tropical:) He ate quickly and much. (TA.) And qatolN *ariyEN (assumed tropical:) Quick slaughter. (S.) And mawotN *ariyEN (tropical:) Spreading death: (K:) or quick, spreading death, such that the people can hardly, or can in no wise, bury one another. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) An ample thing, affair, or state. (K.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) An intercessor. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
*urayoEN * a dim. of *iraAEN, q. v.

*ariyEapN *
A she-camel by which the archer, or the like, conceals himself from the game, (S, K, TA,) walking by her side, and shooting, or casting, when the object puts itself in his power, having first left the she-camel to roam at pleasure with the wild animals in order that they may become familiar with her; (TA;) like dariyoy^apN; (S;) as also ↓ *araEN: (K:) pl. *uruEN. (IAar.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) Anything that brings one near to a thing; (IAar;) a means of access, nearness, intimacy, ingratiation, attachment, or connexion; syn. wasiylapN; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and sababN; and wuSolapN; (TA;) as also ↓ *uroEapN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. *araAy^iEu. (S, Msb.) You say, fulaAnN *ariyEatiY A_ilayoka (tropical:) Such a one is my means of access to thee, and of attachment to thee, or connexion with thee. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [like dariyoy^apN,] A ring by aiming at which one learns the art of shooting, or casting [the lance &c.]. (TA.)
*uray~iEN * : dims. of *iraAEN, q. v.
*uray~iEapN * : dims. of *iraAEN, q. v.

*ar~aAEN *
A measurer with the *iraAE [or cubit]. (T in art. A^br.) ― -b2- A he-camel that drives the she-camel with his arm and so makes her lie down that he may cover her. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

*aAriEN * [so in a copy of the S and of the K and in the TA: in one copy of S and in one of the K, *iraAE: in the CK, *ar~AE: but the right reading is *aAriEN, as is shown by verses in which it occurs, cited in the TA, and by its pl.,] A small [skin of the kind called] ziq~, which is stripped off from the part next to the *iraAE [or arm], (S, K,) and
which is for $araAb [or wine]; (S;) and ↓ mi*oraEN signifies [the same; or simply] a small ziq~: (TA:) or, as some say, ziq~N *aAriEN signifies a zq~ that takes much water: (TA:) the pl. is *awaAriEu. (S, TA.) -A2- naAqapN *aAraEapN An excellent she-camel. (TA.)

A^a*oraEu * [More, and most, light, or active, and quick, with the arms, or hands, or (assumed tropical:) otherwise]. It is said in a trad., xayoru kun~a A^a*oraEukun~a lilogazoli The best of you females is the most light, or active, of hand, of you, in spinning: or, the most able of you to spin. (TA.) And qataluwhumo A^a*oraEa qatolK (assumed tropical:) They slew them with the quickest slaughter. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) More, and most, chaste in speech. (K.) You say, huwa A^a*oraEu minohu (assumed tropical:) He is more chaste of speech than he. (TA.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) One whose mother is Arabian but not his father; syn. muqorifN: or the son of an Arabian man by an emancipated slavewoman: (K:) the former is the more correct. (TA.) [See also mu*ar~aEN.]
ta*oriyEN * The redundant part of the cord with which the arm [of a camel] is bound: [see 2, latter part:] a subst. like [taSodiyrN and] tanobiytN; not an inf. n. (TA.)
mi*oraEN * : see *aAriEN.

mu*ar~aEN * , an epithet applied to an ass, and to a mule, meaning Having what are termed raqomataAni [q. v.] upon his arms. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (L,) (tropical:) A man (TA) whose mother is more noble than his father: (S, L, K:) as though, (K,) or said to be, (S,) so called because of the raqomataAni upon the arm [or arms] of the mule, for they come to him from the side of the ass; (S, K;) or so called as being likened to the mule, because he has upon his arms rqmtAn like those of the arm of the ass, thereby resembling the ass; and the mother of the mule is more noble than his father. (L.) [See also A^a*oraEu.] ― -b3- A lion having upon his arms the blood of his prey. (IAar.) ― -b4- [A beast] struck in the uppermost part of his breast so that the blood has flowed upon his arms. (K.) ― -b5- A horse that outstrips: or (originally, TA) that overtakes the wild animal and has his arms smeared by his rider's piercing the latter so as to make the blood flow forth; (K, TA;) this blood upon his arms being the sign of his having outstripped. (TA,) ― -b6- A bull having black spots, or black places, upon his shanks. (S, K.) ― -b7- mu*ar~aEapN A hyena having stripes upon its arms: (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: or applied to the hyena because of blackness on its arms. (TA.)
mu*ar~iEN * Rain that sinks into the earth to the depth of a cubit. (S, K.)

mi*oraAEN * sing. of ma*aAriEN, [which is contr. to rule,] (S, K,) in a sense pointed out below, (S,) or in all the senses explained below, and of ma*aAriyEN, (K,) which is agreeable to rule. (TA.) ― -b2- ma*aAriEu signifies The legs of a beast; (S, K;) as also ma*aAriyEu, and *ariEaAtN; see *ariyEN; because the beast measures with them the ground: or, as some say, [like the pl. of *iraAEN,] the parts of a beast between the knee and the arm-pit. (TA.) -A2- ma*aAriEu also signifies The towns (quraY, S, or bilaAd, K) that are between the cultivated land and the desert; (S, K;) such as El-Kádiseeyeh and El-Ambár; (TA;) in this sense, (S,) as in others, (K,) pl. of mi*oraAEN; (S, K;) as also ma*aAriyEu; (K;) syn. with mazaAlifu; (S;) and baraAgiylu: (TA:) El-Hasan El-Basree speaks of the ma*aAriEu of El-Yemen. (TA.) [Freytag says, without mentioning his authority, that ma*aAriEu has the same signification with the inhabitants of Nejd as maxaAliyfu with the inhabitants of El-Yemen and mazaAlifu in the region of El-Hijáz: but this is at variance with all that I have found, in respect of the term mxAlyf.] ― -b2- Also Parts, regions, quarters, or tracts, syn. nawaAHK, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) of a land. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- And The places of bending of a valley. (Kh.) ― -b4- And Palm-trees that are near to houses or tents. (S, K.)
ma*aAriEu * a pl. [contr. to rule] of mi*oraAEN, q. v.: (S, K:) and of *iraAEN as signifying (assumed tropical:) A sleeve. (TA.) See the last of these words, near the middle of the paragraph.

1 *arafa Ald~amoEu * , (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
*arifa , inf. n. *arofN (Lth, T, S, K) and *uruwfN (Lth, T, K) and *arafaAnN (S, K) and *ariyfN and ta*oraAfN, (K,) The tears flowed. (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K.) And *arafato Eayonuhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
*arifa , inf. n. *arofN, (Msb,) His eye shed tears; (Msb;) tears flowed from his eye. (S, K.) And *arafato Eayonuhu damoEahaA, (Lth, T,) or *arafati AlEayonu damoEahaA (K) or Ald~amoEa, (M, Msb,) aor.
*arifa , (M,) inf. n. *arofN and *arafN and *arafaAnN (Lth, T, M) and *uruwfN and *ariyfN and ta*oraAfN, and [ISd says,] I think that Lh has mentioned as an inf. n. *uraAfN, but I am not certain of it, (M,) His eye poured forth its tears: (Lth, T:) or the eye made its tears, or the tears, to flow: (M, K:) or let fall tears, or the tears: and ↓ *ar~afatohu, inf. n. ta*oriyfN signifies the same: (M:) [or the latter has an intensive signification: or] you say, ↓ *r~f damoEahu, (K,) or dumuwEahu, (T,) inf. n. ta*oriyfN and ta*oraAfN and ta*orifapN, (T, K,) He poured forth his tears. (K.) ― -b2- [See also *arofN, and *arafaAnN, below.]

2 *ar~afa see above, in two places. -A2- *r~f Ealayohi, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. ta*oriyfN, (S,) He exceeded it; (T, S, M, K;) namely, a hundred [years], (S, K,) or sixty, (T,) or fifty, or some other number. (M.) ― -b2- *r~f fiY Hadiyvihi He added, or exaggerated, in his discourse, or narration; as also zl~f. (IDrd and O in art. zlf.) -A3- *r~fhu Al$~aYo'a He made him to know the thing: a poet says,
laA^u*ar~ifanoka Almawota A_ino lamo tahorubi
i. e. I will assuredly make thee to know death [if thou flee not]: (IAar, M:) or *r~fhu Almawota signifies he made him to be at the point of death. (T, K.)

10 Ast*rfhu *
He desired its (a thing's) dripping, or flowing. (M.) ― -b2- And Ast*rf AlD~aroEu The udder invited one to milk it; and to desire its dripping, or flowing [with milk]. (M.)

*arofN * [app. in the following sense, as well as in others mentioned above, (see 1,) an inf. n., of which the verb is *arafa,] A certain running of horses, in which the legs are put together and [then] the fore legs stretched out with the toes near to the ground. (M.)
*arafaAnN * [app. in the following sense, as well as in others mentioned above, (see 1,) an inf. n., of which the verb is *arafa,] A weak gait or manner of going. (S, K.)
damoEN *ariyfN * and ↓ ma*oruwfN Tears shed, or made to flow. (T, M, K.)
*ar~aAfN * [accord. to Freytag, Largely flowing: but he does not name any authority.] ― -b2- Quick, or swift; and so zar~aAfN. (M.)
*awaArifu * , applied to tears (*umuwEN), Flowing. (T.) [And] Running waters. (KL.)

ma*aArifN *
i. q. madaAmiEN [The channels of the tears; &c.: see madomaEN]. (T, S, K.)
ma*oruwfN * : see *ariyfN.

1 *araqa * , aor.
*aruqa and
*ariqa , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. *aroqN, (Mgh, Msb,) said of a bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) It muted, or dunged; (JK, Mgh, Msb;) [like zaraqa;] as also ↓ A*rAq, (Zj, JK, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i*oraAqN: (JK:) it is also, sometimes, (assumed tropical:) said of a man: (S, * TA:) and the latter is sometimes (tropical:) said of a beast of prey, and [particularly] of a fox. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, mataY ta*oruwqN EalaY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) When wilt thou behave in a lightwitted, or foolish, manner towards men? or utter foul, or obscene, language against them? (TA.) And h`*aA kalaAmN ya*oraqu Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) This is speech, or language, that is deemed foul. (TA.) And laA^a*oruqan~aka A_ino lamo turab~iEo is a phrase meaning a threat. (TA. [But how it should be rendered, unless it be said by a woman to her husband, (see rab~aEa liA@moraA^atihi,) and lA*rqn~k be for laA^a*oruqan~a Ealayoka, I know not.]) -A2- *ariqa AlmaAlu, [in the JK written *araqa, but said in the TA to be like fariH, meaning The cattle suffered from eating the herb called *uraq, is] from Al*~uraqu. (JK, TA.)
4 A^a*oraqa see the first sentence above. -A2- A*rqt AlA^aroDu The land produced [the herb called] *uraq. (S, K.)

5 ta*ar~aqato *
She applied laban mu*ar~aq as a collyrium to her eyes; as also ↓ Ai*~araqato, of the measure AifotaEalato: [so accord, to the copies of the K: but] in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb ” it is said, ↓ A*r~qt AlmaroA^apu baAlkuHoli signifies the woman applied collyrium to her eyes. (TA.)
8 A_i*otaraqa see what next precedes, in two places.

*aroqN *
Dung (JK, S, Mgh) of a bird; (S, Mgh;) as also ↓ *uraAqN: (AZ, TA:) [or] of the bustard (HubaAraY) and the like: (JK:) the former word an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense. (Mgh.)

*uraqN *
A certain plant, resembling fisofisap; (JK;) a certain herb, (TA,) i. q. HanodaquwqN [the herb lotus, melilot, sweet trefoil, or bird's-foot-trefoil: so in the present day]: (JK, IDrd, S, K:) it has a slight and sweet odour, and grows in [plains such as are called] qiyEaAn, and in places where water collects and stagnates; and sheep, or goats, suffer from eating it, and sometimes become distended in their bellies: (AHn, TA:) n. un. with p. (AHn, JK, TA.)
*uraAqN * : see *aroqN.

labanN mu*ar~aqN *
Milk mixed with water: (AZ, S, K:) [like mu*al~aqN.]

div2.head: *rw and *rY
div2.entryFree: 1 *aratohu Alr~iyHu * , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. ta*oruwhu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. *arowN; (S M, Msb, K;) and aor. ta*oriyhi, (S, M,) inf. n. *aroYN; (S;) and ↓ *r~thu; and ↓ A*rthu; (M, K;) the last on the authority of IAar, but said in the T to be disallowed in this sense by AHeyth; (TA;) The wind raised it, (T, S, *) or made it to fly, (AHeyth, T, S, * M, K,) and carried it away; (S, * M, Msb, * K;) and dispersed it; (Msb;) namely, a thing, (Msb, K,) or the dust, (T, S, M,) &c. (S, M.) And accord. to IAar, one says, *arati Alr~iyHu, and ↓ A^a*orat, [elliptically,] meaning *arati Alt~uraAba [i. e. The wind raised the dust, or made it to fly, &c.]. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] *araA Alr~iwaAyapa *arowa Alr~iyHi Alha$iyma (assumed tropical:) He carried on the relation uninterruptedly and rapidly [like as the wind carries away the dry herbage that is broken in pieces.] (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, *araA Aln~aAsu AlHinoTapa [The people winnowed the wheat]. (S.) You say, *arawotu AlHinoTapa, (IAar, T, M, K, *) aor. A^a*oruwhaA, inf. n. *arowN; (IAar, T;) and ↓ *ar~ayotuhaA; (M;) I winnowed the wheat: (M, K: *) or AlT~aEaAma ↓ *ar~ayotu, inf. n. ta*oriyapN; (Msb;) and *arayotuhu and *arawotuhu; (T;) I cleared the wheat from its straw. (Msb.) And *arawotuhu, (S, M,) and *arayotuhu, but the former is more approved; and ↓ *ar~ayotuhu; (M;) I made it to fly, and go away; (S, M;) namely, a thing, (S,) or grain, and the like. (M.) AlA^akodaAsi ↓ ta*oriyapu is well known [as meaning The winnowing of the heaps of grain]. (S.) And hence, (S,) *ar~ayotu turaAba AlmaEodini I sought the gold of the dust of the mine [by sifting it or winnowing it]: (S, K:) and ↓ Ai*~arayotuhu signifies the same. (T and S in art. drY. [See a verse cited in the first paragraph of that art.: and see also 2 in the same art.]) ― -b4- *arayotu Al$~aYo'a, (T,) or ↓ A^a*orayotuhu, (S, TA,) accord. to AHeyth, (TA,) I threw the thing [or scattered it] like as one throws grain for sowing. (T, S, TA.) And *araA AlA^aroDa He sowed the land, scattering the seed; as also *araA^a AlArD; but the former is said to be the more chaste. (MF and TA in art. *rA^.) ― -b5- And *araAhumo, inf. n. *arowN, is a dial. var. of *araA^ahumo, meaning He [God] created them. (M.) ― -b6- *araA Al$~aYo'a He broke the thing (K, TA) without separating. (TA.) And *arawotu naAbahu I broke his canine tooth. (M, TA.) ― -b7- *araAhu biAlr~umoHi He displaced, or uprooted, him, or it, with the spear. (Kr, M.) -A2- *araA, intrans., It (a thing, K, or dust, &c., M) flew up, and went away, or became carried away [by the wind]. (M, K.) ― -b2- He (a gazelle, K, or, accord. to some, any animal, TA) hastened (K, TA) in his running. (TA.) You say, mar~a ya*oruw, inf. n. *arowN, He (a man, S) passed, or went, along quickly: (S, M:) accord. to some, said particularly of a gazelle. (M.) And *araA A_ilaY fulaAnK He rose and betook himself to such a one. (TA.) ― -b3- It (a thing) fell. (S, K.) ― -b4- *araA naAbahu, inf. n. *arowN, His canine tooth broke: or, as some say, fell out. (M.) And *araAfuwhu, (K,) inf. n. *arowN, (TA,) His teeth fell out from his mouth; (K TA;) as also *araY, and *araA^a; but the last is said to be of weak authority, or a mispronunciation. (MF and TA in art. *rA^.)

2 1a2~a3a see 1, in five places. ― -b2- [Hence,] *ar~aY raA^osahu, (M, TA,) inf. n. ta*oriyapN, (TA,) He combed his head (M, TA) [so as to remove the scurf &c.], like as one winnows a thing: but dar~aY [with the unpointed d] is of higher authority. (M.) -A2- *ar~ayotuhu, namely, a sheep, inf. n. as above, I shore, or sheared, his wool, leaving somewhat thereof upon his back in order that he might be known thereby: and in like manner one says in relation to a camel. (S, M.) [See mu*ar~FY.] ― -b2- [Hence, app, or from *irawopN, as is indicated in what follows,] (assumed tropical:) I praised him. (IAar, M, K.) You say, fulaAnN yu*ar~iY fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one exalts the state, or condition, of such a one; and praises him. (T.) A poet says, [namely, Ru-beh, (so in the margin of one of my copies of the S,)]
EayodFA A^u*ar~iY HasabiY A^ano yu$otamaA
(assumed tropical:) [Purposely I praise and exalt what constitutes my grounds of pretension to respect or honour, lest it should be reviled]: (T, S, M:) as though I put it upon the *irowapN [q. v.] (M.)

4 A^a1o2a3a see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Accord. to AHeyth, this verb is not used in the sense first explained above; but one says, A^a*orayotu Al$~aYo'a Eani Al$~aYo'i, meaning I threw down the thing from the thing: (T, TA:) or A_i*oraA='N signifies the striking a thing and throwing it down: (Lth, T:) and sometimes, the throwing down without cutting. (M.) You say, Darabotuhu biAls~ayofi faA^a*orayotu raA^osahu [I struck him with the sword and made his head to fall from him]. (T.) And TaEanotuhu faA^a*orayotuhu Eano farasihi, (T,) or Eano Zahori daAb~atihi, (S,) i. e. [I thrust him, or pierced him, and] threw him down [from his horse, or from the back of his beast]. (T, S.) And A^a*orati Ald~aAb~apu raAkibahaA The beast threw down its rider. (M.) And A*rY Al$~aYo'a biAls~ayofi He struck the thing with the sword so as to throw it down. (M.) And A^a*orati AlEayonu damoEahaA, (S,) or Ald~amoEa, (M,) The eye poured forth [or let fall its tears, or the tears]. (S, M.) [See also A^a*oraA^a.] -A2- A*rY said of a camel, He was, or became, tall, or long, in his *irowap [or hump]. (TA.)

5 t*r~t AlHinoTapu *
The wheat was, or became, winnowed: (M, K:) or was, or became, cleared from its straw. (TA.) -A2- t*r~Y bihi He protected, or sheltered, himself by means of it; (M, Msb;) i. e. by means of a wall, &c., from the wind and the cold; as also bh ↓ Ast*rY. (M.) One says, ta*ar~a mina Al$~amaAli ba*orFY Protect, or shelter, thyself from the north wind by means of a shelter. (T.) And bih`*ihi Al$~ajarapi ↓ Aisota*ori Shelter thyself by means of this tree: (T:) or biAl$~ajarapi ↓ Aisota*orayotu I shaded and sheltered myself by means of the tree. (S.) And t*r~ti AlA_ibilu The camels protected, or sheltered, themselves from the cold, one by means of another; or by means of the [trees called] EiDaAh. (M.) And bifulaAnK ↓ Aisota*orayotu I sought refuge with such a one, and became in his protection. (S.) And A*rY [thus I find it written, without any syll. signs, evidently for ↓ Ai*~araY, of the measure AifotaEala, like AilotajaA^a and Aikotan~a,] He sought protection by means of a king. (TA.) -A3- t*r~Y Als~anaAma, (S,) or Al*~irowapa, (M, K,) He mounted upon [the hump, or the top of the hump &c.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ta*ar~ayotu baniY fulaAnK wa tanaS~ayotuhumo (assumed tropical:) I married among the *irowap and the naASiyap of the sons of such a one; (As, T, * S;) i. e., among the noble and high of them: (T:) or t*r~Y fiyhimo (assumed tropical:) He married among the *irowap of them. (M.)
8 A_i1ota2a3a see 1: -A2- and see also 5.

10 A_isota1o2a3a see 5, in four places. ― -b2- Aisota*orato, said of a she-goat, She desired the ram; (S, K;) like Aisotadar~ato. (S.) ― -b3- And the inf. n. Aisoti*oraA='u signifies The act of leaping upon a female. (KL.)

*urapN * , originally *urawN, (S, Msb, K,) or *uraYN, (S, M, * Msb,) the p being a substitute (S, Msb) for the final radical letter, (Msb,) [A species of millet; the holcus sorghum of Linn.; thus called in the present day, and also, vulgarly, *urap SayofiY~ and *urapqayoZiY~, to distinguish it from maize, the zea mays of Linn., which is vulgarly called *urap$aAmiY~ and *urap kiyzaAn;] a species of grain; (M;) a certain grain, well known: (S, Msb, K:) the word is used as a n. un. and as a coll. n. (T.) [See miyrapN.]

*arowN *
A portion (TarafN) not completed, of a saying; as in the phrase, balaganiY Eanohu *arowN mino qawolK [An uncompleted portion of a saying was related to me from him]: (T, S:) or a little; a dial. var. of *aro'N [q. v.]. (M.) -A2- Also, and ↓ *arFY, i. q. ↓ *ur~iy~apN, (M, TA,) [respecting the derivation of which there are different opinions, explained in art. *rA^,] i. e. Created beings: [or children, or offspring: (see art *rA^:)] or *arowN and ↓ *arFY
signify the number of the *ur~iy~ap. (M.) One says, A^anomaY A@ll~`hu *aroA^aka and *arowaka, meaning May God increase [the number of] thine offspring. (T.) ― -b2- And *arowuAln~aAri occurs in a trad., as some relate it, instead of *aro'u Aln~aAri, as others relate it; meaning [either The children of the fire of Hell, agreeably with what next precedes, or] to be scattered in the fire. (S and TA in art. *rA^.) -A3- Also, *arowN, The curved extremity of a bow. (So in a copy of the S.)

*arFY * , also written *arFA, (or, accord. to some copies of the S, ↓ *urFY,) A thing [such as dust &c.] that the wind has raised, or made to fly, and carried away: (S:) or it signifies what one has winnowed; (M;) or maA ta*oruwhu [what thou winnowest, as is indicated by the context of this explanation]; like as nafaDN signifies maAtanofuDuhu. (T.) ― -b2- And *arFY or ↓ *urFY (accord. to different copies of the S) Tears poured forth: (S:) or so ↓ *ariY~N [or damoEN *ariY~N]. (M, TA.) -A2- Also A shelter; (M, TA;) anything by which one is protected, or sheltered: (S, Msb:) a shelter from the cold wind, consisting of a wall, or of trees: and particularly a shelter that is made for camels such as are termed $awol, by pulling up trees of the kind called Earofaj &c. and placing them one upon another in the direction whence blows the north, or northerly, wind, in the camel's nightly resting-place. (T.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN fiY *araY fulaAnK Such a one is in the protection of such a one. (T.) And A^anaA fiY Zil~i fulaAnN wafiY *araAhu I am in the protection of such a one, and in his shelter. (S.) And [hence, perhaps,] A_in~a fulaAnFA lakariymu Al*~araY (assumed tropical:) Verily such a one is generous in disposition. (AZ, T.) ― -b2- Also The court, or yard, (finaA=',) of a house. (Har pp. 56 and 442.) -A3- see also *arowN, in two places.
*urFY * : see *arFY, in two places: ― -b2- and *uraAwapN.

*arowapN *
Much property; like varowapN: so in the saying, huwa *uw *arowapK [He is a possessor of much property]. (TA.) -A2- See also *irowapN.
*urowapN * : see what next follows.

*irowapN * and ↓ *urowapN The upper, or uppermost, part of a thing (S, M, Msb, K) of any kind; (M, Msb;) and so, accord. to Et-Takee Esh-Shemenee, ↓ *arowapN: (TA:) and particularly, of a camel's hump, (S, M,) and of the head: (M:) and a camel's hump itself: (TA:) pl. *urFY. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad., A^ataY biA_ibilK gurari Al*~uraY [or gur~i Al*~uraY?] He brought camels having white humps. (TA.) And in another trad., EalaY *irowapi kul~i baEiyri $ayoTaAnu [On the hump of every camel is a devil]. (TA.) And in a prov., maA zaAla yafotilu fiY Al*~irowapi waAlgaAribi [He ceased not to twist the fur of the upper part and the fore part of the hump: originating from, or occurring in, a trad., which see explained in art. grb]: it means, (tropical:) he ceased not to render familiar, or tame, [or rather to endeavour to do so,] and to remove refractoriness.
