(TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tazaw~aja minohumo fiY Al*~irowapi wa Aln~aASiyapi (T, M *) (assumed tropical:) He married among the noble and high of them. (T.)
*ariY~N * : see *arFY. -A2- *arFY *ariY~N A warm shelter. (TA.)

*ariy~apN *
A she-camel by means of which one conceals himself from the objects of the chase: on the authority of Th: but the more approved word is with d [i. e. dariy~apN, or, accord. to AZ, dariyoy^apN]. (M.)

*uraAwapN * (vulgarly pronounced daraAwapN, TA) What has become broken into small particles, (M, K,) and dried up, (M,) or of what has dried up, (K,) of a plant, or of herbage, and has been blown away by the wind. (M, K.) ― -b2- And What has fallen of, or from, corn, (M, K,) or especially wheat, (Lh, M,) in the process of winnowing. (M, K.) And What has fallen of, or from, a thing; as also ↓ *urFY. (M, * K.)
*ur~iy~apN * : see *arowN.

Al*~ariyaAtN * [as used in the Kur li. 1] means The winds (S, Bd, Jel) raising, or making to fly, and carrying away, or dispersing, the dust &c.: (Bd, Jel:) or (assumed tropical:) the prolific women; for they scatter children: or (assumed tropical:) the causes of the scattering of the created beings, angels and others. (Bd.)

mi*orFY * (S, M) and ↓ mi*oraApN (M) A wooden implement, (S, M,) or a small wooden implement, (so in one copy of the S,) having [several] ex tremities [or prongs], (S,) with which one winnows (S, M) wheat, and with which the heaps of grain are cleared [from the straw &c.]: (S) or the former word signifies the thing with which the wheat is carried to be winnowed: and the latter, the wooden implement with which one winnows. (T.) -A2- Also, the former word, The extremity of the buttock: (AO, T, M, K:) or ↓ mi*orawaAni signifies the two extremities of the two buttocks; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K *) or the two uppermost parts of the two buttocks; (Meyd in explaining a prov. cited below;) and it has no sing.; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Meyd, K;) for if the sing. were mi*orFY, the dual would be mi*orayaAni. (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Meyd.) Hence, (Meyd,) ↓ jaA='a yanofuDu mi*orawayohi [He came shaking the two extremities, or the two uppermost parts, of his buttocks]; (S, Meyd, K;) a prov., applied to one behaving insolently (baAgK), and threatening; (S, K; *) or to one threatening vainly: (Meyd, and Har p. 603:) and ↓ jaA='a yaDoribu mi*orawayohi [He came striking. &c.]; a prov. also, applied to him who has come empty, not having accomplished that which he sought. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b2- ↓ mi*orawaAni also signifies The two sides of the head: (M, K:) or ma*aArK signifies the temples of the head; and the sing. is mi*orFY; accord. to AA. (S.) ― -b3- Also, ↓ mi*orawaAni, The two places, of a bow, upon which lies the string, in the upper portion and the lower: (AHn, S, M, K: *) and in this sense it has no sing.: (S:) or, accord. to AA, its sing. is mi*orFY. (M.)
mi*oraApN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
mi*orawaAni * : see mi*orFY, in five places.
mu*ar~aY * , fem. mu*ar~aApN, A sheep having a portion of its wool left unshorn between the shoulders when the rest has been shorn. (T.) [See 2.]
5 ta*aE~abatohu Aljin~u * , (K,) as also ta*aA^~abatohu, (TA,) The jinn frightened him, or terrified him. (K.)
7 An*Eb * , (K,) as also AnvEb, the latter thought by Az to be the original word, (TA,) It (water) flowed, ran, streamed, or poured: it flowed in a continuous stream. (K.)

*uEobaAnN *
A young wolf. (K.)
raA^ayotuhumo mu*oEaAb~iyna kaA^an~ahumo Eurofu DiboEaAnK * , (K,) and muvoEaAb~iyna, (TA,) I saw them following one another as though they were the mane of a male hyena. (As, K.)

1 *aEarahu * , aor.
*aEara ; inf. n. *aEorN; (S, A, Msb, K;) and ↓ A*Erhu, (TA,) inf. n. A_i*oEaArN; (K;) He frightened him; made him afraid. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) Hence, qumo faA^oti Alqawoma walaA ta*oEarohumo EalaY~a Arise thou, and go to the people, meaning Kureysh, but do not make them to be frightened at me; i. e. do not acquaint them with thyself, but go clandestinely, lest they take fright at thee: said to Hodheyfeh, on the night of the Ahzáb [on the occasion of the war of the Moat]: so in a trad.: and in another trad. is mentioned the fol lowing saying of 'Omar, to some men contending together in throwing colocynths: ka*`lika laA ta*oEaruwA EalayonaA, meaning, Let that suffice you: make not our camels to be frightened at us. (TA.) ― -b2- *uEira, (S, K,) inf. n. *aEorN; (TA;) and ↓ An*Er; (TA;) [and app. ↓ t*E~r; of which see the act. part. n., below;] He became frightened, or afraid. (S, K, TA.) [You say, *uEira minohu He was frightened at him, or it.]
4 A^a*oEara see above, first sentence.
5 ta*aE~ara and 7: see 1.

*uEorN *
Fright. (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K.)

*aEarN *
A state of stupefaction, (K,) by reason of shame, or pudency. (TA.)
*aEirN * , a possessive epithet, (T, TA,) or ↓ *uEarN, (K,) A thing feared; a frightful thing. (T, K.) ― -b2- See also ma*oEuwrN.
*uEarN * : see *aEirN

*aEorapN *
A fright. (TA.)

*uEarapN * [an intensive epithet, Very fearful. ― -b2- And hence,] A certain bird, (K,) a small bird, (T,) found in trees, always wagging its tail, (T, K,) never seen otherwise than frightened. (T, TA.)

sanapN *uEoriy~apN *
A severe year. (A, K.)

*aEuwrN * : see ma*oEuwrN. ― -b2- Also, [without p,] A woman who becomes frightened at a thing that induces suspicion, or evil opinion, (S, A, Msb, K,) and at foul language. (K, TA: or, accord. to the CK and a MS. copy of the K, “ foul language ” is a distinct signification of the word.) A poet says,
tanuwla bimaEorufi AlHadiyvi wa A_ino turido
siwaY *aAka tu*oEaro minoka wahoYa *aEuwru
[She will give thee kind discourse; but if thou desire other than that, she will be frightened at thee; for she is one who is frightened at a thing inducing suspicion &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A she-camel which, when her udder is touched, takes fright, and will not yield her milk. (So accord. to two copies of the S. [Expl. by A_i*aA mus~a DarEuhaAgaAr~ato; and so in some copies of the K and accord. to the TA: in a copy of the A, EaArato, which has a similar meaning: in some 'copies of the K, gaArato, without teshdeed, i. e., is jealous.])
mu*oEarapN * : see the next paragraph.

ma*oEuwrN *
Frightened; or that becomes frightened; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ *aEirN (A) and ↓ *aEuwrN (K) and ↓ muno*aEirN, (M, TA,) or ↓ muta*aE~irN. (K.) ― -b2- ma*oEuwrapN, and ↓ mu*oEarapN, (K, TA,) or ↓ mu*aE~arapN, (so in the CK, and a MS. copy of the K,) A mad she-camel. (K.)
mu*aE~arapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muta*aE~irN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muno*aEirN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 *aEafahu * , (S, K,) aor.
*aEafa , (K,) inf. n. *aEofN, (TK,) He gave him to drink *uEaAf [i. e. poison, or instantaneous poison]. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And He poisoned food: (see ma*oEuwfN:) for] *aEofN also signifies the infecting with poison. (KL.) -A2- *aEifa and *aEafa, aor.
*aEafa , (K,) inf. n. *aEafaAnN, (K, * TK,) He died: (K:) [or he died quickly: like *aA^afa.]

4 A*Efhu *
He, or it, slew him, or killed him, quickly. (K.)

7 An*Ef *
His breath became interrupted, or short, (Ainobahara,) and his heart broke AinoqaTaEa fuw^aAduhu [a phrase probably to be understood in a figurative sense; like An*A^f]). (K.)
*aEofN * : see *uEaAfN. ― -b2- Hay~apN *aEofu All~uEaAbi A serpent that kills quickly. (K.)

*aEafaAnN *
Death. (K.) [See 1, last sentence.]

*uEaAfN *
Poison: (S, K:) or instantaneous poison; as also ↓ *aEofN: (K:) or such poison is called sam~N *uEaAfN: (Mgh:) pl. *uEufN. (K.) ― -b2- mawotN *uEaAfN i. q. *uw^aAfN; (S, K;) i. e. A quick death; that kills quickly; (S;) and so ↓ mawotN mu*oEifN. (K.)
mu*oEifN * : see what next precedes.
TaEaAm ma*oEuwfN * [Poisoned food; or] food in which is *uEaAf. (S, K.) [This art. is wanting in the copies of the TA known to me. Compare with it art. zEf.]
1 *aEina * : see what next follows.

4 A*En lahu * , (S, Msb, * K, &c.,) inf. n. A_i*oEaAnN, (Msb,) He was, or became, quick in obedience to him, or it: (K:) this is its [proper, or primary,] meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, in the language of the Arabs: (TA:) and he acknowledged, or confessed, to him: (K:) and he was, or became, lowly, or humble, and abject, to him: (S, K:) and he was, or became, tractable, submissive, or manageable, to him; (S, * Msb, * K, TA;) and easy; (K, * TA;) not disobedient; (Msb;) as also ↓ *aEina, aor.
*aEana , (K,) inf. n. *aEanN. (TA.) You say, A*En liY biHaq~iY He obeyed me with respect to that [right, or due,] which I sought to obtain from him, and hastened to render it: and he acknowledged, or confessed, to me my right, or due, willingly, not against his will; as also A^amoEana. (TA.) Some have used A_i*oEaAnN as meaning Perception, and understanding: but there is no foundation for this in the language of the Arabs; and its being tropical, as some of the sheykhs have endeavoured to show it to be, is improbable. (MF.)

mu*oEinN * [act. part. n. of 4]. waA_ino yakuno lahumu A@loHaq~u yaA^otuwA A_ilayohi mu*oEiniyna, in the Kur [xxiv. 48], means [But if the right be theirs,] they come to him quickly obedient: (TA:) or [simply] obedient; not compelled against their will: (Fr, TA:) or acknowledging, or confessing, and lowly, or humble: or tractable, submissive, or manageable, and easy. (TA.) ↓ mi*oEaAnN, also, signifies Tractable, submissive, or manageable, (Msb, K,) to her leader, (TA.) and easy in the head; (K;) applied to a she-camel: (Msb, K:) and, applied to a man, tractable, submissive, or manageable. (A, TA.)
mi*oEaAnN * : see what next precedes.
raA^ayotuhumo mu*oEaAn~iyna * is a mistake for rAythm mu*oEaAb~iyna, meaning I saw them following one another, or doing so uninterruptedly. (K.)

1 *af~a * , aor.
*afi3a , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. *afaAfapN, (M,) He, or it, (a thing, Msb,) was quick (S, M, Msb, K) and light, (M,) fiY AlA^amori in the affair: (K:) or he was light [or went lightly] upon the ground. (M.) You say, *af~a EalaY wajohi AlA^aroDi, and daf~a, (IAar, T in the present art. and in art. df,) i. e. He went lightly upon the ground. (TA in art. df.) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, said of a pestilence, It was quick; and despatched, or killed, quickly. (K.) And *af~a Ealayohi, (M, K,) inf. n. *af~N and *ifaAfN, (S, K,) or *afafN; (M;) and Elyh ↓ *f~f, (T in art. df, S, M, Mgh,) or ↓ *f~fhu, (K,) inf. n. ta*ofiyfN; (S;) and Elyh ↓ *Af~, (T, M, K, in the CK A*Af~,) and laha, and ↓ *Af~h; (M, K, in the CK Aa*Af~ahu;) and Elyh ↓ A*f~, (M,) or ↓ A*f~hu, and ↓ *afo*afahu; (K;) namely, a wounded man; (S, M, Mgh, K;) He despatched him; i. e. hastened and completed his slaughter; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also daf~ Elyh [&c.]. (Msb in art. df. [See 3 in that art.]) ― -b3- Also *af~a, (T, M,) aor.
*afi3a , inf. n. *afiyfN; (M;) and ↓ Ast*f~; (T, M, K;) It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, easy; (T;) within one's power or reach; (M;) feasible, practicable, or prepared. (M, K.) You say, xu*omaA *af~a laka and lk ↓ mAA@sota*af~a, and daf~a and Astdf~: all signify the same: (T, K:) i. e. Take thou what is easy [&c.] to thee. (T. [See 10 in art. df.]) ― -b4- [The signification “ Celeriter obortæ fuerunt manaruntque lacrymæ, ” assigned by Golius to the first of these verbs, as on the authority of the KL, is a mistake: it is taken from an explanation of *arofN, which, in my copy of the KL, immediately follows the explanations of daf~N and difaAfN.]
2 *af~a3a see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, *af~ifo jahaAza raAHilatika Lighten thou the travellingapparatus of thy riding-camel. (K.)
3 *aAofa3a see 1, in two places.
4 A^a*ofa3a see 1, in two places.

10 A_isota*ofa3a see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also It (an affair, or a thing,) was, or became, rightly disposed or arranged; in a right state; or complete, and in a right state; as also Astdf~. (IKtt, IB, TA in art. df.)
R. Q. 1 *afo*afa * : see 1. -A2- Also He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (IAar, T, K.)

*af~N *
Sheep or goats. (Kr, M, K.)

maA='N *uf~N * (M, K) and ↓ *afafN (M) and ↓ *ifaAfN (T, S, K) and ↓ *ufaAfN (M, K) A small quantity of water; water little in quantity: (T, S, M, K:) or the last two signify, (K,) or the last but one signifies, (M,) moisture: (M, K:) the pl. [of mult.] (of *ifaAfN, T, K, or *ufaAfN, K) is *ufufN (T, K) and [of pauc.] A^a*if~apN. (T, M.)
*afafN * : see what next precedes.

*afaAfN * a subst. from *af~a Ealayohi [and as such signifying The act, or a means, of despatching a wounded man; i. e., hastening and completing his slaughter: and hence, of finishing a thing]. (ElHejeree, M, K.) A poet says, referring to a draught of water,
takuwnu $ifaA='a A^awo *afaAfFA limaA biyaA
[That may be a cure, or a means of finishing, of what is in me, i. e., of what I am suffering]. (El-Hejeree, M.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

*ufaAfN * : see *afiyfN, in two places: ― -b2- and *ifaAfN: ― -b3- and *uf~N. ― -b4- You say also, maA*uqotu *ufaAfFA I tasted not a little thing, or a thing small in quantity: (M:) or ↓ maA *aAqa *ifaAfFA and ↓ *afaAfFA [like *awaAqFA] He tasted not anything. (K. In the CK mA *Afa.)

*ifaAfN * [or sam~N *ifaAfN], (AA, T, S,) or ↓ *ufaAfN, (M,) or both, (K,) Deadly poison: (AA, T, S, M, K:) because it kills quickly him who drinks it. (AA, T.) ― -b2- You say also, maA fiyhi *ifaAfN, meaning mutaEal~aqN yutaEal~aqN bihi [i. e. There is not in it that whereby one may retain life; or a bare sufficiency of the means of subsistence]. (K.) ― -b3- See also *uf~N: and *ufaAfN.

*afiyfN *
Quick: (S, Msb:) or, as also ↓ *ufaAfN, quick and light: or light, or going lightly, upon the ground. (M, K.) You say also xafiyfN *afiyfN, (T, S, K,) meaning Quick, (S,) and in like manner ↓ xufaAfN *ufaAfN, (T, K,) in each case using the latter word as an imitative sequent. (K.) ― -b2- Also A death, (M,) or a pestilence, (K.) that kills quickly. (M, K.) -A2- Also The male qunofu* [or hedge-hog]. (M.)

sahomN mu*af~afN *
A swift and light arrow. (K.)

1 *afira * , aor.
*afara , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. *afarN, (Msb,) He, or it, had, or emitted, a pungent, or strong, odour, or smell; (S, Msb;;) or a very pungent, or very strong, odour, or smell; (M, K;) whether sweet or stinking: (S, M, Msb:) or he had stinking arm-pits; or it (the arm-pit) stank. (Lh, M, K.) [See also *afarN, below.] ― -b2- *afira Aln~abotu The plants became abundant. (AHn. M.)

10 Ast*fr fiY AlA^amori * (assumed tropical:) He became very determined, and hardy, [as though he drew forth from himself a pungent odour by sweating,] to do the thing, or affair. (M, TA.) -A2- Ast*frt said of a woman, i. q. Astvfrt [q. v.]. (TA.)

*afarN * inf. n. of 1. (Msb.) ― -b2- Pungency, or strength, of odour; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) or intense pungency or strength thereof; (M, K;) whether sweet or stinking; (S, M, A, Mgh, * Msb;) as also ↓ *afarapN, (K, TA,) or ↓ *uforapN: (so in the TT, as from the M:) a subst. to which it is prefixed, or an epithet by which it is qualified, shows whether it mean sweet or foul: (TA:) or any pungent, or strong, odour; whether sweet or stinking: (T:) or stench of the arm-pit: (Lh, M, K:) or it has this signification as well as the first: (S, M:) or stink, or stench, [absolutely,] (IAar, M, K,) except when relating to musk; not used with reference to any other perfume, or sweet-smelling substance: (IAar, M:) but dafarN, with the unpointed d, signifies only “ stink, or stench. ” (M.) ― -b3- The seminal fluid (maA=') of a stallion. (K.)

*afirN * (S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ A^a*ofaru (M, K) Having, or emitting, a pungent, or strong, odour, or smell; (S, * Msb;) or having, or emitting, a very pungent, or very strong, odour, or smell; (M, K;) whether sweet or stinking: (S, M, Msb:) or especially, (Lh, M, K,) or also, (S, M, A,) a man having stinking arm-pits, (S, M, A, K,) and a foul smell: (S, M, A:) fem. of the former, *afirapN; and of the latter, ↓ *aforaA='u: (M:) or *afirapN signifies a woman having a strong smell; whether sweet, like that of musk, or foul, like that of the arm-pits. (Msb.) You say ↓ misokN A^a*ovaru, (S, A, M, K,) and *afirN, (M, K,) Pungent, or strongscented, musk: (S, A:) or musk of the utmost excellence. (K.) And ↓ faA^orapN *aforaA='u [A pungent, or strong-scented, or] sweet-smelling [follicle, or vesicle, of musk]: Er-Rá'ee says, speaking of camels that had pastured upon herbage and its flowers, and gone to water, and come back from it with their skins moist and diffusing a sweet smell,
kul~a Ea$ay~apK ↓ lahaA faA^orapN *aforaA='u
kamaA fataqa AlkaAfuwra biA@lomisoki faAtiqupN
[They have an odour like that of a strong-scented vesicle of musk, every evening; as when one has imparted additional fragrance to camphire by mixing with it musk]. (T, M, TA.) One says also rawoDapN *afirapN (S, A) A sweet-smelling meadow. (TA.) And ↓ A_iboTN *aforaA='u A stinking arm-pit. (A.) And ↓ katiybapN *aforaA='u, (S, K,) or *aforaA='u Alr~aAy^iHapi, (A,) An army, or a collected portion thereof, or a troop of horse, having a foul smell from the rust of the arms or armour. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- *afirapN A certain plant, (K,) Which grows in the midst of herbage, little in quantity, of no account, growing in hard and level ground, upon a single root, having a yellow fruit, resembling the jaEodap in [the sweetness of] its odour. (TA.) ― -b3- And ↓ *aforaA='N A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (K,) which remains green until the cold smites it: [a coll. gen. n.; and with tenween; for] the n. un. is *aforaA='apN: (TA:) [but it is from *aforaA='N, fem. of A^a*ofaru:] a certain herb, of foul odour, which camels &c. scarcely ever eat: (Yaakoob, S:) or a certain tree, also called EiToru lA^amapi: or, accord. to AHn, a species of [the trees called] HamoD: or, as he says in another place, a certain green herb, which rises a span high, with round leaves, and with branches, having no flower; the odour of which is like that of a slight wind from the anus: it makes the breath of camels to stink; and they desire it eagerly: it is bitter; and grows in rugged places: and Abu-n-Nejm describes it as in meadows. (TA.) [Ruta sylvestris. (Golius, from Er-Rázee.)]

*afrapN *
A single emission of pungent, or strong, odour. (Msb.)
*uforapN * : see *afarN.
*afarapN * : see *afarN.

*iforaY * , without tenween, (S, K,) because the alif [written Y] is the characteristic of the fem. gender, (S,) and sometimes, (S, K,) more rarely, (Sb,) *iforFY, with tenween, (S, K,) when indeterminate, (S,) the alif in this case being considered as making the word quasi-coordinate to dirohamN (S, K,) The place that sweats, in the back of a camel's neck, behind the ear: (Lth, S:) or, in a man, (M,) and in any animal, the part extending from the maqad~ [or part between the two ears, erroneously written in the CK muqad~am,] to the half of the qa*aAl [or entire back of the head]: or the prominent bone behind the ear: (M, K:) or a bone in the upper part of a man's neck, on the right and left of the small hollow which is in the middle: (Sh:) or the *iforayaAni [which is the dual] are the two protuberances on the right and left of the small hollow in the middle of the back of the neck: (M:) it is from *afaru AlEaraqi [“ the pungency of the odour of sweat ”], because it is the first part that sweats in a camel: (S:) pl. *iforayaAtN and *afaAraY, (S, K,) and some say *afaArK. (S.)
*ifar~N * : see what next follows.

*iforaY * A camel large in the part called p: fem. with p: (AZ, S, K:) or a great camel: (AA:) or (so in the TA; but in the K, “ and ”) hard, or firm, and strong: as also ↓ *ifar~N: (K:) but the former (*ifir~N) is of higher authority: also applied to a camel; fem. with p: and in like manner to an ass: (TA:) or (so in the TA; but in the K, “ and ”) great in make: (K:) also a young man tall, perfect [in make], and hardy, strong, or sturdy: (S, K:) and *ifir~apN an excellent she-camel, (K,) long-necked: (TA:) and, accord. to the K, a bulky, or thick, ass: but this is at variance with what is found in other lexicons. (TA.)
A^a*ofaru * and *aforaA='u: see *afirN, in eight places.

rawoDapN ma*ofuwrapN *
A meadow abounding with *aforaA='. (K.) [See *afirN.]

1 *aqanahu * , (JK, S, A, K,) aor.
*aquna , (JK,) inf. n. *aqonN, (TK,) He struck his *aqan [or chin]: (JK, S, A, K:) or he struck him on the back of his neck, or on his head at the part next the back of the neck, with the inside of his hand; syn. qafadahu. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, faqadahu.]) And He struck him, or beat him, with a staff, or stick. (JK.) ― -b2- *aqana EalaY yadihi, (K,) or ElY EaSaAhu, (JK, K,) He put his *aqan [or chin] upon his hand, or upon his staff, or stick, (JK, K, TA,) and leaned [upon it]: (TA:) and *aqana bisawoTihi [He leaned his chin upon his whip]: (TA:) as also ↓ *aq~ana. (K.) -A2- *aqinati Ald~alowu, (JK, S, K,) aor.
*aqana , (JK, K,) inf. n. *aqanN, (JK,) The bucket was, or became, such as is termed *aquwnN (S, K) or *aqonaA='u. (JK.)
2 *aq~ana see the preceding paragraph.

3 *Aqnhu *
He straitened him. (K.)
4 A*qn * is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, to signify Opem tulit in tollenda re: but the word explained in the KL as signifying the doing this is the inf. n. of Azqn, not of A*qn.]
*iqonN * A decrepit, old and weak, or extremely aged, man. (K.)

*aqanN * [The chin;] the place where the laHoyaAnN [here meaning the two lateral portions of the lower jaw] combine, (JK, S, Msb, K,) at their lower part: (K:) it is of a man (S, Msb) [and of a beast]: also pronounced with kesr (ISd, K) to the * [i. e. ↓ *iqanN]: (TK:) of the masc. gender, (Lh, K,) only: (Lh, TA:) pl. A^a*oqaAnN, (Msb, K,)
a pl. of pauc.; and the pl. of mult. is *uquwnN. (Msb.) Hence, (K,) muvoqalN A@sotaEaAna bi*aqanihi [A heavily-burdened, or overburdened, camel sought to help himself to rise by means of his chin]: (S, M, K:) a prov., applied to a low, base, or mean, and weak man, who seeks to help himself by means of another man like himself; (S;) or to him who seeks to help himself by means of one who has no power of defending, and by means of one more low, base, or mean, and weak, than he: (M:) or to him who seeks to help himself by means of one less than he: (K:) originating from the fact that a camel laden with a heavy load, and unable to rise, bears with his chin upon the ground. (S, K.) You say also, xir~uwA liA^a*oqaAnihimo [They fell down prostrate, with their chins to the ground: see the Kur xvii. 108 and 109]: and [hence,] EaSafato riyHN faxar~ati AlA^a$ojaAru liloA^a*oqaAni (tropical:) [A wind blew violently, so that the trees fell, or bent themselves down to the ground]: (A in art. xr:) and hab~ti Alr~iyHu fakab~ati Al$~ajara EalaY A^a*oqaAnihaA (tropical:) [The wind blew, and overturned, or threw down, or bent down, the trees]: and, of a stone, kab~ahu Als~ayolu li*aqanihi (tropical:) The torrent overturned it. (TA.) ― -b2- The hair that grows upon the chin: used in this sense by the vulgar; and said by Esh-Shiháb El-Khafajee, in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel, ” to be post-classical: Z says, in the “ Rabeea el-Abrár, ” that it signifies the beard in the language of the Nabathæans. (TA.)
*iqanN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
*aqanaY * : see the paragraph next following.

*aquwnN * A she-camel that relaxes her chin [so as to make her lower lip hang down] in going along: (S, K:) or that moves about her head in going along: (JK:) or that stretches her steps, and moves about her head, by reason of strength, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, in going along: (A, TA:) pl. *uqunN: (TA:) and ↓ *aAqinapN, applied to a she-camel, signifies the same as *aquwnN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- dalowN *aquwnN (assumed tropical:) A bucket [of leather] which one has sewed in such a manner that its lip inclines on one side: (S, K:) or a large bucket inclining on one side: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ↓ *alowN *aqanaY a bucket with an inclining lip: (IB, TA:) and ↓ dalowN *aqonaA='u a bucket that has had an addition made to one of its two sides, and consequently inclines on one side. (JK.)

Al*~aAqinapu *
The part beneath the *aqan [or chin]: (K:) or the part, of the breast, that is reached by the *aqan: or the *aqan [itself]: (TA:) or the head of the Huloquwm [or windpipe]: (K:) or the prominent extremity of the Hlqwm: (S, K:) thus explained by A'Obeyd and AA in the saying of 'Áïsheh, “ [The Prophet died] between my HaAqinap and my *aAqinap: ” (TA: [see AlHaAqinapu:]) or the taroquw=p [ or collar-bone; or it may here mean the fore part of the throat, next the chest; or the uppermost part of the chest]: (K:) but this, in the M, is an explanation of AlHaAqinapu: (TA:) or the lower part of the belly, next the navel: (K:) but this, also, is given as an explanation of AlHAqnp, by ISd and by Z: (TA:) or the pit of the uppermost part of the breast, or chest: or the upper part of the belly: (K:) and the stomach: (JK:) pl. *awaAqinu. (S, TA.) [See also AlHaAqinapu.] Hence the prov., laA^uloHiqan~a HawaAqinaka ba*awaAqinika [explained in art. Hqn]: Al*~awaAqinu, accord. to Az, means the lower part of the belly. (S.) -A2- See also *aquwnN.

A^a*oqanN * A man long in the *aqan [or chin]: and so [the fem.] *aqonaA='u applied to a woman. (K.) ― -b2- And A man having the two sides of the mouth inclining, or wry. (JK.) ― -b3- And [hence, app.,] *aqonaA='u, (K, TA,) applied to a woman, by way of comparison, (TA,) (tropical:) Having the jahaAz [or pudendum] inclining, or wry. (K, TA.) ― -b4- dalowN *aqonaA='u: see *aquwnN.

1 *akarahu * , [aor.
*akura ,] inf. n. *ikoraY, (S, A, Msb,) which is fem., (Msb,) and imperfectly decl., (S,) and *ikorN (A, K) [and *ukorN, or, accord. to EtTebreezee, (Ham p. 26,) the latter of these two but not the former, or, as is said in the Msb., both are properly substs., and a distinction is made between them, as will be shown below,] and ta*okaArN, (K,) He preserved it in his memory: (K, * TA:) he remembered it; (S, A;) as also *akarahu biqalobihi [to distinguish it from *akara in a sense afterwards to be explained], (S, Msb,) and ↓ t*k~rhu; (S, A;) and ↓ Aid~akarahu (S, K, TA,) originally Ai*otakarahu (S,) and Ai*~akarahu (TA, and so in the CK,) and Ai*odakarahu (K,) and ↓ Ast*krhu, (AZ, K,) signify the same as t*k~rhu (K) [as explained above]: ↓ t*k~rhu signifies also he became reminded of it; (Msb;) [and so ↓ Ad~krhu and its variations: and ↓ Ast*krhu seems properly to signify, as also ↓ t*kr~hu, he recollected it; or called it to mind: and he sought to remember it: and ↓ Ast*kr and ↓ t*k~r used intransitively, he sought, or endeavoured, to remember.] You say, *akarotu Al$~aYo'a baEoda Aln~isoyaAni [I remembered the thing after forgetting]: (S:) and *akarotu AlmanosiY~a and ↓ ta*ak~arotuhu [I remembered the thing forgotten, and I became reminded of it, or I recollected it]: (A:) and baEoda A^amahK ↓ Ad~kr, occurring in the Kur [xii. 45, accord. to one reading of the last word], means He remembered [or became reminded] after forgetting. (S) And rabaTa fiY bihi HaAjatihi ↓ A_iSobaEihi xayoTFA yasota*okiru [He tied upon his finger a thread or string, seeking to remember, or recollect, or call to mind, thereby the thing that he wanted: such a thread or string is commonly called ratiymapN:]: (AZ:) and ↓ Ast*kr is used alone with the like signification [i. e. He sought to remember]: and also signifies He studied a book and preserved it in his memory, accord. to the K; but accord. to other lexicons, he studied a thing in order to remember it, or preserve it in his memory: (TA:) you say, bidiraAsatihi ↓ Ast*kr He sought to remember by his studying of a book. (A.) ― -b2- *akara Haq~ahu, (K,) inf. n. *ikorN (TA,) He was mindful of his right, or claim; and did not neglect it. (K.) Agreeably with this explanation, the words in the Kur [ii. 231, &c.,] waA@*okuruwA niEomapa A@ll~`hi Ealayokumo have been rendered And be ye mindful of, and neglect not to be thankful for, the favour of God conferred upon you: like as an Arab says to his companion, Au*okuro Haq~iYEalayoka Be thou mindful of my claim upon thee; and neglect it not. (TA.) ― -b3- [In like manner also are explained the words] waA@*okuruwA maA fiyhi in the Kur [ii. 60], And study ye what is in it, and forget it not: or think ye upon what is in it: or do ye what is in it. (Bd.) ― -b4- One says, maA A@somuka A^a*okuro, (Fs and Lb, and so in a copy of the K,) or A^a*okurohu, (so in another copy of the K, and in the TA,) the hemzeh of A^a*okuro being disjunctive, (Lb, K,) [in the CK we find maA Asmuka Aa*okirohu bqTEi Alhamozapi mino Aa*okar, as though the reading were A^a*okarohu with a disjunctive hemzeh from A^a*okara, which is manifestly wrong,] and with fet-h, because it is the hemzeh of the first person of a triliteral [unaugmented] verb, and with the r mejzoom, because it is the complement of an interrogative phrase: (Lb:) it is expressive of disapprobation, (Lb, K,) and means, Acquaint me with thy name: [or, lit., what is thy name?] I will remember it, or I will bear it in mind (A*krh): the conditional phrase [if thou tell it to me] is suppressed because unnecessary, on account of frequent usage of the saying, and because what remains is indicative of it: (Lb, MF:) the saying is a prov.; and is also related with the conjunctive hemzeh, [A@*okuro, or A@*okuro; in which case it is most appropriately rendered, What is thy name? Say: or Tell it] but the reading with the disjunctive hemzeh is that which is commonly known: (TA:) [for] -A2- *akarahu, aor.
*akura , (TA,) inf. n. *ikoraY, fem., [and imperfectly decl,] (Msb,) and *ikorN and *ukorN, (TA,) [or the former of these two (which is the most common of all) but not the latter, or, as is said in the Msb, both are properly substs., and a distinction is made between them, as will be shown below,] also signifies He mentioned it; told it; related it; said it; (TA;) and so *akarahu bilisaAnihi [to distinguish it from *akara in the first sense explained above]. (S, Msb.) You say *akarotu lifulaAnK Hadiyva ka*aAwaka*aA I mentioned, or told, or related, to such a one the story of such and such things. (TA.) And *akara A@moraA^u bimaA layosa fiyhi [He mentioned, or spoke of, a man as having that attribute which was not in him]. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer voce mano) ― -b2- And *akarahu (assumed tropical:) He magnified Him, namely, God; celebrated, lauded, or praised, Him; asserted his unity; (Zj;) [saying suboHaAna A@ll~`hi, and AlHamodu lil~`hi, and Aall~`hu A^akobaru; or laAA_ilaAha A_il~aAA@ll~`hu; or huwaA@ll~`hu; or the like.] ― -b3- [And, in like manner, (assumed tropical:) He spoke well of him, namely, a man; mentioned him with approbation; eulogized, praised, or commended, him: for *akarahu biAljamiyli, or bixayorK See *ikorN below.] ― -b4- Also, contr., [for *akarahu biAlqabiyHi or bi$ar~K] (assumed tropical:) He spoke evil of him; men-
tioned him with evil words; (Fr;) mentioned his vices, or faults; spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, saying of him what would grieve him if he heard it, but saying what was true; or merely said of him what would grieve him: an elliptical expression in this and in the contrary sense; what is meant being known. (Zj.) One says to a man, lay^ino *akarotaniY latanodaman~a, meaning [Verily, if thou mention me] with evil words [thou will assuredly repent]: and in like manner the verb is used in the Kur xxi. 37 and 61: and 'Antarah says,
laAta*okuriY farasiY wamaA A^aToEamotuhu
fayakuwna jiloduka mivola jilodi AlA^ajorabi
meaning Mention thou not reproachfully [my horse, and what I have given him for food, for, if thou do, thy skin will be like the skin of the scabby]: (Fr, T:) but AHeyth disallows this signification of the verb, and explains the saying of 'Antarah as meaning, Be not thou fond of mentioning my horse, and my preferring him before the family. (T, TA.) ― -b5- *akara fulaAnapa, inf. n *ikorN, [expressly said to be] with kesr, [so in the CK, and I think it the right reading,] or *akorN, [so in a MS. copy of the K, and in the TA,] with fet-h, [so in the TA,] He demanded such a one in marriage: or he addressed himself to demand her in marriage: (K:) [as though the mentioning a woman implied a desire to demand her in marriage:] it occurs in one of these two senses in a trad. (TA.) -A3- *akarahu, inf. n. *akorN, with fet-h, He struck him upon his penis. (K.)

2 *k~rhu A_iy~aAhu * , (S, A, * Msb, K,) and *k~rhu bihi, (Kur xiv. 5, &c.,) inf. n. ta*okirapN (A, TA) and ta*okiyrN, (K, TA,) and quasi-inf. n. ↓ *ikoraY imperfectly decl.; (A, * K, * TA;) and Ay~Ahu ↓ A*krhu; (S, Msb, K;) He reminded him of, or caused him to remember, him, or it. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And *k~r, (TA,) inf. n. ta*okiyrN (K) [and ta*okirapN also, as in the Kur xx. 2], He exhorted; admonished; exhorted to obedience; gave good advice, and reminded of the results of affairs; reminded of what might soften the heart, by the mention of rewards and punishments. (K, TA.) Thus the verb is used in the Kur lxxxviii. 21. (TA.) -A2- Also *k~rhu, inf. n. ta*okiyru, He made it (a word) masculine; contr. of A^an~avahu. (S, * Msb, K. *) ― -b2- In the Kur [ii. 282], fatu*ak~ira A_iHodaAhumaA AlA^uxoraY is said by some to signify (assumed tropical:) That one of them may make the other to be in the legal predicament of a male: [meaning that both of them together shall be as one man:] or, accord. to others, one of them may remind the other. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., fa*ak~iruwhu ↓ AlquroA=nu *akarN (tropical:) The Kur-án is eminently excellent [lit., masculine]: therefore do ye hold it and know it and describe it as such. (K, TA. [In the CK, for *akarN is put *ikorN.]) ― -b4- [Hence,] *k~rhu, (TA,) inf. n. ta*okiyrN, (K,) He put to it, namely a sword, (TA,) and the head of an axe &c., (K,) an edge of steel. (K, * TA.) [See *ukorapN.]
3 *Akrhu * , (MA,) inf. n. mu*aAkarapN, (KL;) He called to mind with him (MA, KL) a story, or discourse, or the like, (MA,) or a thing. (KL.) ― -b2- [And hence, He conferred with him.]

4 A^a*okara see 2. -A2- A*kr also signifies He (a man [or other]) begat a male. (TA from a trad.) And A*krt She (a woman, S, A, or other female, TA) brought forth a male, (S, A, K,) or males. (Mgh.) It is said in a prayer for a woman in labour, A^ayosarato waA^a*okarato May she have an easy birth, and may she bring forth a male child. (A.) And you say also, A*krt bihi (assumed tropical:) She brought him forth a male, and hardy: (TA from a trad.:) or a male, and sharp and cunning. (Mgh.)
5 ta*ak~ara see 1, in five places, in the first and second sentences. ― -b2- [Also It (a word) was, or became, or was made, of the masculine gender; contr. of tA^n~v.]

6 t*AkrwA *
They called to mind [a story, or discourse, or the like, or a thing,] one with another. (KL. [See 3.]) ― -b2- [And hence, They conferred together.]
8 Aid~akara * and Ai*~akara and Ai*odakara: see 1, in three places, in the first and second sentences.
10 A_isota*okara see 1, in six places, in the first and third sentences.
*akorN * : see *ikorN: -A2- and *akiyrN.

*ukorN * : see *ikorN, in six places. -A2- sayofN *uw *ukorK, or ↓ *ukurK, (as in different copies of the S,) and A^a*okirapK, [which is the pl.,] (A,) (tropical:) A cutting, or sharp, sword. (S, A.) [See *ukorapN.]

*ikorN * (Yoo, A'Obeyd, Yaakoob, S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ *ukorN, (Yoo, A'Obeyd, Yaakoob, S, A, Msb, K, TA,) or the latter only in the first of the senses here to be explained, (Fr, Msb, TA,) and the latter only is mentioned in this sense in the Fs, (TA,) and is said by El-Ahmar to be of the dial. of Kureysh, (TA,) [both said in the Msb to be simple substs., though many hold them to be inf. ns.,] and ↓ *akorN, accord. to one of the expositors of the Fs, but this is strange, (TA,) and ↓ *ikorapN (S, M) and ↓ *ukorapN (M, TA) and ↓ *ikoraY, (S, M, [see 1, first sentence,]) and also dikorN (S) and dukorN, mentioned by ISd as of the dial. of Rabee'ah, but held by him to be of weak authority, (TA,) Remembrance; (S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.;) the presence of a thing in the mind: (Er-Rághib:) also termed *ikorN biAlqalobi, (Msb, TA,) to distinguish it from *ikorN in another sense, to be explained below: (TA:) he pl. of ↓ *ikorapN is *ikarN, (M,) also said to be pl. of ↓ *ikoraY. (MF, art. AHd.) You say, ↓ AijoEalohu minoka EalaY *ukorK and *ikorK in the same sense, Place thou him, or it, in thy remembrance. (S.) And A^ajoEalahu min~iY ↓ EalaY *ukorK, and *ikorK, I will not forget him, or it. (A.) And ↓ maA zaAla min~iY EalaY *ukorK, and *ikorK (K,) or the former only, (Fr, Msb, TA,) He, or it, did not cease to be in my remembrance; (K;) I did not forget him, or it. (Fr, TA.) And ↓ A^anota min~iY EalaY *ukorK Thou art in my mind. (ISd, Lb.) ― -b2- The words in the Kur [xxix. 44] wala*ikoru A@ll~`hi A^akobaru admit of two explanations: The remembrance of God is better for a man than a man's remembrance of a man: and the remembrance of God is better as more efficacious in forbidding evil conduct than is prayer. (TA.) ― -b3- *ikorN also signifies Memory; a certain quality of the mind, by which a man is able to remember what he cares to know; like HifuZN, except that this latter term is used with regard to the preservation of a thing [in the mind], whereas the former is used with regard to calling it to mind. (Er-Rághib.) -A2- Also *ikorN (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA) and ↓ *ukorN, (Msb, TA,) or the former only accord. to Fr, (Msb, TA,) and ↓ *ikoraY (Msb,) The mention, telling, relating, or saying, of a thing: said by some to be contr. of SamotN: (TA:) and also termed *ikorN biAll~isaAni (Msb, TA,) to distinguish it from *ikorN in the sense first explained above. (TA.) ― -b2- Also *ikorN (assumed tropical:) The praise, and glorification, of God; the celebration, or declaration, of his remoteness, or freedom, from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; or the saying suboHaAna, A@ll~`hi, [and AlHamodu lil~`hi, and A^all~`hu A^akobaru,] and laA A_ilaAha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu, [&c., see 1,] and uttering all the forms of his praise: a reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án: a thanking [God]: obedience [to God]: (Abu-l- 'Abbás:) prayer to God; (K;) supplication. (Abu-l-'Abbás, K.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Praise, or eulogy, or good speech, of another. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b4- [And, accord. to some, (tropical:) Dispraise, or evil speech. See 1.] ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) A thing that is current upon the tongue. (K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Fame; renown; report; reputation; (S, A, K;) whether good or evil; (ISd;) as also ↓ *ukorapN. (AZ, ISd, K.) Thus in the saying, lahu *ikorN fiY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) He has fame among the people: in which it has also the signification next following. (A.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Eminence; nobility; honour. (S, A, Msb, K.) So in the Kur [xciv. 4], warafaEonaA laka *ikoraka (tropical:) And We have raised for thee thine eminence, or thy nobility, or thine honour: as some say, it means, when I am mentioned, thou art mentioned with Me: and again, in the Kur [xliii. 43], wa A_in~ahu la*ikorN laka wa liqawomika (tropical:) And verily it (the Kur-án) is an honour to thee and to thy people. (TA.) Also, in the Kur [xxxviii. 1], wa AlquroA=ni *iY Al*~ikori (tropical:) By the Kur-án possessed of eminence, &c. (S) ― -b8- Also (assumed tropical:) A book containing an exposition of religion, and an institution of religious laws: (K:) any book of the prophets: (TA:) and especially the Kur-án: (MF, TA:) and the taworaApN [or Book of the Law revealed to Moses]: (Aboo-Hureyreh, TA in art. zbr:) and that [law] which is [recorded] in heaven. (Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, TA ubi suprà.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) An exhortation; an admonition, or a warning. (Bd in xxxviii. 1.) ― -b10- *ikoru Haq~K (tropical:) A written obligation; syn. Sak~N: (A, K:) pl. *ukuwru Haq~K, (A,) or *ukuwru HuquwqK. (TA.) You say, liY EalaY h`*aA AlA^amori *ikoru Haq~K (tropical:) [I have a written obligation to insure this thing]. (A.) -A3- See also the next paragraph, in the latter half.

*akarN * [probably originally signifying “ mentioned, ” or “ talked of, ” of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN in the
sense of manofuwDN, and xabaTN in the sense of maxobuwTN, and qabaDN in the sense of maqobuwDN, &c.; and hence the first, and perhaps most others, of the significations here following:] Male; masculine; of the male, or masculine, sex, or gender; contr. of A^unovaY: (S, A, Msb, K, &c.:) [the corresponding word in Hebrew () has been supposed to have this signification because a male is much “ mentioned, ” or “ talked of; ” and it is well known that the Arabs make comparatively little account of a female:] pl. *ukuwrN (S, A, Msb, K) and *ukuwrapN (A, Msb, K) and *ikaArN (K) and *ikaArapN and *ukoraAnN (S, A, Msb, K) and *ikarapN: (S, K:) [the last, in one copy of the S, I find written ↓ *ikorapN, which, if correct, is a pl. of pauc.: and in the TA, in the same phrase in which it occurs in the S, it is written ↓ *ukorapN, and expressly said to be with damm, so that it is a quasi-pl. n.:] the pl. form with w and n is not allowable. (Msb.) One says, kami Al*~ikarapu mino waladika, or ↓ Al*~ikorapu, (accord. to different copies of the S,) or ↓ Al*~ukorapu, with damm, (accord. to the TA,) How many are the males of thy children? (S, TA.) ― -b2- The male organ of generation; the penis; syn. EawofN; (S, K, &c.;) of a man: (TA:) or the faroj [an equivocal term, but here evidently used in the above-mentioned sense,] of an animal: (Msb:) pl. *ukuwrN, (K,) or *ikarapN, like EinabapN, (Msb,) or *ikaArapN, (T, TA,) and ↓ ma*aAkiyru: (S, Msb, K:) the last contr. to analogy, (S, Msb,) as though used for the sake of distinction between this signification and the one immediately preceding: (S:) or of the same class as maHaAsinu [with respect to HusonN] and malaAmiHu [with respect to lamoHapN]: (ISd:) Akh says that it is a pl. without a [proper] sing., like EabaAbiydu and A^abaAbiylu: accord. to the T, it has no sing.; or if it have a sing., it is ↓ mu*okirN, like muqodimN, of which the pl. is maqaAdiymu; and signifies the parts next to the penis: (TA:) or it signifies the penis with what is around it; [or the genitals;] and is similar to mafaAriqu in the phrase $aAbato mafaAriqu raA^osihi: and qaTaEa ma*aAkiyrahu signified He extirpated his penis. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Applied to a man, (A, K,) it also signifies (tropical:) Strong; courageous; acute and ardent; vigorous and effective in affairs; [and also] stubborn; and disdainful: (TA:) or [masculine, meaning] perfect; like as A^unovaY is applied to a woman. (T and A in art. Anv.) The signification of “ strong, courageous, and stubborn, ” and the significations which the same word has when applied to rain and to a saying, are assigned in the K to ↓ *ikorN; but [SM says,] I know not how this is; for in the other lexicons they are assigned to *akarN. (TA.) You say, laA yafoEaluhu A_il~aA *ukuwrapu Alr~ijaAli (tropical:) [None will do it but such as are strong, &c., of men]. (A.) ― -b4- Applied to iron, (tropical:) Of the toughest and best quality, (K,) and strongest; (TA;) contr. of A^aniyvN; (S;) [iron converted into steel;] as also ↓ *akiyrN. (K.) [See also *ukorapN.] ― -b5- Applied to a sword, (tropical:) Having maA=' [i. e., diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain]; (S;) as also ↓ mu*~ak~arN: (S, K:) or of which the edge is of steel (HadiydN *akarN) and the maton [or middle of the broad side] of soft iron; of which the people say that they are of the fabric of the Jinn, or Genii: (A'Obeyd, S:) or ↓ mu*ak~aru signifies having a sharp iron blade or edge: (As:) the pl. of the former is *ukuwrN. (Ham p. 168.) ― -b6- *ukuwru Albuquwli (tropical:) Herbs, or leguminous plants, that are hard and thick: (TA voce Eu$obN:) or that are thick, and inclining to bitterness: (S, TA:) like as A^aHoraAruhaA signifies such as are slender and sweet: (TA:) or the former signifies such as are thick and rough. (AHeyth.) ― -b7- *ukuwrapu AlT~iybi, (K,) and *ukuwruhu, and *ikaAratuhu, (TA,) (tropical:) Perfume proper for men, exclusively of women: i. e., (TA,) that leaves no stain; (K, * TA;) that becomes dissipated; such as musk, and aloes-wood, and camphire, and gaAliyap, and *ariyrap. (TA.) [See the contr., TiybN muw^an~avN, in art. Anv.] ― -b8- *akarN applied to the Kur-án signifies (tropical:) Eminently excellent. (K.) See 2. ― -b9- Applied to a saying, (tropical:) Strong and firm: and in like manner to poetry. (A.) ― -b10- The Arabs disliked a she-camel's bringing forth a male; and hence they applied the term *akarN, met., to (tropical:) Anything disliked. (A.) ― -b11- [Thus,] applied to rain, it signifies (tropical:) Violent; (A, K;) falling in large drops. (K.) They said, A^aSaAbati AlA^aroDa *ukuwru AlA^asomiyapi (tropical:) Rains bringing intense cold and torrents fell upon the earth. (A.) ― -b12- Applied to a day, (tropical:) [Severe; distressing; hard to be borne: see also mu*ak~arN]. (A.) ― -b13- IDrd says, I think that the name Al*kr [so in the TA, without any syll. signs; app. Al*~akaru] is applied by some of the Arabs to Als~imaAku Alr~aAmiHu [or the star Arcturus]. (TA.)
*akurN * : see *akiyrN.
*akirN * : see *akiyrN.
sayofN *uw *ukurK * : see *ukorN.
*akorapN * : see mu*ak~arN.

*ukorapN * : see *ikorN, in two places: -A2- and *akarN, in two places. -A3- Also (tropical:) A piece of steel that is added [to the edge of a sword and] to the head of an axe &c. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) Sharpness of a sword: [see also *ukorN:] and of a man. (S, A, K.) You say, *ahabato *ukorapu Als~ayofi, and *ukorapu Alr~ajuli, (tropical:) The sharpness of the sword, and the sharpness of the man, went. (S, A.)
*ikorapN * : see *ikorN, in two places: -A2- and *akarN, in two places.
*akarapN * : see mu*ak~arN.
*akirapN * : see mu*ak~arN.

*ikoraY * : see *ikorN, in three places. ― -b2- Remembrance with the reception of exhortation: so in the following passage of the Kur [xlvii. 20], faA^an~aY lahumo A_i*aA jaA='atohumo *ikoraAhumo [Then how, that is, of what avail, will be to them their remembrance with the reception of exhortation when it (the hour of the resurrection) cometh to them: or] how will it be to them when it (the hour) cometh to them with their remembrance and their reception of exhortation: (K, * TA:) i. e., this will not profit them. (TA.) ― -b3- Repentance: so in the Kur [lxxxix. 24], waA^an~aY lahu Al*~ikoraY, i. e. And how shall he have repentance? (K, TA.) ― -b4- A reminding, or causing to remember: so in the Kur viii. 1, and xi. 121, (K,) and li. 55. (Fr.) See 2. ― -b5- An admonition: so in the Kur xxxviii. 42, and xl. 56. (K.) ― -b6- A being reminded, or caused to remember: so in the Kur [xxxviii. 46], in the phrase *ikoraY Ald~aAri Their being reminded of, or caused to remember, the latter abode, and being made to relinquish worldly things, or not to desire them: (K:) or it may mean their remembering much the latter abode. (B, TA.)

*akiyrN * A man possessing an excellent memory. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (AZ, K,) and ↓ *akorN, (accord. to a MS. copy of the K, and so, as is said in the TA, accord. to the method of the author of the K,) or ↓ *akirN, (accord. to the CK,) and ↓ *akurN and ↓ *ik~iyrN, (K,) (tropical:) A man possessing *ikor, (K,) i. e., fame, or renown: or glory, or boastfulness. (TA.) -A2- See also *akarN, in the latter half of the paragraph.
*ik~iyrN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
*uk~aArapN * The males of palm-trees. (K.)
*aAkirN * [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- maA Halafotu bihi *aAkirFA walaA A=virFA: see art. Avr.

A^a*okaru * (tropical:) More, and most, sharp, (S, TA,) acute and ardent, vigorous and effective in affairs. (TA.) Mohammad used to go round to his wives in one night, and to perform the ablution termed gusol for his visit to every one of them; and being asked wherefore he did so, he answered, A_in~ahu A^a*okaru (tropical:) It is more, or most, sharp [or effective]; syn. A^aHad~u. (S, TA, from a trad.) And it was said to Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, when he was prostrated, waA@ll~`hi maA waladati Aln~isaA='u A^a*okara minoka (tropical:) By God, women have not brought forth one more acute and ardent and vigorous and effective in affairs than thou. (TA from a trad.)

ta*okirapN * an inf. n. of 2. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] A thing by means of which something that one wants [or desires to remember] is called to mind; a memorandum. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- [A biographical memoir. ― -b4- And, in the present day, Any official note; such as a passport; a permit; and the like.]

ma*okarN *
A place of remembrance: pl. ma*aAkiru: whence Alma*aAkiru in a trad., app. meaning The black corner or stone [of the Kaabeh]. (TA.)
mu*okarN * : see its fem., with p, voce mu*ak~arN.

mu*okirN * A woman [or other female (see 4)] bringing forth a male: (S, K:) or a woman that brings forth men-children. (TA in art. rjl.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A desert that produces herbs, or leguminous plants, of the kind called *ukuwr. (As. [See *akarN: and see also mi*okaArN.]) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A road that is feared. (A, K.) ― -b4- See also ma*ak~arN, in two places. ― -b5- And see *akarN, in the former half of the paragraph.

mu*ak~arN * [A masculine word; a word made mas-
culine]. ― -b2- mu*ak~arapN A she-camel resembling a hecamel in make and in disposition. (S.) And also, (K, TA,) or ↓ mu*okarapN, (accord. to the CK,) A woman who makes herself like a male; (K;) as also ↓ *akarapN, (L, and so in a copy of the K,) or ↓ *akirapN, (so in another copy of the K, and in the TA,) or ↓ *akorapN, (so in the CK,) and ↓ muta*ak~irapN. (K.) ― -b3- mu*ak~arapu Alv~unoyaA A she-camel having a large head, (K, TA,) like that of a he-camel: (TA:) because her head is one of the parts that are excepted in the game of chance [called Almayosir] for the man who has sold her: [therefore those parts are termed Alv~unoyaA:] (K:) or resembling the make of the male in [the largeness of] the head and legs. (Th, M in art. vnY.) ― -b4- And yawomN mu*ak~arN (tropical:) A day that is severe, distressing, or hard to be borne; as also ↓ mu*okirN: (K, TA:) or in which a severe fight, or slaughter, has taken place. (A, TA.) [See also *akarN, last sentence but one.] ― -b5- And daAhiyapN mu*ak~arapN (tropical:) A severe calamity or misfortune; (A, K;) and so ↓ mu*okirN [without p because it is from this epithet applied to a she-camel as meaning "bringing forth a male;" for her doing so was disliked, as has been mentioned voce *akarN]: (K:) or the latter means which none can withstand but strong, courageous, stubborn men. (TA.) -A2- See also *akarN, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

mi*okaArN * A woman [or other female] that usually brings forth males. (S, K.) And A man who usually begets male children. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Land that produces herbs, or leguminous plants, such as are termed *ukuwr: (A, TA: [see mu*okirN, and *akarN:]) or that does not produce [anything]: but the former signification is the more common. (TA.) ― -b3- And falaApN mi*okaArN (tropical:) A terrible desert; (As, A, K;) that is not traversed but by strong, courageous, stubborn men. (As, K.)

ma*okuwrN * [pass. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man praised, or spoken of well. (TA.) ― -b3- lamo yakuno $ayoy^FA ma*okuwrFA, in the Kur [lxxvi. 1], means [accord. to some] When he was not a thing existing by itself, though existing in the knowledge of God. (TA.)
ma*aAkiyru * said to be an anomalous pl. of *akarN in a sense pointed out above: see the latter word. (S, Msb, K. *)
muta*ak~rapN * : see mu*ak~arN.

1 *akati Aln~aAru * , (S, K, &c.,) aor. ta*okuw, (S,) inf. n. *akFA (S, Mgh, K, &c.) and *akaA='N accord. to Z (K) and *ukuw~N, (M, K, TA,) like Euluw~N; (TA; [accord. to the CK *akowN; and so accord. to the MA, as well as *ukuw~N and *akFA;]) and ↓ Ast*kt; (K;) The fire blazed, or flamed; burned up; or burned brightly or fiercely: (S:) or blazed, or flamed, vehemently, or intensely: (K:) or blazed, flamed, or burned up, completely; agreeably with the primary signification of the root, which is “ completeness. ” (Mgh.) ― -b2- *akaA Almisoku The mush gave forth odour, or fragrance; (MA;) [or a strong, or pungent, odour; for] the primary signification of *akFA in relation to odour is the being strong, [or pungent,] in sweetness or in fetidness. (TA.) ― -b3- *akiYa, aor. ya*okaY; (S, Msb, K) and *akaA, (Msb, K,) aor. ya*okaY, (K,) or ya*okuw; (Msb;) and *akuwa, (MA, K,) aor. ya*okuw; (K;) all three mentioned by ISd; (TA;) inf. n. *akaA='; (S, MA, K, * TA; [in my copy of the Msb, the inf. n. of the first is said to be *akFY; but this is app. a mistranscription; or the author perhaps held *akFY, more properly written *akFA, to be the inf. n.; for he says that *akiYa is of the class of taEiba, of which the inf. n. is taEabN, and afterwards mentions *akaA='u as though he held this to be a simple subst.;]) said of a man, (S, Msb,) He was, or became, sharp, or acute, in mind, (S, TA,) with quickness of perception, and of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (TA:) or quick of understanding, (Msb, K,) or intelligence, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (K:) or quick of perception, and sharp, or acute, in understanding: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or quick in drawing conclusions. (TA. [See *akaA='u, below.]) [Also, app., said of a camel, and the like, meaning He was, or became, sharp in spirit. See *akiY~N.] -A2- [*akaA seems to have been also used by some as meaning He (a beast) was, or became, legalty slaughtered; and consequently, legally clean: or to have been supposed to have this signification. ― -b2- And hence,] A^ay~umaA A^aroDK jaf~ato faqado *akato means (assumed tropical:) Whatever ground has become dry, it has become clean, or pure: but [Mtr, after mentioning this, adds,] I have not found it in the lexicons. (Mgh. [See also *akaApN, below.])

2 *k~Y Aln~aAra * , (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. ta*okiyapN, (S, TA,) He made the fire to blaze or flame, to burn up, or to burn brightly or fiercely; (T, S, K;) as also ↓ A*kAhA: (S, K:) or he supplied the fire fully with fuel: (Msb, TA:) and Als~iraAja ↓ A*kY He lighted the lamp. (Har p. 53.) ― -b2- [*k~Y AlEaqola, and *k~Y alone, said of a medicine &c., It sharpened the intellect.] -A2- *k~Y, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He slaughtered (S, Mgh, Msb, K) an animal, (Mgh,) or a camel and the like, (Msb,) in the manner [prescribed by the law,] termed *aboHN, (S, Mgh, K,) i. e., (Mgh, K,) in the manner termed *akaApN [q. v. infrà]. (Mgh, Msb, K.) The proper signification of Alt~a*okiyapu is The causing the natural heat to pass forth: but it is peculiarly applied in the law to signify the destroying of life in a particular manner, exclusive of any other manner. (Er-Rághib, TA.) A_il~aA maA *ak~ayotumo, in the Kur [v. 4], means Except that whereof ye shall attain to the *akaAp [or slaughter in the manner prescribed by the law] (Bd, Msb, TA) said of a man, (S,) He became old, or advanced in age, (S, K,) and big-bodied, or corpulent: (K:) [or he attained to full growth or age: said of a man, and of a horse and the like:] see *akaA='N, last sentence. [See also mu*ak~K, below.])
4 A^a*okawa see 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] A^a*okayotu AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) I kindled war. (TA.) ― -b3- A^a*okayotu Ealayohi AlEuyuwna I sent against him the scouts. (S.)
10 A_isota*okawa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Ast*kY AlfaHolu EalaY AlA^unovaY (assumed tropical:) The stallion pressed vehemently upon the female. (TA.)
*akFA * an inf. n. of 1; The blazing, or flaming, &c., of fire. (S, K, &c. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- See also *ukowapN. -A2- And see *akaApN.
*akK * a possessive epithet: (ISd, TA:) you say naArN *akiyapN, (K, TA,) without teshdeed, (TA, [in the CK *akiy~apN,]) A fire blazing, or flaming, &c. (K, TA.)

*akaApN * : see *ukowapN. -A2- [Also] a subst. (Mgh, Msb, TA) syn. with ta*okiyapN (Mgh, Msb, K, TA) as signifying *aboHN [i. e. The slaughter of an animal for food in the manner prescribed by the law]; (Mgh, K, TA;) as also ↓ *akFA, (K, TA, [in the CK *akA',) which is likewise said to be a simple subst.: (TA: [in the TK, *akFA and *akaApN are both said to be inf. ns., of which the verb is *akaA, signifying *abaHa; but this I do not find in any lexicon of authority:]) it is satisfactorily performed by the severing of the windpipe and gullet, as is related on the authority of Ahmad [Ibn- Hambal], or, as is also related on his authority, by severing them an also the wadajaAni, [or two external jugular veins], less than which is not lawful; or, accord to A boo-Haneefeh, the severing of the windpipe and gullet and one of the wdjAn; or, accord. to Málik, the severing of the A^awadaAj [or external jugular veins] though it be without the severing of the windpipe. (Msb.) The saying *akaApu Aljaniyni *akaApu A^um~ihi is for *akaApu Aljaniyni hiYa *akaApu A^um~ihi [The legal slaughter of the fœtus, or young in the belly, it is the legal slaughter of its mother]: (Msb, TA:) or it is an instance of the transposition of the inchoative and enunciative, (Mgh, Msb,) its implied meaning being *akaApu A^um~i Aljaniyni *akaApN lahu [The legal slaughter of the mother of the fœtus, or young in the belly, is a legal slaughter of it also; so that the latter, like the former, may be lawfully eaten]; (Msb;) i. e., when she is legally slaughtered, it is legally slaughtered: (TA:) the use of the accus. case (Mgh, TA) in the like thereof, (Mgh,) [or] in the phrase *kAp Am~h, [i. e., the saying *akaApa A^um~ihi,] is a mistake. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying of Mohammad Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, *akaApu AlA^aroDi yubosuhuA (assumed tropical:) [The cleanness, or purity, of the ground is its becoming dry]; i. e., when it becomes dry from the moisture of uncleanness, it becomes clean, like as a beast becomes clean by means of legal slaughter. (Mgh. [See also 1, last sentence.])

*ukowapN * , (T, TA, &c.,) with damm, not *akowapN as the text of the K indicates it to be (TA) [and as it is written in the copies thereof], and *ukoyapN, (S, TA,) also with damm, (TA,) [in the copies of the K *akoyap,] What is thrown upon the fire, (T, S, K, *) of firewood, or of camel's or similar dung, (T,) to make it blaze, or flame, or burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also
the former, A blazing, or flaming, coal of fire; and so ↓ *akFA, (K, TA,) with the short A, on the authority of IDrd; [in the CK *akaA';] or, as in the M, ↓ *akaApN. (TA.)

*akowaAnN *
A kind of trees: n. un. with p: (IAar, TA:) the pl. of the latter is *akaAwiynu, and signifies small [trees of the kind called] saroH [q. v.]. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, Als~aroj is erroneously put for Als~aroH.])

*akaA='u *
Sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, (S, Msb, TA,) with quickness of perception, and of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (TA:) or completeness of intelligence, with quickness of apprehension: (Msb:) or quickness of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge: (K:) or quickness of perception, and sharpness, or acuteness, of understanding: thus applied, it is like the phrase fulaAnN $uEolapu naArK: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or quickness in drawing conclusions. (TA. [See *ihonN: and see also 1.]) [It app. signifies also Sharpness of spirit; as a quality of a camel and the like. See *akiY~N.] ― -b2- Also Age: (S, K:) or full, or complete, age: so says Mbr in the “ Kámil: ” (TA:) contr. of fataA='N: (Ham p. 217:) accord. to Az, its primary signification, universally, is a state of completeness: and Al*~akaA='u fiY Als~in~ means completeness of age: accord. to Kh, it means the age of completeness of strength, [app. in a horse, or any solid-hoofed animal, for he says that it is] when a year has passed after the quruwH [or finishing of teething]: (TA:) or *akaA='u Als~in~i means the utmost term of youthfulness; from the primary signification of the root, which is “ a state of completeness. ” (Mgh.) Hence the saying of El-Hajjáj, furirotu Eano *akaA='K [I have been examined as to age; app. meaning (assumed tropical:) my abilities have been tested and proved]: and balagati Ald~aAb~apu Al*~akaA='a The beast attained to [fulness of] age (S, TA.) [Hence, also,] one says, fataA= fulaAnK ka*akaA='i fulaAnK and fulaAnK ↓ kata*okiyapi [The youthfulness of such a one is like the fulness of age of such a one], i. e., the prudence, or discretion, of such a one notwithstanding his deficiency of age is like the prudence, or discretion, of such a one with his fulness of age. (Ham p. 217.)

*ukaA='u * , imperfectly decl., The sun: (S, K:) determinate, and not admitting the article Al: you say, h`*ihi *ukaA='u TaAliEapN [This is the sun rising]: (S:) derived from *akati Aln~aAru. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aibonu *ukaA='a The dawn, or daybreak: (S, K:) because it is from the light of the sun. (S.) Homeyd says, [or, accord. to some, Besheer Ibn-En-Nikth, as in one of my copies of the S, in art. kfr,]
fawaradato qabola A@nobilaAji Alfajori
waA@bonu *ukaA='a kaAminN fiY Alkafori
[And she, or they, came to the water before the bright shining of the daybreak, while the dawn lay kid in the darkness of night]. (S.)

*akiY~N * , applied to musk, and so *akiy~apN, (K, TA,) for misokN, as is said by IAmb, is both masc. and fem., and so is EanobarN, (TA,) and ↓ *aAkK, Diffusing odour: (K:) or having a strong [or pungent] odour. (TA. [See 1, second sentence.]) You say also raAy^iHapN *akiy~apN A sharp [or pungent, or a strong,] odour [whether sweet or fetid]; syn. HaAd~apN. (K in art. Hd.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, Having the attribute, or quality, termed *akaA=', (S, Msb, K,) as meaning sharpness, or acuteness, (S, Msb,) or quickness, (K,) of mind, (S, Msb,) or of intel-ligence, &c.: (K, TA, &c.:) pl. A^a*okiyaA='u. (Msb, TA.) It is also, sometimes, applied to a camel [or the like, as meaning Sharp in spirit: see fuw^aAdN]. (TA.) -A2- Also i. q. *abiyHN [meaning Slaughtered in the manner prescribed by the law, termed *aboHN and *akaApN]: (K:) it is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) and [therefore] you say $aApN *akiY~N, meaning [a sheep, or goat, slaughtered in the manner above mentioned; and also,] to whose *akaAp [or slaughter in that manner] one has attained [while life yet remained therein: see 2]: (Mgh, Msb:) *akiy~apN [as its fem.] is extr. [like *abiyHapN]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, jilodN *akiY~N (tropical:) A skin stripped from an animal that has been slaughtered in the manner mentioned above. (Mgh.)
*aAkK * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mu*okK * ; and the fem., mu*okiyapN: see the following paragraph, in three places.

mu*ak~K * , applied to a man, (TA,) Old, or advanced in age, and big-bodied, or corpulent: (K, TA:) [or full-grown, or of full age: see *akaA='N:] or an old man, but only such as is much experienced and disciplined: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and accord. to ISd, anything [i. e. any animal] old, or advanced in age: by some especially applied to a solid-hoofed animal; and said to mean one that has passed the quruwH [or finishing of teething] by a year: (TA:) or ma*aAkK, (S, K, TA,) which is its pl., (S, TA,) [(like as mu*ak~iyaAtN is pl. of the fem.,) and also pl. of its syn. ↓ mu*okK,] signifies, applied to horses, (S, K, TA,) of generous race, advanced in age, (TA,) that have passed a year, or two years, after their quruwH: (S, K, TA:) the sing. is like muxolifN applied to a camel: (S, TA:) or mu*ak~K signifies a horse of full age and of complete strength; as also ↓ mu*okK: (Ham p. 217:) or a horse whose run becomes spent (ya*ohibu), and [then, but not before he has exhausted his power,] stops. (TA.) It is said in a prov., jaroYu Almu*ak~iyaAtu gilaAbN [The running of the horses that have attained to their full age and strength is a contending for superiority]: (Meyd, and so in some copies of the S:) it may mean that the horse in this case contends for superiority with him that runs with him; or that his second run is always more than his first, and his third than his second: (Meyd:) or, as some relate it, gilaA='N; (Meyd, and so in other copies of the S in this art., and in the S and K in art glw;) meaning that the running of such horses is several bowshots: (Meyd, and S and K in art. glw:) it is applied to him who is described as entering into contests for excellence with his compeers. (Meyd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ saHaAbapN mu*okiyapN, (K,) or, as in the Tekmileh, mu*ak~iyapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A cloud that has rained time after time. (K, TA.)

div2.head: Quasi *kY
div2.entryFree: *ukoyapN * : see *ukowapN, in art. *kw.
*akiY~N * : see art. *kw,

1 *al~a * , aor. ya*il~u, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. *ul~N and *il~apN and ma*al~apN, (S, * M, MA, K,) or these three are simple substs., and the inf. n. is *al~N, (Msb,) and *alaAlapN (M, K) and *ulaAlapN, (K,) [contr. of Eaz~a; (see *ul~N below;) i. e.] He, or it, was or became, low, base, vile, abject, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, ignominious, inglorious, abased, humble, and weak; (MA, Msb, K;) syn. haAna, (Msb, K,) and DaEufa. (Msb.) ― -b2- *al~a, (M, K,) and *al~ato, (M, Msb,) aor. as above, (M, K,) inf. n. *il~N, (M, Msb, K,) said of a man, (M,) and of a beast, such as a horse and the like, (daAb~ap, M, Msb,) He, or it, was, or became, easy, tractable, submissive, or manageable; (M, Msb, K;) and Ai*olawolaY [which belongs to art. *lY] signifies the same as *al~a in this sense. (ISd, TA.) And lahu ↓ t*l~l He became lowly, humble, or submissive, [or he lowered, humbled, or submitted, himself,] to him; (S, TA;) as also ta*al~aY, originally ta*al~ala. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] *al~a is also said of a road [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, beaten, or trodden, so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride upon: see *aliylN]. (A in art. tb.) ― -b4- And *al~ati AlqawaA fiY li$~aAEiri (assumed tropical:) The rhymes were easy to the poet. (T.) ― -b5- And *al~a said of a watering-trough or tank, (TA,) or of the upper part thereof, (M,) (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, broken much, or in several places, in its edge, and much demolished. (M, TA.)

2 *l~l * , (M, Msb,) inf. n. ta*oliylN, (Msb,) He made, or rendered, (M, Msb,) a man, (M,) and a beast, such as a horse and the like, (M, Msb,) easy, tractable, submissive, or manageable: (M, Msb:) [said of the former, it may be rendered he brought under, or into, subjection; or he subdued: and said of the latter, he broke, or trained: and said of any animal, he tamed. ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) He beat, or trod, a road, so as to render it even, or easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride upon: see *aliylN.] ― -b3- And *l~l lahu A^amorFA (assumed tropical:) He made an affair easy to him; syn. raw~aDahu and saw~asahu. (TA in art. sws.) ― -b4- And *il~ila Alkaromu (assumed tropical:) The bunches of the grape-vine were made to hang down [so that they might be easily plucked]: (M, K:) or were evenly disposed [for the same purpose]; syn. suw~iyato: (K:) or, accord. to AHn, Alt~a*oliylu signifies the disposing evenly the bunches
of the grape-vine, and making them to hang down. (M.) wa*ul~ilato quTuwfuhaA, in the Kur [lxxvi. 14], means (assumed tropical:) The bunches being evenly disposed, and made to hang down, (S, JM,) exposed to be plucked: (JM:) or being well disposed, and made near: (IAmb, TA:) or being within the reach of the seeker, or desirer: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or being easy to reach by those who will pluck them, in whatever manner they may desire to do so: (Bd:) accord. to Mujáhid, it means that if one stand, the bunch will rise to him; and if one sit, it will hang down to him. (TA.) [In like manner,] Alt~a*oliylu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The putting the raceme of the palm-tree upon the branch [near it] in order that it [the branch] may support it: (AHn, M:) or ta*oliylu AlEu*uwqi, as practised in the present world, is (assumed tropical:) the trimmer's making straight, and fecundating before the usual time, the racemes of the palm-tree, when they come forth from their spathes that covered them, these having slit open and disclosed them, by which means one makes them to hang out from among the branches and prickles, so that the fruit is easily plucked when it ripens. (T. [See also mu*al~alN.]) [Hence it is said in the K that *ul~ila Aln~axolu signifies wuDiEa Ei*oquhaA EalaY Aljariydapi litaHomilahu: the explanation should be wuDiEato Eu*uwquhaA EalaY Aljariydi litaHomilahaA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees had their racemes put upon the branches in order that these might support them.] ― -b5- See also what next follows.

4 A*l~hu * , (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i*olaAlN, (TA,) He (God, Msb) lowered, abased, or humbled, him; or rendered him low, base, vile, abject, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, ignominious, inglorious, abased, humbled, and weak; (M, * Msb K, TA;) as also ↓ *ll~`hu and ↓ Ast*l~hu: (K, TA:) all these signify the same. (S.) ― -b2- See also 10 -A2- A*l~ [as an intrans. verb] He (a man, S, M) became one whose companions were low, base, vile, &c. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- He became in a state, or condition, that was low, base, vile, &c. (S in art. qhr.)
5 ta*al~a3a see 1.

10 Ast*l~hu *
He saw him to be *aliyl [i. e. low, base, vile, &c.]: (M, K:) or he found him to be so; (TA;) as also ↓ A*~lhu. (K.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- Ast*l~ AlbaEiyra AlS~aEoba He plucked off the ticks from the refractory camel in order that he might experience pleasure [or relief], and so become at ease, or tranquil, (M, K,) with him. (K.)

[
A*olawolaY * , a verb of which one of the significations is mentioned in this art. in the K, belongs to art. *lY.]
R. Q. 2 ta*alo*ala * [app. from *ulo*ulN] It was, or became, in a state of commotion, or agitation, and lax, slack, or pendulous. (K.)

*ul~N * and ↓ *il~apN and ↓ ma*al~apN [all mentioned in the M and MA and K as inf. ns.] contr. of Eiz~N; (S, M;) [i. e.] Lowness, baseness, vileness, abjectness, meanness, paltriness, contemptibleness, despicableness, ignominiousness, ingloriousness, abasement, humiliation, and weakness. (Msb, K. *) wa lamo yakuno lahu waliY~N mina Al*~ul~i, in the Kur [xvii. last verse], means Nor hath taken to himself any aider to assist Him and league with Him by reason of any lowness of condition in Him, as is the custom of the Arabs to do: (K, TA: [in the CK, yuxAlifuhu is erroneously put for yuHaAlifuhu:]) for they used to league, one with another, seeking thereby to become strong and inaccessible. (TA.) See also *aliylN. ― -b2- And see the paragraph here following, in five places.

*il~N *
Easiness, tractableness, submissiveness, or manageableness; (S, M, K, and Ham p. 50; [mentioned in the M and Msb and K as an inf. n.;]) as also ↓ *ul~N. (M, K, and Ham ubi suprà.) Hence the saying, baEoDu Al*~il~i A^aboqaY liloA^aholi waAlmaAli [Somewhat of submissiveness is most preservative of the family and the property]: (S:) or A^aboqaY liloA^aholi waAlmaAli ↓ Al*~ul~u, occurring in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr; meaning that abjectness betiding a man when he bears patiently an injury that has befallen him is most preservative of him and of his family and his property. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Gentleness; and mercy; and so ↓ *ul~N: thus in the phrase, ↓ waA@xofiDo lahumaA janaAHa Al*~ul~i or Al*~il~i, (M, K,) in the Kur [xvii. 25, lit. And make soft to them (thy two parents) the side of gentleness; meaning treat them with gentleness]: the former is the common reading: (TA:) or the latter means easiness, tractableness, or submissiveness: (K:) [and so the former, as has been stated above:] Er-Rághib says that ↓ Al*~ul~u is a consequence of subjection; and Al*~il~u is what is after refractoriness: so that the phrase means, [accord. to the former reading,] be gentle like him who is subjected to them; and accord. to the latter reading, be gentle and tractable, or submissive, to them. (TA.) -A2- Also The beaten track, (K,) or part that is trodden and made even, (M,) of a road. (M, K.) Its pl. A^a*olaAl occurs in the saying, A^ajori AlA^umuwraEalaY A^a*olaAlihaA Let events, or affairs, take their course in the ways, or manners, that are fit, or proper, for them, and easy. (T.) El-Khansà says,
litajori Almaniy~api baEoda AlfataY A@lomugaAdari biA@lomaHowi A^a*olaAlahaA
[Let fate take its ways after the youth left behind in El-Mahw]; (S, M;) meaning I mourn not for any thing after him: cited by AA: (S in the present art. and in art. mHw:) AlmHw is here the name of a place. (S in the latter art.) And one says, A^umuwru A@ll~`hi jaAriyapu EalaY A^a*olaAlihaA, (S, M, K,) and jaAriyapN A^a*olaAlahaA, (M, K,) The decrees of God take their [appointed] courses: (S, M, K:) here, also, A*lAl is pl. of *il~N. (M, K.) And ↓ daEohu EalaY A^a*olaAlihi Leave thou him, or it, in his, or its, [present] state, or condition: (S, M, K:) in this case it has no sing. (M, K.) [And so in the saying,] ↓ jaA='a EalaY A^a*olaAlihi It came in its [proper] manner. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also another usage of A^a*olaAl, as a pl. having no sing. assigned to it, voce *ulo*ulN, last sentence.

*il~apN * : see *ul~N. ― -b2- In the following verse,
liyahoniy^o turaAviY liA@moriy^K gayori *il~apK
SanaAbiru A^uHodaAnN lihun~a Hafiyfu
[May my heritage give joy to a man not low, or base; slender arrows, singular of their kind, that have a whizzing sound], the meaning is, gayori *aliylK, or gayori *iY *il~apK; and SnAbr is put in the nom. case as a substitute for trAv. (M.)

*aluwlN *
Easy, tractable, submissive, or manageable; (S, M, Msb, K;) applied to a beast, such as a horse and the like, (daAb~ap), (S, M, Msb,) and to a man [&c.]; (M;) and so ↓ *aluwliY~N, applied to a man: (TA, as from the M: [but not found by me in the latter; and I believe that the right reading is *alawolFY, belonging to art. *lY, q. v.:]) the former alike masc. and fem.: (M, TA:) pl. *ululN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^a*il~apN. (K.) A poet applies the epithet *ulul to spear-heads, as meaning Made easy [to pierce with] by being sharpened, and made thin and slender. (M.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

*aliylN *
Low, base, vile, abject, mean, paltry, contemptible, despicable, ignominious, inglorious, lowered, brought low, abased, humbled, and weak; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (T, S;) and ↓ *ul~aAnN signifies the same, as a sing.; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) or this latter is a pl. of the former, (T,) as also A^a*il~aA='u (S, M, Msb, K) and A^a*il~apN (T, S, Msb, K) and *ilaAlN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Also Gentle; and merciful. Hence,] A^a*il~apK EalaY Almuw^ominiyna A^aEiz~apK EalaY AlkaAfiryna, in the Kur [v. 59], means Gentle, (Zj, T,) and merciful, (T,) to the believers, rough in behaviour, (Zj, T,) and hard, or severe, (T,) to the unbelievers. (Zj, T.) ― -b3- Also applied to a road, meaning (assumed tropical:) Made even, or smooth, and easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride upon; as also with p; being applied to TariyqN [which is fem. as well as masc.] ; (M;) and so ↓ *aluwlN: (T:) pl. of the latter, (T,) or of the former, (M,) *ululN: (T, M:) and [in like manner] ↓ mu*al~alN, so applied, beaten, or trodden, and [made] even, or easy [to walk or ride upon]: (T:) [in like manner also] ↓ *aluwlN is applied to land or ground &c. [as meaning easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride upon, &c.]. (As, M voce tarabuwtN.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Low, applied to a wall, and to a house, or chamber; (T;) and [so] applied to a mountain: (S and K in art. dk:) or (tropical:) low and thin, applied to a wall: (Mgh:) and (assumed tropical:) short, applied to a spear. (T.) ― -b5- You say also *aliylN ↓ *ul~N, [meaning Exceeding lowness or baseness &c.; or lowering, or abasing, lowness or baseness &c.; i. e.,] using the latter word as an intensive epithet; or as signifying mu*il~N. (M, K.)

*aluwliY~N *
Good and easy in respect of natural disposition: pl. *aluwliy~uwna. (Ibn-' Abbád, K. [In the CK, Alxaloqi is erroneously put for Alxuluqi.]) See also *aluwlN.
*ul~aAnN * : see *aliylN.

*ulo*ulN * is sing. of *alaA*ilu, which signifies The lower, or lowest, parts, (AZ, T, S,) that are next the ground, of a shirt, (S,) or of a long shirt; (AZ, T;) and IAar says that the sing. is ↓ *ula*ilN, and ↓ *ilo*ilapN, also; and they are also called *anaA*inu, pl. of *ino*inN; (T;) and danaAdinu: (K in art. dn:) or *ulo*ulN and ↓ *ilo*ilN and ↓ *ilo*ilapN and ↓ *ula*ilN and ↓ *ula*ilapN all signify the lower, or lowest, parts of a long shirt (M, K) when it dangles and becomes old and worn out; (M;) as also *alaA*ilu; (K;) [or rather] this last is pl. of all the foregoing words; (M;) and ↓ *ala*ilu and ↓ *ala*ilapN [in some copies of the K, erroneously, *alo*al, or *alo*ul, and *alo*alap,] signify the same; (K;) [or rather] the former of these two is a contraction of the pl. *alaA*ilu (S, M) [and the latter of them is the same contracted pl. with the addition of p]. ― -b2- [Hence,] *alaA*ilu Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) Those who are the last of the people; (K;) or the last of a few of the people; so in the Moheet; (TA;) and ↓ *ulo*ulaAnuhumo and ↓ *ulayo*ilaAnuhumo, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, *ulo*ulAtuhumo and *uliy*alAtuhumo,]) the latter a dim., (TA,) and ↓ A^a*olaAluhumo, signify the same: (K:) or this last signifies the lower, baser, viler, or meaner, of them. (O, TA.)
*ilo*ilN * and *ula*ilN and *ala*ilN and see *ulo*ulN, in eight places.
*ilo*ilapN * and *ula*ilapN and *ala*ilapN and see *ulo*ulN, in eight places.
*ulo*ulaAnu Aln~aAsi * and *ulayo*ilaAnuhumo: see *ulo*ulN.
A^a*al~N * [More, and most, low, base, vile, &c.]: see A^axonaEu.
A^a*olaAlN * as a pl. without a sing.: see *il~N (of which it is also a pl.), in two places: -A2- and see *ulo*ulN, last sentence.
ma*al~apN * : see *ul~N. ― -b2- [Hence,] gayoruAlma*al~api (assumed tropical:) The wooden pin, peg, or stake: (S, K:) because its head is broken [or battered by beating]. (S.) [See EayorN.]

mu*al~alN * : see *aliylN. ― -b2- Also, [applied to palmtrees (naxol),] (assumed tropical:) Having the fruit thereof bent [down] in order that it may be [easily] gathered: [see also its verb (2):] so in the following verse of Imra-el-Keys: (Sgh, TA:)
waka$oHK laTiyfK kaAljadiyli muxaS~arK
wasaAqK kaA^unobuwbi Als~aqiY~i Almu*al~ali
meaning And a waist slender like the camel's nose-rein of [twisted] leather, thin; and a shank resembling, in the clearness of its colour, the stalk (lit. internodal portion) of the papyrus (barodiY~) growing among irrigated palm-trees having their racemes bent down (*ul~ilato) by reason of the abundance of their fruit; so that their branches overshade these papyrus-plants: or, accord. to some, and a shank resembling the stalk of the irrigated papyrus that is bent down (mu*al~al) by saturation: (EM pp. 28 and 29:) As says that it means, [agreeably with the former explanation,] saAqK kaA^unobuwbi barodiY~K bayona h`*aA Aln~axoli Almu*~alali: AO says that saqiY~ means watered [naturally,] without occasioning one's taking any trouble to water: IAar explained Almu*al~al as meaning having the way of the water thereto made easy: and some say that by Als~aqiY~ is meant the tender, white, stalk of the barodiY~. (T.)

1 *alifa * , aor.
*alafa , inf. n. *alafN, said of a nose, It was short and small: (M, Msb:) or short in the bone, and small in the tip, or lower portion: or *alafN is like xanasN [inf. n. of xanisa, q. v.]: (M:) or the verb means it was small, and even in the tip, or lower portion: (S, * K:) or small and slender: or thick and even in the lower extremity; (M, K;) or, as some say, it had in it what resembled a pit, or depression; (M;) not being very thick (layosa bijid~i galiyZK): (M, K: * [in the latter I find layosa biHad~K galiyZK, which I doubt not to be a mistranscription:]) or it was short in the tip, or lower portion, and even in the bone, without prominence.
