And A nose such as is described above. (K.) ― -b2- And *ulofN, applied to sands, (assumed tropical:) Even and compact; as also duk~N. (AHn, M.)

1 *aliq * , aor.
*alaqa , (S, K,) inf. n. *alaqN, (S,) It (a spear-head [and the like]) was, or became, sharp, cutting, or penetrating. (S, K.) ― -b2- And in like manner, aor. and inf. n. as above, [the inf. n. erroneously written in the CK *aloq,] said of the tongue, (tropical:) It was, or became, sharp and eloquent; as also *aluqa, aor.
*aluqa , inf. n. *alaAqapN; and *alaqa, aor.
*aluqa : (K, TA:) and i. q. *ariba [which means it was, or became, sharp properly speaking; and also chaste, or eloquent; and profuse of speech, or clamorous]. (S in explanation of the first verb, and app. of the second also, i. e. *aluqa, inf. n. *alaAqapN; and K in explanation of the first only.) ― -b3- Also, i. e. like fariHa, (assumed tropical:) It (a lamp, or lighted wick,) gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly: (K:) [or] so *alaqa, inf. n. *aloqN. (JK.) -A2- Also, i. e. *aliqa, aor.
*alaqa , inf. n. *alaqN, It, or he, was, or became, unsettled, unsteady, unquiet, restless, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or in a state of commotion. (S, TA.) You say, *aliqotu Eano makaAniY I rose from my place, and became disquieted, or disturbed. (JK.) ― -b2- And, said of the [lizard called] Dab~, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) It came forth from the roughness of the sand to the softness of the water. (K.) ― -b3- And *aliqa mina AlEaTa$i He (a man) became at the point of death from thirst: (K:) or he became affected severely by thirst so that his tongue protruded. (TA.) -A3- *alaqahu, (JK, K,) aor.
*aluqa , (TA,) inf. n. *aloqN, (JK, TA,) He sharpened it; (JK, K;) namely, a knife, (K,) or anything; (JK;) as also ↓ A*lqhu; (Lth, K;) and ↓ *l~qh, (K,) inf. n. ta*oliyqN. (TA.) -A4- And *alaqahu said of the [hot wind called] samuwm, or of fasting, It weakened him, (K,) and emaciated him, and disquieted him, or disturbed him; (TA;) as also ↓ A*lqhu: (K, TA:) or the latter, thus used, it affected him severely, afflicted him, or distressed him. (JK.) -A5- *alaqa said of a bird, i. q. *araqa [It muted, or dunged]; (K;) and in like manner, *aroqahu ↓ A*lq (K, * TA) it cast forth its dung quickly. (TA.)

2 *l~qhu * , inf. n. ta*oliyqN: see 1: -A2- and 4 -A3- *l~q Alfarasa, (JK, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) i. q. Dam~arahu [He made the horse lean, or light of flesh; or prepared him for racing, &c. by feeding him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat, or after he had been fed with fodder so that he had become fat; &c.;] (JK, K;) and took good care of him. 4 A*lqhu * as syn. with *alaqahu and *l~qhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also, (inf. n. A_i*olaAqN, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made it to give light, shine, become bright, or shine brightly; namely, a lamp, or lighted wick. (JK, K.) -A2- Also He, or it, unsettled, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or put into a state of commotion, him, or it. (JK, S, K.) You say, A^ataAniY xabarN faA^a*olaqaniY News came to me, and unsettled me, or disquieted me, &c. (JK.) And it is said in a trad. of Má'iz, lam~aA A^a*olaqatohu AlHijaArapu jamaza, (Mgh, TA,) i. e. When the stones disquieted him, &c.: (TA:) or when the stones hit him, or hurt him, with the point, or edge, [or rather the points, or edges,] thereof, he ran [or went] quickly. (Mgh.) And A*lq AlD~ab~a He poured water into the hole of the [lizard called] Db~ in order that he might come forth, (S, K, TA,) thus disturbing him; (TA;) as also ↓ *l~qhu, (K,) inf. n. ta*oliyqN. (TA.) -A3- A*lq also signifies He dug A^axaAdiyd [i. e. furrows, trenches, or channels; or rivulets, or streamlets]. (TA.) -A4- And A_i*olaAqN The casting quickly. (JK, TA.) See 1, last sentence.

He sought, or endeavoured, to make the [lizard called] Db~ come forth from its hole. (TA.) One says likewise, AlmaTaru yasota*oliqu AlHa$araAti The rain draws forth the reptiles, or small creeping things, or makes them to come forth, from their holes; as also ystdlqhA. (TA in art. dlq.) *aloqN * (JK, S, Mgh, K) and ↓ *aloqapN and ↓ *alafapN (K) and *awolaqN (S, K) The point, extremity, or edge, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) of anything: (JK, S, K:) and the sharpness thereof: (AA, TA:) and the last, [particularly,] the extremity of a spear-head,
and (assumed tropical:) of the tongue. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the first, The slender part of an arrow. (TA.) ― -b3- And The place in which turns the pin, or pivot, of the sheave of a pulley. (S, TA.) -A2- For the first, also, see *aliqN, in three places.

*alaqN * inf. n. of *aliqN. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- It may be also pl. of ↓ *aAliqN, signifying Sharpened, or pointed, in the iron head or blade: [like mu*al~aqN:] ― -b3- and it may be used by poetic license for *aloqN. (L.) ― -b4- See also the paragraph next following.

*aliqN * and ↓ A^a*olaqu, applied to a spear-head [and the like], Sharp, cutting, or penetrating: (S, K:) pl. of the latter *uloqN. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And in like manner, both words, applied to the tongue, (tropical:) i. q. *aribN [which means Sharp properly speaking; and also chaste, or eloquent; and profuse of speech, or clamorous]: (S, K:) and ↓ *aliyqN and ↓ *aloqN and ↓ *ulaqN and ↓ *uluqN, so applied, signify sharp and eloquent. (K.) You say lisAnN *aliqN TaliqN, expl. in art. Tlq [q. v.]: (K:) and TaloqN ↓ lisaAnN *aloqN and TaliyqN ↓ *aliyqN and TuluqN ↓ *uluqN and TulaqN ↓ *ulaqN: (IAar, S:) and ↓ TaloqN *aloqN and ↓ TalaqN *alaqN [or TaliqN *aliqN] and ↓ TaliyqN *aliyqN: all meaning [a tongue] sharp, penetrating, or effective: and TuloqN ↓ A^alosinapN *uloqN, or TuloqN *uloqN. (TA.) And xaTiybN *aliqN and ↓ *aliyqN (S, K) (assumed tropical:) [An orator, or a preacher,] chaste in speech, or eloquent: (K, * TA:) the fem. of each of these epithets is with p. (S, K. *)
*ulaqN * and *uluqN: see the next preceding paragraph, each in two places.
*aloqapN * and *alaqapN: see *aloqN.
*aliyqN * : see *aliqN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A vehement run or running. (JK, TA.)
*aAliqN * : see *alaqN.
*awolaqN * : see *aloqN.
*awolaqiy~apN * : see the paragraph next following, in two places.

A^a*olaqu * , and its pl. *uloqN: see *aliqN. ― -b2- AlHuruwfu Al*~uloqu The letters [that are pronounced by means] of the tip of the tongue and the lip: (S, K:) sing. A^a*olaqu: they are six; (S;) [comprised in the phrase muro binafolK:] three of these are termed ↓ *awolaqiy~apN, namely, r and l and n; and three, $afawiy~apN, namely, b and f and m: (S, K:) or all of these six letters are termed ↓ *awolaqiy~apN. (TA voce EasojadN.) Every quadriliteral-radical or quinqueliteral-radical word [that is genuine Arabic] contains one or two or three of these six letters: every word of either of these classes that does not contain one of these six letters is to be judged adventitious: all the other letters are termed AlHuruwfu AlmuSomatahu. (IJ.)

mu*al~aqN * Anything sharpened, or pointed, at the extremity: (S:) [like *aAliqN:] or a sharp point. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Milk mixed with water: (AZ, K:) [like mu*ar~aqN:] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, like naso'N. (TA.)

1 *alaYAlr~uTaba * , like saEaY, (K,) [i. e.,] aor.
*aAala , inf. n. *aloYN, (TA,) He gathered the fresh ripe dates: (K:) so in the copies of the K; in which is added, faA@no*alaY maEahu: but what we find in the Tekmileh is this: Zl~ y*lY AlrTb AY yjnyh fyn*lY mEh: and y*lY is written as [the aor. of] a quadriliteral [i. e. as the aor. of A*lY, for it is without a sheddeh]: (TA:) [here, however, fyn*lY is evidently, in my opinion, a mistranscription for fayatadal~aY; and the right reading and rendering I therefore hold to be as follows: Alr~uTaba ↓ Zal~a yu*oliY, or perhaps ya*olaY, means He continued gathering the fresh ripe dates, they hanging down with him: for the gatherer laying hold upon the raceme, it hangs down with his weight. In the TK, this passage in the TA has been misunderstood and misrepresented, as though it meant that A^a*olaY maEahu signifies “ he gathered with him. ”]

i. q. t*l~l [He became lowly, humble, or submissive; or he lowered, humbled, or submitted, himself]: (T, K:) the latter verb is the original: the former being like tZn~Y, originally tZn~n. (T.) [See also the next paragraph.]

*alawolFY * , [in copies of the K *alawlaY,] applied to a man, i. q. mu*olawolK [part. n. of 12, q. v.]: (K, TA: [in some copies of the K ma*oluwlN:]) of the measure faEawoEalN; or, as some say, faEaloEalN. (TA.)

1 *am~ahu * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
*amu3a , (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. *am~N (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and ma*am~apN, (M, K,) He blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, him, in respect of evil conduct; Al*~am~u signifying All~awomu (T, Mgh) fiY AlA_isaA='api; (T;) contr. of AlmadoHu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of AlHamodu: (Mgh:) and ↓ *m~mhu, (MA,) inf. n. ta*omiymN, (KL,) signifies the same: (MA, KL:) [or this has an intensive meaning: see its pass. part. n., below.] Hence the saying, AifoEalo ka*aA wxalaAka *am~N, (T, S, K,) i. e. xalaA minoka *am~N, meaning [Do thou such a thing, and] thou wilt not be blamed; (ISk, S, K;) or thou wilt have an excuse; [lit.] blame will full from thee: (S in art. xlw:) one should not say xalaAka *anobN. (ISk, S in the present art.) *um~a, also, signifies He was satirized, particularly in verse. (IAar, T.) And He was made to suffer loss or diminution [app. in respect of his reputation]. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- *am~a AlmakaAnu (tropical:) The place was, or became, affected with drought, or barrenness, and its good things [or produce] became scanty. (TA.) [But perhaps *am~a is here a mistranscription for *um~a; for] you say of a land, *am~a maroEaAhaA [He dispraised, or discommended, its pasture, when its pasture is scanty]. (S and M and K in art. b*A^.) -A2- *am~a, [aor.
*ami3a ,] said of the nose, (S, K,) It flowed [with *amiym, i. e. mucus]; (K;) like *an~a. (S, K.) And [the aor.] ya*im~u is said of *amiym; (S, K;) like ya*in~u; (S, TA;) meaning It flows. (TA.)
2 *am~a3a see 1, first sentence.
3 fulaAnN yu*aAm~u Eayo$ahu * (assumed tropical:) Such a one passes his life contended with scantiness. (TA.)

4 A*m~ *
He (a man) did [or said] that for which he should be blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (S;) contr. of A^aHomada. (A in art. Hmd.) And A_ilayohi ↓ Ast*m~, (M, K,) or A_ilaY Aln~aAsi, (S,) He did to him, or to the people, that for which he should be blamed, &c. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^a*am~ato raAHilatuhu (tropical:) His riding-camel ceased going on; as though she made the people to blame her. (TA.) And A^a*am~ato rikaAbuhumo (tropical:) Their camels upon which they were riding became jaded, and lagged behind, (S, M, K, TA,) not keeping up with the main body of camels; (S, TA;) [as though they made their riders to blame them; or] as though [the idea of] their strength in journeying were derived from *am~apN meaning “ a well having little water. ” (TA.) And A*m~ biha baEiyruhu (tropical:) [His camel became jaded, and lagged behind with him]. (S, TA.) And A^a*am~ato biAlr~akobi, said of a she-ass, (tropical:) She kept back the company of riders upon camels by her weakness and her ceasing to go on. (TA from a trad.) -A2- A*m~hu He found him, or it, to be such as is blamed, dispraised, &c.; (S, M, K, TA;) contr. of A^aHomadahu. (TA.) One says, A^atayotu mawoDiEa ka*aA faA^a*omamotuhu, i. e. [I came to such a place, and] I found it to be such as is discommended. (S) ― -b2- A*~m bihi, (S,) or bihimo, (M, K,) He held him, or them, in little, or light, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: (S, K:) or he left [him or] them blamed, dispraised, &c., among the people. (IAar, M, K.) -A3- Also, A*m~hu, He protected him; granted him protection, or refuge. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A*m~ lahu Ealayohi He took, or obtained, a promise, or an
assurance, of security or safety, and a compact, or covenant, for him, or in his favour, of, or against, him [i. e. another person, making the latter responsible for his (the former's) security, or safety, &c.]. (M, * K, * TA.) -A4- See also the next paragraph.

5 t*m~m *
He shunned, or avoided, (T, * Mgh,) or he preserved, or guarded, himself from, (MA,) blame, dispraise, &c.: (T, * MA, Mgh:) this is the proper meaning; and hence, (Mgh,) he felt disdain, or scorn, and shame. (S, MA, Mgh, K, KL.) One says, lawo lamo A^atoruki Alka*iba taA^av~umFA latarakotuhu ta*am~umaA [If I did not refrain from lying for the purpose of abstaining from sin, I would refrain from it from a feeling of disdain, or scorn, or shame]. (S, K.) And t*m~m minohu [He abstained, or refrained, from it to avoid blame, or through disdain, or scorn, or shame; disdained, or scorned, it; or was ashamed of it]. (K in art. H$m.) And Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà mentions his having heard an Arab of the desert use the expression lA y*m~wn [app. ↓ laA yu*im~uwna, for the A in the measure A^afoEala sometimes has a privative property,] meaning They do not shun, or avoid, blame; (laA yata*am~amuwna;) and are not affected with shame. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mino xilaAli AlmakaArimi Alt~a*am~umu lilS~aAHibi, meaning [Of the properties of generous, or honourable, practices, is] the being regardful of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in the character and appertenances of the companion, or friend, and dispelling from oneself the blame that he would incur from men if he were not regardful thereof. (TA.) And one says, lilojaAri Einodaka ta*am~umN and ↓ musota*am~N [To the neighbour, with thee, is shown regard of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in his character and appertenances: musota*am~N being app. an inf. n. of ↓ Ast*m~, and this being syn. with t*m~m]. (TA.)

6 t*Am~wA *
They blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, one another. (M, K.)

10 Ast*m~ * [He required blame, &c.; as though he called for it; or] he was blamed, or dispraised, &c. (KL.) See also 4, second sentence. ― -b2- And see 5, last sentence. ― -b3- [Ast*m~ bi*imaAmihi is used by post-classical writers, and is perhaps a classical phrase, meaning He begged, or implored, his protection. See an instance in “ Abulfedæ Annales, ” vol. iii. p. 170.]

R. Q. 1 *amo*ama *
He made his gift small, or scanty. (IAar, T, K.)

*am~N * inf. n. of *am~ahu. (T, S, M, &c.) [As a simple subst., Blame, dispraise, or censure.] ― -b2- And [the pl.] *umuwmN signifies Vices, faults, defects, or the like. (M, K. [See *aAm~N.]) -A2- See also *amiymN. -A3- And see *am~apN.
*im~N * : see *amiymN. ― -b2- Also Excessively lean or emaciated; and perishing: (K:) or like him who is perishing. (T, TA.) ― -b3- See also *im~apN.

*am~apN * [as a subst.]; (T, Mgh;) and biy^orN *am~apN, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) in which the latter word is an epithet, (Mgh,) and ↓ *im~apN also, with kesr, (so in one of my copies of the S,) and ↓ *amiymN, and *amiymapN; (M, K;) A well containing little water; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) because discommended: (M, Mgh:) and, (M, K,) as some say, (M,) containing much water: thus having two contr. significations: (M, K:) pl. *imaAmN (T, S, M, K) and ↓ *am~N, (T, TA,) [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., of which *am~apN is the n. un.] A poet says, (S,) namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, describing camels whose eyes were sunk in their sockets by reason of fatigue, (T,)
EalaY Himoyariy~aAtK kaA^an~a EuyuwnahaA
*imaAmu Alr~akaAyaA A^anokazatohaA AlmawaAtiHu
[Upon camels of Himyer that were as though their eyes were wells containing little water which the camels employed to draw it had exhausted]. (T, S.)

*im~apN *
A compact, a covenant, a contract, a league, a treaty, an engagement, a bond, or an obligation; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) because the breaking thereof necessitates blame: (Mgh:) and a right, or due, (Haq~N,) for the neglect of which one is to be blamed: (Bd in ix. 8:) [an inviolable right or due:] and ↓ *imaAmN and ↓ ma*im~apN and ↓ ma*am~apN signify in like manner a compact, a covenant, &c. as above, for the neglect, or nonobservance, of which a man is to be blamed: (Msb:) or these three words [in the CK the first and last only] signify a right, or due; syn. Haq~N: (M, K:) or so the first of them: (T, * S:) and each of them, (M, K,) or the first of them, i. e. *imaAmN, (T, S, Mgh,) i. q. HuromapN [which includes all the significations of *im~apN likewise, those above and those which follow, but appears here to be used as meaning especially a thing that should be sacred, or inviolable; or which one is under an obligation to reverence, respect, or honour, and defend; everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence. in the character and appertenances of a person]; (S, M, Mgh, K;) every Huromap for the neglect, or non-observance, of which one is to be blamed: (T:) ↓ *amaAmapN, also, and ↓ *imaAmapN, are syn. with Haq~N and HuromapN: (TA:) and *im~apN signifies also i. q. A^amaAnN [as meaning security, or safety; security of life and property; protection, or safeguard; a promise, or an assurance, of security, safety, protection, or safeguard; indemnity; or quarter]; (S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA;) and so ↓ *imaAmN: (MA, KL: [explained in both by the Pers. zinohaAro; and in the latter by HuromapN and Haq~N also:]) and responsibility [for the fulfilment of an obligation, for the payment of a sum of money, for the restitution of a thing, or for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a thing or person]; suretiship; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ *amaAmapN and ↓ *imaAmapN; (M, K; [in the former of which, these two words are said to be syn. with *im~apN, app. meaning, in all the senses mentioned above;]) and ↓ *im~N: (M, K: [said in the M to be syn. with *im~apN in the first only of the senses mentioned above in this paragraph: in the CK, wAl*~im~u is erroneously put for wa Al*~im~i:]) the pl. of *im~apN is *imamN (T, Msb) and *imaAmN: (T:) and the pl. of ↓ *imaAmN as [a sing.] syn. with [*im~apN and] ma*am~apN and ma*im~apN is A^a*im~apN. (M, K.) Hence, i. e. from *im~apN in the first of the senses explained above, A^ahlu Al*~im~api, (S, Mgh, TA.) and Al*~im~ipu, (T, M, * Mgh, K, TA,) with the prefixed noun Ahl suppressed, (TA,) The people with whom a compact, or covenant, &c., has been made; (T, S, M, K, TA;) [and particularly] those, of the believers in a plurality of Gods, [by which are here meant the Christians, Jews, and Sabians, but no others,] who pay the [tax called] jizoyap; (T, TA;) [i. e. the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government, who pay a poll-tax for which the Muslims are responsible for their security and freedom and toleration: see A^aholN:] the appellation ↓ *im~iY~N, (Mgh, Msb,) a rel. n. from Al*~im~apu, (Msb;) is applied to a person of this class; (Mgh, Msb;) because he is rendered secure, or free from fear, for his property and his blood, by means of the jizoyap. (Mgh.) jaEala Eumaru A^ahola Als~awaAdi *im~apF means 'Omar treated [lit. made] the people of the Sawád as those who are termed A^aholu Al*~im~api. (Mgh.) And A^aqobilonaA bi*im~apK [or A^aqolibonaA?], in the prayer of the traveller, means Restore us to our family in safety. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of 'Alee, that he said, *im~atiY bimaA A^aquwlu rahiynapN wa A^anaA bihi zaEiymN, meaning My responsibility is pledged for [the truth of] what I say, and I am answerable for it; (Mgh, TA; *) i. e. this my saying is true, and I am responsible for it. (Mgh.) And it is said in another trad., faqado bariy^ato minohu Al*~im~ap [Then the responsibility of God is clear, or quit, of him]; i. e. there is given to every one, by God, a covenant whereby He binds Himself to preserve and protect him; and when he throws himself into destruction, or does that which is unlawful for him to do, or acts at variance with that which he is commanded to do, the covenant of God fails to aid him. (TA.) fiY *im~atiY ka*aA means fY DamaAniY [virtually I am responsible for such a thing; i. e. for paying it, or restoring it, &c.; but lit. in my responsibility is such a thing; or on my responsibility rests, or lies, or be, such a thing; for fY may be here used, as it is in many other instances, in the sense of EalaY]: (Msb:) [or,] in the saying vabata fiY *im~atiY ka*aA, [which means Such a thing became, or has become, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on me,] the term *im~ap is applied to designate [the moral sense considered as] the seat [of the sense] of obligation to fulfil what is [properly] termed *im~ap [i. e. a compact, or covenant, or the like]. (Mgh.) Alr~aDaAEi ↓ maA yu*ohibu Ean~iY ma*im~apa (T, S, Mgh, *) or Alr~aDaAEi ↓ ma*am~apa, (T, Mgh,) meaning [What will put away from me the obligation of] the right, or due, of the woman who has suckled for the sucking? is a question occurring in a trad., (T, S, Mgh, *) as put by a man to the
Prophet: (T:) and the answer was, “ A slave, male or female: ” (T, S, Mgh:) En-Nakha'ee says, (S,) they liked, on the occasion of the weaning of a child, to give the woman who had suckled it something beside the hire: (S, Mgh:) ↓ ma*am~apN in this case is a dial. var. of ↓ ma*im~apN: (Mgh:) or, as IAth says, the former is from Al*~am~u; and the latter, from Al*~im~ahu. (TA.) You say also, Alr~aDaAEi bi$~aYo'K tuEoTiyhi ↓ A^a*ohibo Eanoka ma*am~a AlZ~iy^ora and Alr~aDaAEi ↓ ma*im~a, meaning [Put away from thee the obligation of] the right, or due, that is incumbent on thee to render her for the sucking of thy child [by something that thou shalt give to her who has suckled]. (T.) And A^a*ohibo Eanoka bi$aYo'K ↓ ma*im~atahumo and ↓ ma*am~atahumo, (T, and so accord. to different copies of the S and K, in which Enk is omitted,) ma*am~ap being a dial. var., (T,) i. e. [Put away from thee the obligation of their right, or due, by something; meaning] feed them with something, (T,) or give to them something, (S, K,) for they have a right, or due. (T, S, K.) And ↓ qaDaY ma*im~atahu and ↓ ma*am~atahu [He paid his right, or due;] meaning he did good to him, or conferred upon him a benefit or benefits, in order that he might not be blamed. (M, K.) And rajulN ↓ *uw ma*im~apK and ↓ ma*am~apK [in the CK the latter only, A man who has a right, or due,] meaning kal~N EalaY Aln~aAsi (tropical:) [a man who is a burden upon people, to be maintained, or supported, by them]. (M, K, TA.) -A2- Also (i. e. *im~apN) A repast, or banquet, to which guests are invited, [simply] for food, or for a wedding. (K.) -A3- See also *am~apN.
*imaAmN * : see *im~apN, in three places. It is also a pl. of *im~apN [as well as syn. therewith]. (T.)

*amiymN *
Blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. q. ↓ ma*omuwmN; (T, M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ *im~N (T, K, TA) and ↓ *am~N, (M, K, TA,) which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet, and, like [its contr.] HamodN, is applied to a man and to a place of alighting or sojourning or abiding. (TA.) [See mu*im~N] ― -b2- See also *am~apN. ― -b3- Also, applied to water, Disliked, or disapproved. (S, K. *) -A2- [As a subst.,] Urine and mucus, (K,) so in the copies of the K, but correctly, (TA,) mucus, and urine (S, TA) that flows from the penis of the goat: (S, K, TA:) or a fluid that flows from the nose. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And in like manner, Milk [that flows] from the teats of sheep or goats; (K;) or, as in some copies of the S, form the teats of the she-camel; (TA;) or from the teats of the sheep or goat: (so in one of my copies of the S: in the other of those copies omitted:) or milk that becomes sprinkled upon the udders: (Th, M:) or milk that flows upon the thighs and udders of camels and sheep or goats. (M.) ― -b3- Also Dew, (M, K,) absolutely; (TA;) accord. to IDrd: (M:) or dew that falls in the night upon the trees, and upon which dust lights, so that it becomes like bits of clay or mud. (M, K.) ― -b4- And A thing [meaning the sebaceous matter] that comes forth from the pores of the soft part of the nose, like the eggs of ants: (S:) or pimples, or small pustules, (bavorN, T, K,) or a thing resembling bavor, black, or red, (M,) like the eggs of ants, (T, M,) coming forth upon the nose, (T,) or arising upon the faces (M, K) and the noses, (M,) from heat (T, M, K) or from the scab: (M, K:) or the dirty matter that comes forth upon the nose: n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b5- And Whiteness upon the nose of a kid. (Kr, M, K.)

*amaAmapN * : see *im~apN, in two places. ― -b2- Also Shame, and fear of blame: whence the saying, A^axa*atohu mino SaAHibihi *amaAmapN [Shame, and fear of blame, with respect to his companion, seized him]: and A^aSaAbatohu minohu *amaAmapN, i. e. Shame and disgrace affected him on account of him, or it. (TA.) One says also, ↓ A^axa*atoniY minohu ma*am~apN and ↓ ma*im~apN, meaning Shame and disgrace by reason of the neglect of that which should be sacred or inviolable, or of that which was entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, or of the obligation or duty, or the right or due, that should be regarded as sacred or inviolable, (mino taroki AlHuromapi,) [seized me on account of him, or it.] (S, K.)
*umaAmapN * (assumed tropical:) A remain, remainder, remaining portion, remnant, or relic. (K.) [See also *am~aA=', below.]
*imaAmapN * : see *im~apN, in two places.

bihi *amiymapN *
In him is a crippleness, or a chronic disease, (K, [in the CK *amAnapN is erroneously put for zamaAnapN,]) or an infirmity arising therefrom or from some evil affection, (M,) that prevents him from going forth. (M, K.)

A^aboqaY *am~aA='a AlS~ub~i * (tropical:) [He left] the last remains [of what was poured out, or forth, at once]: so in the A. (TA. [But the last word is there written without any syll. signs.]) [See also *umaAmapN.]
*im~iY~N * : see *im~apN, in the former half of the paragraph.
*am~aAmN * One who blames, dispraises, discommends, &c., much, or often. (TA.)
*aAm~N * and *aAmN, with and without teshdeed, [the latter belonging to art. *ym,] A vice, fault, defect, or the like. (As, T.) [See also *am~N.]
A^a*am~u * A horse fatigued, and standing still. (TA.)
ma*am~N * and ma*im~N: see *im~apN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

mu*~im~N * A thing blamed, dispraised, &c.; [like *amiymN;] or made, or caused, to be faulty, or defective, or to have a vice, fault, defect, or the like; (S. K;) as also ↓ mi*am~N. (K.) ― -b2- And A man (S) in whom is no motion. (S, K.)
mi*am~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ma*am~apN * , with fet-h only [to the *, A cause of blame, dispraise, discommendation, censure, or reprehension; a blamable, or discommendable, quality or action;] a thing for which one is, or is to be, blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended: contr. of maHomadapN: (S:) [pl. ma*aAm~N.] You say, Albuxolu ma*am~apN, (S, K,) i. e. [Niggardliness is] one of the things for which one is, or is to be, blamed, &c. (S.) And A_iy~aAka wa Alma*aAm~a [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, causes of blame, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also *im~apN, in six places. ― -b3- And see *amaAmapN.
ma*im~apN * : see *im~apN, in six places. ― -b2- And see also *amaAmapN.
mu*am~amN * A man blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, much. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A place held in reverence, respect, or honour. (TA.)
ma*omuwmN * : see *amiymN, first sentence.
musota*am~N * : see 5, last sentence.

1 *amara * , (S,) inf. n. *amorN, (K,) He (a lion) roared. (S, K.) -A2- *amarahu, aor.
*amura , (S, M, A,) inf. n. *amorN, (T, S, M, K,) He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, him, (T, S, M, A, K, *) with chiding, or reproof, (T, M, A, K, *) and encouraged him, (L,) EalaY AlA^amori to do the thing; (A;) as also ↓ *m~rhu: (L, TA:) and he threatened him; (L, K; *) and was angry with him. (L.) -A3- *amarahu, aor.
*amura ; and ↓ *m~rhu, [inf. n. ta*omiyrN;] He felt his mu*am~ar [q. v.]. (M.) You say also, *amara Alr~aAEiY Als~aliyla The pastor felt the place where the head of the young camel just born was set upon the neck, to know if it were a male or a female: (A:) [or its inf. n., *amorN, signifies the same as] ↓ ta*omiyrN a man's inserting the hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female. (S.) [See mu*am~irN.]

2 *am~ara see 1, in three places. ― -b2- ta*omiyrN also signifies The determining the quantity, measure, size, or bulk, of a thing; or computing by conjecture the quantity or measure thereof. (K, * TA.)

5 t*m~r * , an irreg. quasi-pass. of *amarahu, (M,) [or rather a reg. quasi-pass. of *am~arahu, which is mentioned in the L, and meaning He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, himself,] as though he blamed himself for a thing that had escaped him: (S:) or he blamed himself (M, K) for a thing that had escaped him: (K:) or he blamed himself for negligence, in order to inspirit himself, that he might not be negligent a second time: (A:) or he blamed himself for the escape, or loss, of [what he was bound to preserve and defend, or] what is termed *imaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- He became angry. (M, K.) ― -b3- He disliked a thing, and was angry in consequence thereof. (Har p. 517.) ― -b4- t*m~r Ealayohi He became changed, or altered, to him, and threatened him with evil. (S, K.) ― -b5- But in the trad. in which it is said of Moses, kaAna yata*am~aru EalaY rab~ihi, this expression means that He emboldened himself to his Lord, and raised his voice in his expression of disapproval. (TA.)

6 t*AmrwA *
They excited, incited, urged, or instigated, one another, (S, K,) in war, (S,) or to fight. (K.) ― -b2- Also, sometimes, They blamed one another for neglecting an opportunity. (TA.)

*imorN * and ↓ *amirN and ↓ *imir~N and ↓ *amiyrN A courageous man: (S, * M, K: *) or who combines sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, with courage, (M,) or with strength; (T;) and ↓ *umaAy^irN has also this last signification: (TA:) or the four preceding words signify, (M,) or signify also, (K,) clever, intelligent, and a good assistant: (M, K:) pl. of the first (S, M) and second and fourth, (M,) A^a*omaArN; (S, M;) and pl. of the third, *imir~uwna. (M.) ― -b2- Al*~imoru and ↓ Al*~umaAy^iru are also names of Calamities, or misfortunes. (K.)
*amirN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
*imir~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
*amaAri * a verbal noun, like nazaAli; [signifying Excite thou, or incite, urge, or instigate, thy companions to the fight: or, perhaps, be thou excited, &c.:] from *amarahu fiY AlHarobi. (R.)
*amaArN * : see the next paragraph.

*imaArN *
Whatever one is obliged, or bound, to preserve and guard and defend or protect, (T, M, K, *) and for the loss or neglect of which one must be blamed: (T:) things that are sacred, or inviolable; a man's family, and property (Hawozap), and servants or dependents, and relations: (AA, T:) as also ↓ *amaArN: (TA:) things for which, if he did not defend or protect them, a man would be blamed, and severely reproved: (A:) or what is behind a man, [as a burden upon him,] of those things which it is his duty to defend or protect; for they say HaAmiYAl*~imaAri, [see below,] like as they say HaAmiY AlHaqiyqapi; and those things are termed *mAr because anger (ta*am~urN) on their account is incumbent on him to whom they pertain; and they are termed Hqyqp because it is the duty of him to whom they pertain to defend them. (S.) HaAmiYAl*~imaAri signifies The defender, or protector, of those things for which a man is to be blamed, and severely reproved, if he do not defend or protect them: (A:) [or of those things which he is bound to preserve and guard and defend, &c.: see above:] or one who, when he is incited, or instigated, and angry, defends, or protects. (S.) One says also, fulaAnN A^amonaEu *imaArFA mino fulaAnK [app., Such a one is a greater defender of those things which it is his duty to defend than such a one]. (S.) ― -b2- yawomu Al*~imaAri The day of war: or of perdition: or of anger. (Et-Towsheeh.)
*amiyrN * : see *imorN. ― -b2- Also A man goodly, or beautiful, (K, TA,) in make. (TA.)

*amaArapN *
Courage: (M, K:) or sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, combined with courage [or with strength: see *imorN]: or cleverness, intelligence, and the quality of rendering good assistance. (M.)
*umaAy^iru * : see *imorN, in two places.
*ayomuriY~N * , (K, TA,) with damm to the m, (TA,) [in the CK *ayomariY~,] A man sharp in temper, who adheres to things and minds them pertinaciously. (K, * TA.) [And so dayomuriY~N.]

mu*am~arN * The back of the neck: (M, K:) or two bones in the base of the back of the neck: or the part called *iforaY [behind the ear]: or the kaAhil [or upper part of the back, next the neck]: (M:) or this last-mentioned part with the neck and what surrounds it as far as the *iforaY; which is what the mu*am~ir [q. v.] feels: (As, S:) or the place where the head of a camel is set upon the neck. (A.) ― -b2- balaga AlA^amoru Almu*m~aru (tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch; (A, * K;) like balaga Almuxan~aqa. (A.)

mu*am~irN * A man who inserts his hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female: (S, M, K:) because he feels its mu*am~ar, and thus knows it: he feels its jaw-bones: if they be thick, it is a male; and if thin, a female. (M.) El-Kumeyt says,
waqaAla Almu*am~iru liln~aAtijiyna
mataY *um~irato qaboliYa AlA^arojulu
[And he whose business it was to feel the fœtus, for the purpose of discovering if it were male or female, said to those assisting the she-camels in bringing forth, When, before my time, were the legs felt to discover the sex of the fœtus?]: (S, M:) for it is the head that is felt, as above explained. (M.) The mu*am~ir is, to camels, as the midwife to human beings. (A.)

1 *amala * , (S, M, K,) or *amalato, (T,) aor.
*amula (T, S, M, K) and
*amila , (S, M, K,) inf. n. *amiylN (T, S, M, K) and *amolN and *umuwlN and *amalaAnN, (M, K,) said of a camel, (T, S,) He, or she, went a gentle pace: (T, M, K:) or went a pace above that which is termed AlEanaqu, (S, M, K,) and above that which is termed Alt~azay~udu: [for] A'Obeyd says, when the pace rises a little above that which is termed AlEanaqu, it is termed Alt~azay~udu; and when it rises above this, it is termed Al*~amiylu; and then, Alr~asiymu: As says that no camel goes the pace termed Al*~amiyl for a day and a night except the mahoriY. (S.)
2 *am~alotuhu * , inf. n. ta*omiylN, I urged him, or made him, (namely, a camel, TA,) to go the pace above mentioned. (K.)
naAqapN *amuwlN * [A she-camel that is accustomed to go the pace above mentioned]: (M, K:) pl. *umulN, (M, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) or *umolN. (TA: in the CK *um~al.)

*amiylapN *
Fatigued, or jaded; (IAar, T, K;) applied to a she-camel. (IAar, TA.)
naAqapN *aAmilapN * [A she-camel going the pace above mentioned]: pl. *awaAmilu. (T.)

1 *amiYa * , (M, K, and so in some copies of the S,) aor. ya*omaY; (K, and some copies of the S;) or *amaY, aor. ya*omiY; (T, and so in some copies of the S;) or both; (Sgh, TA;) inf. n. *amaA='N; (T, * S, M, * K, * TA;) said of a slaughtered animal, (S, TA,) It moved. (T, S, M, Sgh, K, TA.) And *amiYa; (M;) or *amaY, aor. ya*omiY; (K;) inf. n. as above; (M, K; *) He retained remains of the soul, or vital principle: or had strength of heart [remaining: app. said of one dying]. (M, K. [These meaning are there indicated, but not expressed.]) You say, mar~a ya*omiY, inf. n. as above, He passed by at his last gasp of breath. (Har p. 220.) And *amaY, aor. ya*omiY, inf. n. *amoYN [and app. *amaA='N also, as seems to be indicated by what here follows, or perhaps the latter only], He (a sick person) was seized by the agony of death, and was long in suffering the disquietude thereof: whence one says, maA A^aTowala *amaA='ahu [How long is his suffering of the agong and disquietude of death!]. (As, T.) [See *amA='N below.] You say also, of a man, *amiYa, inf. n. *amaA='N, meaning He remained long sick, or diseased. (M.) -A2- *amaY, aor, ya*omiY, inf. n. *amayaAnN, He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly: (Fr, T, S, M, K:) some also mention *amiYa, aor. ya*omaY, [in this sense, and thus I find in one copy of the S,] but [ISd says,] I am not sure of this. (M.) -A3- *amiYa liY minohu $aYo'N means Somewhat thereof was, or became, prepared for me; or feasible, or practicable, to me: (M:) [and so, app., *amaY lY: for] one says, xu*~ mino fulaAnK maA *amaY laka, meaning Take thou, from such a one, what has risen up for thee, or arisen for thee; i. e. maAA@rotafaEa laka. (S.) -A4- *amatoniY Alr~iyHu signifies The odour annoyed me, or molested me; (S, M, K;) accord. to AHn: (M:) and took away my breath; referring to a wind emitted from the anus; inf. n. *amoYN: (M:) and killed me; (T, M;) accord. to AZ; (T;) aor. ta*omiY, (M,) inf. n. *amoYN: (TA:) but Aboo-Málik disallows this, and says, you say, *amato fiY A^anofihi Alr~iyHu, meaning The odour flew [or rose] into his [nose and] head: and accord. to As, you say, *amaY AlHaba$iY~u fiY A^anofi Alr~ajuli biSunaAnihi, aor. ya*omiY, inf. n. *amoYN, The Abyssinian annoyed the man in his nose by the odour of his armpits. (T.) One says also, *amaY, aor. ya*omiY, meaning He, or it, emitted a displeasing odour. (M.)

4 A*mAhu *
He left him ill, or sick, (A^awoqa*ahu, T, or waqa*ahu, K, [which latter may mean thus, or he beat him, or struck him, violently, or so that he became at the point of death, &c.,]) and left him at his last gasp. (T, K.) And A*mY ramiy~atahu He failed of hitting the animal at which he shot, or cast, in a vital part, and therefore hastened to kill it: (T.) [or] he hit the animal at which he shot, or cast, and drove it along, and it drove along with him. (M.)

10 Ast*mY *
He sought, or demanded, a thing: (M:) or he sought, sought for, or sought after, repeatedly, or gradually, (S, K,) and took, (S,) a thing that another had. (S, K.)

*amFY *
A fetid odour: (M:) an odour that is disliked, hated, or hateful. (K.)

*amaA='N * [an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in several senses: as a simple subst., it signifies] Motion [in a slaughtered animal: see 1]: (T, M, K:) and remains of the soul, or vital principle, (S, M, K, and Meyd in explanation of a prov. cited in what follows,) in a slaughtered animal: (S:) or strength of heart: (M, K:) or the state between slaughter and the exit of the soul; but there is no *amaA=' in the case of a human being: or strong tenaciousness of life after slaughter. (Meyd in explaining the prov. above referred to.) It is said, AlD~ab~u A^aTowalu $aYo'K *amaA='F [The lizard called Db~ is the longest thing in retaining the remains of life, &c.]. (T, S.) Hence the prov., A^aTowalu *amaA='F mina AlD~ab~i [Longer in retaining the remains of life, &c., than the Db~]. (Meyd, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Sickness; as in the saying, fulaAnN baAqiY Al*~amaA='i Such a one is long suffering sickness. (MF.) ― -b3- And A fracture of the head: and a spear-wound, or the like, such as is termed jaAy^ifN [q. v.]. (Meyd ubi suprà.)
*aAmK * (M, K) and ↓ mu*am~aApN, (M,) or ma*omaApN, (K,) An animal shot at, or cast at, which is hit, (M, K,) and which one drives along, and which drives along with one. (M.)
mu*am~aApN * , or ma*omaApN: see what next precedes.

1 *an~a * , aor. ya*n~u, inf. n. *aniynN (S, M, K) and *nanu, (K, [but the latter app. belongs to the verb as said of a man,]) It (what is termed *aniyn, S, or mucus, TA, or a thing, and likewise the seminal fluid, M,) flowed; (S, M, K, * TA;) [like *am~a, aor. ya*im~u;] as also ↓ *n~n, inf. n. ta*oniynN, (IAar, T, K,) said of what is termed *aniyn. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And *an~a said of the nose, It flowed [with what is termed *aniyn]; (Lth, T;) like *am~a. (S and K in art. *m.) ― -b3- And *an~a said of a man, (MA,) or *anina, (K, [but this latter I think doubtful,]) see. pers. *aninota, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M,) aor. ya*an~u, (A'Obeyd, T, S,) inf. n. *ananN (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and *aniynN, (K, [but this latter app. belongs to the verb in the senses explained above,]) His nose flowed (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, MA, K *) with what is termed *aniyn: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K: *) and both his nostrils flowed. (M.) ― -b4- *ananN also signifies The flowing of the eye with tears. (M.) [You say, app., *an~ati AlEayonu, meaning The eye flowed with tears] ― -b5- A_in~ahu laya*in~u (tropical:) Verily he is weak and perishing, by reason of extreme old age, or of disease; (S, K, TA;) said of a man: (S:) or ya*in~u, (K,) or ya*in~u fiY ma$oyihi, inf. n. *aniynN, (As, T,) means he walks, or goes along, in a weak manner. (As, T, K.) And *an~N, as an inf. n. [of *an~a], signifies (assumed tropical:) The being in a state of perishing. (KL.) ― -b6- maA zaAla ya*in~u fiY tiloka AlHaAjapi Hat~aY A^anojaHahaA (tropical:) He ceased not to labour, or exert himself, (A, K, TA,) with moderation and gentleness [to attain that object of want until he accomplished it]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- *an~a Albarodu, inf. n. *aniynN, (assumed tropical:) The cold became intense. (TA.)
2 *an~a3a see 1, first sentence.
3 huwa yu*aAn~uhu EalaY HaAjapK * (assumed tropical:) He seeks, or demands, of him an object of want. (S, L, K. *)
4 A^a*ona3a see *unaAnapN, below.
*ano * , for A_i*aAno or A_i*FA: see A_i*FA, in art. A*A.

*ananN * [originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Dirt, or filth; and tfl [i. e. tufol or tafol, meaning saliva; or froth, or foam, or the like; or perhaps it is a mistranscription for vufol, meaning sediment, settlings, dregs, or lees, &c.]: mentioned by Suh. (TA.)
*unaAnN * : see what next follows.

*aniynN * (Lh, T, S, M, K) and ↓ *unaAnN (Lh, S, M, K) [the former originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Mucus (Lh, T, * S, M, K) of any sort, (Lh, M,) or thin mucus, (M, K,) or a thin fluid, (K,) or any fluid, (Lh, M, K,) that flows from the nose. (Lh, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- And the former signifies also The seminal fluid of a stallion, and of an ass, and of a man, (M, TA,) that flows from the penis by reason of excessive appetence. (TA.)

*unaAnapN *
A remainder, or remains, of a thing that is weak, or frail, (S, L, K,) and perishing; (S, L; in both of which is added, $ayoy^FA baEoda $aYo'K ↓ yu*in~uhaA [app. meaning that leaves it portion after portion, by perishing, or passing away, gradually; but this rendering is purely conjectural, for I have not found the verb here used anywhere explained, nor elsewhere even mentioned];) and particularly of a debt, or of a promise: it is distinguished from *ubaAbapN, which signifies a remainder, or remains, of a thing that is sound, or valid, or substantial. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also An object of want; syn. HaAjapN. (K.)

*unaAnaY * The mucus of camels: (K:) or [a fluid] like mucus, that falls from the noses of camels: or, accord. to Kr, it is *unaAbaY: [but see this latter word:] or, as is said by some persons in whom confidence is placed, [in the TA, “ in whom confidence is not placed, ”] it is termed zunaAnaY: (M:) or it is a dial var. of zunaAnaY: or it is correctly with *. (K.)

*unayonaA='u * is mentioned by AHn as being in wheat, but not explained by him, except by his likening it to murayoraA=', which is taken forth from wheat and thrown away. (M.) [It is perhaps a mistranscription for *unayobaA='u, q. v.]

*uno*unN * , (S, M,) or *ino*inN, (T,) The lower, or lowest, part (T, M) of a shirt, (T,) or of a long shirt; a dial. var. of *ulo*ulN (M) [or *ilo*ilN]; mentioned by AA: pl. *anaA*inu: (T:) the *anaA*in of a shirt, (ISk, S,) or of a garment, (K,) are like its *alaA*il: (ISk, S, K:) and some say that the n of the former is a substitute for the l of the latter. (TA.)

A^a*an~N * A man (S, M) whose nose flows with what is termed *aniyn: (S, M, K:) and one whose nostrils flow: (T, M:) fem. *an~aA='u, (S, M, K,) applied to a woman. (S, M.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a nose; as in the prov., A^anofuka minoka waA_ino kaAna A^a*an~a [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be flowing with *aniyn]. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) the fem. signifies also (tropical:) A woman whose menstrual discharge ceases not. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- And qaroHapN *an~aA='u (assumed tropical:) [A wound] that will not be stanched. (TA.)

1 *anabahu * , (M, K,) aor.
*anuba (S, M, A, K) and
*aniba , (M, K,) inf. n. *anobN; (TK;) and ↓ Ast*nbhu; (M, K;) [properly signifies] He followed his tail, not quitting his track: (M:) [and hence, tropically,] (assumed tropical:) he followed him [in any case], not quitting his track. (K.) You say, *anaba AlA_ibila and ↓ Ast*nbhA He followed the camels. (A: there mentioned among proper significations.) ElKilábee says,
wajaA='ati Alxayolu jamiyEaA ta*onubuho
[And the horses, or horsemen, came all together, following him]. (S [in which the meaning is indicated by the context; but whether it be proper or tropical in this instance is not shown].) And Ru-beh says,
Alr~awaAHilaA ↓ mivolu AlA^ajiyri A@sota*onaba
[Like the hired man,] he was at the tails of the ridden camels. (T, S.) *anabati Alqawomu, and [*anabati] AlT~ariyqu, and AlA^amoru [*anaba], and AlsaHaAbu ya*onubu baEoDuhu baEoDFA, are tropical phrases [meaning (tropical:) The people followed one another, and (tropical:) The road followed on uninterruptedly, and (tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, proceeded by successive steps, uninterruptedly, and (tropical:) The clouds follow one another]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2 *n~b * , (T, M, A,) inf. n. ta*oniybN, (T, A,) said of the locust, It stuck its tail into the ground to lay its eggs: (A:) or, said of the [lizard called] Db~, (Lth, T, M,) and of the locust, (M,) and of the [locust in the stage in which it is termed] faraA$, (Lth, T, M,) and the like, (Lth, T,) it desired to copulate, (Lth, T, M,) or to lay eggs, and therefore stuck its tail into the ground: (M:) or, said of the Dab~, it signifies only it struck with its tail a hunter or serpent desiring to catch it: (T:) or, said of the Dab~, it signifies also it put forth its tail (M, A) from the nearest part of its hole, having its head within it, as it does in hot weather, (M,) or when an attempt was made to catch it: (A:) [or it put its tail foremost in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raA^~asa.] ― -b2- *an~abati Albusorapu, (T, S, M, K,) or *an~aba Albusoru, (As, A, Mgh,) or Alr~uTabu, (Msb,) inf. n. ta*oniybN, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) [The full-grown unripe date or dates, or the ripening dates,] began to ripen, (Mgh, and so in a copy of the S,) or showed ripening, (Msb,
and so in a copy of the S,) or became speckled by reason of ripening, (As, T, M, K,) or ripened, (A,) at the *anab, (As, T, S, M, A, Mgh, K,) i. e. the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.) The dates in this case are termed ↓ ta*onuwbN (Fr, T, S, M, A, K) in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, (Fr, T,) and ↓ tu*onuwbN (Fr, T, K) in the dial. of Temeem (Fr, T) and ↓ mu*an~ibN; (A, Mgh;) and a single date is termed ↓ ta*onuwbapN (T, M, * K) and ↓ mu*an~ibapN. (T, S.) -A2- *n~b AlD~ab~a, [or, probably, ↓ *anaba, being similar to raA^asa and janaba and faA^ada &c., or perhaps both,] He seized the tail of the Db~; said of one endeavouring to catch it. (A.) ― -b2- *n~b AlA^afoEaY, said of a Dab~, It turned its tail towards the viper, or met the viper tail-foremost, in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raA^~asa AlA^afoEaY. (TA in art. rA^s.) ― -b3- *n~b EimaAmatahu (tropical:) [He made a tail to his turban;] (S, K, TA;) i. e. (tropical:) he made a portion of his turban to hang down like a tail: (S, TA:) you say of him who has done this, ↓ ta*an~aba. (S, A, K, TA.) ― -b4- *an~abotu kalaAmahu [and kitaAbahu (tropical:) I added an appendix to his discourse and his writing, or book; like *ay~alotuhu]. (A, TA.) [Hence, the inf. n. ta*oniybN is used to signify (assumed tropical:) An appendix; like ta*oyiylN.] ― -b5- *an~abuwA xu$obaAnahu (assumed tropical:) They made channels for water (which are termed ma*aAnib) in its rugged ground. (TA from a trad.)

3 *aAnabato * , (AO, T, K,) written by Sgh, with his own hand, with ', but by others without, (MF,) said of a mare [in parturition], She was in such a state that her fœtus came to her quHoquH [or ischium (here described by MF as the place of meeting of the two hips)], and the siqoY [q. v. (here explained by MF as a skin containing yellow water]) was near to coming forth, (AO, T, K,) and the root of her tail rose, and the part thereof that is bare of hair, and she did not [or could not] lower it. (AO, T.) In this case, she is said to be ↓ mu*aAnibN, (AO, T, K.)

4 A*nb *
He committed a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, &c.; (S, * M, * A, * MA, K; *) he became chargeable with a *anob [or sin, &c.]: (Msb:) it is an instance, among others, of a verb of which no proper inf. n. has been heard; [*anobN being used instead of such, as a quasi-inf. n.;] for A_i*onaAbN, like A_ikoraAmN, [though mentioned in the KL, as signifying the committing of a sin or the like, and also in the TK,] has not been heard. (MF.)

5 t*n~b EalaY fulaAnK *
He accused such a one of a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like, which he had not committed, or though he had not committed any. (A, TA.) -A2- See also 2, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- ta*an~abotu AlwaAdiYa (tropical:) I came to the valley from the direction of its *anab [q. v.]. (A.) And t*n~b AlT~ariyqa (tropical:) He took the road; (K, TA;) as though he took its *inaAbap, or came to it from [the direction of] its *anab. (TA.)

10 Ast*nbhu *
He found him to be committing [or to have committed] a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like: and he attributed, or imputed, to him a sin, &c. (Har p. 450.) -A2- See also 1, in three places. -A3- Ast*nb AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) The affair was, or became, complete, [as though it assumed a tail,] and in a right state. (K, * TA.)

*anobN *
A sin, a crime, a fault, a misdemeanour, a misdeed, an unlawful deed, an offence, a transgression, or an act of disobedience; syn. A_ivomN, (T, M, A, Msb,) or juromN, (S,) or both, (TA,) and maEoSiyapN: (T, TA:) or it differs from A_ivomN in being either intentional or committed through inadvertence; whereas the Avm is peculiarly intentional: (Kull p. 13:) or a thing that precludes one from [the favour of] God: or a thing for which he is blamable who does it intentionally: (KT:) pl. *unuwbN (M, Msb, K) and pl. pl. *unuwbaAtN. (M, K.) walahumo EalaY~a *anobN [in the Kur xxvi. 13, said by Moses, meaning And they have a crime to charge against me,] refers to the speaker's slaughter of him whom he struck, who was of the family of Pharaoh. (M.)

*anabN * and ↓ *unaAbaY (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and ↓ dinib~aY and ↓ *unub~aY (El-Hejeree, M, K) signify the same; (T, S, M, &c.;) i. e. The tail; syn. *ayolN: (TA: [in the CK, Al*~inobiY~u is erroneously put for Al*~inobiY~a:]) but accord. to Fr, one uses the first of these words in relation to the horse, and the second in relation to the bird: (T:) or the first is used in relation to the horse (S, A) and the ass [and the like] (S) more commonly than the second; (S, A; *) and the second is used in relation to a bird (S, M, A, Msb) more commonly than the first, (S, M, *) or more chastely: (M, * Msb:) or the second is [properly] of a winged creature; and the first is of any other; but the second is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: (Er-Riyáshee, TA:) or, as some say, the second signifies the place of growth of the *anab [or tail]: (M:) the pl. of *anabN is A^a*onaAbN. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) [Hence the following phrases &c.] ― -b2- rakiba *anaba AlbaEiyri [lit. He rode on the tail of the camel, meaning] (tropical:) he was content with a deficient lot. (T, A, K.) ― -b3- Daraba bi*anibihi [lit. He smote the earth with his tail, AlA^aroDa being understood, meaning] (assumed tropical:) he (a man) stayed, or abode, and remained fixed. (K.) [See also another explanation of this phrase below.] And A^aqaAma biA^aroDinaA wa garaza *anabahu, meaning (tropical:) [He stayed, or abode, in our land, and remained fixed, or] did not quit it; [lit., and stuck his tail into the ground;] originally said of the locust. (A, TA. [See art. grz.]) ― -b4- bayoniY wa bayonahu *anbu AlD~ab~i [lit. Between me and him is the tail of the Db~,] means (tropical:) between me and him is opposition or competition [as when two persons are endeavouring to seize the tail of the Db~]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- AisotaroxaY *nabu Al$~ayoxi (tropical:) The old man's $aYo' became lax, or languid. (Á, TA.) ― -b6- rakiba *anaba Alr~iyHi [lit. He rode upon the tail of the wind,] means (tropical:) he outwent, or outstripped, and was not reached, or overtaken. (T, A, K.) ― -b7- wal~aY xamosiyna (??) [lit. He turned his tail upon the fifty,] means (tropical:) he passed the [age of] fifty [years]: (M, TA:) and so walatohu Alxamosuwna *anabahaA [lit. the fifty turned their tail upon him]: (A, TA:) the former accord. to Yaakoob: accord. to IAar, El-Kilábee, being asked his age, said, qado wal~ato liYa Alxamosuwna *anabahaA [lit. The fifty have turned their tail to me]. (M, TA.) ― -b8- Ait~abaEa *anaba A^amorK mudobirK [lit. He followed the tail of an event retreating,] means (tropical:) he regretted an event that had passed. (T, A, * TA. *) ― -b9- [The *anab of a man is (assumed tropical:) The part corresponding to the tail: and hence,] rajulN waqaAHu Al*~anabi (assumed tropical:) [A man hard in the caudal extremity;] meaning (assumed tropical:) a man very patient in enduring riding. (IAar, M, and K in art. wqH.) ― -b10- [And of a garment, The skirt:] you say, taEal~aqotu biA^a*onaAbihi (tropical:) [I clung to his skirts]. (A.) ― -b11- The *anaba of a ship or boat is (assumed tropical:) The rudder. (Lth and S * and L in art. skn. [See also xayozuraAnN.]) ― -b12- *anabN also signifies [(assumed tropical:) Anything resembling a tail. ― -b13- Hence,] (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a whip. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b14- And, of an unripe date, (M, Mgh,) and of any date, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The kinder part; (M;) the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.) ― -b15- (tropical:) And (tropical:) The outer extremity of the eye, next the temple; as also ↓ *inaAbN and ↓ *inaAbapN (M, A) and ↓ *unaAbapN (A) [and ↓ *unaAbaY, as used in the K voce Aizodaj~a, in art. zj]. ― -b16- See also *anuwbN, third sentence. ― -b17- Also (assumed tropical:) The end; or last, or latter, part; of anything: pl. *inaAbN (T) [and A^a*onaAbN]: and ↓ *inaAbN [as a sing.], (K,) or ↓ *unaAbN, (so in the TT as from the M,) has this meaning. (M, K.) You say, kaAna *`lika fiY *anabi Ald~ahori (assumed tropical:) That was in the end of the time [past]. (M.) And *anabu AlwaAdiY and ↓ Al*unaAbapu: both signify the same [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The end of the valley]: (A 'Obeyd, M, TA:) or ↓ *unaAbapN and ↓ *inaAbapN and ↓ *anabapN signify the (tropical:) last, or latter, parts, (K, TA,) in some copies of the K, the last, or latter, part, (TA, [and so in the TT as from the M, and this meaning seems to be indicated in the A,]) of a valley, (A, K, TA,) and of a river, (A, TA,) and of time; (K, TA;) [and ↓ *inaAbN app. has the former of these two significations in relation to a valley, accord. to Az; for he says,] it seems that *inaAbN and ↓ *inaAbapN in relation to a valley are pls. of *anabN, like as jimaAlN and jimaAlapN are pls. of jamalN: (T:) or ↓ *inaAbapN and ↓ *anabapN, (S, Msb,) the former of which is more common than the latter, (Th, S, Msb,) signify (assumed tropical:) the place to which finally comes the torrent of a valley: (S, Msb:) the pl. of ↓ *inaAbapN is *anaAy^ibu: (T:) the *anab of a valley and its ↓ mi*onaba are the same; [i. e. (assumed tropical:) the lowest, or lower, part thereof;] (T;) [for the pls.] A^a*onaAbN (T, TA) and ma*aAnibu (TA) signify (assumed tropical:) the lowest, or lower, parts of valleys: (T, TA:) and A^a*onaAbN signifies [in like manner] (assumed tropical:) the last, or latter, parts, of [water-courses such as are termed] tilaAE. (T, TA. See also mi*onabN.) It is said in a trad, laA yamonaEu fulaAnN *anaba taloEapK [(assumed tropical:) Such a one will not impede the last part of a water-course]; applied to the abject, weak, and contemptible. (T.) And A^a*onaAbu A^umuwrK means (tropical:) The last, or latter, parts of affairs or events. (M.) You say also, HadiyvN Tawiylu Al*~anabi (tropical:) [A long-tailed story;] a
story that hardly, or never, comes to an end. (M.) And yawomN Tawiylu Al*~anabi (assumed tropical:) A day of which the evil does not come to an end: (TA:) and ↓ yawomN *anuwbN has this meaning; (T, M, TA;) as though it were long in the tail; (M;) or means (assumed tropical:) a day of long-continued evil. (K.) And Ait~abaEa Alqawomi ↓ *inaAbapa, and AlA_ibili, (tropical:) He followed [the last of] the people, and the camels, not quitting their track. (A.) ― -b18- Also (tropical:) The followers, or dependants, of a man: (T, TA:) and ↓ *aAnibN and ↓ *unaAbapN (assumed tropical:) a [single] follower, or dependant: (S, K:) and A^a*onaAbN (M, A, K) and ↓ *unaAbaY (S) and danaAy^ibu [pl. of ↓ *unaAbapN] (A) and ↓ *unubaAtN, (so in the TT as from the M,) or ↓ *anabaAtN, (K,) but some state that this last is not said of men, (Ham p. 249,) (tropical:) followers, or dependants, (S, M, A, K,) of a people or party; (M, K;) and the lower, or lowest, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, thereof; (M, A, K;) and such as are below the chiefs. (TA.) Daraba yaEosuwbu Ald~iyni bi*anabihi, in a trad. of 'Alee, means, [accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) The leader of the religion] shall go away through the land with followers, or dependants, (T, * TA,) and those holding his opinions. (T. [But see arts. Drb and Esb.]) And EuqayolN TawiylapN Al*~anabi, a phrase mentioned by IAar, but not explained by him, app. means (assumed tropical:) [The tribe of] 'Okeyl have numerous horsemen. (M.) ― -b19- [Also *anabN (as will be shown by the use of its pl. in the verse here following) and] ↓ *inaAbN, (S, K, TA,) or ↓ *unaAbN, (so in the TT as from the M,) (assumed tropical:) The sequel, consequence, or result, syn. EaqibN, of anything. (S, M, K.) A poet says,
taEal~aqota mino A^a*onaAbi law~K balayotaniY
walayota kalaw~K xayobapN layosa yanofaEu
[From considering what might be the sequels of “ if, ” (i. e. of the word lawo,) Thou clungest to the reflection “ Would that I had done so and so: ” but “ would that, ” like “ if, ” is disappointment: it does not profit]. (TA.) And one says, mano laka law~K ↓ bi*inaAbi i. e. [Who will be responsible to thee for] the sequel [of the word lawo]? (TA:) [or, as in the Proverbs of El-Meydánee, law~K ↓ bi*unaAbapi, which means the same.] ― -b20- *anabu Als~iroHaAni: see art. srH. ― -b21- *anabu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) A certain asterism (najomN, M, K, TA) in the sky, (TA,) resembling the *anab [or tail] of the horse. (M, K.) [Al*~anabu is a name applied to each of several stars or asterisms: as (assumed tropical:) The star a of Cygnus; also called *anabu Ald~ajaAjapi, and Alr~idofu: and (assumed tropical:) The star beta of Leo; also called *anabu AlA^asadi. And Alr~aA^osu waAl*~anabu signifies (assumed tropical:) The two nodes of a planet: see tin~iynN.] ― -b22- *anabu Alxayoli, (K,) or A^a*onaAbu Alxayoli, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A certain herb, (M, K,) of which the expressed juice concretes: so called by way of comparison [to horses' tails: the latter name is now applied to the equisetum, or horse-tail]. (M.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxii.,) the Portulaca oleracea (or garden-purslane) is called in some parts of El-Yemen *anabu Alfarasi.] *anabu Alv~aEolabi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, resembling the *anab [or tail] of the fox; (M, K;) a name applied by some of the Arabs to the *anabaAn [q. v.] (T.) ― -b23- [*anabu Als~abuEi (assumed tropical:) Cauda leonis, i. e. circium (or cirsium): (Golius, from Diosc. iv. 119:) now applied to the common creeping way-thistle. ― -b24- *anabu AlfaA^orapi (assumed tropical:) Cauda muris, i. e. plantago. (Golius, from Ibn-Beytár.) ― -b25- *anaba Alvawori (assumed tropical:) A species of aristida, supposed by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. civ,) to be the aristida adscensionis. ― -b26- *anabu AlEaqorabi (assumed tropical:) Scorpioides, or scorpion-grass: so called in the present day.]
*anabapN * , and its pl. *anabaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
*unubaAtN * : see *anabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

*anabaAnN *
A certain plant, (T, S,) well known, called by some of the Arabs *anabu Alv~aEolabi: (T:) a certain plant having long branches, somewhat dust-coloured (M, TA) in its leaves, growing in plain, or soft, land, upon the ground, not rising high, approved as pasture, (TA,) and not growing except in fruitful years: (M, TA:) or a certain herb, or plant, like *urap [or millet]; (K;) or a certain herb having ears at its extremities like the ears of *urap, (M, TA, *) and having reeds, (qSb [i. e. qaSab], M,) or twigs, (qDb [i. e. quDub], TA,) and leaves, growing in every place except in unmixed sand, [for Hur~a Alr~amoli in the TA, I find in the M Haw~a Alrumli,] and growing upon one stem and two stems: (M, TA:) or, accord. to AHn, a certain herb, having a jzrp [app. meaning rhizoma like the carrot], which is not eaten, and twigs bearing a fruit from the bottom thereof to the top thereof, having leaves like those of the Turoxuwn, agreeing well with the pasturing cattle, and having a small dust-coloured blossom upon which bees feed; (M, TA;) rising about the height of a man, (TA,) or half the height of a man; (M;) two whereof suffice to satiate a camel: (M, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (M, K.)
*unub~aY * and *inib~aY: see *anabN, first sentence.
*unaAbN * : see *anabN, in two places.

*inaAbN * : see *anabN, in five places: ― -b2- and see also mi*onabN. ― -b3- Also A small cord with which a camel's tail is tied to his hind girth, lest he should swing about his tail and so dirt his rider. (M, K.)

*anuwbN * A horse (T, S, &c.) having a long tail: (T, S:) or having a full, or an ample, tail. (M, A, K.) [See also A^a*onabN.] ― -b2- Hence applied to a day: see *anabN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b3- Also A great dalow [or bucket]: (Fr, T, Msb:) or one that has a ↓ *anab [or tail]: (TA:) or one that is full (S, M, Msb, K) of water; (S, Msb;) not applied to one that is empty: (S, TA:) or one that is nearly full of water: (ISk, S:) or one containing less than fills it: or one containing water: or a dalow (M, K) in any case: (M:) or a bucketful of water: (A:) masc. and fem.; (Fr, Lh, T, S, M, Msb;) sometimes the latter: (Lh, M:) pl. (of pauc., S) A^a*onibapN and (of mult., S) *anaAy^ibu (S, M, K) and *inaAbN. (M, A, * Msb, K.) Fr. cites as an ex.,
lanaA *anuwbN walakumo *anuwbu
faA_ino A^abayotumo falanaA Alqaliybu
[as meaning For you shall be a great bucket, and for us a great bucket: or, if ye refuse this, for us shall be the well]. (T.) [Accord. to the K, it also signifies A grave: but this is evidently a mistake, which seems to have arisen from a misunderstanding of a statement by ISd, who says,] Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it metaphorically in relation to a grave, calling it [i. e. the grave] a well, in his saying,
fakunotu *anuwba Albiy^ora lam~aA tabas~alato
wasurobilotu A^akofaAniY wawus~idotu saAEidiY
[app. meaning (tropical:) And I was as though I were the corpse of the grave (lit. the bucket of the well) when she frowned, and clad with my grave-clothes, and made to recline upon my upper arm: for the corpse is laid in the grave upon its right side, or so inclined that the face is turned towards Mekkeh]. (M.) [And Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee, describing a wild he-ass and she-asses, likens to it a certain rate of running which he contrasts with another rate likened by him to a well such as is termed xasiyfN: see Kosegarten's “ Carmina Hudsailitarum, ” p. 189.] ― -b4- Hence metaphorically applied to (tropical:) Rain. (Ham p. 410.) ― -b5- [Hence, also,] (tropical:) A lot, share, or portion: (Fr, T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) [see the former of the two verses cited in this paragraph:] in this sense masc.: (Msb:) and in this sense it is used in the Kur li. last verse but one. (Fr, T, M.) -A2- Also (tropical:) The flesh of the [portion of the back next the back-bone, on either side, which is called the] maton: (M, K:) or the part where the maton ends; (M;) the flesh of the lower, or lowest, part of the maton: (S:) or the [buttocks, or parts called] A^aloyap and maA^okim: (M, K:) or the flesh of the A^aloyap and maA=kim: (CK:) and the *anuwbaAni are the [two parts called the] matonaAni, (M, K,) on this side and on that [of the back-bone]: (M:) or *anuwbu Almatoni means the flesh that is called yaraAbiyEu Almatoni [which are the portions of flesh next the back-bone, on either side thereof]. (A.)
*unayobN * [dim. of *anabN: -A2- and] i. q. *unayobiY~N, q. v. (TA.)
dunaAbapN * The A^alof [i. e. toe, or foremost extremity, also called the A^asalap,] of a sandal. (K.) ― -b2- See also *anabN, in six places. ― -b3- And see mi*onabN.

*inaAbapN * : see *anabN, in six places: ― -b2- and see mi*onabN, in two places. ― -b3- *inaAbapN AlT~ariyqi (assumed tropical:) The point, or place, to which the way, or road, leads; syn. wajohuhu. (IAar, M, K.) So in the saying of Abu-l-Jarráh, to a certain man, A_in~aka lamo taro$ado *inaAbapa AlT~ariyqi [(assumed tropical:) Verily thou didst not follow a right course in
respect of the point, or place, to which the way that thou tookest leads]. (IAar, M.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Relationship; nearness with respect to kindred; or near relationship. (K.)

*unaAbaY * : see *anabN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also applied to Four [feathers] in the wing of a bird, after what are called AlxawafiY. (S.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., mano maAta EalaY *unaAbaY TariyqK fahuwa mino A^aholihi, meaning [(assumed tropical:) Whosoever dies] purposing to pursue a way leading to some particular end, [he is to be reckoned as one of the people thereof.] (TA.) -A2- Accord. to Fr and the S, it signifies also A fluid like mucus that falls from the noses of camels: but this is a mistake: the right word, as stated by IB and others, is *unaAnaY. (L, MF, TA.)

*unayobaA='u *
A certain grain that is found in wheat, whereof the latter is cleared [by winnowing or other means]. (M, K.) [See also *unayonaA='u, in art. *n.]
*unayobiY~N * (assumed tropical:) A certain kind of [the striped garments called] buruwd [pl. of burodN]; (AHeyth, K;) as also ↓ *unayobN. (TA.)
*aAnibN * (tropical:) Following in the track of a thing. (TA.) See also *anabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.
A^a*onabu * A [lizard of the kind called] Dab~ having a long tail. (T, L.) [See also *anuwbN.]
ta*onuwbN * and tu*onuwbN, and with p: see 2.
ma*onabN * : see the next paragraph.

mi*onabN *
A long tail. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, app. for *uw mi*onabK], (T,) or ↓ mu*an~ibN, (TA, [but see this latter below,]) A [lizard of the kind called] Dab~. (T, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) or ↓ ma*onabN, like maqoEadN, (A,) and ↓ mi*onabapN, (M, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A ladle; (S, M, A, K;) because it has a tail, or what resembles a tail: (M:) pl. ma*aAnibu. (S, M.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A water-course, or channel of a torrent, in a tract at the foot of a mountain; (Lth, T, S, M, A, K;) not wide; (A;) or not very wide; (M;) or not very long and wide; (Lth, T;) as also ↓ *inaAbapN: (S:) the taloEap is in the lower part of a mountain (Lth, T, A) or in an acclivity: (Lth, T, S, A:) also a water-course or channel of a torrent, between what are termed taloEataAni; (TA; [see taloEapN, and see also madofaEN;]) or this is termed taloEap ↓ *anabu; (T;) or it is termed ↓ *inaAbN, of which the pl. is *anaAy^ibu: (M, K:) also a water-course, or channel of a torrent, [running] to a tract of land: (M, K:) and a rivulet, or streamlet, (K,) or the like thereof, (AHn, T, M,) flowing from one rawoDap [or meadow] to another, (AHn, T, M, K,) and separating therein; (T;) as also ↓ *unaAbapN and ↓ *inaAbapN; (K;) and the tract over which this flows is also called mi*onabN. (T.) See also *anabN, in the middle of the paragraph.
mi*onabapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mu*an~ibN * [app. applied to a she-camel, accord. to the K, or perhaps to a lizard of the kind called Dab~, as seems to be indicated in the TA,] Finding difficulty in parturition, and therefore stretching out her tail: (K:) [but accord. to Az,] it is applied to a Dab~ only when he is striking with his tail a hunter or a serpent desiring to catch him. (T.) See also mi*onabN. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.
ma*onuwbN * (tropical:) A man followed [by dependants]. (A.)
mu*aAnibN * A camel that is at the rear of other camels; (K;) as also ↓ musota*onibN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3.
saHaAbN muta*aAnibN * (tropical:) Clouds following one another. (A.)
musota*onibN * : see mu*aAnibN. ― -b2- Also One who is at the tails of camels, (S, TA,) not quitting their track. (TA.)
*iho * and *ihiY: see art. *A.

1 *ahaba * , (S, A, &c.,) aor.
*ahaba , (A, K,) inf. n. *ahaAbN (S, A, Msb, K) and *ihaAbN (TA) and *uhuwbN (S, A, K) and ma*ohabN, (A, K,) He (a man, S, [and a beast,]) went [in any manner, or any pace]; went, or passed, along; marched; journeyed; proceeded: went, or passed, away; departed: syn. ma$aY, (A,) or saAra, (K,) or mar~: (S, A, K:) and said of a mark or trace or the like [as meaning it went away]. (Msb.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) It wasted away; became consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended.] ― -b2- *ahaba A_ilayohi He went, repaired, betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it. (TA.) And they say also, *ahaba Al$~aA^oma [He went to Syria]; making the verb trans. without a particle; for although Al$A^m is here a special adv. n., they liken it to a vague locality. (TA.) ― -b3- *ahaba Eanohu He, or it, went from, quitted, relinquished, or left, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- *ahaba fiYAlA^aroDi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. *ahaAbN and *uhuwbN and ma*ohabN, He went away [into the country, or in the land]: (Msb:) [but it often means (assumed tropical:) he went into the open country, or out of doors, to satisfy a want of nature: or simply] (tropical:) he voided his excrement, or ordure. (A.) ― -b5- *ahaba bihi He went, or went away, with him, or it: (A:) and he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart; (A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A*hbhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) and bihi ↓ A*hb, (K,) but this is rare; (Zj, TA;) and ↓ *h~bhu, inf. n. ta*ohiybN: (MF:) [all may likewise be rendered he removed, dispelled, put away, or banished, it; properly and tropically: and (assumed tropical:) he made it to cease; made away with it, did away with it, made an end of it; wasted, consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended, it; and these meanings may perhaps be intended by A^azaAlahu, whereby the first is explained in the A and K, as are also the second and third in the K:] or, accord. to some, when *ahaba is trans. by means of bi, accompaniment is necessarily signified; but not otherwise; so that if you say *ahaba bihi, the meaning is, he went away with him, or it; i. e., accompanying him, or it; [he took away, or carried off or away, him, or it;] but if you say ↓ A*hbhu or ↓ *h~bhu, the meaning is, he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart, alone, without accompanying him, or it: this, however, is not agreeable with the phrase in the Kur [ii. 16], *ahaba A@ll~`hu binuwrihimo [though this may be well rendered God taketh away their light]. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] one says, A^ayona yu*ohabu bika, which may mean (assumed tropical:) Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mtr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning A^ayona yu*ohabu biEaqolika (assumed tropical:) [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Har p. 574.) [In like manner one says, *ahaba Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His reason, or intellect, quitted him, or forsook him; he became bereft of his reason, or intellect. And *ahaba fuw^aAduhu (assumed tropical:) His heart forsook him, or failed him, by reason of fear or the like.] And *ahaba laHomuhu (assumed tropical:) [His flesh wasted away]. (K in art. bHr, &c.) And *ahaba Alr~ajulu fiY Alqawomi (tropical:) The man became lost [or he disappeared] among the people, or party. (A.) And *ahaba AlmaA='a fiY All~abani (tropical:) The water became lost [or it disappeared] in the milk. (A.) ― -b6- *ahaba Ealayohi (tropical:) It escaped his memory; he forgot it. (A, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, dubious, confused, or vague, to him. (MA.) ― -b7- *ahaba ma*ohabFA HasanFA (S, A, TA) (tropical:) He pursued a good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (TA.) And *ahaba fiY Ald~iyni ma*ohabFA (assumed tropical:) He formed, or held, an opinion, or a persuasion, or a belief, respecting religion: or, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, he introduced an innovation in religion. (Msb.) And *ahaba ma*ohaba fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He pursued the way, course, mode, or manner, of acting &c. of such a one. (Msb.) And *ahaba li*ahobihi and lima*ohabihi (tropical:) He pursued his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting &c. (JK, TA.) And *ahaba A_ilaY ma*ohabK (tropical:) He betook himself to [or took to or held] a belief, a creed, a persuasion, a doctrine, an opinion, a tenet, or a body of tenets or articles of belief. (K, TA.) And fulaAnN ya*ohabu A_ilaY qawoli A^abiY Haniyfapa (tropical:) Such a one takes to, or holds, [the saying, or] the belief, creed, persuasion, doctrine, &c., of Aboo-Haneefeh. (A.) [And *ahaba A_ilaY A^an~a AlA^amora ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He held, or was of opinion, that the thing, or affair, or case, was so. And *ahaba bilafoZK A_ilaYlafoZK A=xara (assumed tropical:) He regarded a word, or an expression, in his manner of using it, as equivalent to another word, or expression; as, for instance, when one makes a fem. noun masc. because it is syn. with a noun that is masc., or makes a verb trans. by means of a certain perticle because it is syn. with a verb that is trans. by means of that same particle: and also (assumed tropical:) he regarded a word, or an expression, as etymologically relating, or traceable, to another word, or expression. And *ahaba bihi A_ilaY maEonaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He regarded it, or used it, (i. e. a word, or an expression,) as relating to such a meaning, or as
meaning such a thing.] ― -b8- *ahaba fiY Talabi Al$~aYo'i kul~a ma*ohabK (assumed tropical:) [He tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking the thing]. (K in art. mwt.) And *ahaba fiYAll~iyni kul~a ma*ohabK (assumed tropical:) [It attained the utmost degree of softness]: said of the skin. (TA in that art.) ― -b9- Ai*ohabo A_ilayoka (assumed tropical:) Betake, or apply, thyself to thine own affairs; or occupy thyself therewith. (T and K * voce A_ilaY.) ― -b10- *ahaba A_ilaY A^abiyhi fiY Al$~abahi i. q. nazaEa (assumed tropical:) [He inclined to his father in likeness; resembled him; or had a natural likeness to him]. (S in art. nzE.) -A2- *ahiba, (S, K,) aor.
*ahaba , (K,) inf. n. *ahabN; (TA;) and *ihiba, with two kesrehs, (IAar, K,) of the dial. of Temeem, held by AM to be a variation generally allowable in the case of a verb of which the medial radical letter is a faucial and with kesr; (TA;) He (a man) saw gold in the mine, (S,) or came suddenly, in the mine, upon much gold, and his reason departed in consequence thereof, (K,) and his eyes became dazzled, so as not to close, or move, the lids, or became confused, so as not to see, (S, K,) by reason of the greatness thereof in his eye: (S:) it is derived from *ahabN: and the epithet applied to a man in this case is ↓ *ahibN. (TA.)
2 *ah~aba see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places: -A2- and see also 4.

4 A^a*ohaba see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places. -A2- Also A*hbhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i*ohaAbN; (S;) and ↓ *h~bhu, (K,) inf. n. ta*ohiybN; (S;) He gilded it; did it over with gold. (S, Msb, K.)
[ Q. Q. 2 tama*ohaba * , from ma*ohabN, is used by late writers as meaning (assumed tropical:) He followed, or adopted, a certain religious persuasion or the like.]
*ahobN * : see ma*ohabN: -A2- and see also the last sentence of the paragraph here following.

*ahabN * [Gold;] a certain thing well known; (S, Msb, &c.;) accord. to several of the leading lexicologists, (TA,) i. q. tiborN; (A, L, K, &c.;) but it seems to have a more general meaning; for tiborN is specially applied to such [gold] as is in the mine, or such as is uncoined and unwrought: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.; and therefore] it is masc. and fem.: (S, * Msb, K, * TA:) or it is fem. in the dial. of El-Hijáz: or, accord. to Az, it is masc., and not to be made fem. unless regarded as pl. of ↓ *ahabapN, (Msb, TA,) [or rather as a coll. gen. n., for] *ahabapN is the n. un., (K,) signifying a piece of *ahab [or gold]: (S, A, L, TA:) or, accord. to El-Kurtubee, it is fem., and sometimes masc., but more commonly fem.: ↓ *uhayobapN is the dim. of *ahabN, the p being added because the latter word is fem., like as it is in quwayosapN and $umayosapN; or it is the dim. of *ahabapN, and signifies a little piece of *ahab [or gold]: (TA:) the pl. of *ahabN is A^a*ohaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, A, Msb, K) and *uhuwbN (S, K) and *uhobaAnN (Nh, Msb, K) and *ihobaAnN. (Nh, TA.) [maA='u Al*~ahabi means Water-gold; goldpowder mixed with size, for ornamental writing &c.] ― -b2- The yolk, or the entire contents, i. e. yolk and white, (muH~, K, TA, with the unpointed H, TA, [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K mux~,]) of an egg. (K.) -A2- Also, (S, K,) in a copy of the T written ↓ *ahobN, (TA,) A certain measure of capacity, for corn, used by the people of ElYemen, (S, K,) well known: (S:) pl. *ihaAbN (K) and A^a*ohaAbN, [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] (S, K,) and pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of the latter of the pls. above] A^a*aAhibu, (S, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) mentioned by A' Obeyd, (S,) or A^a*aAhiybu. (So in the CK.)
*ahibN * : see 1, last sentence.

*ihobapN *
A rain: (S:) or a weak rain: or a copious rain: (A'Obeyd, K:) pl. *ihaAbN. (A'Obeyd, S, K.)
*ahabapN * : see *ahabN, first sentence.
*ahuwbN * : see *aAhibN.
*ahiybN * : see mu*ohabN, first sentence.
*uhayobapN * : see *ahabN, first sentence.

*aAhibN * [part. n. of *ahaba;] Going [in any manner, or any pace]; going, or passing, along; marching; journeying; proceeding: going, or passing, away; departing: [&c.:] (A, K:) and ↓ *ahuwbN signifies the same [in an intensive manner]. (K.) ― -b2- [*aAhibN fiY AlT~uwli means (assumed tropical:) Excessive in length or tallness.]

ma*ohabN * is an inf. n.: (JK, A, K:) ― -b2- and also signifies A place of *ahaAb [or going, &c.]: and a time thereof. (JK.) ― -b3- [Also A place to which one goes: see an ex. voce maHoDarN. ― -b4- And hence,] (tropical:) A place to which one goes for the purpose of satisfying a want of nature; a privy; (TA;) i. q. mutawaD~aA^N; (JK, A, K, TA;) in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz. (JK, A, TA.) ― -b5- [Also A way by which one goes or goes away. ― -b6- And hence, as in several exs. in the first paragraph of this art.,] (tropical:) A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (Msb, K, TA:) (tropical:) [a way that one pursues in respect of doctrines and practices in religion &c.; and particularly a way of believing, opining, thinking, or judging;] a belief, a creed, a persuasion, a doctrine, an opinion, a tenet, or a body of tenets or articles of belief; (K, TA;) an opinion in, or respecting, religion; and, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, an innovation in religion: (Msb:) and ↓ *ahobN signifies the same. (JK, TA.) [The pl. is ma*aAhibu. Hence, *awuw ma*aAhibu (assumed tropical:) Persuasions, as meaning persons holding particular tenets in religion or the like.] ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) Origin: (Ks, Lh, K:) so in the sayings, maA yudoraY lahu A^ayona ma*ohabahu and laA yudoraY lahu ma*ohabN, i. e.
