(assumed tropical:) It is not known whence is his origin. (Ks, Lh, TA.)

mu*ohabN *
Gilt, or done over with gold; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ mu*ah~abN (A, K) and ↓ *ahiybN. (T, K.) ― -b2- Also sing. of ma*aAhibu, which signifies Skins gilt, (ISk, JK, TA,) i. e. having gilt tines, or stripes, regularly, or uniformly, succeeding one another: (ISk, TA:) or gilt straps or thongs: (S, TA:) and variegated, or figured, [garments of the kind called] buruwd: (JK, TA:) [or it is applied as an epithet to such garments; for] you say burodN mu*ohabN. (TA.) The pl. above mentioned is also applied [as an epithet] to swords [app. meaning Adorned with gilding]. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a horse, Of a red colour tinged over with yellow; (TA;) and so kumayotN mu*ohabN [i. e. of a gilded bay colour]: (S, TA:) fem. with p: the mare thus termed is of a clearer colour and thinner skin. (TA.) -A2- Almu*ohabu is also a name of The Kaabeh. (K, TA.) -A3- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

mu*ohibN *
A gilder. (S.) ― -b2- ↓ Almu*ohabu, explained by Lth as the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain devil, said to be of the offspring of Iblees, who tempts reciters of the Kur-án in the performance of [the ablution termed] AlwuDuwo', (K, * TA,) and on other occasions, (TA,) is [said to be] correctly [Almu*ohibu,] with kesr to the h: (K:) applied to the devil, (TA in art. $yT,) as meaning (assumed tropical:) he who embellishes, or renders goodly in appearance, acts of disobedience [to God], as also Almuha*~ibu, (Fr, TA in art. h*b,) IDrd thinks that it is not [genuine] Arabic. (TA.) And accord. to the S and El-Kurtubee and many others, ↓ bihi mu*ohabN means (assumed tropical:) [In him is] a vain suggestion [of the devil] respecting the water, and [respecting] the using much thereof in the wuDuwo': [i. e. a vain suggestion that may induce him to think that the water is unfit, or deficient in quantity, or the like:] but accord. to the K, it is correctly Almu*ohibu. (TA.) Az says that the people of Baghdád apply the appellation mu*ohibN to (assumed tropical:) A man who inspires vain suggestions; and that the vulgar among them pronounce it ↓ mu*ohabN. (TA.)

ma*ohabapN * [A cause, or means, of doing away with, removing, dispelling, or banishing]. Fasting is said, in a trad., to be ma*ohabapN liloA^a$ari [i. e. (assumed tropical:) A cause, or means, of dispelling exultation, or excessive exultation, and resting the mind upon things agreeable with natural desire]. (T and S voce maHosamapN, q. v.)
mu*ah~abN * : see mu*ohabN.

1 *ahala Eanohu * , (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor.
*ahala , (S, K,) inf. n. *aholN, (JK, S,) or *uhuwlN, (Msb,) or both; (K;) and *ahila, (S, Msb,) aor.
*ahala , (Msb,) inf. n. *uhuwlN; (S;) He forgot it, or neglected it; (S;) he was, or became, unmindful of it; (S, Msb:) or he neglected it intentionally; (JK, T, M, K, * TA; EalaY EahodK in the K being a mistake for ElY EamodK, as in the [JK and T and] M; TA;) or in consequence of his being diverted by something: (T, K:) or he forgot it, or dismissed it from his mind, intentionally, and became diverted from it: (Z, Msb:) *uhuwlN is the neglecting a thing, dismissing it from the mind: (Ham p. 31:) or the quitting a thing, with confusion, or perplexity, or alienation of mind, such as arises from fear &c.: (Ksh and Bd in xxii. 2:) or the being diverted from one's constant companion, or familiar, so
as to forget him; and being content to relinquish him: (K;) or diversion that occasions grief and forgetfulness. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxii. 2], yawoma tarawonahaA ta*ohalu kul~u muroDiEapK Eam~aA A^aroDaEatN [On the when thou shalt see it, every woman giving suck shall forget, or neglect, &c., what she has suckled]. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

4 A^a*ohalaniY Eanohu * , (JK, * S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. A_i*ohaAlN, (TA,) It (a thing, JK, S, TA,) or he, (a man, Msb,) caused me to forget it, or neglect it; (S;) or to be unmindful of it; (S, Msb;) or to neglect it intentionally: (JK:) [like A^a*ahananiY Enh:] and sometimes one says ↓ *ahalaniY; (Msb, TA;) [like *ahananY;] but this is rare; or, rather, unknown. (TA.)
*aholN * : see what next follows.

jaA='a baEoda *uholK mina All~ayoli * , (S, K, *) and ↓ *aholK, (S, K,) He came after a short portion, or a period, (saAEap, K, or hado', S,) of the night: (S, K:) so called because sleep causes men to forget (yu*ohilu Aln~aAsa) therein: (Ham p. 4:) or a large portion; such as the third, or the half: so says IDrd; but he doubts its correctness; and ISd holds it to be preferably with d. (TA.) -A2- *uholN also signifies The tree [or plant] ba$aAm [q. v.]. (JK, Sgh, K.)
*uholuwlN * A horse fleet, or swift: (K:) or light, or active: and so a man: pl. *ahaAliylu. (JK.)
*aAhilN * [act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- And] A man who cares not for ornament and the anointing of himself. (JK.)

1 *ahina * , (MA, TA,) aor.
*ahana , (TA,) inf. n. *ihonN and *ahanN, (MA, KL,) He was, or became, intelligent, possessed of understanding, sagacious, acute, skilful, knowing, (MA, KL, PS, TA,) and endowed with a retentive mind. (KL, PS.) You say, Ai*ohano A_ilaY maA A^aquwlu Understand thou what I say. (TA.) And huwa laA ya*ohanu $ayoy^FA He does not understand anything. (TA.) And *ahinotu ka*aA wa ka*aA I understood such and such things. (TA) And *ahinotu Eano ka*aA I understood from such a thing. (TA.) -A2- *aAhananiY fa*ahanotuhu: see 3. ― -b2- *ahananiY Eanohu, and ↓ A^a*ohananiY, and ↓ Aisota*ohananiY, He, or it, made me to forget it; diverted me from remembering it: (K, * TA:) [like *ahalaniY Eanohu, and A^a*ohalaniY.] And *uhina Memory, or understanding, escaped him, or left him. (JK.)

3 *aAohana ↓ *aAhananiY fa*ahanotuhu He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, in intelligence, understanding, sagacity, acuteness, skill, or knowledge, and I surpassed him [therein, i. e.,] in *ihon. (K.)
4 A^a*ohana see 1.

10 A_isota*ohana see 1. ― -b2- You say also, Aisota*ohanaka Hub~u Ald~unoyaA The love of the present world took away, or has taken away, thy *ihon [i. e. intelligence, understanding, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Aisota*ohanati Als~anapu AlqaSaba (assumed tropical:) The year of drought took away the *ihon, i. e. pith (niqoY), of the canes, or reeds. (TA.)

*ihonN * (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ *ahanN (S, K) Intellect, intelligence, understanding, sagacity, acuteness, skill, or knowledge; syn. EaqolN, (JK, K,) and fahomN, (K,) and fiTonapN, (S, Msb, K,) and *akaA='N; (Msb;) and retentiveness of mind, or memory: (JK, * S, * K:) or, as some say, a faculty of the soul, provided for the acquisition of the several species of knowledge, including the external and internal senses: strength thereof is termed *akaA='N: and a good quality thereof for the forming ideas of the things that present themselves to it is termed fiTonapN: (TA:) pl. A^a*ohaAnN. (Msb, K. *) One says, AijoEalo *ihonaka A_ilaY ka*aA waka*aA [Apply thine intellect, &c., to such and such things]. (TA.) [Both are also inf. ns.: see 1, first sentence.] ― -b2- Also, the former, (assumed tropical:) Strength: (JK, S, K:) and fat: (JK, K:) pl. as above. (K.) One says, maA birijolaY~a *ihonN There is not in my legs any strength to walk. (TA.) And huwa mino A^aholi Al*~ihoni and AlA^a*ohaAni (tropical:) He is of those endowed with strength [of body: and also, of those endowed with intelligence, &c., and intelligent faculties]. (TA.) And maA raA^ayotu biAlA_ibili *ihonFA (assumed tropical:) I saw not, in the camels, fat and strength. (JK.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The pith (niqoY) of canes, or reeds. (TA.) -A2- See also *ahinN.
*ahanN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

*ahinN * and ↓ *ihonN Intelligent, possessed of understanding, sagacious, acute, skilful, or knowing, [and endowed with a retentive mind;] each [said to be] a possessive epithet, [signifying possessing *ihon, though the former is agreeable with a general rule as part. n. of *ahina,] applied to a man; the latter app. changed [or contracted] from the former. (TA.)

[
*ihoniY~N *
Of, or relating to, the *ihon, or intellect, &c.; intellectual; subjective; ideal. Hence, AlA^amuwru Al*~ihoniy~apu Intellectual things; the things that are conceived in the mind, or considered subjectively; opposed to AlA^amuwru AlxaArijiy~apu.]

*uw * meaning SaAHib [i. e. A possessor, an owner, a lord, or a master, but often better rendered having, possessing, possessed of, or endowed with], (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, but omitted in the CK,) used as a prefixed noun, (S, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) is originally *awFA, like EaSFA, the A being changed from w; (S;) or it is originally *aw~aY; and if one used it as a proper name, he would say, h`*aA *aw~aYqado jaA='a [This is Dhawà, he has come]; (M;) [not *awFA, as in copies of the S; i. e.,] its third radical letter is Y, not, as J says, w; this Y being afterwards suppressed; (IB;) [so that the word becomes *awN, and then, by reason of its being prefixed to another noun, *uw, like as A^abawN, the original form of A^abN, becomes A^abuw:] it is declined [like A^abuw] with w and | and Yi; (Msb;) [i. e.,] the nom. case is *uw, accus. *aA, and gen. *iY: (Mgh:) the fem. is *aAtu; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K; in a copy of the M, *Ap, and the CK, *aApN [as though it were not a prefixed noun];) and in the case of a pause, some say *aAto, and others say *aAho: (Lth, T: the latter usage, only, is mentioned in the S:) dual. masc., *awaA, (S, * M,) [accus and gen. *awaYo;] fem. *awaAtaA, (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) for which *aAtaA is allowable in poetry, but *awaAtaA is better, (T,) [accus, and gen. *awaAtaYo:] pl., masc., *awuw, (T, *, S, * M, Msb, K, but omitted in the CK,) [accus, and gen. *awiY;] fem. *awaAtu, (T, S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K,) accus. and gen. *awaAti; (S;) and A^uwluw and A^uwlaAt are like *awuw and *awaAt [in signification]. (T. [See art. Alw.]) In this sense it is not used otherwise than as a prefixed noun: when used to characterize an indeterminate noun, prefixed to an indeterminate noun; and when used to characterize a determinate noun, prefixed to [a noun rendered determinate by] the article Al. (S.) [Thus you say rajulN *uw maAlK A man a possessor of wealth; and Alr~ajulu *uw AlmaAli The man the possessor of wealth.] In the phrase gayora *aAti Al$awokapi [Not those possessed of weapons, &c.], in the Kur [viii. 7], the fem. form is used as meaning the TaAy^ifap [or party]. (T.) SaAra *aA *anobK [He became one having a sin, or crime, &c., attributable to him, i. e. he had a sin, &c., attributable to him,] means taHam~ala *anobFA [he became chargeable with a sin, &c.]. (Msb in art. *nb.) ― -b2- Accord. to the S, it is not prefixed to a pronoun (muDomar); nor to a proper name, such as zayod and Eamorw and the like: but there are several instances of its being prefixed, in its pl. form, to a pronoun; among which is the saying of a poet,
A_in~amaA yaSoTaniEu AlmaEoruwfu fiY Aln~aAsi *awuwhu
[Only they who are possessors thereof do that which is good among men]: (TA:) [this usage, however, is perhaps only allowable by poetic license: see another ex. (also here cited in the TA) in the Ham p. 442, and the remarks there appended to it:] and it is also prefixed to proper names, as is shown by the phrase, (TA,) h`*aA *uw zayodK (M, K, TA,) mentioned, as heard from the Arabs, by Ahmad Ibn-Ibráheem, the preceptor of Th, meaning This is Zeyd, (M, TA,) i. e., this is the owner of the name Zeyd; (M, K, TA;) and [perhaps] by the name *uw AlxalaSapi, for AlxlSp is [said by some to be] the name of a certain idol, and *w is a metonymical appellation of its bayot; and by the proper names *uw ruEayonK and *uw yazana and [accord. to some] *uw jadonK [and the like, of which several are mentioned in the S, as well as in the M &c.]. (IB, TA.) [But see a later portion of this paragraph, where, prefixed to a proper name, it is said to be redundant.] ― -b3- *awuw AlA^aroHaAm, [or, as in the Kur viii. last verse, and xxxiii. 6, A^uwluw AlA^aroHaAmi, pls. of *uw Alr~aHimi,] in the classical
language, means [The possessors of relationship; i. e.] any relations: and in law, any relations that have no portion [of the inheritances termed faraAy^iD] and are not [such heirs as are designated by the appellation] EaSabap [q. v.: they are so called because they are relations by the women's side: see raHimN]. (KT, TA.) ― -b4- If you form a pl. from *uwmaAlK, you say, h`w^ulaA='i *awuwna [These are possessors of wealth]; because in this case the pl. is not a prefixed noun. (S.) Accord. to Lth, Al*~awuwna signifies The former, or first, [of persons,] and the more, or most, distinguished. (T, TA. *) Also, (S, M,) and AlA^a*owaA='u, [which is another pl. of *uw,] (S,) The kings (S, M) of El-Yemen, of the tribe of Kudá'ah, (S,) whose surnames commenced with *uw, (M,) [i. e.] who were named [or rather surnamed] (S) *uw yazana (S, M) and *uw jadanK and *uw nuwaAsK (S) and the like. (S, M.) qura$iY~N layosa mino *iY walaA *uw, occurring in a trad., means A Kurashee in respect of lineage, not of the A^a*owaA=' [above mentioned]. (TA.) ― -b5- [*uw and *aAt and *aA and *iY are also used as prefixed nouns in various expressions here following, in several thereof as meaning Something in possession, or the like; not a possessor: or, in these instances, as is said in explanation of the first of the following phrases, and also of the phrase *aAtu Alyadi (mentioned below) in Har p. 93, that which is contained is made to be as though it were the possessor (SaAHib) of that which contains.] ― -b6- maw~ata *aAbaTonihaA [He killed what was in her belly]. (Har ubi suprá.) And waDaEati AlmaroA^apu *aA baTonihaA, (T,) or *aAta baTonihaA, (TA,) The woman brought forth [her child]. (T, TA.) And navarato *aA baTonihaA She brought forth many children. (T in art. nvr; and Mgh there and in the present art., in the latter of which it is added that the usual phrase is navarato baTonahaA.) And A^aloqati Ald~ajaAjapu *aA baTonihaA The hen laid her egg, or eggs: or muted. (Mgh.) And A^aloqaY Alr~ajulu *aA baTonihi The man ejected his excrement, or ordure. (T.) And Al*~iy^obu magobuwTN bi*iY baTonihi The wolf is envied [for what is in his belly, or] for his distention of the belly [with food]. (TA.) ― -b7- [In like manner,] *aAtu Alyadi means (tropical:) Wealth; as though it were the possessor of that which contains it: (Har ubi suprá:) [or what is in the possession of the hand:] or what one possesses, of wealth; because gained by the hand and disposed of by the hand. (Har p. 66.) You say, qal~ato *aAtu yadihi (assumed tropical:) What his hand possessed became little in quantity; (Lth, T;) or the possessions accompanying his hand; (Mgh;) app. meaning his riches. (Lth, T.) ― -b8- *aAtu Alr~iy^api and *aAtu Aljanobi are Two well-known diseases. (TA. [See arts. rA^Y and jnb.]) ― -b9- EaliymN bi*aAti AlS~uduwri, in the Kur iii. 115, means [Acquainted, or well acquainted,] with what is in the minds: (Ksh, Bd, Jel: [and the like is indicated in the Mgh:]) or with the true, or real, nature of the notions that are concealed in the minds: (IAmb, T:) or with the hidden things of the minds: or with the minds themselves. (Msb. [If the last meaning be correct, the phrase should be mentioned with others later in this paragraph.]) [And similar to this is the saying,] Earafahu mino *aAti nafosihi He knew it from what he conceived in his mind [without his being informed thereof; i. e. he knew it of himself]. (Lth, T.) And jaA='a mino *iYnafosihi and mino *aAti nafosihi (M, K) He came [from a motive in his own mind; of himself;] of his own accord; or willingly; syn. Tay~iEFA: (M, TA:) in the copies of the K, TaboEFA; but the former is the right explanation. (TA.) And maA kal~amotu fulaAnFA *aAta $afapK and *aAta famK I spoke not to such a one a word. (AZ, T.) ― -b10- *aAta Alyamiyni and *aAta Al$~imaAli [are adverbial expressions, and] mean In the direction of the right hand and of the left: properly in the direction that has the name of the right hand [and that has the name of the left hand]. (Bd in xviii. 16.) And A^atayonaA *aA yamiynK means We came on the right hand. (TA.) ― -b11- *aAta mar~apK and *aA SabaAHK [also, and the like,] are adverbial expressions, which may not be used otherwise than as such: (S:) you say, laqiytuhu *aAta mar~apK [I met him once, or once upon a time], (S,) and *aAta AlmiraAri many times, (M and K in art. mr,) or sometimes, (S in that art.,) and *aAta yawomK (Fr, T, S) i. e. mar~apF fiY yawomK [once upon a day, or one day], therefore you use the fem. form, (T,) and *aAta layolapK [one night], (Fr, T, S,) and *aAta gadaApK [one morning, or one morning between daybreak and sunrise], and *aAta AlEi$aA='i [once in the evening at nightfall], (S,) meaning, accord. to Th, in the hour, or time, in which is nightfall, (T,) and *aAta Alz~umayoni (Fr, T, S) [some time ago, or] three [or more, to ten,] seasons ago, (mu*o valaAvapu A^azomaAnK, T, [by AzmAn being app. meant periods of two, or three, or six, months,]) and *aAta AlEuwayomi (Fr, T, S) [some years ago, or] three years ago (T,) or three years ago or more, to ten; (Az on the authority of AZ, TA in art. Ewm;) and *aA SabaAHK [one morning], and *aA masaA='K [one evening], (T, S,) and *aA SabuwHK [lit, at a time of drinking the morning-draught], and *aA gabuwqK [lit. at a time of drinking the evening-draught]; in these four instances without p: and this mode of expression has been heard only in the cases of the times here mentioned: they did not say *aAta $ahorK nor *aAta sanapK: (S:) or one may also well say *aAta SabaAHK, like *aAta yawomK; for *A and *At both mean the time: and accord. to IAar, one says, A^atayotuhu *aAta AlS~abuwHi and *aAta Algabuwqi, as meaning I came to him in the morning, or in the morning between daybreak and sunrise, and in the evening, or in the evening between sunset and nightfall. (T.) ― -b12- You say also, laqiytuhu *aAta yadayoni, (TA,) or laqiytuhu A^aw~ala *iY yadayoni (M) and *aAti yadayoni, (AZ, M, Msb, [whence it seems to be not improbable that the phrase in the TA is imperfectly transcribed,]) meaning I met him the first thing, (M,) or first of everything. (AZ, Msb, TA.) And A^afoEaluhu A^aw~ala *iY yadayoni and *aAti yadayoni [I will do it the first thing, or first of everything]. (M.) And A^am~aA A^aw~ala *aAti yadayoni faA_in~aniY A^aHomadu A@ll~`ha, (AZ, M, Msb,) i. e. [Whatever be the case, the first thing, or] first of everything, I praise God. (AZ, Msb.) ― -b13- [Respecting the phrase *aAtu Albayoni, which has two contr. meanings, see art. byn. It is inadequately explained in this art. in the T and M and K, as follows.] waA^aSoliHuwA *aAta bayonikumo, (T, M, K, *) in the Kur [viii. 1], accord. to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, means [And do ye rightly dispose, or arrange, or order,] the case that is between you: (T:) or, accord. to Zj, (M,) that wherein consists your union; (Haqiyqapa waSolikumo, M, K;) i. e. be ye of one accord, or in unison, respecting that which God and his Apostle have commanded: (M:) or *aAtu Albayoni means the state of circumstances whereby the Muslims become of one accord, or in unison: (K:) this is the meaning in the saying, Aall~`hum~a A^aSoliHo *aAta Albayoni [O God, do Thou rightly dispose &c.]. (M.) ― -b14- *aAtN is sometimes used as a noun independent in its meaning, (Mgh, Msb,) so as to denote material [or real] things; (Msb;) and is described by the epithets mutamay~izapN [or “ distinct ”] (Mgh, Msb) and qadiymapN [as meaning “ that has existed from eternity ”] (Mgh) and muHodavapN [as meaning “ that has been brought into existence ”]. (Mgh, Msb.) Thus used, (Msb,) it signifies The essence of a thing, meaning that by being which a thing is what it is, or that in being which a thing consists; or the ultimate and radical constituent of a thing: and the essence as meaning the peculiar nature of a thing: syn. HaqiyqapN, (T, IB, Msb, TA,) and maAhiy~apN, (Msb,) and xaAS~apN: (T, IB, TA:) it is also used as meaning a thing's self: (Mgh, * Msb:) [a man's self, or person: (see $axoSN:)] and a thing; a being; anything, whatever it be; every $aYo' being a *aAt, and every *At being a $Y': (Aboo-Sa'eed, Mgh, Msb:) and particularly a substance, or thing that subsists by itself: [hence Aisomu *aAtK meaning a real substantive; also termed Aisomu EayonK: opposed to Aisomu maEonFY, i. e. an ideal substantive:] and [hence] it signifies also a word that is independent in its meaning; [i. e. *aAtN (alone), though oftener used in the sense assigned above to Aisomu *aAtK, signifies also, absolutely, a substantive;] opposed to SifapN as signifying a word that is not independent in its meaning. (Kull p. 187.) Its application to God, in the sense of HaqiyqapN and xaAS~apN, is forbidden by most persons: (TA:) [for] *aAtu A@ll~`hi [as meaning The essence of God], used by the scholastic theologians, is said to be an ignorant expression, because the names of God do not admit the fem. affix p; so that one does not apply to Him the epithet Eal~aAmapN, though He is the all-surpassing in knowledge. (Msb.) The phrase fiY *aAti A@ll~`hi is like fiY janobi A@ll~`hi [In, or in respect of, that which is the right, or due, of God; or in, or in respect of, obedience to God, or the means of obtaining nearness to God, or the way of God]: and like liwajohi A@ll~`hi [for the sake of God; or to obtain the countenance, or favour, or approbation, or recompense, of God]: (Msb:) or it means in obedience to God; and in the way of God or his religion: (TA:) [or it may be rendered for the sake of God Himself; and so
liwajohi A@ll~`hi: it is said to have been used by the Arabs [of the classical age], as well as by Aboo-Temmám, [who was a Muwelled;] (Mgh, Msb, *) but some deny that it occurs in the old language. (Msb. [See, however, an ex. from a trad. voce A^uxayo$inu.]) [It is said that] the phrase majal~atuhumo *aAtu AlA_il`hi, used by En-Nábighah, (Msb,) i. e. EdhDhubyánee, (TA in art. jl,) means Their book is the service of God Himself: (Msb:) [but it seems more reasonable to render this phrase agreeably with the primary signification of *At as meaning their book is that of God, in a sense like that in which a house of worship is said to be a house of God; for,] as some relate it, the phrase used by En-Nábighah is maHal~atuhumo *aAtu AlA_il`hi, with HA', [i. e. their abode is in a peculiar manner that of God,] meaning, their abode is one of pilgrimage and of sacred sites. (S and TA in art. jl.) ― -b15- *uw is sometimes redundant [in respect of meaning, though governing as a prefixed n.]; and so is its pl. (T, * TA.) Az says, (TA,) I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, kun~aA bimawoDiEi ka*aA maEa *iY EamorKw, i. e. We were in such a place with Amr: (T, TA:) and kaAna maEanaA *uw EamorKw, i. e. 'Amr was with us: and A^atayonaA *aA yamanK, meaning A^atayonaA Alyamana [We came to El-Yemen]. (T.) [See an ex. similar to this last, and evidently belonging to the present art., in the latter half of art. *A. And see laA *aA jarama and laA A^ano *aA jarama and laA Eano *aA jarama and laA *aA jara (in which *A is in like manner redundant, as are also A^ano and Eano, the latter of which is a dial. var. of the former of them,) in art. jrm: perhaps belonging to the present art., like A^atayonaA *aAyamanK; or perhaps to art. *A. See also what is said respecting *uw prefixed to a proper name in an early portion of this paragraph.] ― -b16- It is also used in the sense of Aal~a*iY, (T, S, M, K,) in the dial. of Teiyi, (T, S, TA,) for the purpose of qualifying a determinate noun (S, M, K) by means of a proposition which it connects with that noun: (M, K:) and when thus used, it [generally] retains the same form when it denotes a dual and a pl. (S, M, K) and a fem., (S,) and exhibits no sign of case: (M, K:) you say, A^anaA *uw Earafotu [I who knew], and *uw samiEotu [who heard]; and h`*ihi AlmaroA^apu *uw qaAlato ka*aA [This is the woman who said such a thing: (S:) and A^ataAniY *uw qaAla *`lika [He who said that came to me]; and A^ataAniY *uw qaAlaA *`lika [They two who said that came to me]; and A^ataAni *uw qaAluwA *`lika [They who said that came to me]. (M.) But Fr says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, biAlfaDoli *uw faD~alakumo A@ll~`hu bihi waAlkaraAmapi *aAtu A^akoramakumu A@ll~`hu bihaA [By the excellence wherewith God hath made you to excel, and the honour wherewith God hath honoured you]; thus they use *aAtu in the place of Aal~atiY, and they make it to be with refa in every case: and they confuse [numbers and genders] in speaking of a dual number and a pl. number [and a fem.]; they sometimes say, [for ex.,] in the case of the dual, h`*aAni *uw taEorifu and haAtaAni *uw taEorifu [These two whom, or which, thou knowest]; and a poet says, [namely, Sinán Ibn-El-Fahl, of the tribe of Teiyi, (Ham p. 292,)]
faA_in~a AlmaA='a A^abiY wajad~iY
wabiy^oriY *uw Hafarotu wa*uw Tawayotu
[For verily the water is the water of my father and my grandfather, and my well which I dug and which I cased; making *w to relate to a fem. noun]: and some, he adds, use the dual and pl. and fem. forms; thus they say, h`*aAna *awaA qaAlaA *aAka [These two who said that], and h`w^ulaA='i *awuwA qaAluwA [These who said], and h`*ihi *aAtu qaAlato [This female who said]; and he cites the saying of a poet,
jamaEotuhaA mino A^ayonuqK sawaAbiqo
*awaAtu yanohaDona bigayori saAy^iqo
[I collected them from outstripping she-camels, that rise and hasten in their pace without a driver]; and the prov., A^ataY Ealayohi *uw A^ataY EalaY Aln~aAsi, meaning Al~a*iY A^ataY [i. e. What has come upon men in general has come, or came, upon him]. (T.) Accord. to the usage most in repute, *uw in this sense is indecl., and has no variation of gender or number; but some decline it, like *w in the sense of SaAHib, except that they make *aAt and *awaAt indecl., with damm for the termination, saying *aAtu and *awaAtu in every case, if they adopt the chaste mode; otherwise, in the accus. and gen. cases, saying *aAti, and in like manner *awaAti (I' Ak pp. 40 and 41.) ― -b17- They said also, laAA^afoEalu *`lika bi*iY tasolamu (M, K) and b*Y tasolamiyna, (M,) and b*Y tasolamaAni, (M, K,) and b*Y tasolamuwna and b*Ytasolamona, (M,) meaning I will not do that by thy, and by your, safety: (M, K:) or by God who, (M,) or by Him who, (K,) maketh thee, and you, to be in safety. (M, K.) [See also art. slm.]
*aAtN * fem. of *uw [q. v. passim]. (T, S, M, &c.)
*aAtiY~N * : see *awawiY~N, below, in three places.

*aAtiy~apN * [a post-classical word, used in philosophy, The essential property or quality, or the aggregate of the essential properties or qualities, of a thing]. The *aAtiy~ap of a human being is [the essential property or quality of] rational animality; and is also termed maAhiy~apN. (Kull p. 148.)

*awawiY~N * the rel. n. of *uw; (S, TA;) and of *aAtN also, (S, M, Msb, TA,) the p of the original being rejected in forming the rel. n.: (S, Msb, * TA:) ↓ *aAtiY~N, as rel. n. of *aAtN, is not allowable: (M:) [but it is much used, mostly in philosophical and religious writings, as meaning Essential, &c.:] they say ↓ AlS~ifaAtu Al*~aAtiy~apu [meaning The essential attributes]; (Mgh, Msb;) but this is a wrong expression: and ↓ EayobN *aAtiY~N [An essential, or] a natural, an innate, an original, or a constitutional, fault or imperfection &c. (Msb.)

1 *aAba * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. ya*uwbu, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. *awobN (S, M, Msb, K) and *awabaAnN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) It melted, dissolved, or became fluid or liquid; contr. of jamada: (S, M, A, K:) it flowed. (T, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] *Ab damoEuhu (tropical:) [His tears flowed]. (A.) And *aAbato Hadaqatuhu (tropical:) [His eye] shed tears; (A;) or flowed [with tears]. (T.) ― -b3- *Ab jisomuhu (tropical:) His body became lean, or emaciated: one says, vaAba baEodamaA *aAba (tropical:) [He became fat after he had been lean]. (A.) ― -b4- And *aAba [alone] (assumed tropical:) He became foolish, or stupid, after having been intelligent. (T, K.) ― -b5- naHonu laA najomudu fiY AlHaq~i walaA na*uwbu fiY AlbaATili (tropical:) [We will not be hard, or niggardly, in the case of truth, or right, nor will we be soft, or easily yielding, in the case of falsity, or wrong]. (A.) ― -b6- h`*aA AlkalaAmu fiyhi *awobu Alr~uwHi (tropical:) [This speech, or discourse, contains that which melts the soul]. (A.) ― -b7- *aAbati Al$~amosu [and ↓ Ast*Abt (as is shown by a phrase mentioned in the L in art. Sxd)] (tropical:) The sun became intensely hot. (S, A, K.) ― -b8-
A^a*uwbu All~ayaAliY A^awoyujiybu SadaAkumaA
occurring in a trad. of Kuss, means (assumed tropical:) I will wait in expectation during the lapse of the nights [or the echo of you two shall answer]; from AlA_i*aAbapu, which signifies “ spoil, booty, or plunder. ” (TA.) ― -b9- maA *aAba fiY yadiY $aYo'N (assumed tropical:) There remained not in my hand anything. (AHeyth, TA.) And maA *aAba fiY yadayohi minohu xayorN, (M,) or fiY yadiY, (K,) (assumed tropical:) There came not [into his hands, or into my hands, from him, or it, any good]. (M, K.) ― -b10- *Ab Ealayohi AlmaAlu (assumed tropical:) The property became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him to render as a debt. (T.) And *Ab liY Ealayohi Haq~N (tropical:) A right, or due, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him to render to me, and established against him. (S, A, Mgh, K. *) And *Ab Ealayohi mina AlA^amori ka*aA, inf. n. *awobN, (assumed tropical:) Such a part of the thing, or affair, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; like jamada and barada. (M.) -A2- *Ab also signifies He continued in the eating of *awob i. e. honey. (T, L, K. *)

2 *w~bhu * : see 4. -A2- Also, inf. n. ta*owiybN, He made [or disposed] for him a *uwaAbap [or *uw^aAbap]: irreg.; being originally with ' [i. e. *aA^~abahu]. (T, K.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh, kaAna yu*aw~ibu A^um~ahu, meaning He used to plait the *wAbp of his mother. (TA.)

4 A*Abhu * and ↓ *w~bhu He melted it, dissolved it, rendered it fluid or liquid, liquified it; (S, M, A, K;) or made it to flow. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., (S, TA,) respecting butter, (S,) maA yadoriY A^ayuxoviru A^amo yu*iybu [expl. in art. xvr]. (S, M, TA.) [See also a verse of Bishr cited below in this paragraph.] ― -b2- [Hence,] the former [as meaning (tropical:) It dissolved him, or emaciated him,] is said of anxiety, (A, TA,) and grief. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A*Ab HaAjatahu, and ↓ Ast*AbhA, (tropical:) He matured,
and fully accomplished, the object of his want. (A, TA.) And A*AbwA A^amorahumo (assumed tropical:) They put their affair into a good, sound, or right, state. (K.) ― -b4- A*AbwA EalayonaA, (S, M,) or Ealayohimo, (A, K,) inf. n. A_i*aAbapN, (S,) (tropical:) They made an inroad or incursion, or a sudden attack, urging their horses, upon us, or upon them, (S, M, A, K,) and took spoil [from us, or them, or made, or left, our property, or theirs, to be taken as spoil]. (A.) Hence the saying of Bishr (S) Ibn-Abee-Kházim, (TA,)
fakaAnuw ka*aAti Alqidori lamo tadori A_i*o galato
A^atatorukuhaA ma*omuwmapF A^amo tu*iybuhaA
(S,) or wakunotumo, (M, TA,) and A^atonoziluhaA, (so in some copies of the S and M,) meaning (assumed tropical:) [And they were, or and ye were, like her having the cookingpot, not knowing, when it boiled, whether she should leave it, or put it down from the fire, disapproved, or] whether she should let it be taken as spoil: (S, TA:) so accord. to AZ: (S:) or the meaning is, [whether she should put it down from the fire,] or make it to remain; i. e. tuvobituhaA, (S, TA,) or tuboqiyhaA; (AHeyth, TA;) from *aAba liY Ealayohi Haq~N, expl. above, (S, TA,) or from maA *aAba fiY yadiY $aYo'N, also expl. above: (A Heyth, TA:) or, accord. to As, the meaning is, or whether she should melt it; from the prov. mentioned above in this paragraph: (S, TA:) i. e., whether she should leave it in a thick state, [disapproved,] or should melt it; fearing that the butter [in the cooking-pot] would spoil. (TA.) [In the TT, for ma*omuwmapF, I find madomuwmapF, which, applied to a cooking-pot, means smeared, or done over, with spleen, &c. See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 626 et seq.]

10 Aisota*abotuhu * signifies Talabotu minohu Al*~awoba [which may be rendered I asked, or desired, of him honey, &c.]: (K:) [but accord. to ISd,] it signifies, agreeably with other verbs of this form, I asked, or desired, of him that he would melt or dissolve [butter &c.]. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] Ast*Abt Al$~amosu: see 1. ― -b3- Ast*Ab HaAjatahu: see 4. ― -b4- Ast*Ab *awobapF (assumed tropical:) He preserved a residue of his wealth, or property. (TA.)

*aAbN *
A vice, fault, defect, or the like; (K;) like [*ayobN and] *aAmN and *ayomN. (TA.)

*awobN * [What is fluid, or liquid, of water &c.; contr. of jamodN: see jaAmidN: and see also *aAy^ibN. ― -b2- ] Honey, (T, M, K,) in a general sense: (M:) or honey cleared from its wax: (T, M, K:) or honey in the bees' cells: (S, M, K:) and melted, or liquefied, honey: (M:) or melted, or liquefied, honey, cleared from its wax: so in the saying, ↓ huwa A^aHolaYmina Al*~awobi biAlA_i*owaAbapi (tropical:) [He, or it, is sweeter than honey melted and cleared of its wax, with fresh butter melted in a cooking-pot to clarify it]. (A.) ― -b3- Gum flowing upon the ground. (TA voce migofarN.) ― -b4- *awobu Al*~ahabi Watergold: or, accord. to Er-Rázee, fluid, or liquid, gold; the inf. n. *awob being used in this instance in the sense of *aAy^ib. (Har p. 448.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) Foolishness, or stupidity. (TA.) [But see the next paragraph.]

*awobapN * (assumed tropical:) A residue of wealth, or property: so in the saying A^asolama EalaY *awobapK (assumed tropical:) He became a Muslim on the condition of his preserving a residue of his wealth, or property. (TA from a trad.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) Manifest foolishness or stupidity: so in the phrase fiY fulaAnK *awobapN (assumed tropical:) In such a one is manifest foolishness or stupidity. (TA in art. $wb.) You say also, Zaharato fiyhi *awobapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Foolishness, or stupidity, appeared in him. (T.)

*uwbaAnN * and *iybaAnN [like *iy^obaAnN] The remains of the [fur, or soft hair, called] wabar [after the greater part has fallen off or been shorn]: or the hair (Al$~aEaru [for which Al$~Eri is erroneously put in the CK]) on the neck (M, K) and lip (M) of the camel (M, K) or horse. (K.) -A2- Also the former, Paupers and thieves; for *uw^abaAnN [a pl. of *iy^obN, q. v.], the ' being changed into w. (TA.)
*aw^uwbN * [originally *awuwbN] A fat she-camel: (A, K:) because what is melted (maA yu*aAbu) is collected from her. (A, TA.)
haAjirapN *aw~aAbapN * (tropical:) A midday, or summer-midday, intensely hot. (T, A, TA.)

*aAy^ibN * part. n. of 1, [Melting or dissolving, fluid or liquid; or] flowing; contr. of jaAmidN. (Msb.) ― -b2- lahu dumuwEN *awaAy^ibu (tropical:) [He has flowing tears]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- *aAy^ibu AlmaAli, as opposed to jaAmid [q. v.], (tropical:) Such property as consists in what is fluid, or liquid: (L in art. jmd:) or such as consists in live stock: (L and K in that art.:) or such as consists in trees. (L in that art.) ― -b4- *aAy^ibu Aln~afosi (tropical:) Heavy, slow, indolent, or dull, of soul; syn. vaqiylN. (A.)

A_i*aAbapN *
Spoil; booty; plunder: [in this sense] a subst. [in the proper meaning of the term]; not an inf. n. (M, TA.)

A_i*owaAbN * and A_i*owaAbapN, [the latter, only, mentioned in the A, app. as being the more common,] Fresh butter when it is put into the cooking-pot to be cooked so as to become samon [i. e. clarified butter]: (AZ in explanation of the latter word, T, S:) or fresh butter which is melted in the cooking-pot to make samon: this name continues to be applied to it until it is put into the skin. (M, K.) See *awobN.
mu*aAbN * and ↓ mu*aw~abN Melted, or dissolved, fat [&c.]. (A.)

mi*owabN *
A vessel in which a thing is melted, or dissolved. (M, K.)

mi*owabapN *
A ladle. (Lh, M, K.)
mu*aw~abN * : see mu*aAbN.
*uwbaAjN * : see jw*Ab, in art. j*b.

1 *aAda * , (M, A,) first pers. *udotu, (T, S,) aor. ya*uwdu, (T, A,) inf. n. *awodN, (T,) or *iyaAdN, (S,) or both, (M, A, K,) He drove: (S, M, K:) he drove away: (T, S, M, A, K:) and he repelled. (M, K.) You say, *adotu AlA_ibila I drove the camels: (S:) and I drove them away: (T, S:) and [so ↓ *aw~adotuhaA, for] ta*owiydN signifies the same as *iyaAdN. (S.) And *Ad AlA_ibali Eani AlmaA='i, (A, Msb,) aor. ya*uwdu, inf. n. *awodN and *iyaAdN, He (the pastor) [drove away, or repelled, or] kept back, or debarred, the camels from the water; or prevented them from coming to it. (Msb.) And *Adhu Eano ka*aA, (A,) and *udotuhu, (S,) He, and I, drove him away from such a thing. (S, A. [And the like is said in the M.]) And *Ad Eani AlHarami He repelled from, or defended, the sacred territory. (L.) And Alv~aworu ya*uwdu Eano nafosihi bimi*owadihi, i. e. (tropical:) [The bull repels from, or defends, himself] with his horn: and AlfaArisu bimi*owadihi, i. e. (tropical:) [the horseman] with his spear, or short spear. (A.) And *Ad Eano EiroDihi (assumed tropical:) He defended his honour. (L.) And *Ad Ean~iY Alham~a (tropical:) [He dispelled from me anxiety.] (A.)
2 *aw~ada see above.

4 A*Adhu *
He aided, or assisted, him to drive, or drive away, (T, S, M, A,) his camels. (T, S, A.) [In the K, A^a*adotuhu is said to signify A^aEanotuhu EalaY *iyaAdi A^aholihi: but Ahlh is app. a mistake for A_ibilihi: or Eano is omitted before Ahlh; and if so, the meaning is I aided, or assisted, him to defend his family; but in this latter case, we should read *iyaAdK, which would be less chaste than Al*~iyaAdi.]

*awodN *
A number of camels, from three to ten: (Lth, AZ, As, T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) this is the meaning that is of best repute: (TA:) [in this explanation in the T from AZ, and in the K, the nouns of number are mase.; and so in the next here following: in the rest, fem.:] or from three to ten: and a little more: (IAar, M:) or from three to nine: (M, L:) or from three to fifteen: or from three to twenty; (M, L, K;) and a little more: (L:) or from three to thirty: (M, L, K:) or from two to nine: (M, Mgh, L, K:) [said to be] applied only to females: (Lth, A'Obeyd, T, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) so in the Bári': (Msb:) and it is of the fem. gender; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) i. e., the word is fem.: (MF:) but its dim. is [↓ *uwayodN,] without p; contr. to analogy: (M:) the word *awodN is a pl., (M, K,) meaning a quasipl. n., (MF,) having no sing. (S, M, K) of the same root: (S:) or a sing.; (K;) and its pl. is A^a*owaAdN: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) or a sing. and pl.: (M, K:) the Arabs said valaAvu A^a*owaAdK and valaAvu *awodK and so with all the inferior ns. of number, making *awod a substitute for A^a*owaAd: and they also said valaAvu *awodK meaning thereby three she-camels. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., layosa fiymaA duwna xamosi *awodK mina AlA_ibili SadaqapN, (T, L,) or layosa fiYA^aqal~a mino xamosK *awodK SadaqapN, (T, Msb,) meaning [There is not in the case of less than five] camels [any poorrate]: for the poor-rate is incumbent on him who possesses five camels whether they be males or females. (L.) And in another trad. it is said,
fiY xamosi *awodK $aApN [In the case of five camels, a sheep or goat shall be given]. (Mgh.) And it is said in a prov., Al*~awodu A_ilaY Al*~awodi A_ibilN [A few she-camels with a few she-camels are a herd of camels]; (T, S, M, A;) meaning that a little with a little is much; AlY being here used in the sense of maEa: (S, A:) or AlY is here used in its proper sense; a word signifying “ joined ” or the like being understood; (TA;) i. e. a few joined to a few becomes much: (M:) [or,] accord. to the K [and the T], this prov. shows that *wd is here used in the place of AivonataAni [i. e. two she-camels]; for two added to two are a pl.; but this requires consideration. (MF.)
*uwayodN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
*aw~aAdN * : see the next following paragraph.

*aAy^idN *
Driving: driving away: and repelling: pl. *uw~adN and *uw~aAdN and *aAdapN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ *aw~aAdN, [but the latter has an intensive meaning,] (assumed tropical:) A man who is a defender, or protector, of that which, or those whom, it is necessary to defend, or protect: (S, K:) who is wont to repel attacks upon his honour. (S, * TA.)

ma*aAdN *
A place where beasts pasture at pleasure, where they eat and drink what they please, amid abundance of herbage. (IAar, K.)

mi*owadN * [An instrument for driving, driving away, or repelling. ― -b2- ] (tropical:) A spear, or short spear, with which one repels from, or defends, himself. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The horn of a bull, (T, A, K,) with which he repels from, or defends, himself. (A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The tongue: (S, M, A, K:) because with it a man defends his honour. (M.) Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
lisaAniY wasayofiY SaArimaAni kilaAhumaA
wayabolugu maA laA yabolugu Als~ayofu mi*owadiY
(tropical:) [My tongue and my sword are sharp, both of them; and my tongue reacheth what my sword will not reach]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) [A man who defends well, or vigorously; as also ↓ mi*owaAdN:] you say rijaAlN ma*aAwidN and ma*aAwiydu. (A.) ― -b6- The manger (miEolaf, T, K, TA, in some copies of the K mEtlf, TA) of a horse or similar beast. (T, K. [A manger is thus called in the present day.])
mi*owaAdN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

div2.head: Quasi *wr
div2.entryFree: *aArato * for *aAr~ato or *aA='arato: see 3 in art. *r.

1 *aAfa * , (M, K,) aor. ya*uwfu, (M,) inf. n. *awofN, He walked with short steps, and in a straddling manner. (M, K.) -A2- And *ufotu is a dial. var. of *ufotu, signifying I mixed [medicine &c.] (M.)
*uwfaAnN * [like *uw^ofaAnN &c.] Poison: (K:) or poison made into a confection: or deadly poison: like *iyfaAnN [&c.]. (M.)

1 *aAqahu * , (K,) first pers. *uqotuhu, aor. A^a*uwqohu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. *awoqN and *awaAqN and ma*aAqN (S, Msb, K) and ma*aAqapN, (S, K,) He tasted it; i. e., perceived its taste, by means of the moisture of the tongue: (Msb:) or he tried, or knew, its taste: (K:) it is originally said of that of which little is taken: when much is taken, the term A^akolN is used [and one says A^akalahu]: and ↓ t*Awqhu signifies the same as *aAqahu. (TA.) You say, *uqotu Al$~aYo'a [I tasted the thing], (S,) or AlT~aEaAma [the food]. (Msb.) And yawomN maA *uqotuhu TaEaAmFA, meaning maA *uqotu fiyhi [i. e. A day in which I tasted not food]. (TA.) ― -b2- By amplification, Al*~awoqu is used to signify (assumed tropical:) The perceiving, beside tastes, all other objects of the senses, and states or conditions: (Bd in iii. 177:) it is not restricted to the sense of the mouth [or tongue] in the language of the Kur-án nor in the [genuine or classical] language of the [Pagan] Arabs. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur iii. 177, *uwquwA Ea*aAba AlHariyqi (assumed tropical:) [Taste ye the punishment of burning]: (Bd, TA:) for, although, in the common conventional acceptation, the verb relates to what is little in quantity, it is regarded as suitable to be used in relation to what is much. (TA.) One says also, fulaAnN *aAqa ka*aA waA^anaA A^akalotuhu [lit. Such a one tasted such a thing, and I ate it;] meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one knew, or tried or tested, such a thing, and I knew it, or tried it or tested it, more. (TA.) *uqotu Al$~aYo'a means (assumed tropical:) I tried, or tested, the thing. (Msb.) And hence one says, *Aq fulaAnN AlbaA^osa (assumed tropical:) Such a one experienced harm, &c.; i. e., knew it by its befalling him. (Msb.) And *uqotu maA Einoda fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I knew, or tried or tested, what [qualities &c.] such a one possessed; (S, TA;) and so *uqotu fulaAnFA. (TA.) And *aAqa Alr~ajulu Eusayolapa AlmaroA^api wa *aAqato Eusayolatahu (assumed tropical:) The man [tasted or] experienced the sweetness of the carnal enjoyment of the woman, and she in like manner. (Msb.) And *Aq TaEoma AlA_iymaAni (assumed tropical:) He tasted, or experienced, the savour of faith with his heart, like as the mouth tastes, or experiences, the savour of food and drink. (TA from a trad.) And *uqotu ka*ibahu waxabarotu HaAlahu (tropical:) [I experienced his lying, and knew his condition]. (TA.) And *aAqatohaA yadiY, and *aAqato fulaAnapa, (tropical:) My hand felt her, and felt such a female. (TA.) ― -b3- *Aq Alqawosa, (S, K,) inf. n. *awoqN; (TA;) [and ↓ *aw~aqahaA; (so in Freytag's Lex. from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen;)] (tropical:) He pulled the string of the bow (S, K, TA) for the purpose of trial, (K, TA,) that he might see what was its strength. (S, TA.) ― -b4- ↓ Al*~awoqu is also employed to signify (assumed tropical:) [Taste, as meaning intellectual discernment and relish; i. e.] the faculty that is adapted to the acquisition of matters of knowledge, considered as being, in its perfection of perception, like sensation, regarded as a natural property; and particularly that [faculty] which concerns the niceties of language; because it [i. e. nice language] is, to the soul of man, like delicious intellectual food. (Kull. [When used as a subst in this sense, its pl. is A^a*owaAqN.]) One says, huwaHasanu Al*~awoqi lil$~iEori, meaning (tropical:) He has a good [taste or] natural faculty for poetry. (TA.) ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) Voluptuousness; sensuality: see *aw~aAqN.]
2 *w~qhu * [He gave him something to taste]: it is like lam~ajahu. (M and TA in art. lmZ.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

4 A^a*aqotuhu AlT~aEaAma * , (Msb, K, *) inf. n. A_i*aAqapN, (TA,) I made him to taste the food; i. e., to perceive its taste by means of the moisture of the tongue: (Msb:) or I made him to try, or know, the taste [of the food]. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^a*aAqahu A@ll~`hu wabaAla A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) [God made him to taste, or experience, the evil result of his affair]. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xvi. 113], faA^a*aAqahaAA@ll~`hu libaAsa AljuwoEi waAlxawofi (assumed tropical:) [So God made her to taste, or experience, the utmost degree of hunger and of fear]: the verb is here used with libaAs because meant to convey the meaning of experiencing: or the sentence is elliptical, and means, made them to taste, or experience, hunger and fear, and clad them with the clothing thereof. (TA.) And in the same [xlii. 47], A_i*aA A^a*aqonaA AlA_inosaAnu min~aA raHomapF (assumed tropical:) [When we make man to taste, or experience, mercy from us]; where, afterwards, AlA_iSaAbapN is opposed to AlA_i*aAqapN, in the words waA_ino tuSibohumo say~iy^apN. (TA.) ― -b3- A^a*aAqa zayodN baEodaka karamFA means (tropical:) Zeyd became generous [after thee, i. e. after thou knewest him, or sawest him, or wast with him]: (Aboo-Hamzeh, K, TA:) [lit., made people to taste generosity:] and A*Aq Alfarasu baEodaka EadowFA (tropical:) The horse became a good runner [after thee, i. e. after thou knewest him, &c.] (Aboo-Hamzeh, TA.)

5 t*w~qhu *
He tasted it (*aAqahu, S, K) by degrees, (S,) or repeatedly. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] daEoniY A^ata*aw~aqu TaEoma fulaAnK (tropical:) [Let me try, or test, the character of such a one]. (TA.) And ta*aw~aqotu TaEoma firaAqihi (tropical:) [I tasted, or experienced, the savour of his separation]. (TA.)

6 ta*aAowaqa see 1, first sentence. [The primary signification of ta*aAwuqN seems to be The tasting a thing one with another. ― -b2- And hence,] t*AwqwA Alr~imaAHa i. q. tanaAwaluwhaA (tropical:) [They took the spears, one from another, app. to test their qualities: see *aAqa Alqawosa, above]. (K, TA.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
A^awo kaA@hotizaAzi rudayoniY~K ta*aAwaqahu
A^ayodiY AltijaAri fazaAduwA matonahu liynaA
(tropical:) [Or like the quivering of a well-straightened spear (lit. a spear of Rudeyneh, a woman famous for the straightening of spear-shafts, accord. to the explanation commonly received,) which the hands of the dealers have taken, one from another, to test its quality, so that they have made the middle of it to increase in suppleness]. (TA.)

entryFree.key: Aisota*aAqa fulaAnFA xuborahu falamo yaHomado maxobaratahu

div2.entryFree:
10 Aisota*aAqa fulaAnFA xuborahu falamo yaHomado maxobaratahu * (tropical:) [app. He endeavoured to test such a one, to ascertain the knowledge of his internal state, and did not approve his internal state: see the pass, part. n. below]. (TA, in which xbrh is without any syllabical signs.) ― -b2- Ast*Aq AlA^amoru lifulaAnK (tropical:) The
affair was, or became, easy, or feasible, to such a one. (JK, TA.) You say, laA yasota*iyqu liYa Al$~iEoru A_il~a fiY fulaAni (tropical:) [Poetry, or versification, will not be easy, or feasible, to me, except in relation to such a one]. (TA.)
*awoqN * an inf. n. used as a simple subst.; pl. A^a*owaAqN: see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

*awaAqN * an inf. n.: and also a subst. signifying A thing that is tasted; (JM, TA; *) of the measure faEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.) It is said of Mohammad, lamo yakuno ya*um~u *awaAqFA walaA yamodaHuhu, i. e. [He used not to praise] what was tasted [by him nor to dispraise it]. (JM.) And one says, maA *uqotu *awaAqFA, meaning I tasted not anything. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Hence it is said in a trad., kaAnuwA A_i*aA xarajuwA mino Einodihi laA yatafar~aquwna A_il~aA Eano *awaAqK, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [They used, when they went forth from his (Mohammad's) presence, not to disperse themselves save after receiving] knowledge and discipline that were, to their minds and souls, as food and drink to their bodies. (JM.)

*aw~aAqN * (assumed tropical:) That contracts new marriages time after time: (JM:) quick in marrying and quick in divorcing: (TA:) that conceives frequent disgust (maluwlN, S, JM, and Har p. 569), not remaining [long] in one state with respect to marriage &c.: fem. with p. (Har ubi suprà.) Hence the saying, in a trad., A_in~a A@ll~`ha laA yuHib~u Al*~aw~aAqiyna walaA Al*~aw~aqaAti (assumed tropical:) [Verily God will not love those men who frequently contract new marriages, nor those women who do so]. (JM, and Har ubi suprà.)
ma*aAqN * an inf. n.: and also a subst. (TA) signifying A place, or time, of tasting. (KL.)
A^amorN musota*aAqN * (assumed tropical:) A thing, or an affair, tried, or tested, and known: (S:) and in like manner rajulN [a man]. (JK.)

2 *aw~alotu *aAlFA *
I wrote a *; (Az, Sgh, K;) or *aAlFA HasanapN [a beautiful *]. (B, TA.) [See also 2 in art. *yl.]

*aAlN *
A certain letter of the alphabet, (Lth, ISd, K,) [*,] pronounced with the voice, [not with the breath only,] and always a radical, not a substitute for another letter, nor augmentative; (ISd, TA;) its place of utterance is at the roots of the teeth, near the place of utterance of t [or v]; and it may be masc. and fem.; (B, TA;) [but generally it is fem.; and therefore] the dim. is ↓ *uwayolapN: (K:) the pl. is A^a*owaAlN and *aAlaAtN. (TA.) -A2- Also The comb of a cock. (Kh, TA.)
*awiylN * , explained by IDrd as signifying What is dry, of plants &c., and so in the K, is said by ISd to be correctly dawiylN [q. v.]. (TA.)
*uwayolapN * : see *aAlN, above.

5 t*w~n *
He was, or became, in a state of richness, wealth, or competence, and ease and plenty. (IAar, K. [In the CK, Aln~Eomapu is here, as in many other instances, erroneously put for Aln~aEomapu.]) [See also tdw~n. Perhaps both are correct, as dial. vars.]

*aAnN * (S, K) and *ayonN, (TA,) [the latter belonging to art. *yn,] A vice, fault, defect, or the like; (S, K;) syn. with *aAbN [and *ayobN] and *aAmN and *ayomN; (S, TA;) as heard by ISk from AA. (S.)

*uwnuwnN *
A certain plant: a dial. var. of *uw^onuwnN, with ': [see the latter in art. *A^n:] pl. *awaAniynu: mentioned by Az, on the authority of Ks. (TA.)

1 *awaY * , (ISk, T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. ya*owiY, (ISk, S, &c.,) inf. n. *aY~N, (T,) or *uwiY~N, (ISk, S, K,) or both; (M, Msb;) and *awiYa, (T, S, M, K,) used by some of the Arabs, but bad, (T,) disallowed by ISk, but said by AO on the authority of Yoo to be a dial. var., (S,) aor. ya*owaY; (T, K;) said of a branch, or twig, (T, M, Msb,) or of a herb, or leguminous plant, (S, K,) It withered; lost its moisture; or became thin, or unsubstantial, after being succulent; syn. *abala: (S, M, Msb, K:) it dried up: (T, A:) it obtained not moisture sufficient for it, or was marred by the heat, and in consequence withered, and became weak: (T:) in the dial. of the people of Beesheh, *aA^aY. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] *awato sakiynatuhu (assumed tropical:) [His calmness, or gravity,] ceased. (Har p. 109.)

4 A*wAhu * , said of heat, (S, Msb, K,) or of want of irrigation, (M,) It withered it; caused it to wither, or lose its moisture; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, a herb, or leguminous plant, (S, K,) or a branch, or twig. (M, Msb.)

*awFY * The skins of grapes: (IAar, T:) a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or rather the n. un.] is *awaApN: (Kr, M:) [or] this latter signifies the skin, or husk, or rind, of the grape, (AA, T, Kr, M, K,) and of wheat (AlHinoTap), (AA, T, and so in some copies of the K,) or of the colocynth (AlHanoZalap), (Kr, M, and so in some copies of the K,) and of the melon: (AA, T, Kr, M, K:) and so [dawaApN] with the unpointed d. (TA.) -A2- Also *awFY, (IAar, T,) or ↓ *iwFY, (K,) Weak, (IAar, T,) or small, or young, (K,) ewes. (IAar, T, K.)
*iwFY * : see what next precedes.
*awaApN * sing. [or rather n. un.] of *awFY [q. v.]
*awaAtN * pl. of *aAtN, fem. of *uw, q. v.

*aAwK *
Withering, or withered; losing, or having lost, its moisture. (S, TA.)

*aAy^ika *
i. q. *`lika: so in the phrase *aAy^ika Alr~ajulu [That man]: (K, TA:) a dial. var., or a mispronunciation. (TA.)
*Y * fem. of *aA: see art. *A.
*ay~apa wa *ay~apa * : see art. *yt.
*ay~aA * , and *ay~aAka, and *ay~aAlika: see the two sentences next before the last in art. *A.
*ay~aA='a wa *ay~aA='a * : see art. *yt.
2 *y~A^ * , (T, S, K,) inf. n. ta*oyoYo'N, (K,) He cooked flesh-meat thoroughly, so that it fell off from the bone. (T, S, K.)

5 t*y~A^ * , said of flesh, or flesh-meat, (T, S, M, K,) It became separated from the bone by reason of corruption, (T, M, K,) or in consequence of cooking, (T,) or by slaughter, (M, K,) or from some other cause: (TA:) or became thoroughly cooked, so that it fell off from the bone. (S.) It (a wound, As, S, M, K,) became dissundered, or ragged, and corrupt, or putrid: (As, S, M, K:) and so said of other things: (K:) thus ta*ay~aA^ato said of a qirobap [or water-skin], (M, * TA,) and of a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (TA.) ― -b2- It (the face) became swollen. (K.)
*ayobN * , (K,) like *aAbN, mentioned in art. *wb, [and *ayomN] and *aAmN, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or the like. (K.)
*iybN * : see *iy^obN, in art. *A^b.
*iybaAnN * : see *uwbaAnN, in art. *wb.

A^a*ayobu * , [like A^azayobu,] Much water. (K.) ― -b2- Fright, or fear. (K.) As mentions the saying, mar~a fulaAnN wa lahu A^a*ayobu [as though meaning Such a one passed having fright, or fear]: and he says, I think that one says A^azayobu, with zAY having the meaning here following. (TA.) ― -b3- Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or agility. (K.)
A^aroDN ma*oyabapN * : see ma*oA^abapN, in art. *A^b.
ma*oyuwbN * : see ma*ow^uwbN, in art. *A^b.

*ayota wa*ayota * (AO, S, M voce *aA, Msb, * K) and *ayoti wa*ayoti and *ayotu wa*aytu, (K,) the last of which is unknown, except as mentioned by IKtt, (TA,) and *ay~apa wa*ay~apa (M, K) and *ay~aA='a wa*ay~aA='a, (K,) i. q. kayota wakayota: (AO, S, M, Msb, * K:) so in the saying, kaAna mina AlA^amori *ayota wa*ayota [&c., Some of the circumstances of the case were thus and thus, or so and so, or such and such things]. (AO, S, M.) It is plainly implied in the K [and the S] that the t in *yt is a radical letter, the last radical letter of the word: but AHei says that the t in *yt and kyt is substituted for Y; that they are originally *ay~apa and kay~apa; and that the p is elided, and the Y which is the last radical letter is changed into t: [in like manner also says ISd in the M, voce *aA:] and most of the leading authorities on inflection assert the same: therefore, [though most persons would look for them among words of which the last radical letter
is t,] they are incorrectly placed in the K [and in the S]. (MF.) Or *ayota is formed from *ayowN, by eliding the w and doubling the Y and then substituting for the teshdeed t; and if you elide the t and replace it by h, you must restore the teshdeed, and say, kaAna *ay~aho wa*ay~aho. (S at the end of art. *w.)

2 *y~r * , (K,) inf. n. ta*oyiyrN, (S,) He smeared a she-camel's teats with *iyaAr, (S, K,) in order that the young one might not suck her. (S.) ― -b2- And *y~r Aln~aAqapa He bound the she-camel's udder with a SiraAr [q. v.], in order that the pieces of wood bound upon her udder to prevent her young one from sucking her might not make any impression upon her. (K, * TA.) [But see *iyaArN, which indicates that the true meaning is, He smeared the she-camel's teats with *iyaAr in order that the pieces of wood above mentioned might not make any impression upon them.] ― -b3- *uy~ira fuwhu, inf. n. ta*oyiyrN, His (a man's, S) teeth became black. (Lth, S, K.)
*iyrapN * : see *iyaArN.

*iyaArN *
Fresh camels' or similar dung (baEara), [mixed with dust, or earth,] with which a she-camel's teats are smeared, (T, S, M, *) in order that the young one may not such her, (S, M,) and that the pieces of wood which are bound upon her udder to prevent her young one from sucking may not make any impression upon her; (T, M;) i. q. *iy^aArN: or dung (siroqiyn) before mixed with dust or earth is called xuv~apN: and when mixed, ↓ *iyrapN: and when the teats are smeared with it, *iyaArN. (Lth, K.)

1 *aAEa * , aor. ya*iyEu, inf. n. *ayoEN and *uyuwEN (S, Msb, K) and *ayoEuwEapN and *ayaEaAnN, (S, K,) It (information, news, or tidings, S, K, or discourse, Msb, and a thing, TA) became spread, published, or divulged; (S, Msb, K, TA;) became revealed, made known, or disclosed. (Msb.) ― -b2- You say also, *aAEa Aljaworu (assumed tropical:) Injustice, or tyranny, spread. (TA.) ― -b3- And *aAEa Aljarabu fiY Aljilodi (tropical:) The mange, or scab, became general, and spread, in the skin. (TA.)

4 A*AEhu * , (S, Msb, K,) and A*AE bihi, (Zj, K,) as in the Kur iv. 85, (Zj,) inf. n. A_i*aAEapN, (TA in art. *wE,) He spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed, it; (Zj, S, Msb, * K;) and (so Zj, but in the K, “ or, ”) proclaimed it among the people; (Zj, K;) namely, information, news, or tidings, (S,) or discourse, (Msb,) or a secret. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, app., (TA in art. *wE,) A*AE Alqawomu (S, K,) and A*AEt AlA_ibilu, (K,) maA fiY AlHwD, (S,) or bimaA fY AlHwD, (K,) (tropical:) The people, or company of men, and the camels, drank what was in the watering-trough, or tank, (S, K, TA,) all of it. (S.) ― -b3- And hence, app., (TA,) A*AE bihi signifies also (tropical:) He took it away; namely, another's property, (K,) and anything. (TA.) ― -b4- Accord. to the K, the medial radical letter is both w and Y; but correctly it is Y: (TA in the present art. and in art. *wE:) so accord. to AZ and J and Z. (TA in art. *wE.)

mi*oyaAEN * [A babbler of secrets &c.;] one who will not keep, or conceal, a secret: (S, K:) or one who is unable to conceal his information, news, or tidings: an epithet of an intensive form: (TA:) pl. ma*aAyiyEu. (S.)

*iyfaAnN * and *ayofaAnN (S, M, K) and *ayafaAnN (M, K) Deadly poison: (S, M, K:) or poison that takes effect; or that remains fixed, and collects: (M:) a dial. var. of *iy^ofaAnN &c., (K,) and *uwfaAnN. (M.) And the second of these words, Death: so in the saying, saqaAhu A@ll~`hu kaA^osa Al*~ayofaAni [May God give him to drink the cup of death]; as mentioned by Lh. (M.)

1 *aAla * , aor. ya*iylu, inf. n. *ayolN, It (a garment) was long, so that it touched the ground. (Msb.) ― -b2- He, or it, had a *ayol; [app. said of a horse &c., as meaning he had a long tail, or a pendent portion to his tail; and probably of a garment, as meaning it had a skirt, or lower extremity, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or dragged upon the ground, when made to hang down; and perhaps of a man, as meaning he had a *yl to his garment;] as also ↓ A^a*oyala. (M, K.) ― -b3- And, said of a man, (M, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (M,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, dragging his *ayol [or skirt, or the lower extremity of his garment]; (M, K;) and in like manner *aAlato is said of a she-camel: (M:) or he dragged his A^a*oyaAl [or skirts, or the lower extremities of his garment or garments], by reason of pride and self-conceit: (Msb:) or *aAlato, (T, S,) fiY mi$oyatihaA, said of a girl, or young woman, (T,) or of a woman, (S,) aor. ta*iylu, (T, S,) inf. n. as above, (T,) she dragged her A^a*oyaAl, (T,) or her *ayol, (S,) upon the ground, walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait. (T, S.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- *Al bi*anabihi He raised his tail; (M, K;) said of a horse, and of a mountaingoat. (M.) And *Alt bi*anabihaA She (a camel) spread her tail upon her thighs. (T.) ― -b5- *Al A_ilayohi i. q. AinobasaTa [app. as meaning He acted towards him, or behaved to him, with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance]; as also ↓ t*y~l. (K.) ― -b6- *Al Al$~aYo'u, (M, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) The thing was, or became, low, base, vile, mean, contemptible, or ignominious. (M, Msb, K.) And *Alt HaAluhu His state, or condition, became lowered, or abased; as also ↓ t*Aylt. (O, K.) ― -b7- *Alt said of a woman, (M, K,) and of a she-camel, (M,) She was, or became, lean, or emaciated, (M, K,) and in a bad condition. (M.)

2 *y~l vawobahu * , inf. n. ta*oyiylN, [He made his garment to have a *ayol, i. e. shirt, or lower extremity, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or such as to be dragged upon the ground; or] he made his garment long: (T:) and vawobahu ↓ A*Al he made his garment to have a long *ayol. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, *ay~alotu kitaAbahu (assumed tropical:) I added an appendix to his writing, or book; like *an~abotuhu. And hence, the inf. n. ta*oyiylN is used to signify (assumed tropical:) An appendix; like ta*oniybN; as also ↓ *ayolN.] -A2- *ay~alotu *aAlFA [I wrote a *]. (IB, TA on the letter A.) [See also 2 in art. *wl.]

4 A^a*oyala * : see 1, second sentence. -A2- A*Al vawobahu: see 2. ― -b2- A*Alt qinaAEahaA She (a woman) let down her head-covering. (T, S, K. *) ― -b3- A*Alhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i*aAlapN, (S, * M, Msb,) He lowered him; abased him; rendered him vile, mean, contemptible, or ignominious; or held him in low, or mean, estimation; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and did not tend him, or take care of him, well; (M, K;) namely, his horse, (T, S, M,) and his young man, or slave; (S;) or it is said of the owner of a thing. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., (S, M,) of the Prophet, (M,) nahaY Eano A_i*aAlapi Alxayoli, (S, M,) i. e. [He forbade] the using of horses for mean work, and burdens. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And A^a*olotuhaA I rendered her lean; or emaciated her; namely, a woman, and a camel. (TA.)

5 t*y~lt Ald~aAb~apu *
The beast moved about its tail. (M.) ― -b2- And hence, (M,) t*y~l He (a man, TA) walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, (M, K,) [app., dragging his *ayol (or skirt), like *aAla.] ― -b3- [It occurs in the M and L, in art. rA^d: said of a branch, or twig, app. as meaning It inclined limberly from side to side: but in the K, I there find in its place t*b~l.] ― -b4- See also 1.
6 ta*aAoyala see 1, last sentence but one.

*ayolN * The latter, or kinder, or the last, or kindmost, part of anything. (M, K.) Accord. to MF, this is the proper signification, and the other significations here following are tropical. (TA.) [But in my opinion, the word in each of the next two senses, or at least in the former of them; if not strictly proper, is what is termed HaqiyqapN Eurofiy~apN, i. e. a word so much used in a tropical sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper.] ― -b2- [A skirt, or lower extremity, of a garment, reaching nearly, or quite, to the ground, or that is dragged upon the ground, when made to hang down:] the extremity, of a garment, that is next the ground, and so if not touching it [as well as if touching it]; an inf. n. used in this sense: (Msb:) or the part of a waist-wrapper (A_izaAr), and of a garment [of any kind], that is dragged [upon the ground], (M, K,) when it is made to hang down: (M:) or the part, of an A_izaAr, and of a [garment of the kind called] ridaA=', that is made to hang down, and touches the ground: and the part, of any kind of garment worn by a woman, that the wearer drags upon the ground behind her: (Lth, T:) or the parts, all round, of a woman's garment, that fall upon the ground: and the portion that is made
to hang down, of a woman's shift and of her qinaAE [or head-covering]: you do not [properly] say of a man that he has a *ayol [but only when you liken the lower part of his garment to the similar part of a woman's garment]: a man's having a long garment, such as a shirt and a jub~ap, [or his dragging the skirt thereof,] is termed A_irofaAlN: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, T:) the pl. of *ayolN (in this sense, T, Msb, as relating to a shirt [&c.], S, and in all its senses, T, M) is A^a*oyaAlN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and A^a*oyulN (El-Hejeree, M, K) [both pls. of pauc.] and *uyuwlN (T, S, M, Msb, K) which is a pl. of mult. (M.) Hence Tuwlu Al*~ayoli is a metonymical expression meaning (tropical:) Richness, or competency; because long A^a*oyaAl generally pertain to the rich and the prodigal and the proud and self-conceited: (Er-Rázee, Har p. 493:) and you say, TaAla *ayolu fulaAnK, meaning (tropical:) The state, or condition, of such a one became good, and his wealth became abundant: and huwa Tawiylu Al*~ayoli, meaning (tropical:) He is rich. (Har p. 319.) ― -b3- Of a horse (T, K) &c., (K,) [i. e.] of a horse and a camel and the like, (M,) The tail: (T, M, K:) or the tail when long: (TA:) or the part, of the tail, that is made to hang down. (M, K.) ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) Of a cloud, The skirt; or lower, pendent, part: used in this sense in the K voce hayodabN.] ― -b5- *ayolu Alr~iyHi (assumed tropical:) What is dragged along, (T, S, O,) or drawn together, (M,) by the wind, upon the ground, (T, S, O, M,) of dust (T, M, O) and rubbish: (T, O:) or what the wind leaves upon the sand, (M, K,) in the form of a rope, (M,) resembling the track of a *ayol [or skirt] dragged along: (M, K:) or, as some say, A^a*oyaAluAlr~iyHi means (assumed tropical:) the after-parts of the wind, with which it sweeps what is light to it. (M.) ― -b6- *ayolu jabalK (assumed tropical:) The foot, bottom, base, or lowest part, of a mountain. (A and TA voce jar~N.) ― -b7- A^a*oyaAlu Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) The hindmost of the people. (K.) You say, jaA='a A^a*oyaAlN mina Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) Some few of the hindmost of the people came. (S, Sgh.) ― -b8- See also 2. -A2- And see *aAy^ilN.

*ay~aAlN * : see *aAy^ilN, in three places. ― -b2- Also That behaves proudly, conceitedly, or vainly, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait. (TA.) Applied to a horse, That carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, in his step, and in curvetting, or raising his fore legs together and putting them down together, and kneading with his hind legs, or in prancing, as though he dragged along the *ayol [or pendent portion] of his tail. (M.)

*aAy^ilN * , applied to a horse, Having a *ayol, (T, K,) i. e. tail: (T:) and ↓ *ay~aAlN having a long *ayol: (T, K:) or the former word has the latter signification; (IKt, T, M;) it means having a long tail: (S:) and ↓ the latter word, tall, and having a long *ayol, (M, K,) and that carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, in his step; (K;) and is applied in the same sense to a wild bull: (M:) or the former word signifies short, and having a long tail; and its fem. is with p: (T:) or when a horse is of this description, they say Al*~anabi ↓ *ay~aAlu, mentioning the *anab. (T, S.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a diroE, (S, M, K,) [i. e. a coat of mail, as is shown in the S and TA,] Long (S, M, K) in the *ayol [or shirt]; (S;) and so *aAy^ilapN and ↓ mu*aAlapN. (M, K. [In the CK, the last word is erroneously written ma*aAlapN.]) ― -b3- And HaloqapN *aAy^ilapN and ↓ mu*aAlapN A ring [app. of a coat of mail] that is slender (M, K *) and elongated. (M.) -A2- *aAy^ilN ↓ *ayolN [an expression like *ul~N *aliylN, the former word an inf. n.,] means [Exceeding] lowness, baseness, vileness, meanness, contemptibleness, or ignominiousness. (S.)

mu*aAlN * ; fem. with p: see the latter in the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- The fem. also means (assumed tropical:) A female slave: (T, S, M:) because she is held in low, or mean, estimation, while she carries herself in an elegant and a proud and selfconceited manner: so in the prov., A^axiylu mino mu*aAlapK [More proud and self-conceited than a female slave]. (S, K.)

mu*oyilN * [so in my MS. copy of the K, as in the M, but in other copies of the K mu*ay~alN,] and ↓ muta*ay~ilN [in the CK muta*ay~alN] i. q. mutaba*~ilN [One who performs his own work; or who is careless of himself or his honour or reputation]. (M, K.)

mu*ay~alN * A garment, (T,) of the kind called mulaA=', (T, S,) or ridaA=', (K,) Long (T, S, K) in the *ayol [or skirt]. (S, K.) So in a verse of Imra-el- Keys, of which the latter hemistich is cited voce duwaArN. (T, TA.)

A^aroDN muta*ay~alapN *
A land upon which has fallen a weak and small quantity (laToxN DaEiyfN) of rain. (Sgh, K.)
muta*ay~ilN * : see mu*iylN.

1 *aAmahu * , (T, M, Msb, K,) first pers. *imotuhu, (S,) aor. ya*iymu, (T, &c.,) inf. n. *ayomN and *aAmN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) namely, a commodity; like *aA^amahu: (Msb:) accord. to Akh, *imotuhu and *aA^amotuhu and *amamotuhu all signify the same. (S.)
*aAmN * : see what next follows, in two places.

*ayomN * and ↓ *aAmN are inf. ns., (S, M, Msb, K,) and are syn. with EayobN [as such, and also as meaning A vice, fault, defect, or the like; in the latter sense syn. with *aAm~N, which belongs to art. *m]: (T, S, M, Msb, * K:) or, as some say, syn. with *am~N [blame, &c.]. (M.) It is said in a prov., ↓ laAtaEodamu AlHasonaA='u *aAmFA [The beautiful female is not without a defect]. (S.)

ma*iymN *
Blamed, or found fault with; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ma*oyuwmN: (S, K:) the former defective, and the latter complete: (S:) applied [app. to a man; (see the dial. var. ma*ow^uwmN, as used in the Kur vii. 17;) and] to a commodity. (Msb.)
ma*oyuwmN * : see what next precedes.
1 *aAnahu * , [aor. ya*iynu, inf. n., app., *ayonN,] He blamed, or found fault with, him, or it; like *aAmahu. (IAar, T.)
*ayonN * , (M, TA,) incorrectly said in the K to be *iyonN, with kesr, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or the like, (M, K, TA;) as also *aAnN [which belongs to art. *wn]. (M.)
mu*aAnN * a dial. var. of mu*aAlN. (M.) [See the latter in art. *yl.]
